signal.name: GtkAboutDialog::activate-link
signal.description:
The signal which gets emitted to activate a URI. Applications may connect to it to override the default behaviour, which is to call gtk_show_uri().
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: The object on which the signal was emitted

signal.return: %TRUE if the link has been activated

signal.name: GtkAccelGroup::accel-activate
signal.description: The accel-activate signal is an implementation detail of #GtkAccelGroup and not meant to be used by applications.

parameter.name: acceleratable
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the accelerator was activated

parameter.name: modifier
parameter.parameter_description: the modifier combination of the accelerator

signal.return: %TRUE if the accelerator was activated

signal.name: GtkAccelGroup::accel-changed
signal.description:
The accel-changed signal is emitted when an entry is added to or removed from the accel group.
Widgets like #GtkAccelLabel which display an associated accelerator should connect to this signal, and rebuild their visual representation if the @accel_closure is theirs.

parameter.name: modifier
parameter.parameter_description: the modifier combination of the accelerator

signal.name: GtkAccelMap::changed
signal.description:
Notifies of a change in the global accelerator map. The path is also used as the detail for the signal, so it is possible to connect to changed::<replaceable>accel_path</replaceable>.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: accel_path
parameter.parameter_description: the path of the accelerator that changed

parameter.name: accel_key
parameter.parameter_description: the key value for the new accelerator

parameter.name: accel_mods
parameter.parameter_description: the modifier mask for the new accelerator

signal.name: GtkAction::activate
signal.description:
The "activate" signal is emitted when the action is activated.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GSimpleAction:activate instead

signal.name: GtkActionGroup::connect-proxy
signal.description:
The ::connect-proxy signal is emitted after connecting a proxy to an action in the group. Note that the proxy may have been connected to a different action before.
This is intended for simple customizations for which a custom action class would be too clumsy, e.g. showing tooltips for menuitems in the statusbar.
#GtkUIManager proxies the signal and provides global notification just before any action is connected to a proxy, which is probably more convenient to use.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

signal.name: GtkActionGroup::disconnect-proxy
signal.description:
The ::disconnect-proxy signal is emitted after disconnecting a proxy from an action in the group.
#GtkUIManager proxies the signal and provides global notification just before any action is connected to a proxy, which is probably more convenient to use.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

signal.name: GtkActionGroup::post-activate
signal.description:
The ::post-activate signal is emitted just after the @action in the @action_group is activated
This is intended for #GtkUIManager to proxy the signal and provide global notification just after any action is activated.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

signal.name: GtkActionGroup::pre-activate
signal.description:
The ::pre-activate signal is emitted just before the @action in the @action_group is activated
This is intended for #GtkUIManager to proxy the signal and provide global notification just before any action is activated.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

signal.name: GtkAdjustment::changed
signal.description: Emitted when one or more of the #GtkAdjustment properties have been changed, other than the #GtkAdjustment:value property.

parameter.name: adjustment
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkAdjustment::value-changed
signal.description: Emitted when the #GtkAdjustment:value property has been changed.

parameter.name: adjustment
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

enum.name: GtkAlign
enum.description:
Controls how a widget deals with extra space in a single (x or y) dimension.
Alignment only matters if the widget receives a "too large" allocation, for example if you packed the widget with the #GtkWidget:expand flag inside a #GtkBox, then the widget might get extra space. If you have for example a 16x16 icon inside a 32x32 space, the icon could be scaled and stretched, it could be centered, or it could be positioned to one side of the space.
Note that in horizontal context @GTK_ALIGN_START and @GTK_ALIGN_END are interpreted relative to text direction.
GTK_ALIGN_BASELINE support for it is optional for containers and widgets, and it is only supported for vertical alignment. When its not supported by a child or a container it is treated as @GTK_ALIGN_FILL.

parameter.name: GTK_ALIGN_FILL
parameter.parameter_description: stretch to fill all space if possible, center if no meaningful way to stretch

parameter.name: GTK_ALIGN_START
parameter.parameter_description: snap to left or top side, leaving space on right or bottom

parameter.name: GTK_ALIGN_END
parameter.parameter_description: snap to right or bottom side, leaving space on left or top

parameter.name: GTK_ALIGN_CENTER
parameter.parameter_description: center natural width of widget inside the allocation

parameter.name: GTK_ALIGN_BASELINE
parameter.parameter_description: align the widget according to the baseline. Since 3.10.

signal.name: GtkAppChooserButton::custom-item-activated
signal.description: Emitted when a custom item, previously added with gtk_app_chooser_button_append_custom_item(), is activated from the dropdown menu.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: item_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the activated item

signal.name: GtkAppChooserWidget::application-activated
signal.description:
Emitted when an application item is activated from the widget's list.
This usually happens when the user double clicks an item, or an item is selected and the user presses one of the keys Space, Shift+Space, Return or Enter.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkAppChooserWidget::application-selected
signal.description: Emitted when an application item is selected from the widget's list.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkAppChooserWidget::populate-popup
signal.description: Emitted when a context menu is about to popup over an application item. Clients can insert menu items into the provided #GtkMenu object in the callback of this signal; the context menu will be shown over the item if at least one item has been added to the menu.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkApplication::window-added
signal.description:
Emitted when a #GtkWindow is added to @application through gtk_application_add_window().
Since: 3.2

signal.name: GtkApplication::window-removed
signal.description:
Emitted when a #GtkWindow is removed from @application, either as a side-effect of being destroyed or explicitly through gtk_application_remove_window().
Since: 3.2

enum.name: GtkApplicationInhibitFlags
enum.description:
Types of user actions that may be blocked by gtk_application_inhibit().
Since: 3.4

parameter.name: GTK_APPLICATION_INHIBIT_LOGOUT
parameter.parameter_description: Inhibit ending the user session by logging out or by shutting down the computer

parameter.name: GTK_APPLICATION_INHIBIT_SUSPEND
parameter.parameter_description: Inhibit suspending the session or computer

parameter.name: GTK_APPLICATION_INHIBIT_IDLE
parameter.parameter_description: Inhibit the session being marked as idle (and possibly locked)

enum.name: GtkArrowPlacement
enum.description: Used to specify the placement of scroll arrows in scrolling menus.

parameter.name: GTK_ARROWS_BOTH
parameter.parameter_description: Place one arrow on each end of the menu.

parameter.name: GTK_ARROWS_START
parameter.parameter_description: Place both arrows at the top of the menu.

parameter.name: GTK_ARROWS_END
parameter.parameter_description: Place both arrows at the bottom of the menu.

enum.name: GtkArrowType
enum.description: Used to indicate the direction in which a #GtkArrow should point.

signal.name: GtkAssistant::apply
signal.description:
The ::apply signal is emitted when the apply button is clicked.
The default behavior of the #GtkAssistant is to switch to the page after the current page, unless the current page is the last one.
A handler for the ::apply signal should carry out the actions for which the wizard has collected data. If the action takes a long time to complete, you might consider putting a page of type %GTK_ASSISTANT_PAGE_PROGRESS after the confirmation page and handle this operation within the #GtkAssistant::prepare signal of the progress page.
Since: 2.10

signal.name: GtkAssistant::cancel
signal.description:
The ::cancel signal is emitted when then the cancel button is clicked.
Since: 2.10

signal.name: GtkAssistant::close
signal.description:
The ::close signal is emitted either when the close button of a summary page is clicked, or when the apply button in the last page in the flow (of type %GTK_ASSISTANT_PAGE_CONFIRM) is clicked.
Since: 2.10

signal.name: GtkAssistant::prepare
signal.description:
The ::prepare signal is emitted when a new page is set as the assistant's current page, before making the new page visible.
A handler for this signal can do any preparations which are necessary before showing @page.
Since: 2.10

enum.name: GtkAssistantPageType
enum.description:
An enum for determining the page role inside the #GtkAssistant. It's used to handle buttons sensitivity and visibility.
Note that an assistant needs to end its page flow with a page of type %GTK_ASSISTANT_PAGE_CONFIRM, %GTK_ASSISTANT_PAGE_SUMMARY or %GTK_ASSISTANT_PAGE_PROGRESS to be correct.
The Cancel button will only be shown if the page isn't "committed". See gtk_assistant_commit() for details.

parameter.name: GTK_ASSISTANT_PAGE_CONTENT
parameter.parameter_description: The page has regular contents. Both the Back and forward buttons will be shown.

parameter.name: GTK_ASSISTANT_PAGE_INTRO
parameter.parameter_description: The page contains an introduction to the assistant task. Only the Forward button will be shown if there is a next page.

parameter.name: GTK_ASSISTANT_PAGE_CONFIRM
parameter.parameter_description: The page lets the user confirm or deny the changes. The Back and Apply buttons will be shown.

parameter.name: GTK_ASSISTANT_PAGE_SUMMARY
parameter.parameter_description: The page informs the user of the changes done. Only the Close button will be shown.

parameter.name: GTK_ASSISTANT_PAGE_PROGRESS
parameter.parameter_description: Used for tasks that take a long time to complete, blocks the assistant until the page is marked as complete. Only the back button will be shown.

parameter.name: GTK_ASSISTANT_PAGE_CUSTOM
parameter.parameter_description: Used for when other page types are not appropriate. No buttons will be shown, and the application must add its own buttons through gtk_assistant_add_action_widget().

enum.name: GtkAttachOptions
enum.description: Denotes the expansion properties that a widget will have when it (or its parent) is resized.

parameter.name: GTK_EXPAND
parameter.parameter_description: the widget should expand to take up any extra space in its container that has been allocated.

parameter.name: GTK_SHRINK
parameter.parameter_description: the widget should shrink as and when possible.

parameter.name: GTK_FILL
parameter.parameter_description: the widget should fill the space allocated to it.

enum.name: GtkBaselinePosition
enum.description:
Whenever a container has some form of natural row it may align children in that row along a common typographical baseline. If the amount of verical space in the row is taller than the total requested height of the baseline-aligned children then it can use a #GtkBaselinePosition to select where to put the baseline inside the extra availible space.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: GTK_BASELINE_POSITION_TOP
parameter.parameter_description: Align the baseline at the top

parameter.name: GTK_BASELINE_POSITION_BOTTOM
parameter.parameter_description: Align the baseline at the bottom

enum.name: GtkBorderStyle
enum.description: Describes how the border of a UI element should be rendered.

parameter.name: GTK_BORDER_STYLE_INSET
parameter.parameter_description: Looks as if the content is sunken into the canvas

parameter.name: GTK_BORDER_STYLE_OUTSET
parameter.parameter_description: Looks as if the content is coming out of the canvas

parameter.name: GTK_BORDER_STYLE_DOUBLE
parameter.parameter_description: Two parallel lines with some space between them

parameter.name: GTK_BORDER_STYLE_GROOVE
parameter.parameter_description: Looks as if it were carved in the canvas

parameter.name: GTK_BORDER_STYLE_RIDGE
parameter.parameter_description: Looks as if it were coming out of the canvas

enum.name: GtkBuilderError
enum.description: Error codes that identify various errors that can occur while using #GtkBuilder.

parameter.name: GTK_BUILDER_ERROR_INVALID_TYPE_FUNCTION
parameter.parameter_description: A type-func attribute didn't name a function that returns a #GType.

parameter.name: GTK_BUILDER_ERROR_UNHANDLED_TAG
parameter.parameter_description: The input contained a tag that #GtkBuilder can't handle.

parameter.name: GTK_BUILDER_ERROR_MISSING_ATTRIBUTE
parameter.parameter_description: An attribute that is required by #GtkBuilder was missing.

parameter.name: GTK_BUILDER_ERROR_INVALID_ATTRIBUTE
parameter.parameter_description: #GtkBuilder found an attribute that it doesn't understand.

parameter.name: GTK_BUILDER_ERROR_INVALID_TAG
parameter.parameter_description: #GtkBuilder found a tag that it doesn't understand.

parameter.name: GTK_BUILDER_ERROR_MISSING_PROPERTY_VALUE
parameter.parameter_description: A required property value was missing.

parameter.name: GTK_BUILDER_ERROR_VERSION_MISMATCH
parameter.parameter_description: The input file requires a newer version of GTK+.

parameter.name: GTK_BUILDER_ERROR_OBJECT_TYPE_REFUSED
parameter.parameter_description: A specified object type is of the same type or derived from the type of the composite class being extended with builder XML.

parameter.name: GTK_BUILDER_ERROR_TEMPLATE_MISMATCH
parameter.parameter_description: The wrong type was specified in a composite class's template XML

signal.name: GtkButton::activate
signal.description: The ::activate signal on GtkButton is an action signal and emitting it causes the button to animate press then release. Applications should never connect to this signal, but use the #GtkButton::clicked signal.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkButton::clicked
signal.description: Emitted when the button has been activated (pressed and released).

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkButton::enter
signal.description:
Emitted when the pointer enters the button.
Deprecated: 2.8: Use the #GtkWidget::enter-notify-event signal.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkButton::image-spacing
signal.description:
Spacing in pixels between the image and label.
Since: 2.10

signal.name: GtkButton::leave
signal.description:
Emitted when the pointer leaves the button.
Deprecated: 2.8: Use the #GtkWidget::leave-notify-event signal.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkButton::pressed
signal.description:
Emitted when the button is pressed.
Deprecated: 2.8: Use the #GtkWidget::button-press-event signal.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkButton::released
signal.description:
Emitted when the button is released.
Deprecated: 2.8: Use the #GtkWidget::button-release-event signal.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

enum.name: GtkButtonBoxStyle
enum.description: Used to dictate the style that a #GtkButtonBox uses to layout the buttons it contains. (See also: #GtkVButtonBox and #GtkHButtonBox).

parameter.name: GTK_BUTTONBOX_SPREAD
parameter.parameter_description: Buttons are evenly spread across the box.

parameter.name: GTK_BUTTONBOX_EDGE
parameter.parameter_description: Buttons are placed at the edges of the box.

parameter.name: GTK_BUTTONBOX_START
parameter.parameter_description: Buttons are grouped towards the start of the box, (on the left for a HBox, or the top for a VBox).

parameter.name: GTK_BUTTONBOX_END
parameter.parameter_description: Buttons are grouped towards the end of the box, (on the right for a HBox, or the bottom for a VBox).

parameter.name: GTK_BUTTONBOX_CENTER
parameter.parameter_description: Buttons are centered in the box. Since 2.12.

enum.name: GtkButtonsType
enum.description: Prebuilt sets of buttons for the dialog. If none of these choices are appropriate, simply use %GTK_BUTTONS_NONE then call gtk_dialog_add_buttons(). <note> Please note that %GTK_BUTTONS_OK, %GTK_BUTTONS_YES_NO and %GTK_BUTTONS_OK_CANCEL are discouraged by the <ulink url="http://library.gnome.org/devel/hig-book/stable/">GNOME HIG</ulink>. </note>

signal.name: GtkCalendar::day-selected
signal.description: Emitted when the user selects a day.

parameter.name: calendar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkCalendar::day-selected-double-click

parameter.name: calendar

signal.name: GtkCalendar::month-changed
signal.description: Emitted when the user clicks a button to change the selected month on a calendar.

parameter.name: calendar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkCalendar::next-month
signal.description: Emitted when the user switched to the next month.

parameter.name: calendar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkCalendar::next-year
signal.description: Emitted when user switched to the next year.

parameter.name: calendar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkCalendar::prev-month
signal.description: Emitted when the user switched to the previous month.

parameter.name: calendar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkCalendar::prev-year

parameter.name: calendar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

enum.name: GtkCalendarDisplayOptions
enum.description: These options can be used to influence the display and behaviour of a #GtkCalendar.

parameter.name: GTK_CALENDAR_SHOW_HEADING
parameter.parameter_description: Specifies that the month and year should be displayed.

parameter.name: GTK_CALENDAR_SHOW_DAY_NAMES
parameter.parameter_description: Specifies that three letter day descriptions should be present.

parameter.name: GTK_CALENDAR_NO_MONTH_CHANGE
parameter.parameter_description: Prevents the user from switching months with the calendar.

parameter.name: GTK_CALENDAR_SHOW_WEEK_NUMBERS
parameter.parameter_description: Displays each week numbers of the current year, down the left side of the calendar.

parameter.name: GTK_CALENDAR_SHOW_DETAILS
parameter.parameter_description: Just show an indicator, not the full details text when details are provided. See gtk_calendar_set_detail_func().

signal.name: GtkCellArea::add-editable
signal.description:
Indicates that editing has started on @renderer and that @editable should be added to the owning cell-layouting widget at @cell_area.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: cell_area
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkWidget relative #GdkRectangle coordinates where @editable should be added

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreePath string this edit was initiated for

signal.name: GtkCellArea::apply-attributes
signal.description:
This signal is emitted whenever applying attributes to @area from @model
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: area
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkCellArea to apply the attributes to

parameter.name: model
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeModel to apply the attributes from

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeIter indicating which row to apply the attributes of

parameter.name: is_expander
parameter.parameter_description: whether the view shows children for this row

parameter.name: is_expanded
parameter.parameter_description: whether the view is currently showing the children of this row

signal.name: GtkCellArea::focus-changed
signal.description:
Indicates that focus changed on this @area. This signal is emitted either as a result of focus handling or event handling.
It's possible that the signal is emitted even if the currently focused renderer did not change, this is because focus may change to the same renderer in the same cell area for a different row of data.
Since: 3.0

signal.name: GtkCellArea::remove-editable
signal.description:
Indicates that editing finished on @renderer and that @editable should be removed from the owning cell-layouting widget.
Since: 3.0

signal.name: GtkCellEditable::editing-done
signal.description:
This signal is a sign for the cell renderer to update its value from the @cell_editable.
Implementations of #GtkCellEditable are responsible for emitting this signal when they are done editing, e.g. #GtkEntry is emitting it when the user presses Enter.
gtk_cell_editable_editing_done() is a convenience method for emitting #GtkCellEditable::editing-done.

parameter.name: cell_editable
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

signal.name: GtkCellEditable::remove-widget
signal.description:
This signal is meant to indicate that the cell is finished editing, and the widget may now be destroyed.
Implementations of #GtkCellEditable are responsible for emitting this signal when they are done editing. It must be emitted after the #GtkCellEditable::editing-done signal, to give the cell renderer a chance to update the cell's value before the widget is removed.
gtk_cell_editable_remove_widget() is a convenience method for emitting #GtkCellEditable::remove-widget.

parameter.name: cell_editable
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

signal.name: GtkCellRenderer::editing-canceled
signal.description:
This signal gets emitted when the user cancels the process of editing a cell. For example, an editable cell renderer could be written to cancel editing when the user presses Escape.
See also: gtk_cell_renderer_stop_editing().
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: renderer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkCellRenderer::editing-started

parameter.name: renderer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: the path identifying the edited cell

signal.name: GtkCellRendererAccel::accel-cleared
signal.description:
Gets emitted when the user has removed the accelerator.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: path_string
parameter.parameter_description: the path identifying the row of the edited cell

signal.name: GtkCellRendererAccel::accel-edited
signal.description:
Gets emitted when the user has selected a new accelerator.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: path_string
parameter.parameter_description: the path identifying the row of the edited cell

parameter.name: hardware_keycode
parameter.parameter_description: the keycode of the new accelerator

signal.name: GtkCellRendererCombo::changed
signal.description:
This signal is emitted each time after the user selected an item in the combo box, either by using the mouse or the arrow keys. Contrary to GtkComboBox, GtkCellRendererCombo::changed is not emitted for changes made to a selected item in the entry. The argument @new_iter corresponds to the newly selected item in the combo box and it is relative to the GtkTreeModel set via the model property on GtkCellRendererCombo.
Note that as soon as you change the model displayed in the tree view, the tree view will immediately cease the editing operating. This means that you most probably want to refrain from changing the model until the combo cell renderer emits the edited or editing_canceled signal.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: combo
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: path_string
parameter.parameter_description: a string of the path identifying the edited cell (relative to the tree view model)

parameter.name: new_iter
parameter.parameter_description: the new iter selected in the combo box (relative to the combo box model)

enum.name: GtkCellRendererMode
enum.description: Identifies how the user can interact with a particular cell.

parameter.name: GTK_CELL_RENDERER_MODE_INERT
parameter.parameter_description: The cell is just for display and cannot be interacted with. Note that this doesn't mean that eg. the row being drawn can't be selected -- just that a particular element of it cannot be individually modified.

parameter.name: GTK_CELL_RENDERER_MODE_EDITABLE
parameter.parameter_description: The cell can be edited or otherwise modified.

enum.name: GtkCellRendererState
enum.description: Tells how a cell is to be rendered.

parameter.name: GTK_CELL_RENDERER_SELECTED
parameter.parameter_description: The cell is currently selected, and probably has a selection colored background to render to.

parameter.name: GTK_CELL_RENDERER_PRELIT
parameter.parameter_description: The mouse is hovering over the cell.

parameter.name: GTK_CELL_RENDERER_INSENSITIVE
parameter.parameter_description: The cell is drawn in an insensitive manner

parameter.name: GTK_CELL_RENDERER_SORTED
parameter.parameter_description: The cell is in a sorted row

parameter.name: GTK_CELL_RENDERER_FOCUSED
parameter.parameter_description: The cell is in the focus row.

parameter.name: GTK_CELL_RENDERER_EXPANDABLE
parameter.parameter_description: The cell is in a row that can be expanded. Since 3.4

parameter.name: GTK_CELL_RENDERER_EXPANDED
parameter.parameter_description: The cell is in a row that is expanded. Since 3.4

signal.name: GtkCellRendererText::edited
signal.description:
This signal is emitted after @renderer has been edited.
It is the responsibility of the application to update the model and store @new_text at the position indicated by @path.

parameter.name: renderer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: the path identifying the edited cell

signal.name: GtkCellRendererToggle::toggled
signal.description: The ::toggled signal is emitted when the cell is toggled.

parameter.name: cell_renderer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: string representation of #GtkTreePath describing the event location

signal.name: GtkCheckMenuItem::toggled
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when the state of the check box is changed.
A signal handler can use gtk_check_menu_item_get_active() to discover the new state.

parameter.name: checkmenuitem
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkClipboard::owner-change
signal.description:
The ::owner-change signal is emitted when GTK+ receives an event that indicates that the ownership of the selection associated with @clipboard has changed.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: clipboard
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkClipboard on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkColorButton::color-set
signal.description:
The ::color-set signal is emitted when the user selects a color. When handling this signal, use gtk_color_button_get_rgba() to find out which color was just selected.
Note that this signal is only emitted when the <emphasis>user</emphasis> changes the color. If you need to react to programmatic color changes as well, use the notify::color signal.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkColorChooser::color-activated
signal.description:
Emitted when a color is activated from the color chooser. This usually happens when the user clicks a color swatch, or a color is selected and the user presses one of the keys Space, Shift+Space, Return or Enter.
Since: 3.4

parameter.name: chooser
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkColorSelection::color-changed
signal.description: This signal is emitted when the color changes in the #GtkColorSelection according to its update policy.

parameter.name: colorselection
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkComboBox::changed
signal.description:
The changed signal is emitted when the active item is changed. The can be due to the user selecting a different item from the list, or due to a call to gtk_combo_box_set_active_iter(). It will also be emitted while typing into the entry of a combo box with an entry.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkComboBox::format-entry-text

parameter.name: combo
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: the GtkTreePath string from the combo box's current model to format text for

signal.return: a newly allocated string representing @path for the current GtkComboBox model.

signal.name: GtkComboBox::move-active
signal.description:
The ::move-active signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to move the active selection.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkComboBox::popdown
signal.description:
The ::popdown signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to popdown the combo box list.
The default bindings for this signal are Alt+Up and Escape.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkComboBox::popup
signal.description:
The ::popup signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to popup the combo box list.
The default binding for this signal is Alt+Down.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

enum.name: GtkCornerType
enum.description: Specifies which corner a child widget should be placed in when packed into a #GtkScrolledWindow. This is effectively the opposite of where the scroll bars are placed.

parameter.name: GTK_CORNER_TOP_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: Place the scrollbars on the right and bottom of the widget (default behaviour).

parameter.name: GTK_CORNER_BOTTOM_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: Place the scrollbars on the top and right of the widget.

parameter.name: GTK_CORNER_TOP_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Place the scrollbars on the left and bottom of the widget.

parameter.name: GTK_CORNER_BOTTOM_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Place the scrollbars on the top and left of the widget.

signal.name: GtkCssProvider::parsing-error
signal.description:
Signals that a parsing error occured. the @path, @line and @position describe the actual location of the error as accurately as possible.
Parsing errors are never fatal, so the parsing will resume after the error. Errors may however cause parts of the given data or even all of it to not be parsed at all. So it is a useful idea to check that the parsing succeeds by connecting to this signal.
Note that this signal may be emitted at any time as the css provider may opt to defer parsing parts or all of the input to a later time than when a loading function was called.

parameter.name: provider
parameter.parameter_description: the provider that had a parsing error

enum.name: GtkCssSectionType
enum.description:
The different types of sections indicate parts of a CSS document as parsed by GTK's CSS parser. They are oriented towards the CSS grammar <ulink url="http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/grammar.html">CSS grammer</ulink>, but may contain extensions.
More types might be added in the future as the parser incorporates more features.
Since: 3.2

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_SECTION_DOCUMENT
parameter.parameter_description: The section describes a complete document. This section time is the only one where gtk_css_section_get_parent() might return %NULL.

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_SECTION_IMPORT
parameter.parameter_description: The section defines an import rule.

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_SECTION_COLOR_DEFINITION
parameter.parameter_description: The section defines a color. This is a GTK extension to CSS.

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_SECTION_BINDING_SET
parameter.parameter_description: The section defines a binding set. This is a GTK extension to CSS.

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_SECTION_RULESET
parameter.parameter_description: The section defines a CSS ruleset.

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_SECTION_SELECTOR
parameter.parameter_description: The section defines a CSS selector.

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_SECTION_DECLARATION
parameter.parameter_description: The section defines the declaration of a CSS variable.

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_SECTION_VALUE
parameter.parameter_description: The section defines the value of a CSS declaration.

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_SECTION_KEYFRAMES
parameter.parameter_description: The section defines keyframes. See <ulink url="http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css3-animations/#keyframes">CSS animations</ulink> for details. Since 3.6

enum.name: GtkDestDefaults
enum.description: The #GtkDestDefaults enumeration specifies the various types of action that will be taken on behalf of the user for a drag destination site.

parameter.name: GTK_DEST_DEFAULT_MOTION
parameter.parameter_description: If set for a widget, GTK+, during a drag over this widget will check if the drag matches this widget's list of possible targets and actions. GTK+ will then call gdk_drag_status() as appropriate.

parameter.name: GTK_DEST_DEFAULT_HIGHLIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: If set for a widget, GTK+ will draw a highlight on this widget as long as a drag is over this widget and the widget drag format and action are acceptable.

parameter.name: GTK_DEST_DEFAULT_DROP
parameter.parameter_description: If set for a widget, when a drop occurs, GTK+ will will check if the drag matches this widget's list of possible targets and actions. If so, GTK+ will call gtk_drag_get_data() on behalf of the widget. Whether or not the drop is successful, GTK+ will call gtk_drag_finish(). If the action was a move, then if the drag was successful, then %TRUE will be passed for the @delete parameter to gtk_drag_finish().

parameter.name: GTK_DEST_DEFAULT_ALL
parameter.parameter_description: If set, specifies that all default actions should be taken.

signal.name: GtkDialog::close
signal.description:
The ::close signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user uses a keybinding to close the dialog.
The default binding for this signal is the Escape key.

signal.name: GtkDialog::response
signal.description: Emitted when an action widget is clicked, the dialog receives a delete event, or the application programmer calls gtk_dialog_response(). On a delete event, the response ID is #GTK_RESPONSE_DELETE_EVENT. Otherwise, it depends on which action widget was clicked.

parameter.name: dialog
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

enum.name: GtkDialogFlags
enum.description: Flags used to influence dialog construction.

parameter.name: GTK_DIALOG_MODAL
parameter.parameter_description: Make the constructed dialog modal, see gtk_window_set_modal()

parameter.name: GTK_DIALOG_DESTROY_WITH_PARENT
parameter.parameter_description: Destroy the dialog when its parent is destroyed, see gtk_window_set_destroy_with_parent()

enum.name: GtkDragResult
enum.description: Gives an indication why a drag operation failed. The value can by obtained by connecting to the #GtkWidget::drag-failed signal.

parameter.name: GTK_DRAG_RESULT_USER_CANCELLED
parameter.parameter_description: The user cancelled the drag operation.

parameter.name: GTK_DRAG_RESULT_GRAB_BROKEN
parameter.parameter_description: The pointer or keyboard grab used for the drag operation was broken.

parameter.name: GTK_DRAG_RESULT_ERROR
parameter.parameter_description: The drag operation failed due to some unspecified error.

signal.name: GtkEditable::changed
signal.description:
The ::changed signal is emitted at the end of a single user-visible operation on the contents of the #GtkEditable.
E.g., a paste operation that replaces the contents of the selection will cause only one signal emission (even though it is implemented by first deleting the selection, then inserting the new content, and may cause multiple ::notify::text signals to be emitted).

parameter.name: editable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEditable::delete-text
signal.description: This signal is emitted when text is deleted from the widget by the user. The default handler for this signal will normally be responsible for deleting the text, so by connecting to this signal and then stopping the signal with g_signal_stop_emission(), it is possible to modify the range of deleted text, or prevent it from being deleted entirely. The @start_pos and @end_pos parameters are interpreted as for gtk_editable_delete_text().

parameter.name: editable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEditable::insert-text
signal.description: This signal is emitted when text is inserted into the widget by the user. The default handler for this signal will normally be responsible for inserting the text, so by connecting to this signal and then stopping the signal with g_signal_stop_emission(), it is possible to modify the inserted text, or prevent it from being inserted entirely.

parameter.name: editable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: new_text_length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of the new text, in bytes, or -1 if new_text is nul-terminated

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position, in characters, at which to insert the new text. this is an in-out parameter. After the signal emission is finished, it should point after the newly inserted text.

signal.name: GtkEntry::activate
signal.description:
The ::activate signal is emitted when the user hits the Enter key.
While this signal is used as a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link>, it is also commonly used by applications to intercept activation of entries.
The default bindings for this signal are all forms of the Enter key.

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: The entry on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkEntry::backspace
signal.description:
The ::backspace signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
The default bindings for this signal are Backspace and Shift-Backspace.

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEntry::copy-clipboard
signal.description:
The ::copy-clipboard signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to copy the selection to the clipboard.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-c and Ctrl-Insert.

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEntry::cut-clipboard
signal.description:
The ::cut-clipboard signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to cut the selection to the clipboard.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-x and Shift-Delete.

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEntry::delete-from-cursor
signal.description:
The ::delete-from-cursor signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user initiates a text deletion.
If the @type is %GTK_DELETE_CHARS, GTK+ deletes the selection if there is one, otherwise it deletes the requested number of characters.
The default bindings for this signal are Delete for deleting a character and Ctrl-Delete for deleting a word.

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: type
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the deletion, as a #GtkDeleteType

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @type units to delete

signal.name: GtkEntry::icon-press
signal.description:
The ::icon-press signal is emitted when an activatable icon is clicked.
Since: 2.16

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: The entry on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: icon_pos
parameter.parameter_description: The position of the clicked icon

signal.name: GtkEntry::icon-release
signal.description:
The ::icon-release signal is emitted on the button release from a mouse click over an activatable icon.
Since: 2.16

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: The entry on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: icon_pos
parameter.parameter_description: The position of the clicked icon

signal.name: GtkEntry::insert-at-cursor
signal.description:
The ::insert-at-cursor signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user initiates the insertion of a fixed string at the cursor.
This signal has no default bindings.

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEntry::move-cursor
signal.description:
The ::move-cursor signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user initiates a cursor movement. If the cursor is not visible in @entry, this signal causes the viewport to be moved instead.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control the cursor programmatically.
The default bindings for this signal come in two variants, the variant with the Shift modifier extends the selection, the variant without the Shift modifer does not. There are too many key combinations to list them all here. <itemizedlist> <listitem>Arrow keys move by individual characters/lines</listitem> <listitem>Ctrl-arrow key combinations move by words/paragraphs</listitem> <listitem>Home/End keys move to the ends of the buffer</listitem> </itemizedlist>

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: step
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the move, as a #GtkMovementStep

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @step units to move

parameter.name: extend_selection
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the move should extend the selection

signal.name: GtkEntry::paste-clipboard
signal.description:
The ::paste-clipboard signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to paste the contents of the clipboard into the text view.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-v and Shift-Insert.

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEntry::populate-popup
signal.description:
The ::populate-popup signal gets emitted before showing the context menu of the entry.
If you need to add items to the context menu, connect to this signal and append your items to the @widget, which will be a #GtkMenu in this case.
If #GtkEntry:populate-all is %TRUE, this signal will also be emitted to populate touch popups. In this case, @widget will be a different container, e.g. a #GtkToolbar. The signal handler should not make assumptions about the type of @widget.

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: The entry on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: popup
parameter.parameter_description: the container that is being populated

signal.name: GtkEntry::preedit-changed
signal.description:
If an input method is used, the typed text will not immediately be committed to the buffer. So if you are interested in the text, connect to this signal.
Since: 2.20

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEntry::tabs
signal.description:
A list of tabstops to apply to the text of the entry.
Since: 3.8

signal.name: GtkEntry::toggle-overwrite
signal.description:
The ::toggle-overwrite signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to toggle the overwrite mode of the entry.
The default bindings for this signal is Insert.

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEntryBuffer::deleted-text
signal.description:
This signal is emitted after text is deleted from the buffer.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position the text was deleted at.

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: The number of characters that were deleted.

signal.name: GtkEntryBuffer::inserted-text
signal.description:
This signal is emitted after text is inserted into the buffer.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position the text was inserted at.

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: The number of characters that were inserted.

signal.name: GtkEntryCompletion::action-activated
signal.description:
Gets emitted when an action is activated.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the activated action

signal.name: GtkEntryCompletion::cursor-on-match
signal.description:
Gets emitted when a match from the cursor is on a match of the list. The default behaviour is to replace the contents of the entry with the contents of the text column in the row pointed to by @iter.
Note that @model is the model that was passed to gtk_entry_completion_set_model().
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkTreeIter positioned at the selected match

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal has been handled

signal.name: GtkEntryCompletion::insert-prefix
signal.description:
Gets emitted when the inline autocompletion is triggered. The default behaviour is to make the entry display the whole prefix and select the newly inserted part.
Applications may connect to this signal in order to insert only a smaller part of the @prefix into the entry - e.g. the entry used in the #GtkFileChooser inserts only the part of the prefix up to the next '/'.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: prefix
parameter.parameter_description: the common prefix of all possible completions

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal has been handled

signal.name: GtkEntryCompletion::match-selected
signal.description:
Gets emitted when a match from the list is selected. The default behaviour is to replace the contents of the entry with the contents of the text column in the row pointed to by @iter.
Note that @model is the model that was passed to gtk_entry_completion_set_model().
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkTreeIter positioned at the selected match

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal has been handled

enum.name: GtkEntryIconPosition
enum.description:
Specifies the side of the entry at which an icon is placed.
Since: 2.16

parameter.name: GTK_ENTRY_ICON_PRIMARY
parameter.parameter_description: At the beginning of the entry (depending on the text direction).

parameter.name: GTK_ENTRY_ICON_SECONDARY
parameter.parameter_description: At the end of the entry (depending on the text direction).

enum.name: GtkExpanderStyle
enum.description: Used to specify the style of the expanders drawn by a #GtkTreeView.

parameter.name: GTK_EXPANDER_COLLAPSED
parameter.parameter_description: The style used for a collapsed subtree.

parameter.name: GTK_EXPANDER_EXPANDED
parameter.parameter_description: The style used for an expanded subtree.

signal.name: GtkFileChooser::confirm-overwrite

parameter.name: chooser
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.return: a #GtkFileChooserConfirmation value that indicates which action to take after emitting the signal.

signal.name: GtkFileChooser::current-folder-changed
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when the current folder in a #GtkFileChooser changes. This can happen due to the user performing some action that changes folders, such as selecting a bookmark or visiting a folder on the file list. It can also happen as a result of calling a function to explicitly change the current folder in a file chooser.
Normally you do not need to connect to this signal, unless you need to keep track of which folder a file chooser is showing.
See also: gtk_file_chooser_set_current_folder(), gtk_file_chooser_get_current_folder(), gtk_file_chooser_set_current_folder_uri(), gtk_file_chooser_get_current_folder_uri().

parameter.name: chooser
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkFileChooser::file-activated
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when the user "activates" a file in the file chooser. This can happen by double-clicking on a file in the file list, or by pressing <keycap>Enter</keycap>.
Normally you do not need to connect to this signal. It is used internally by #GtkFileChooserDialog to know when to activate the default button in the dialog.
See also: gtk_file_chooser_get_filename(), gtk_file_chooser_get_filenames(), gtk_file_chooser_get_uri(), gtk_file_chooser_get_uris().

parameter.name: chooser
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkFileChooser::selection-changed
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when there is a change in the set of selected files in a #GtkFileChooser. This can happen when the user modifies the selection with the mouse or the keyboard, or when explicitly calling functions to change the selection.
Normally you do not need to connect to this signal, as it is easier to wait for the file chooser to finish running, and then to get the list of selected files using the functions mentioned below.
See also: gtk_file_chooser_select_filename(), gtk_file_chooser_unselect_filename(), gtk_file_chooser_get_filename(), gtk_file_chooser_get_filenames(), gtk_file_chooser_select_uri(), gtk_file_chooser_unselect_uri(), gtk_file_chooser_get_uri(), gtk_file_chooser_get_uris().

parameter.name: chooser
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkFileChooser::update-preview
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when the preview in a file chooser should be regenerated. For example, this can happen when the currently selected file changes. You should use this signal if you want your file chooser to have a preview widget.
Once you have installed a preview widget with gtk_file_chooser_set_preview_widget(), you should update it when this signal is emitted. You can use the functions gtk_file_chooser_get_preview_filename() or gtk_file_chooser_get_preview_uri() to get the name of the file to preview. Your widget may not be able to preview all kinds of files; your callback must call gtk_file_chooser_set_preview_widget_active() to inform the file chooser about whether the preview was generated successfully or not.
Please see the example code in <xref linkend="gtkfilechooser-preview"/>.
See also: gtk_file_chooser_set_preview_widget(), gtk_file_chooser_set_preview_widget_active(), gtk_file_chooser_set_use_preview_label(), gtk_file_chooser_get_preview_filename(), gtk_file_chooser_get_preview_uri().

parameter.name: chooser
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

enum.name: GtkFileChooserAction
enum.description: Describes whether a #GtkFileChooser is being used to open existing files or to save to a possibly new file.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ACTION_OPEN
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates open mode. The file chooser will only let the user pick an existing file.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ACTION_SAVE
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates save mode. The file chooser will let the user pick an existing file, or type in a new filename.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ACTION_SELECT_FOLDER
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates an Open mode for selecting folders. The file chooser will let the user pick an existing folder.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ACTION_CREATE_FOLDER
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates a mode for creating a new folder. The file chooser will let the user name an existing or new folder.

signal.name: GtkFileChooserButton::file-set
signal.description:
The ::file-set signal is emitted when the user selects a file.
Note that this signal is only emitted when the <emphasis>user</emphasis> changes the file.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

enum.name: GtkFileChooserConfirmation
enum.description:
Used as a return value of handlers for the #GtkFileChooser::confirm-overwrite signal of a #GtkFileChooser. This value determines whether the file chooser will present the stock confirmation dialog, accept the user's choice of a filename, or let the user choose another filename.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_CONFIRMATION_CONFIRM
parameter.parameter_description: The file chooser will present its stock dialog to confirm about overwriting an existing file.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_CONFIRMATION_ACCEPT_FILENAME
parameter.parameter_description: The file chooser will terminate and accept the user's choice of a file name.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_CONFIRMATION_SELECT_AGAIN
parameter.parameter_description: The file chooser will continue running, so as to let the user select another file name.

enum.name: GtkFileChooserError
enum.description: These identify the various errors that can occur while calling #GtkFileChooser functions.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ERROR_NONEXISTENT
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates that a file does not exist.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ERROR_ALREADY_EXISTS
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates a duplicate path (e.g. when adding a bookmark).

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ERROR_INCOMPLETE_HOSTNAME
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates an incomplete hostname (e.g. "http://foo" without a slash after that).

enum.name: GtkFileFilterFlags
enum.description: These flags indicate what parts of a #GtkFileFilterInfo struct are filled or need to be filled.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_FILTER_FILENAME
parameter.parameter_description: the filename of the file being tested

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_FILTER_URI
parameter.parameter_description: the URI for the file being tested

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_FILTER_DISPLAY_NAME
parameter.parameter_description: the string that will be used to display the file in the file chooser

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_FILTER_MIME_TYPE
parameter.parameter_description: the mime type of the file

signal.name: GtkFontButton::font-set
signal.description:
The ::font-set signal is emitted when the user selects a font. When handling this signal, use gtk_font_button_get_font_name() to find out which font was just selected.
Note that this signal is only emitted when the <emphasis>user</emphasis> changes the font. If you need to react to programmatic font changes as well, use the notify::font-name signal.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkFontChooser::font-activated
signal.description: Emitted when a font is activated. This usually happens when the user double clicks an item, or an item is selected and the user presses one of the keys Space, Shift+Space, Return or Enter.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkHandleBox::child-attached
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when the contents of the handlebox are reattached to the main window.
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkHandleBox has been deprecated.

parameter.name: handlebox
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the child widget of the handlebox. (this argument provides no extra information and is here only for backwards-compatibility)

signal.name: GtkHandleBox::child-detached
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when the contents of the handlebox are detached from the main window.
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkHandleBox has been deprecated.

parameter.name: handlebox
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the child widget of the handlebox. (this argument provides no extra information and is here only for backwards-compatibility)

signal.name: GtkIMContext::commit
signal.description: The ::commit signal is emitted when a complete input sequence has been entered by the user. This can be a single character immediately after a key press or the final result of preediting.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: the completed character(s) entered by the user

signal.name: GtkIMContext::delete-surrounding
signal.description: The ::delete-surrounding signal is emitted when the input method needs to delete all or part of the context surrounding the cursor.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: offset
parameter.parameter_description: the character offset from the cursor position of the text to be deleted. A negative value indicates a position before the cursor.

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: the number of characters to be deleted

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal was handled.

signal.name: GtkIMContext::preedit-changed
signal.description: The ::preedit-changed signal is emitted whenever the preedit sequence currently being entered has changed. It is also emitted at the end of a preedit sequence, in which case gtk_im_context_get_preedit_string() returns the empty string.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIMContext::preedit-end
signal.description: The ::preedit-end signal is emitted when a preediting sequence has been completed or canceled.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIMContext::preedit-start
signal.description: The ::preedit-start signal is emitted when a new preediting sequence starts.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIMContext::retrieve-surrounding
signal.description: The ::retrieve-surrounding signal is emitted when the input method requires the context surrounding the cursor. The callback should set the input method surrounding context by calling the gtk_im_context_set_surrounding() method.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal was handled.

enum.name: GtkIconLookupFlags
enum.description: Used to specify options for gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon()

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_NO_SVG
parameter.parameter_description: Never return SVG icons, even if gdk-pixbuf supports them. Cannot be used together with %GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_FORCE_SVG.

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_FORCE_SVG
parameter.parameter_description: Return SVG icons, even if gdk-pixbuf doesn't support them. Cannot be used together with %GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_NO_SVG.

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_USE_BUILTIN
parameter.parameter_description: When passed to gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon() includes builtin icons as well as files. For a builtin icon, gtk_icon_info_get_filename() returns %NULL and you need to call gtk_icon_info_get_builtin_pixbuf().

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_GENERIC_FALLBACK
parameter.parameter_description: Try to shorten icon name at '-' characters before looking at inherited themes. For more general fallback, see gtk_icon_theme_choose_icon(). Since 2.12.

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_FORCE_SIZE
parameter.parameter_description: Always return the icon scaled to the requested size. Since 2.14.

signal.name: GtkIconTheme::changed
signal.description: Emitted when the current icon theme is switched or GTK+ detects that a change has occurred in the contents of the current icon theme.

enum.name: GtkIconThemeError
enum.description: Error codes for GtkIconTheme operations.

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_THEME_NOT_FOUND
parameter.parameter_description: The icon specified does not exist in the theme

signal.name: GtkIconView::activate-cursor-item
signal.description:
A <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user activates the currently focused item.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control activation programmatically.
The default bindings for this signal are Space, Return and Enter.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIconView::item-activated
signal.description: The ::item-activated signal is emitted when the method gtk_icon_view_item_activated() is called, when the user double clicks an item with the "activate-on-single-click" property set to %FALSE, or when the user single clicks an item when the "activate-on-single-click" property set to %TRUE. It is also emitted when a non-editable item is selected and one of the keys: Space, Return or Enter is pressed.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIconView::move-cursor
signal.description:
The ::move-cursor signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user initiates a cursor movement.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control the cursor programmatically.
The default bindings for this signal include <itemizedlist> <listitem>Arrow keys which move by individual steps</listitem> <listitem>Home/End keys which move to the first/last item</listitem> <listitem>PageUp/PageDown which move by "pages"</listitem> </itemizedlist>
All of these will extend the selection when combined with the Shift modifier.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: step
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the move, as a #GtkMovementStep

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @step units to move

signal.name: GtkIconView::select-all
signal.description:
A <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user selects all items.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control selection programmatically.
The default binding for this signal is Ctrl-a.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIconView::select-cursor-item
signal.description:
A <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user selects the item that is currently focused.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control selection programmatically.
There is no default binding for this signal.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIconView::selection-changed
signal.description: The ::selection-changed signal is emitted when the selection (i.e. the set of selected items) changes.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIconView::toggle-cursor-item
signal.description:
A <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user toggles whether the currently focused item is selected or not. The exact effect of this depend on the selection mode.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control selection programmatically.
There is no default binding for this signal is Ctrl-Space.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIconView::unselect-all
signal.description:
A <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user unselects all items.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control selection programmatically.
The default binding for this signal is Ctrl-Shift-a.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

enum.name: GtkIconViewDropPosition
enum.description: An enum for determining where a dropped item goes.

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_VIEW_DROP_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: droppped item is inserted to the left

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_VIEW_DROP_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: dropped item is inserted to the right

enum.name: GtkImageType
enum.description: Describes the image data representation used by a #GtkImage. If you want to get the image from the widget, you can only get the currently-stored representation. e.g. if the gtk_image_get_storage_type() returns #GTK_IMAGE_PIXBUF, then you can call gtk_image_get_pixbuf() but not gtk_image_get_stock(). For empty images, you can request any storage type (call any of the "get" functions), but they will all return %NULL values.

parameter.name: GTK_IMAGE_EMPTY
parameter.parameter_description: there is no image displayed by the widget

parameter.name: GTK_IMAGE_STOCK
parameter.parameter_description: the widget contains a stock icon name (see <xref linkend="gtk3-Stock-Items"/>)

parameter.name: GTK_IMAGE_ICON_NAME
parameter.parameter_description: the widget contains a named icon. This image type was added in GTK+ 2.6

parameter.name: GTK_IMAGE_GICON
parameter.parameter_description: the widget contains a #GIcon. This image type was added in GTK+ 2.14

parameter.name: GTK_IMAGE_SURFACE
parameter.parameter_description: the widget contains a #cairo_surface_t. This image type was added in GTK+ 3.10

signal.name: GtkInfoBar::close
signal.description:
The ::close signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user uses a keybinding to dismiss the info bar.
The default binding for this signal is the Escape key.
Since: 2.18

signal.name: GtkInfoBar::response
signal.description:
Emitted when an action widget is clicked or the application programmer calls gtk_dialog_response(). The @response_id depends on which action widget was clicked.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: info_bar
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

enum.name: GtkInputHints
enum.description:
Describes hints that might be taken into account by input methods or applications. Note that input methods may already tailor their behaviour according to the #GtkInputPurpose of the entry.
Some common sense is expected when using these flags - mixing @GTK_INPUT_HINT_LOWERCASE with any of the uppercase hints makes no sense.
This enumeration may be extended in the future; input methods should ignore unknown values.
Since: 3.6

parameter.name: GTK_INPUT_HINT_LOWERCASE
parameter.parameter_description: Suggest to convert all text to lowercase

parameter.name: GTK_INPUT_HINT_UPPERCASE_WORDS
parameter.parameter_description: Suggest to capitalize the first character of each word

parameter.name: GTK_INPUT_HINT_UPPERCASE_SENTENCES
parameter.parameter_description: Suggest to capitalize the first word of each sentence

parameter.name: GTK_INPUT_HINT_INHIBIT_OSK
parameter.parameter_description: Suggest to not show an onscreen keyboard (e.g for a calculator that already has all the keys).

enum.name: GtkInputPurpose
enum.description:
Describes primary purpose of the input widget. This information is useful for on-screen keyboards and similar input methods to decide which keys should be presented to the user.
Note that the purpose is not meant to impose a totally strict rule about allowed characters, and does not replace input validation. It is fine for an on-screen keyboard to let the user override the character set restriction that is expressed by the purpose. The application is expected to validate the entry contents, even if it specified a purpose.
The difference between @GTK_INPUT_PURPOSE_DIGITS and @GTK_INPUT_PURPOSE_NUMBER is that the former accepts only digits while the latter also some punctuation (like commas or points, plus, minus) and 'e' or 'E' as in 3.14E+000.
This enumeration may be extended in the future; input methods should interpret unknown values as 'free form'.
Since: 3.6

parameter.name: GTK_INPUT_PURPOSE_NAME
parameter.parameter_description: Edited field expects the name of a person

enum.name: GtkJunctionSides
enum.description: Describes how a rendered element connects to adjacent elements.

parameter.name: GTK_JUNCTION_CORNER_TOPLEFT
parameter.parameter_description: Element connects on the top-left corner.

parameter.name: GTK_JUNCTION_CORNER_TOPRIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Element connects on the top-right corner.

parameter.name: GTK_JUNCTION_CORNER_BOTTOMLEFT
parameter.parameter_description: Element connects on the bottom-left corner.

parameter.name: GTK_JUNCTION_CORNER_BOTTOMRIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Element connects on the bottom-right corner.

parameter.name: GTK_JUNCTION_TOP
parameter.parameter_description: Element connects on the top side.

parameter.name: GTK_JUNCTION_BOTTOM
parameter.parameter_description: Element connects on the bottom side.

parameter.name: GTK_JUNCTION_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: Element connects on the left side.

parameter.name: GTK_JUNCTION_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Element connects on the right side.

enum.name: GtkJustification
enum.description: Used for justifying the text inside a #GtkLabel widget. (See also #GtkAlignment).

parameter.name: GTK_JUSTIFY_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: The text is placed at the left edge of the label.

parameter.name: GTK_JUSTIFY_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: The text is placed at the right edge of the label.

parameter.name: GTK_JUSTIFY_CENTER
parameter.parameter_description: The text is placed in the center of the label.

parameter.name: GTK_JUSTIFY_FILL
parameter.parameter_description: The text is placed is distributed across the label.

signal.name: GtkLabel::activate-current-link
signal.description:
A <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user activates a link in the label.
Applications may also emit the signal with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control activation of URIs programmatically.
The default bindings for this signal are all forms of the Enter key.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: The label on which the signal was emitted

signal.name: GtkLabel::activate-link
signal.description:
The signal which gets emitted to activate a URI. Applications may connect to it to override the default behaviour, which is to call gtk_show_uri().
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: The label on which the signal was emitted

signal.return: %TRUE if the link has been activated

signal.name: GtkLabel::copy-clipboard
signal.description:
The ::copy-clipboard signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to copy the selection to the clipboard.
The default binding for this signal is Ctrl-c.

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkLabel::move-cursor
signal.description:
The ::move-cursor signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user initiates a cursor movement. If the cursor is not visible in @entry, this signal causes the viewport to be moved instead.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control the cursor programmatically.
The default bindings for this signal come in two variants, the variant with the Shift modifier extends the selection, the variant without the Shift modifer does not. There are too many key combinations to list them all here. <itemizedlist> <listitem>Arrow keys move by individual characters/lines</listitem> <listitem>Ctrl-arrow key combinations move by words/paragraphs</listitem> <listitem>Home/End keys move to the ends of the buffer</listitem> </itemizedlist>

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: step
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the move, as a #GtkMovementStep

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @step units to move

parameter.name: extend_selection
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the move should extend the selection

signal.name: GtkLabel::populate-popup
signal.description:
The ::populate-popup signal gets emitted before showing the context menu of the label. Note that only selectable labels have context menus.
If you need to add items to the context menu, connect to this signal and append your menuitems to the @menu.

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: The label on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: menu
parameter.parameter_description: the menu that is being populated

signal.name: GtkLevelBar::offset-changed
signal.description:
Emitted when an offset specified on the bar changes value as an effect to gtk_level_bar_add_offset_value() being called.
The signal supports detailed connections; you can connect to the detailed signal "changed::x" in order to only receive callbacks when the value of offset "x" changes.
Since: 3.6

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the offset that changed value

enum.name: GtkLevelBarMode
enum.description:
Describes how #GtkLevelBar contents should be rendered. Note that this enumeration could be extended with additional modes in the future.
Since: 3.6

parameter.name: GTK_LEVEL_BAR_MODE_CONTINUOUS
parameter.parameter_description: the bar has a continuous mode

parameter.name: GTK_LEVEL_BAR_MODE_DISCRETE
parameter.parameter_description: the bar has a discrete mode

enum.name: GtkLicense
enum.description:
The type of license for an application.
This enumeration can be expanded at later date.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: GTK_LICENSE_CUSTOM
parameter.parameter_description: A license text is going to be specified by the developer

parameter.name: GTK_LICENSE_GPL_2_0
parameter.parameter_description: The GNU General Public License, version 2.0

parameter.name: GTK_LICENSE_GPL_3_0
parameter.parameter_description: The GNU General Public License, version 3.0

parameter.name: GTK_LICENSE_LGPL_2_1
parameter.parameter_description: The GNU Lesser General Public License, version 2.1

parameter.name: GTK_LICENSE_LGPL_3_0
parameter.parameter_description: The GNU Lesser General Public License, version 3.0

signal.name: GtkLinkButton::activate-link
signal.description:
The ::activate-link signal is emitted each time the #GtkLinkButton has been clicked.
The default handler will call gtk_show_uri() with the URI stored inside the #GtkLinkButton:uri property.
To override the default behavior, you can connect to the ::activate-link signal and stop the propagation of the signal by returning %TRUE from your handler.

signal.name: GtkListBox::row-activated
signal.description:
The ::row-activated signal is emitted when a row has been activated by the user.
Since: 3.10

signal.name: GtkListBox::row-selected
signal.description:
The ::row-selected signal is emitted when a new row is selected, or (with a %NULL @row) when the selection is cleared.
Since: 3.10

enum.name: GtkMenuDirectionType
enum.description: An enumeration representing directional movements within a menu.

parameter.name: GTK_MENU_DIR_CHILD
parameter.parameter_description: To the submenu, if any, associated with the item

signal.name: GtkMenuItem::activate
signal.description: Emitted when the item is activated.

parameter.name: menuitem
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkMenuItem::activate-item
signal.description: Emitted when the item is activated, but also if the menu item has a submenu. For normal applications, the relevant signal is #GtkMenuItem::activate.

parameter.name: menuitem
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkMenuShell::activate-current
signal.description: An action signal that activates the current menu item within the menu shell.

parameter.name: menushell
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: force_hide
parameter.parameter_description: if %TRUE, hide the menu after activating the menu item

signal.name: GtkMenuShell::cancel
signal.description: An action signal which cancels the selection within the menu shell. Causes the #GtkMenuShell::selection-done signal to be emitted.

parameter.name: menushell
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkMenuShell::cycle-focus
signal.description: A keybinding signal which moves the focus in the given @direction.

parameter.name: menushell
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkMenuShell::deactivate
signal.description: This signal is emitted when a menu shell is deactivated.

parameter.name: menushell
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkMenuShell::insert
signal.description:
The ::insert signal is emitted when a new #GtkMenuItem is added to a #GtkMenuShell. A separate signal is used instead of GtkContainer::add because of the need for an additional position parameter.
The inverse of this signal is the GtkContainer::removed signal.
Since: 3.2

parameter.name: menu_shell
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position at which the insert occurs

signal.name: GtkMenuShell::move-current
