signal.description: An keybinding signal which moves the current menu item in the direction specified by @direction.

parameter.name: menushell
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkMenuShell::move-selected
signal.description:
The ::move-selected signal is emitted to move the selection to another item.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: menu_shell
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: distance
parameter.parameter_description: +1 to move to the next item, -1 to move to the previous

signal.return: %TRUE to stop the signal emission, %FALSE to continue

signal.name: GtkMenuShell::selection-done
signal.description: This signal is emitted when a selection has been completed within a menu shell.

parameter.name: menushell
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkMenuToolButton::show-menu
signal.description:
The ::show-menu signal is emitted before the menu is shown.
It can be used to populate the menu on demand, using gtk_menu_tool_button_set_menu().
Note that even if you populate the menu dynamically in this way, you must set an empty menu on the #GtkMenuToolButton beforehand, since the arrow is made insensitive if the menu is not set.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

enum.name: GtkMessageType
enum.description: The type of message being displayed in the dialog.

parameter.name: GTK_MESSAGE_OTHER
parameter.parameter_description: None of the above, doesn't get an icon

parameter.name: GTK_MOVEMENT_LOGICAL_POSITIONS
parameter.parameter_description: Move forward or back by graphemes

parameter.name: GTK_MOVEMENT_VISUAL_POSITIONS
parameter.parameter_description: Move left or right by graphemes

parameter.name: GTK_MOVEMENT_WORDS
parameter.parameter_description: Move forward or back by words

parameter.name: GTK_MOVEMENT_DISPLAY_LINES
parameter.parameter_description: Move up or down lines (wrapped lines)

parameter.name: GTK_MOVEMENT_DISPLAY_LINE_ENDS
parameter.parameter_description: Move to either end of a line

parameter.name: GTK_MOVEMENT_PARAGRAPHS
parameter.parameter_description: Move up or down paragraphs (newline-ended lines)

parameter.name: GTK_MOVEMENT_PARAGRAPH_ENDS
parameter.parameter_description: Move to either end of a paragraph

parameter.name: GTK_MOVEMENT_BUFFER_ENDS
parameter.parameter_description: Move to ends of the buffer

signal.name: GtkNotebook::create-window
signal.description:
The ::create-window signal is emitted when a detachable tab is dropped on the root window.
A handler for this signal can create a window containing a notebook where the tab will be attached. It is also responsible for moving/resizing the window and adding the necessary properties to the notebook (e.g. the #GtkNotebook:group-name ).
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: page
parameter.parameter_description: the tab of @notebook that is being detached

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the X coordinate where the drop happens

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y coordinate where the drop happens

signal.return: a #GtkNotebook that @page should be added to, or %NULL.

signal.name: GtkNotebook::page-added
signal.description:
the ::page-added signal is emitted in the notebook right after a page is added to the notebook.
Since: 2.10

signal.name: GtkNotebook::page-removed
signal.description:
the ::page-removed signal is emitted in the notebook right after a page is removed from the notebook.
Since: 2.10

signal.name: GtkNotebook::page-reordered
signal.description:
the ::page-reordered signal is emitted in the notebook right after a page has been reordered.
Since: 2.10

signal.name: GtkNotebook::switch-page
signal.description: Emitted when the user or a function changes the current page.

parameter.name: notebook
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

enum.name: GtkNumberUpLayout
enum.description: Used to determine the layout of pages on a sheet when printing multiple pages per sheet.

enum.name: GtkOrientation
enum.description: Represents the orientation of widgets which can be switched between horizontal and vertical orientation on the fly, like #GtkToolbar.

parameter.name: GTK_ORIENTATION_HORIZONTAL
parameter.parameter_description: The widget is in horizontal orientation.

parameter.name: GTK_ORIENTATION_VERTICAL
parameter.parameter_description: The widget is in vertical orientation.

signal.name: GtkOverlay::get-child-position
signal.description:
The ::get-child-position signal is emitted to determine the position and size of any overlay child widgets. A handler for this signal should fill @allocation with the desired position and size for @widget, relative to the 'main' child of @overlay.
The default handler for this signal uses the @widget's halign and valign properties to determine the position and gives the widget its natural size (except that an alignment of %GTK_ALIGN_FILL will cause the overlay to be full-width/height). If the main child is a #GtkScrolledWindow, the overlays are placed relative to its contents.
Return: %TRUE if the @allocation has been filled

enum.name: GtkPackDirection
enum.description: Determines how widgets should be packed inside menubars and menuitems contained in menubars.

enum.name: GtkPackType
enum.description: Represents the packing location #GtkBox children. (See: #GtkVBox, #GtkHBox, and #GtkButtonBox).

parameter.name: GTK_PACK_START
parameter.parameter_description: The child is packed into the start of the box

parameter.name: GTK_PACK_END
parameter.parameter_description: The child is packed into the end of the box

signal.name: GtkPaned::accept-position
signal.description:
The ::accept-position signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to accept the current position of the handle when moving it using key bindings.
The default binding for this signal is Return or Space.
Since: 2.0

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkPaned::cancel-position
signal.description:
The ::cancel-position signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to cancel moving the position of the handle using key bindings. The position of the handle will be reset to the value prior to moving it.
The default binding for this signal is Escape.
Since: 2.0

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkPaned::cycle-child-focus
signal.description:
The ::cycle-child-focus signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to cycle the focus between the children of the paned.
The default binding is f6.
Since: 2.0

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkPaned::cycle-handle-focus
signal.description:
The ::cycle-handle-focus signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to cycle whether the paned should grab focus to allow the user to change position of the handle by using key bindings.
The default binding for this signal is f8.
Since: 2.0

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkPaned::move-handle
signal.description:
The ::move-handle signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to move the handle when the user is using key bindings to move it.
Since: 2.0

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkPaned::toggle-handle-focus
signal.description:
The ::toggle-handle-focus is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to accept the current position of the handle and then move focus to the next widget in the focus chain.
The default binding is Tab.
Since: 2.0

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

enum.name: GtkPlacesOpenFlags
enum.description:
These flags serve two purposes. First, the application can call gtk_places_sidebar_set_open_flags() using these flags as a bitmask. This tells the sidebar that the application is able to open folders selected from the sidebar in various ways, for example, in new tabs or in new windows in addition to the normal mode.
Second, when one of these values gets passed back to the application in the #GtkPlacesSidebar::open-location signal, it means that the application should open the selected location in the normal way, in a new tab, or in a new window. The sidebar takes care of determining the desired way to open the location, based on the modifier keys that the user is pressing at the time the selection is made.
If the application never calls gtk_places_sidebar_set_open_flags(), then the sidebar will only use #GTK_PLACES_OPEN_NORMAL in the #GtkPlacesSidebar::open-location signal. This is the default mode of operation.

parameter.name: GTK_PLACES_OPEN_NORMAL
parameter.parameter_description: This is the default mode that #GtkPlacesSidebar uses if no other flags are specified. It indicates that the calling application should open the selected location in the normal way, for example, in the folder view beside the sidebar.

parameter.name: GTK_PLACES_OPEN_NEW_TAB
parameter.parameter_description: When passed to gtk_places_sidebar_set_open_flags(), this indicates that the application can open folders selected from the sidebar in new tabs. This value will be passed to the #GtkPlacesSidebar::open-location signal when the user selects that a location be opened in a new tab instead of in the standard fashion.

parameter.name: GTK_PLACES_OPEN_NEW_WINDOW
parameter.parameter_description: Similar to @GTK_PLACES_OPEN_NEW_TAB, but indicates that the application can open folders in new windows.

signal.name: GtkPlacesSidebar::drag-action-ask
signal.description:
The places sidebar emits this signal when it needs to ask the application to pop up a menu to ask the user for which drag action to perform.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: sidebar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: actions
parameter.parameter_description: Possible drag actions that need to be asked for.

signal.return: the final drag action that the sidebar should pass to the drag side of the drag-and-drop operation.

signal.name: GtkPlacesSidebar::drag-action-requested
signal.description:
When the user starts a drag-and-drop operation and the sidebar needs to ask the application for which drag action to perform, then the sidebar will emit this signal.
The application can evaluate the @context for customary actions, or it can check the type of the files indicated by @source_file_list against the possible actions for the destination @dest_file.
The drag action to use must be the return value of the signal handler.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: sidebar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: #GdkDragContext with information about the drag operation

parameter.name: dest_file
parameter.parameter_description: #GFile with the tentative location that is being hovered for a drop

parameter.name: source_file_list
parameter.parameter_description: List of #GFile that are being dragged

signal.return: The drag action to use, for example, #GDK_ACTION_COPY or #GDK_ACTION_MOVE, or 0 if no action is allowed here (i.e. drops are not allowed in the specified @dest_file).

signal.name: GtkPlacesSidebar::drag-perform-drop
signal.description:
The places sidebar emits this signal when the user completes a drag-and-drop operation and one of the sidebar's items is the destination. This item is in the @dest_file, and the @source_file_list has the list of files that are dropped into it and which should be copied/moved/etc. based on the specified @action.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: sidebar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkPlacesSidebar::open-location
signal.description:
The places sidebar emits this signal when the user selects a location in it. The calling application should display the contents of that location; for example, a file manager should show a list of files in the specified location.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: sidebar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: location
parameter.parameter_description: #GFile to which the caller should switch.

parameter.name: open_flags
parameter.parameter_description: a single value from #GtkPlacesOpenFlags specifying how the @location should be opened.

signal.name: GtkPlacesSidebar::populate-popup
signal.description:
The places sidebar emits this signal when the user invokes a contextual menu on one of its items. In the signal handler, the application may add extra items to the menu as appropriate. For example, a file manager may want to add a "Properties" command to the menu.
It is not necessary to store the @selected_item for each menu item; during their GtkMenuItem::activate callbacks, the application can use gtk_places_sidebar_get_location() to get the file to which the item refers.
The @selected_item argument may be #NULL in case the selection refers to a volume. In this case, @selected_volume will be non-NULL. In this case, the calling application will have to g_object_ref() the @selected_volume and keep it around for the purposes of its menu item's "activate" callback.
The @menu and all its menu items are destroyed after the user dismisses the menu. The menu is re-created (and thus, this signal is emitted) every time the user activates the contextual menu.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: sidebar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: selected_item
parameter.parameter_description: #GFile with the item to which the menu should refer, or #NULL in the case of a @selected_volume.

parameter.name: selected_volume
parameter.parameter_description: #GVolume if the selected item is a volume, or #NULL if it is a file.

signal.name: GtkPlacesSidebar::show-connect-to-server
signal.description:
The places sidebar emits this signal when it needs the calling application to present an way to connect directly to a network server. For example, the application may bring up a dialog box asking for a URL like "sftp://ftp.example.com". It is up to the application to create the corresponding mount by using, for example, g_file_mount_enclosing_volume().
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: sidebar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkPlacesSidebar::show-error-message
signal.description:
The places sidebar emits this signal when it needs the calling application to present an error message. Most of these messages refer to mounting or unmounting media, for example, when a drive cannot be started for some reason.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: sidebar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: primary
parameter.parameter_description: primary message with a summary of the error to show.

parameter.name: secondary
parameter.parameter_description: secondary message with details of the error to show.

signal.name: GtkPlug::embedded
signal.description: Gets emitted when the plug becomes embedded in a socket.

parameter.name: plug
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

enum.name: GtkPolicyType
enum.description: Determines when a scroll bar will be visible.

parameter.name: GTK_POLICY_AUTOMATIC
parameter.parameter_description: The scrollbar will appear and disappear as necessary. For example, when all of a #GtkCList can not be seen.

enum.name: GtkPositionType
enum.description: Describes which edge of a widget a certain feature is positioned at, e.g. the tabs of a #GtkNotebook, the handle of a #GtkHandleBox or the label of a #GtkScale.

parameter.name: GTK_POS_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: The feature is at the left edge.

parameter.name: GTK_POS_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: The feature is at the right edge.

parameter.name: GTK_POS_TOP
parameter.parameter_description: The feature is at the top edge.

parameter.name: GTK_POS_BOTTOM
parameter.parameter_description: The feature is at the bottom edge.

enum.name: GtkPrintCapabilities
enum.description: An enum for specifying which features the print dialog should offer. If neither %GTK_PRINT_CAPABILITY_GENERATE_PDF nor %GTK_PRINT_CAPABILITY_GENERATE_PS is specified, GTK+ assumes that all formats are supported.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_CAPABILITY_PAGE_SET
parameter.parameter_description: Print dialog will offer printing even/odd pages.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_CAPABILITY_COPIES
parameter.parameter_description: Print dialog will allow to print multiple copies.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_CAPABILITY_COLLATE
parameter.parameter_description: Print dialog will allow to collate multiple copies.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_CAPABILITY_REVERSE
parameter.parameter_description: Print dialog will allow to print pages in reverse order.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_CAPABILITY_SCALE
parameter.parameter_description: Print dialog will allow to scale the output.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_CAPABILITY_GENERATE_PDF
parameter.parameter_description: The program will send the document to the printer in PDF format

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_CAPABILITY_GENERATE_PS
parameter.parameter_description: The program will send the document to the printer in Postscript format

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_CAPABILITY_PREVIEW
parameter.parameter_description: Print dialog will offer a preview

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_CAPABILITY_NUMBER_UP
parameter.parameter_description: Print dialog will offer printing multiple pages per sheet. Since 2.12

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_CAPABILITY_NUMBER_UP_LAYOUT
parameter.parameter_description: Print dialog will allow to rearrange pages when printing multiple pages per sheet. Since 2.14

enum.name: GtkPrintError
enum.description: Error codes that identify various errors that can occur while using the GTK+ printing support.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_ERROR_INVALID_FILE
parameter.parameter_description: An error occurred while loading a page setup or paper size from a key file.

signal.name: GtkPrintJob::status-changed
signal.description:
Gets emitted when the status of a job changes. The signal handler can use gtk_print_job_get_status() to obtain the new status.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: job
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkPrintJob object on which the signal was emitted

signal.name: GtkPrintOperation::begin-print
signal.description:
Emitted after the user has finished changing print settings in the dialog, before the actual rendering starts.
A typical use for ::begin-print is to use the parameters from the #GtkPrintContext and paginate the document accordingly, and then set the number of pages with gtk_print_operation_set_n_pages().
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: operation
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted

signal.name: GtkPrintOperation::create-custom-widget
signal.description:
Emitted when displaying the print dialog. If you return a widget in a handler for this signal it will be added to a custom tab in the print dialog. You typically return a container widget with multiple widgets in it.
The print dialog owns the returned widget, and its lifetime is not controlled by the application. However, the widget is guaranteed to stay around until the #GtkPrintOperation::custom-widget-apply signal is emitted on the operation. Then you can read out any information you need from the widgets.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: operation
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted

signal.return: A custom widget that gets embedded in the print dialog, or %NULL

signal.name: GtkPrintOperation::custom-widget-apply
signal.description:
Emitted right before #GtkPrintOperation::begin-print if you added a custom widget in the #GtkPrintOperation::create-custom-widget handler. When you get this signal you should read the information from the custom widgets, as the widgets are not guaraneed to be around at a later time.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: operation
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the custom widget added in create-custom-widget

signal.name: GtkPrintOperation::done
signal.description:
Emitted when the print operation run has finished doing everything required for printing.
@result gives you information about what happened during the run. If @result is %GTK_PRINT_OPERATION_RESULT_ERROR then you can call gtk_print_operation_get_error() for more information.
If you enabled print status tracking then gtk_print_operation_is_finished() may still return %FALSE after #GtkPrintOperation::done was emitted.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: operation
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted

parameter.name: result
parameter.parameter_description: the result of the print operation

signal.name: GtkPrintOperation::draw-page

parameter.name: operation
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted

parameter.name: page_nr
parameter.parameter_description: the number of the currently printed page (0-based)

signal.name: GtkPrintOperation::end-print
signal.description:
Emitted after all pages have been rendered. A handler for this signal can clean up any resources that have been allocated in the #GtkPrintOperation::begin-print handler.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: operation
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted

signal.name: GtkPrintOperation::paginate
signal.description:
Emitted after the #GtkPrintOperation::begin-print signal, but before the actual rendering starts. It keeps getting emitted until a connected signal handler returns %TRUE.
The ::paginate signal is intended to be used for paginating a document in small chunks, to avoid blocking the user interface for a long time. The signal handler should update the number of pages using gtk_print_operation_set_n_pages(), and return %TRUE if the document has been completely paginated.
If you don't need to do pagination in chunks, you can simply do it all in the ::begin-print handler, and set the number of pages from there.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: operation
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted

signal.return: %TRUE if pagination is complete

signal.name: GtkPrintOperation::preview
signal.description:
Gets emitted when a preview is requested from the native dialog.
The default handler for this signal uses an external viewer application to preview.
To implement a custom print preview, an application must return %TRUE from its handler for this signal. In order to use the provided @context for the preview implementation, it must be given a suitable cairo context with gtk_print_context_set_cairo_context().
The custom preview implementation can use gtk_print_operation_preview_is_selected() and gtk_print_operation_preview_render_page() to find pages which are selected for print and render them. The preview must be finished by calling gtk_print_operation_preview_end_preview() (typically in response to the user clicking a close button).
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: operation
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted

parameter.name: parent
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkWindow to use as window parent, or %NULL

signal.return: %TRUE if the listener wants to take over control of the preview

signal.name: GtkPrintOperation::request-page-setup
signal.description:
Emitted once for every page that is printed, to give the application a chance to modify the page setup. Any changes done to @setup will be in force only for printing this page.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: operation
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted

parameter.name: page_nr
parameter.parameter_description: the number of the currently printed page (0-based)

signal.name: GtkPrintOperation::status-changed
signal.description:
Emitted at between the various phases of the print operation. See #GtkPrintStatus for the phases that are being discriminated. Use gtk_print_operation_get_status() to find out the current status.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: operation
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted

signal.name: GtkPrintOperation::update-custom-widget
signal.description:
Emitted after change of selected printer. The actual page setup and print settings are passed to the custom widget, which can actualize itself according to this change.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: operation
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the custom widget added in create-custom-widget

enum.name: GtkPrintOperationAction
enum.description: The @action parameter to gtk_print_operation_run() determines what action the print operation should perform.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_OPERATION_ACTION_PRINT
parameter.parameter_description: Start to print without showing the print dialog, based on the current print settings.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_OPERATION_ACTION_EXPORT
parameter.parameter_description: Export to a file. This requires the export-filename property to be set.

signal.name: GtkPrintOperationPreview::got-page-size
signal.description:
The ::got-page-size signal is emitted once for each page that gets rendered to the preview.
A handler for this signal should update the @context according to @page_setup and set up a suitable cairo context, using gtk_print_context_set_cairo_context().

parameter.name: preview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkPrintOperationPreview::ready
signal.description:
The ::ready signal gets emitted once per preview operation, before the first page is rendered.
A handler for this signal can be used for setup tasks.

parameter.name: preview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

enum.name: GtkPrintOperationResult
enum.description: A value of this type is returned by gtk_print_operation_run().

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_OPERATION_RESULT_APPLY
parameter.parameter_description: The print settings should be stored.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_OPERATION_RESULT_CANCEL
parameter.parameter_description: The print operation has been canceled, the print settings should not be stored.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_OPERATION_RESULT_IN_PROGRESS
parameter.parameter_description: The print operation is not complete yet. This value will only be returned when running asynchronously.

enum.name: GtkPrintStatus
enum.description: The status gives a rough indication of the completion of a running print operation.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_STATUS_INITIAL
parameter.parameter_description: The printing has not started yet; this status is set initially, and while the print dialog is shown.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_STATUS_PREPARING
parameter.parameter_description: This status is set while the begin-print signal is emitted and during pagination.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_STATUS_GENERATING_DATA
parameter.parameter_description: This status is set while the pages are being rendered.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_STATUS_SENDING_DATA
parameter.parameter_description: The print job is being sent off to the printer.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_STATUS_PENDING
parameter.parameter_description: The print job has been sent to the printer, but is not printed for some reason, e.g. the printer may be stopped.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_STATUS_PENDING_ISSUE
parameter.parameter_description: Some problem has occurred during printing, e.g. a paper jam.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_STATUS_PRINTING
parameter.parameter_description: The printer is processing the print job.

parameter.name: GTK_PRINT_STATUS_FINISHED
parameter.parameter_description: The printing has been completed successfully.

signal.name: GtkPrinter::details-acquired
signal.description:
Gets emitted in response to a request for detailed information about a printer from the print backend. The @success parameter indicates if the information was actually obtained.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: printer
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkPrinter on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: success
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the details were successfully acquired

enum.name: GtkQueueResizeFlags
enum.description: Flags that affect the operation of queueing a widget for resize.

parameter.name: GTK_QUEUE_RESIZE_INVALIDATE_ONLY
parameter.parameter_description: invalidate all cached sizes as we would normally do when a widget is queued for resize, but don't actually add the toplevel resize container to the resize queue. Useful if we want to change the size of a widget see how that would affect the overall layout, then restore the old size.

signal.name: GtkRadioAction::changed
signal.description:
The ::changed signal is emitted on every member of a radio group when the active member is changed. The signal gets emitted after the ::activate signals for the previous and current active members.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

parameter.name: action
parameter.parameter_description: the action on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: current
parameter.parameter_description: the member of @action<!-- -->s group which has just been activated

signal.name: GtkRadioButton::group-changed
signal.description:
Emitted when the group of radio buttons that a radio button belongs to changes. This is emitted when a radio button switches from being alone to being part of a group of 2 or more buttons, or vice-versa, and when a button is moved from one group of 2 or more buttons to a different one, but not when the composition of the group that a button belongs to changes.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkRange::adjust-bounds
signal.description: Emitted before clamping a value, to give the application a chance to adjust the bounds.

signal.name: GtkRange::change-value
signal.description:
The #GtkRange::change-value signal is emitted when a scroll action is performed on a range. It allows an application to determine the type of scroll event that occurred and the resultant new value. The application can handle the event itself and return %TRUE to prevent further processing. Or, by returning %FALSE, it can pass the event to other handlers until the default GTK+ handler is reached.
The value parameter is unrounded. An application that overrides the GtkRange::change-value signal is responsible for clamping the value to the desired number of decimal digits; the default GTK+ handler clamps the value based on #GtkRange:round-digits.
It is not possible to use delayed update policies in an overridden #GtkRange::change-value handler.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: scroll
parameter.parameter_description: the type of scroll action that was performed

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: the new value resulting from the scroll action

signal.return: %TRUE to prevent other handlers from being invoked for the signal, %FALSE to propagate the signal further

signal.name: GtkRange::move-slider
signal.description: Virtual function that moves the slider. Used for keybindings.

signal.name: GtkRange::value-changed
signal.description: Emitted when the range value changes.

enum.name: GtkRcTokenType
enum.description:
The #GtkRcTokenType enumeration represents the tokens in the RC file. It is exposed so that theme engines can reuse these tokens when parsing the theme-engine specific portions of a RC file.
Deprecated: 3.0: Use #GtkCssProvider instead.

signal.name: GtkRecentChooser::item-activated
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when the user "activates" a recent item in the recent chooser. This can happen by double-clicking on an item in the recently used resources list, or by pressing <keycap>Enter</keycap>.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: chooser
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkRecentChooser::selection-changed
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when there is a change in the set of selected recently used resources. This can happen when a user modifies the selection with the mouse or the keyboard, or when explicitely calling functions to change the selection.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: chooser
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

enum.name: GtkRecentChooserError
enum.description:
These identify the various errors that can occur while calling #GtkRecentChooser functions.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_CHOOSER_ERROR_NOT_FOUND
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates that a file does not exist

enum.name: GtkRecentFilterFlags
enum.description: These flags indicate what parts of a #GtkRecentFilterInfo struct are filled or need to be filled.

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_FILTER_URI
parameter.parameter_description: the URI of the file being tested

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_FILTER_DISPLAY_NAME
parameter.parameter_description: the string that will be used to display the file in the recent chooser

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_FILTER_MIME_TYPE
parameter.parameter_description: the mime type of the file

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_FILTER_APPLICATION
parameter.parameter_description: the list of applications that have registered the file

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_FILTER_GROUP
parameter.parameter_description: the groups to which the file belongs to

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_FILTER_AGE
parameter.parameter_description: the number of days elapsed since the file has been registered

signal.name: GtkRecentManager::changed
signal.description:
Emitted when the current recently used resources manager changes its contents, either by calling gtk_recent_manager_add_item() or by another application.
Since: 2.10

enum.name: GtkRecentManagerError
enum.description:
Error codes for #GtkRecentManager operations
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_MANAGER_ERROR_NOT_FOUND
parameter.parameter_description: the URI specified does not exists in the recently used resources list.

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_MANAGER_ERROR_INVALID_URI
parameter.parameter_description: the URI specified is not valid.

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_MANAGER_ERROR_INVALID_ENCODING
parameter.parameter_description: the supplied string is not UTF-8 encoded.

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_MANAGER_ERROR_NOT_REGISTERED
parameter.parameter_description: no application has registered the specified item.

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_MANAGER_ERROR_READ
parameter.parameter_description: failure while reading the recently used resources file.

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_MANAGER_ERROR_WRITE
parameter.parameter_description: failure while writing the recently used resources file.

enum.name: GtkRecentSortType
enum.description:
Used to specify the sorting method to be applyed to the recently used resource list.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_SORT_NONE
parameter.parameter_description: Do not sort the returned list of recently used resources.

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_SORT_MRU
parameter.parameter_description: Sort the returned list with the most recently used items first.

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_SORT_LRU
parameter.parameter_description: Sort the returned list with the least recently used items first.

parameter.name: GTK_RECENT_SORT_CUSTOM
parameter.parameter_description: Sort the returned list using a custom sorting function passed using gtk_recent_chooser_set_sort_func().

enum.name: GtkRegionFlags
enum.description: Describes a region within a widget.

parameter.name: GTK_REGION_EVEN
parameter.parameter_description: Region has an even number within a set.

parameter.name: GTK_REGION_ODD
parameter.parameter_description: Region has an odd number within a set.

parameter.name: GTK_REGION_FIRST
parameter.parameter_description: Region is the first one within a set.

parameter.name: GTK_REGION_LAST
parameter.parameter_description: Region is the last one within a set.

parameter.name: GTK_REGION_ONLY
parameter.parameter_description: Region is the only one within a set.

parameter.name: GTK_REGION_SORTED
parameter.parameter_description: Region is part of a sorted area.

enum.name: GtkReliefStyle
enum.description: Indicated the relief to be drawn around a #GtkButton.

parameter.name: GTK_RESIZE_PARENT
parameter.parameter_description: Pass resize request to the parent

enum.name: GtkResponseType
enum.description: Predefined values for use as response ids in gtk_dialog_add_button(). All predefined values are negative, GTK+ leaves positive values for application-defined response ids.

parameter.name: GTK_RESPONSE_NONE
parameter.parameter_description: Returned if an action widget has no response id, or if the dialog gets programmatically hidden or destroyed

parameter.name: GTK_RESPONSE_REJECT
parameter.parameter_description: Generic response id, not used by GTK+ dialogs

parameter.name: GTK_RESPONSE_ACCEPT
parameter.parameter_description: Generic response id, not used by GTK+ dialogs

parameter.name: GTK_RESPONSE_DELETE_EVENT
parameter.parameter_description: Returned if the dialog is deleted

parameter.name: GTK_RESPONSE_OK
parameter.parameter_description: Returned by OK buttons in GTK+ dialogs

parameter.name: GTK_RESPONSE_CANCEL
parameter.parameter_description: Returned by Cancel buttons in GTK+ dialogs

parameter.name: GTK_RESPONSE_CLOSE
parameter.parameter_description: Returned by Close buttons in GTK+ dialogs

parameter.name: GTK_RESPONSE_YES
parameter.parameter_description: Returned by Yes buttons in GTK+ dialogs

parameter.name: GTK_RESPONSE_NO
parameter.parameter_description: Returned by No buttons in GTK+ dialogs

parameter.name: GTK_RESPONSE_APPLY
parameter.parameter_description: Returned by Apply buttons in GTK+ dialogs

parameter.name: GTK_RESPONSE_HELP
parameter.parameter_description: Returned by Help buttons in GTK+ dialogs

enum.name: GtkRevealerTransitionType
enum.description: These enumeration values describe the possible transitions when the child of a #GtkRevealer widget is shown or hidden.

signal.name: GtkScale::format-value

parameter.name: scale
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: allocated string representing @value

signal.name: GtkScaleButton::popdown
signal.description:
The ::popdown signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to popdown the scale widget.
The default binding for this signal is Escape.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkScaleButton::popup
signal.description:
The ::popup signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to popup the scale widget.
The default bindings for this signal are Space, Enter and Return.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkScaleButton::value-changed
signal.description:
The ::value-changed signal is emitted when the value field has changed.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

enum.name: GtkScrollablePolicy
enum.description: Defines the policy to be used in a scrollable widget when updating the scrolled window adjustments in a given orientation.

parameter.name: GTK_SCROLL_MINIMUM
parameter.parameter_description: Scrollable adjustments are based on the minimum size

parameter.name: GTK_SCROLL_NATURAL
parameter.parameter_description: Scrollable adjustments are based on the natural size

signal.name: GtkScrolledWindow::move-focus-out
signal.description: The ::move-focus-out signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when focus is moved away from the scrolled window by a keybinding. The #GtkWidget::move-focus signal is emitted with @direction_type on this scrolled windows toplevel parent in the container hierarchy. The default bindings for this signal are <keycombo><keycap>Tab</keycap><keycap>Ctrl</keycap></keycombo> and <keycombo><keycap>Tab</keycap><keycap>Ctrl</keycap><keycap>Shift</keycap></keycombo>.

signal.name: GtkScrolledWindow::scroll-child
signal.description: The ::scroll-child signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when a keybinding that scrolls is pressed. The horizontal or vertical adjustment is updated which triggers a signal that the scrolled windows child may listen to and scroll itself.

parameter.name: scroll
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkScrollType describing how much to scroll

parameter.name: horizontal
parameter.parameter_description: whether the keybinding scrolls the child horizontally or not

signal.name: GtkSearchEntry::search-changed
signal.description:
The #GtkSearchEntry::search-changed signal is emitted with a short delay of 150 milliseconds after the last change to the entry text.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: the entry on which the signal was emitted

enum.name: GtkSelectionMode
enum.description: Used to control what selections users are allowed to make.

parameter.name: GTK_SELECTION_SINGLE
parameter.parameter_description: Zero or one element may be selected.

parameter.name: GTK_SELECTION_BROWSE
parameter.parameter_description: Exactly one element is selected. In some circumstances, such as initially or during a search operation, it's possible for no element to be selected with %GTK_SELECTION_BROWSE. What is really enforced is that the user can't deselect a currently selected element except by selecting another element.

parameter.name: GTK_SELECTION_MULTIPLE
parameter.parameter_description: Any number of elements may be selected. The Ctrl key may be used to enlarge the selection, and Shift key to select between the focus and the child pointed to. Some widgets may also allow Click-drag to select a range of elements.

enum.name: GtkSensitivityType
enum.description: Determines how GTK+ handles the sensitivity of stepper arrows at the end of range widgets.

parameter.name: GTK_SENSITIVITY_AUTO
parameter.parameter_description: The arrow is made insensitive if the thumb is at the end

signal.name: GtkSettings::gtk-button-images
signal.description:
Whether images should be shown on buttons
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10: This setting is ignored

signal.name: GtkSettings::gtk-menu-images
signal.description:
Whether images should be shown in menu items
Deprecated: 3.10: This setting is ignored

enum.name: GtkShadowType
enum.description: Used to change the appearance of an outline typically provided by a #GtkFrame.

parameter.name: GTK_SHADOW_OUT
parameter.parameter_description: The outline is bevelled outwards like a button.

parameter.name: GTK_SHADOW_ETCHED_IN
parameter.parameter_description: The outline has a sunken 3d appearance.

parameter.name: GTK_SHADOW_ETCHED_OUT
parameter.parameter_description: The outline has a raised 3d appearance.

enum.name: GtkSizeGroupMode
enum.description: The mode of the size group determines the directions in which the size group affects the requested sizes of its component widgets.

parameter.name: GTK_SIZE_GROUP_BOTH
parameter.parameter_description: group affects both horizontal and vertical requisition

enum.name: GtkSizeRequestMode
enum.description: Specifies a preference for height-for-width or width-for-height geometry management.

signal.name: GtkSocket::plug-added
signal.description: This signal is emitted when a client is successfully added to the socket.

parameter.name: socket_
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkSocket::plug-removed
signal.description: This signal is emitted when a client is removed from the socket. The default action is to destroy the #GtkSocket widget, so if you want to reuse it you must add a signal handler that returns %TRUE.

parameter.name: socket_
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked.

enum.name: GtkSortType
enum.description: Determines the direction of a sort.

signal.name: GtkSpinButton::input
signal.description:
The ::input signal can be used to influence the conversion of the users input into a double value. The signal handler is expected to use gtk_entry_get_text() to retrieve the text of the entry and set @new_value to the new value.
The default conversion uses g_strtod().

parameter.name: spin_button
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

parameter.name: new_value
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the new value

signal.return: %TRUE for a successful conversion, %FALSE if the input was not handled, and %GTK_INPUT_ERROR if the conversion failed.

signal.name: GtkSpinButton::output

parameter.name: spin_button
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE if the value has been displayed

signal.name: GtkSpinButton::wrapped
signal.description:
The wrapped signal is emitted right after the spinbutton wraps from its maximum to minimum value or vice-versa.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: spinbutton
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

enum.name: GtkSpinButtonUpdatePolicy
enum.description: The spin button update policy determines whether the spin button displays values even if they are outside the bounds of its adjustment. See gtk_spin_button_set_update_policy().

parameter.name: GTK_UPDATE_ALWAYS
parameter.parameter_description: When refreshing your #GtkSpinButton, the value is always displayed

parameter.name: GTK_UPDATE_IF_VALID
parameter.parameter_description: When refreshing your #GtkSpinButton, the value is only displayed if it is valid within the bounds of the spin button's adjustment

enum.name: GtkSpinType
enum.description: The values of the GtkSpinType enumeration are used to specify the change to make in gtk_spin_button_spin().

parameter.name: GTK_SPIN_STEP_FORWARD
parameter.parameter_description: Increment by the adjustments step increment.

parameter.name: GTK_SPIN_STEP_BACKWARD
parameter.parameter_description: Decrement by the adjustments step increment.

parameter.name: GTK_SPIN_PAGE_FORWARD
parameter.parameter_description: Increment by the adjustments page increment.

parameter.name: GTK_SPIN_PAGE_BACKWARD
parameter.parameter_description: Decrement by the adjustments page increment.

parameter.name: GTK_SPIN_HOME
parameter.parameter_description: Go to the adjustments lower bound.

parameter.name: GTK_SPIN_END
parameter.parameter_description: Go to the adjustments upper bound.

enum.name: GtkStackTransitionType
enum.description: These enumeration values describe the possible transitions between pages in a #GtkStack widget.

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_SLIDE_LEFT_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Slide from left or right according to the children order

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_SLIDE_UP_DOWN
parameter.parameter_description: Slide from top down or bottom up according to the order

enum.name: GtkStateFlags
enum.description: Describes a widget state. Widget states are used to match the widget against CSS pseudo-classes. Note that GTK extends the regular CSS classes and sometimes uses different names.

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_FLAG_PRELIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Widget has a mouse pointer over it.

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_FLAG_BACKDROP
parameter.parameter_description: Widget is in a background toplevel window.

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_FLAG_DIR_LTR
parameter.parameter_description: Widget is in left-to-right text direction. Since 3.8

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_FLAG_DIR_RTL
parameter.parameter_description: Widget is in right-to-left text direction. Since 3.8

enum.name: GtkStateType
enum.description: This type indicates the current state of a widget; the state determines how the widget is drawn. The #GtkStateType enumeration is also used to identify different colors in a #GtkStyle for drawing, so states can be used for subparts of a widget as well as entire widgets.

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_ACTIVE
parameter.parameter_description: State of a currently active widget, such as a depressed button.

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_PRELIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: State indicating that the mouse pointer is over the widget and the widget will respond to mouse clicks.

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_SELECTED
parameter.parameter_description: State of a selected item, such the selected row in a list.

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_INSENSITIVE
parameter.parameter_description: State indicating that the widget is unresponsive to user actions.

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_INCONSISTENT
parameter.parameter_description: The widget is inconsistent, such as checkbuttons or radiobuttons that aren't either set to %TRUE nor %FALSE, or buttons requiring the user attention.

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_FOCUSED
parameter.parameter_description: The widget has the keyboard focus.

signal.name: GtkStatusIcon::activate
signal.description:
Gets emitted when the user activates the status icon. If and how status icons can activated is platform-dependent.
Unlike most G_SIGNAL_ACTION signals, this signal is meant to be used by applications and should be wrapped by language bindings.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: status_icon
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkStatusIcon::button-press-event
signal.description:
The ::button-press-event signal will be emitted when a button (typically from a mouse) is pressed.
Whether this event is emitted is platform-dependent. Use the ::activate and ::popup-menu signals in preference.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: status_icon
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkStatusIcon::button-release-event
signal.description:
The ::button-release-event signal will be emitted when a button (typically from a mouse) is released.
Whether this event is emitted is platform-dependent. Use the ::activate and ::popup-menu signals in preference.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: status_icon
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkStatusIcon::popup-menu
signal.description:
Gets emitted when the user brings up the context menu of the status icon. Whether status icons can have context menus and how these are activated is platform-dependent.
The @button and @activate_time parameters should be passed as the last to arguments to gtk_menu_popup().
Unlike most G_SIGNAL_ACTION signals, this signal is meant to be used by applications and should be wrapped by language bindings.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: status_icon
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the button that was pressed, or 0 if the signal is not emitted in response to a button press event

parameter.name: activate_time
parameter.parameter_description: the timestamp of the event that triggered the signal emission

signal.name: GtkStatusIcon::query-tooltip
signal.description:
Emitted when the hover timeout has expired with the cursor hovering above @status_icon; or emitted when @status_icon got focus in keyboard mode.
Using the given coordinates, the signal handler should determine whether a tooltip should be shown for @status_icon. If this is the case %TRUE should be returned, %FALSE otherwise. Note that if @keyboard_mode is %TRUE, the values of @x and @y are undefined and should not be used.
The signal handler is free to manipulate @tooltip with the therefore destined function calls.
Whether this signal is emitted is platform-dependent. For plain text tooltips, use #GtkStatusIcon:tooltip-text in preference.
Since: 2.16

parameter.name: status_icon
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the cursor position where the request has been emitted, relative to @status_icon

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the cursor position where the request has been emitted, relative to @status_icon

parameter.name: keyboard_mode
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the tooltip was trigged using the keyboard

signal.return: %TRUE if @tooltip should be shown right now, %FALSE otherwise.

signal.name: GtkStatusIcon::scroll-event
signal.description:
The ::scroll-event signal is emitted when a button in the 4 to 7 range is pressed. Wheel mice are usually configured to generate button press events for buttons 4 and 5 when the wheel is turned.
Whether this event is emitted is platform-dependent.
Since: 2.16

parameter.name: status_icon
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkStatusIcon::size-changed
signal.description:
Gets emitted when the size available for the image changes, e.g. because the notification area got resized.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: status_icon
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE if the icon was updated for the new size. Otherwise, GTK+ will scale the icon as necessary.

signal.name: GtkStatusbar::text-popped
signal.description: Is emitted whenever a new message is popped off a statusbar's stack.

parameter.name: statusbar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: context_id
parameter.parameter_description: the context id of the relevant message/statusbar

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: the message that was just popped

signal.name: GtkStatusbar::text-pushed
signal.description: Is emitted whenever a new message gets pushed onto a statusbar's stack.

parameter.name: statusbar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: context_id
parameter.parameter_description: the context id of the relevant message/statusbar

signal.name: GtkStyle::group-changed
signal.description:
Emitted when the group of radio menu items that a radio menu item belongs to changes. This is emitted when a radio menu item switches from being alone to being part of a group of 2 or more menu items, or vice-versa, and when a button is moved from one group of 2 or more menu items ton a different one, but not when the composition of the group that a menu item belongs to changes.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: style
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkStyle::realize
signal.description:
Emitted when the style has been initialized for a particular visual. Connecting to this signal is probably seldom useful since most of the time applications and widgets only deal with styles that have been already realized.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: style
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkStyle::unrealize
signal.description:
Emitted when the aspects of the style specific to a particular visual is being cleaned up. A connection to this signal can be useful if a widget wants to cache objects as object data on #GtkStyle. This signal provides a convenient place to free such cached objects.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: style
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkSwitch::activate
signal.description: The ::activate signal on GtkSwitch is an action signal and emitting it causes the switch to animate. Applications should never connect to this signal, but use the notify::active signal.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

enum.name: GtkTargetFlags
enum.description: The #GtkTargetFlags enumeration is used to specify constraints on an entry in a #GtkTargetTable.

parameter.name: GTK_TARGET_SAME_APP
parameter.parameter_description: If this is set, the target will only be selected for drags within a single application.

parameter.name: GTK_TARGET_SAME_WIDGET
parameter.parameter_description: If this is set, the target will only be selected for drags within a single widget.

parameter.name: GTK_TARGET_OTHER_APP
parameter.parameter_description: If this is set, the target will not be selected for drags within a single application.

parameter.name: GTK_TARGET_OTHER_WIDGET
parameter.parameter_description: If this is set, the target will not be selected for drags withing a single widget.

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::apply-tag
signal.description:
The ::apply-tag signal is emitted to apply a tag to a range of text in a #GtkTextBuffer. Applying actually occurs in the default handler.
Note that if your handler runs before the default handler it must not invalidate the @start and @end iters (or has to revalidate them).
See also: gtk_text_buffer_apply_tag(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_with_tags(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_range().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: the start of the range the tag is applied to

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: the end of the range the tag is applied to

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::begin-user-action
signal.description:
The ::begin-user-action signal is emitted at the beginning of a single user-visible operation on a #GtkTextBuffer.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_begin_user_action(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_range_interactive(), gtk_text_buffer_delete_interactive(), gtk_text_buffer_backspace(), gtk_text_buffer_delete_selection().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::changed
signal.description: The ::changed signal is emitted when the content of a #GtkTextBuffer has changed.

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::delete-range
signal.description:
The ::delete-range signal is emitted to delete a range from a #GtkTextBuffer.
Note that if your handler runs before the default handler it must not invalidate the @start and @end iters (or has to revalidate them). The default signal handler revalidates the @start and @end iters to both point to the location where text was deleted. Handlers which run after the default handler (see g_signal_connect_after()) do not have access to the deleted text.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_delete().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: the start of the range to be deleted

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: the end of the range to be deleted

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::end-user-action
signal.description:
The ::end-user-action signal is emitted at the end of a single user-visible operation on the #GtkTextBuffer.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_end_user_action(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_range_interactive(), gtk_text_buffer_delete_interactive(), gtk_text_buffer_backspace(), gtk_text_buffer_delete_selection(), gtk_text_buffer_backspace().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::insert-child-anchor
signal.description:
The ::insert-child-anchor signal is emitted to insert a #GtkTextChildAnchor in a #GtkTextBuffer. Insertion actually occurs in the default handler.
Note that if your handler runs before the default handler it must not invalidate the @location iter (or has to revalidate it). The default signal handler revalidates it to be placed after the inserted @anchor.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_insert_child_anchor().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::insert-pixbuf
signal.description:
The ::insert-pixbuf signal is emitted to insert a #GdkPixbuf in a #GtkTextBuffer. Insertion actually occurs in the default handler.
Note that if your handler runs before the default handler it must not invalidate the @location iter (or has to revalidate it). The default signal handler revalidates it to be placed after the inserted @pixbuf.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_insert_pixbuf().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::insert-text
signal.description:
The ::insert-text signal is emitted to insert text in a #GtkTextBuffer. Insertion actually occurs in the default handler.
Note that if your handler runs before the default handler it must not invalidate the @location iter (or has to revalidate it). The default signal handler revalidates it to point to the end of the inserted text.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_insert(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_range().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: the UTF-8 text to be inserted

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: length of the inserted text in bytes

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::mark-deleted
signal.description:
The ::mark-deleted signal is emitted as notification after a #GtkTextMark is deleted.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_delete_mark().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::mark-set
signal.description:
The ::mark-set signal is emitted as notification after a #GtkTextMark is set.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_create_mark(), gtk_text_buffer_move_mark().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::modified-changed
signal.description:
The ::modified-changed signal is emitted when the modified bit of a #GtkTextBuffer flips.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_set_modified().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::paste-done
signal.description:
The paste-done signal is emitted after paste operation has been completed. This is useful to properly scroll the view to the end of the pasted text. See gtk_text_buffer_paste_clipboard() for more details.
Since: 2.16

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::remove-tag
signal.description:
The ::remove-tag signal is emitted to remove all occurrences of @tag from a range of text in a #GtkTextBuffer. Removal actually occurs in the default handler.
Note that if your handler runs before the default handler it must not invalidate the @start and @end iters (or has to revalidate them).
See also: gtk_text_buffer_remove_tag().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: the start of the range the tag is removed from

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: the end of the range the tag is removed from

enum.name: GtkTextSearchFlags
enum.description:
Flags affecting how a search is done.
If neither #GTK_TEXT_SEARCH_VISIBLE_ONLY nor #GTK_TEXT_SEARCH_TEXT_ONLY are enabled, the match must be exact; the special 0xFFFC character will match embedded pixbufs or child widgets.

parameter.name: GTK_TEXT_SEARCH_VISIBLE_ONLY
parameter.parameter_description: Search only visible data. A search match may have invisible text interspersed.

parameter.name: GTK_TEXT_SEARCH_TEXT_ONLY
parameter.parameter_description: Search only text. A match may have pixbufs or child widgets mixed inside the matched range.

parameter.name: GTK_TEXT_SEARCH_CASE_INSENSITIVE
parameter.parameter_description: The text will be matched regardless of what case it is in.

signal.name: GtkTextTag::event
signal.description: The ::event signal is emitted when an event occurs on a region of the buffer marked with this tag.

parameter.name: tag
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTextTag on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: object
parameter.parameter_description: the object the event was fired from (typically a #GtkTextView)

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: the event which triggered the signal

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkTextIter pointing at the location the event occured

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

parameter.name: texttagtable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: texttagtable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: size_changed
parameter.parameter_description: whether the size has been changed.

parameter.name: texttagtable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkTextView::backspace
signal.description:
The ::backspace signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
The default bindings for this signal are Backspace and Shift-Backspace.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::copy-clipboard
signal.description:
The ::copy-clipboard signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to copy the selection to the clipboard.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-c and Ctrl-Insert.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::cut-clipboard
signal.description:
The ::cut-clipboard signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to cut the selection to the clipboard.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-x and Shift-Delete.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::delete-from-cursor
signal.description:
The ::delete-from-cursor signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user initiates a text deletion.
If the @type is %GTK_DELETE_CHARS, GTK+ deletes the selection if there is one, otherwise it deletes the requested number of characters.
The default bindings for this signal are Delete for deleting a character, Ctrl-Delete for deleting a word and Ctrl-Backspace for deleting a word backwords.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: type
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the deletion, as a #GtkDeleteType

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @type units to delete

signal.name: GtkTextView::insert-at-cursor
signal.description:
The ::insert-at-cursor signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user initiates the insertion of a fixed string at the cursor.
This signal has no default bindings.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::move-cursor
signal.description:
The ::move-cursor signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user initiates a cursor movement. If the cursor is not visible in @text_view, this signal causes the viewport to be moved instead.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control the cursor programmatically.
The default bindings for this signal come in two variants, the variant with the Shift modifier extends the selection, the variant without the Shift modifer does not. There are too many key combinations to list them all here. <itemizedlist> <listitem>Arrow keys move by individual characters/lines</listitem> <listitem>Ctrl-arrow key combinations move by words/paragraphs</listitem> <listitem>Home/End keys move to the ends of the buffer</listitem> <listitem>PageUp/PageDown keys move vertically by pages</listitem> <listitem>Ctrl-PageUp/PageDown keys move horizontally by pages</listitem> </itemizedlist>

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: step
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the move, as a #GtkMovementStep

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @step units to move

parameter.name: extend_selection
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the move should extend the selection

signal.name: GtkTextView::move-viewport
signal.description:
The ::move-viewport signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which can be bound to key combinations to allow the user to move the viewport, i.e. change what part of the text view is visible in a containing scrolled window.
There are no default bindings for this signal.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: step
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the move, as a #GtkMovementStep

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @step units to move

signal.name: GtkTextView::paste-clipboard
signal.description:
The ::paste-clipboard signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to paste the contents of the clipboard into the text view.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-v and Shift-Insert.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::populate-popup
signal.description:
The ::populate-popup signal gets emitted before showing the context menu of the text view.
If you need to add items to the context menu, connect to this signal and append your items to the @popup, which will be a #GtkMenu in this case.
If #GtkTextView:populate-all is %TRUE, this signal will also be emitted to populate touch popups. In this case, @popup will be a different container, e.g. a #GtkToolbar.
The signal handler should not make assumptions about the type of @widget, but check whether @popup is a #GtkMenu or #GtkToolbar or another kind of container.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: The text view on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: popup
parameter.parameter_description: the container that is being populated

signal.name: GtkTextView::preedit-changed
signal.description:
If an input method is used, the typed text will not immediately be committed to the buffer. So if you are interested in the text, connect to this signal.
This signal is only emitted if the text at the given position is actually editable.
Since: 2.20

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::select-all
signal.description:
The ::select-all signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to select or unselect the complete contents of the text view.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-a and Ctrl-/ for selecting and Shift-Ctrl-a and Ctrl-\ for unselecting.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::set-anchor
signal.description:
The ::set-anchor signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user initiates setting the "anchor" mark. The "anchor" mark gets placed at the same position as the "insert" mark.
This signal has no default bindings.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::toggle-cursor-visible
signal.description:
The ::toggle-cursor-visible signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to toggle the visibility of the cursor.
The default binding for this signal is F7.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::toggle-overwrite
signal.description:
The ::toggle-overwrite signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted to toggle the overwrite mode of the text view.
The default bindings for this signal is Insert.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkToggleAction::toggled
signal.description:
Should be connected if you wish to perform an action whenever the #GtkToggleAction state is changed.
Deprecated: 3.10

parameter.name: toggleaction
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkToggleButton::toggled
signal.description: Should be connected if you wish to perform an action whenever the #GtkToggleButton's state is changed.

parameter.name: togglebutton
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkToggleToolButton::toggled
signal.description: Emitted whenever the toggle tool button changes state.

parameter.name: toggle_tool_button
parameter.parameter_description: the object that emitted the signal

signal.name: GtkToolButton::clicked
signal.description: This signal is emitted when the tool button is clicked with the mouse or activated with the keyboard.

parameter.name: toolbutton
parameter.parameter_description: the object that emitted the signal

signal.name: GtkToolItem::create-menu-proxy
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when the toolbar needs information from @tool_item about whether the item should appear in the toolbar overflow menu. In response the tool item should either <itemizedlist> <listitem>call gtk_tool_item_set_proxy_menu_item() with a %NULL pointer and return %TRUE to indicate that the item should not appear in the overflow menu </listitem> <listitem> call gtk_tool_item_set_proxy_menu_item() with a new menu item and return %TRUE, or </listitem> <listitem> return %FALSE to indicate that the signal was not handled by the item. This means that the item will not appear in the overflow menu unless a later handler installs a menu item. </listitem> </itemizedlist>
The toolbar may cache the result of this signal. When the tool item changes how it will respond to this signal it must call gtk_tool_item_rebuild_menu() to invalidate the cache and ensure that the toolbar rebuilds its overflow menu.

parameter.name: tool_item
parameter.parameter_description: the object the signal was emitted on

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal was handled, %FALSE if not

signal.name: GtkToolItem::toolbar-reconfigured
signal.description: This signal is emitted when some property of the toolbar that the item is a child of changes. For custom subclasses of #GtkToolItem, the default handler of this signal use the functions <itemizedlist> <listitem>gtk_tool_shell_get_orientation()</listitem> <listitem>gtk_tool_shell_get_style()</listitem> <listitem>gtk_tool_shell_get_icon_size()</listitem> <listitem>gtk_tool_shell_get_relief_style()</listitem> </itemizedlist> to find out what the toolbar should look like and change themselves accordingly.

parameter.name: tool_item
parameter.parameter_description: the object the signal was emitted on

enum.name: GtkToolPaletteDragTargets
enum.description: Flags used to specify the supported drag targets.

signal.name: GtkToolbar::focus-home-or-end
signal.description: A keybinding signal used internally by GTK+. This signal can't be used in application code

parameter.name: focus_home
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the first item should be focused

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal was handled, %FALSE if not

signal.name: GtkToolbar::orientation-changed
signal.description: Emitted when the orientation of the toolbar changes.

parameter.name: toolbar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which emitted the signal

signal.name: GtkToolbar::popup-context-menu
signal.description:
Emitted when the user right-clicks the toolbar or uses the keybinding to display a popup menu.
Application developers should handle this signal if they want to display a context menu on the toolbar. The context-menu should appear at the coordinates given by @x and @y. The mouse button number is given by the @button parameter. If the menu was popped up using the keybaord, @button is -1.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the point where the menu should appear

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the point where the menu should appear

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the mouse button the user pressed, or -1

signal.return: return %TRUE if the signal was handled, %FALSE if not

signal.name: GtkToolbar::style-changed
signal.description: Emitted when the style of the toolbar changes.

enum.name: GtkToolbarStyle
enum.description: Used to customize the appearance of a #GtkToolbar. Note that setting the toolbar style overrides the user's preferences for the default toolbar style. Note that if the button has only a label set and GTK_TOOLBAR_ICONS is used, the label will be visible, and vice versa.

parameter.name: GTK_TOOLBAR_ICONS
parameter.parameter_description: Buttons display only icons in the toolbar.

parameter.name: GTK_TOOLBAR_TEXT
parameter.parameter_description: Buttons display only text labels in the toolbar.

parameter.name: GTK_TOOLBAR_BOTH
parameter.parameter_description: Buttons display text and icons in the toolbar.

parameter.name: GTK_TOOLBAR_BOTH_HORIZ
parameter.parameter_description: Buttons display icons and text alongside each other, rather than vertically stacked

signal.name: GtkTreeModel::row-changed
signal.description: This signal is emitted when a row in the model has changed.

parameter.name: tree_model
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeModel on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a valid #GtkTreeIter pointing to the changed row

signal.name: GtkTreeModel::row-deleted
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when a row has been deleted.
Note that no iterator is passed to the signal handler, since the row is already deleted.
This should be called by models after a row has been removed. The location pointed to by @path should be the location that the row previously was at. It may not be a valid location anymore.

parameter.name: tree_model
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeModel on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkTreeModel::row-has-child-toggled
signal.description: This signal is emitted when a row has gotten the first child row or lost its last child row.

parameter.name: tree_model
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeModel on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a valid #GtkTreeIter pointing to the row

signal.name: GtkTreeModel::row-inserted
signal.description:
