This signal is emitted when a new row has been inserted in the model.
Note that the row may still be empty at this point, since it is a common pattern to first insert an empty row, and then fill it with the desired values.

parameter.name: tree_model
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeModel on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a valid #GtkTreeIter pointing to the new row

signal.name: GtkTreeModel::rows-reordered
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when the children of a node in the #GtkTreeModel have been reordered.
Note that this signal is <emphasis>not</emphasis> emitted when rows are reordered by DND, since this is implemented by removing and then reinserting the row.

parameter.name: tree_model
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeModel on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkTreePath identifying the tree node whose children have been reordered

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a valid #GtkTreeIter pointing to the node whose

parameter.name: new_order
parameter.parameter_description: an array of integers mapping the current position of each child to its old position before the re-ordering, i.e. @new_order<literal>[newpos] = oldpos</literal>

enum.name: GtkTreeModelFlags
enum.description:
These flags indicate various properties of a #GtkTreeModel.
They are returned by gtk_tree_model_get_flags(), and must be static for the lifetime of the object. A more complete description of #GTK_TREE_MODEL_ITERS_PERSIST can be found in the overview of this section.

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_MODEL_ITERS_PERSIST
parameter.parameter_description: iterators survive all signals emitted by the tree

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_MODEL_LIST_ONLY
parameter.parameter_description: the model is a list only, and never has children

signal.name: GtkTreeSelection::changed
signal.description: Emitted whenever the selection has (possibly) changed. Please note that this signal is mostly a hint. It may only be emitted once when a range of rows are selected, and it may occasionally be emitted when nothing has happened.

parameter.name: treeselection
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkTreeSortable::sort-column-changed
signal.description: The ::sort-column-changed signal is emitted when the sort column or sort order of @sortable is changed. The signal is emitted before the contents of @sortable are resorted.

parameter.name: sortable
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkTreeView::columns-changed
signal.description: The number of columns of the treeview has changed.

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkTreeView::cursor-changed
signal.description: The position of the cursor (focused cell) has changed.

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkTreeView::row-activated
signal.description:
The "row-activated" signal is emitted when the method gtk_tree_view_row_activated() is called, when the user double clicks a treeview row with the "activate-on-single-click" property set to %FALSE, or when the user single clicks a row when the "activate-on-single-click" property set to %TRUE. It is also emitted when a non-editable row is selected and one of the keys: Space, Shift+Space, Return or Enter is pressed.
For selection handling refer to the <link linkend="TreeWidget">tree widget conceptual overview</link> as well as #GtkTreeSelection.

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: column
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeViewColumn in which the activation occurred

signal.name: GtkTreeView::row-collapsed
signal.description: The given row has been collapsed (child nodes are hidden).

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: the tree iter of the collapsed row

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a tree path that points to the row

signal.name: GtkTreeView::row-expanded
signal.description: The given row has been expanded (child nodes are shown).

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: the tree iter of the expanded row

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a tree path that points to the row

signal.name: GtkTreeView::test-collapse-row
signal.description: The given row is about to be collapsed (hide its children nodes). Use this signal if you need to control the collapsibility of individual rows.

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: the tree iter of the row to collapse

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a tree path that points to the row

signal.return: %FALSE to allow collapsing, %TRUE to reject

signal.name: GtkTreeView::test-expand-row
signal.description: The given row is about to be expanded (show its children nodes). Use this signal if you need to control the expandability of individual rows.

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: the tree iter of the row to expand

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a tree path that points to the row

signal.return: %FALSE to allow expansion, %TRUE to reject

enum.name: GtkTreeViewColumnSizing
enum.description: The sizing method the column uses to determine its width. Please note that @GTK_TREE_VIEW_COLUMN_AUTOSIZE are inefficient for large views, and can make columns appear choppy.

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_VIEW_COLUMN_GROW_ONLY
parameter.parameter_description: Columns only get bigger in reaction to changes in the model

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_VIEW_COLUMN_AUTOSIZE
parameter.parameter_description: Columns resize to be the optimal size everytime the model changes.

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_VIEW_COLUMN_FIXED
parameter.parameter_description: Columns are a fixed numbers of pixels wide.

enum.name: GtkTreeViewDropPosition
enum.description: An enum for determining where a dropped row goes.

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_VIEW_DROP_INTO_OR_BEFORE
parameter.parameter_description: dropped row becomes a child or is inserted before

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_VIEW_DROP_INTO_OR_AFTER
parameter.parameter_description: dropped row becomes a child or is inserted after

enum.name: GtkTreeViewGridLines
enum.description: Used to indicate which grid lines to draw in a tree view.

signal.name: GtkUIManager::actions-changed
signal.description:
The ::actions-changed signal is emitted whenever the set of actions changes.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

signal.name: GtkUIManager::add-widget
signal.description:
The ::add-widget signal is emitted for each generated menubar and toolbar. It is not emitted for generated popup menus, which can be obtained by gtk_ui_manager_get_widget().
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

signal.name: GtkUIManager::connect-proxy
signal.description:
The ::connect-proxy signal is emitted after connecting a proxy to an action in the group.
This is intended for simple customizations for which a custom action class would be too clumsy, e.g. showing tooltips for menuitems in the statusbar.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

signal.name: GtkUIManager::disconnect-proxy
signal.description:
The ::disconnect-proxy signal is emitted after disconnecting a proxy from an action in the group.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

signal.name: GtkUIManager::post-activate
signal.description:
The ::post-activate signal is emitted just after the @action is activated.
This is intended for applications to get notification just after any action is activated.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

signal.name: GtkUIManager::pre-activate
signal.description:
The ::pre-activate signal is emitted just before the @action is activated.
This is intended for applications to get notification just before any action is activated.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

enum.name: GtkUIManagerItemType
enum.description:
These enumeration values are used by gtk_ui_manager_add_ui() to determine what UI element to create.
Deprecated: 3.10

parameter.name: GTK_UI_MANAGER_AUTO
parameter.parameter_description: Pick the type of the UI element according to context.

parameter.name: GTK_UI_MANAGER_POPUP_WITH_ACCELS
parameter.parameter_description: Same as %GTK_UI_MANAGER_POPUP, but the actions' accelerators are shown.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::button-press-event
signal.description:
The ::button-press-event signal will be emitted when a button (typically from a mouse) is pressed.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_BUTTON_PRESS_MASK mask.
This signal will be sent to the grab widget if there is one.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::button-release-event
signal.description:
The ::button-release-event signal will be emitted when a button (typically from a mouse) is released.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_BUTTON_RELEASE_MASK mask.
This signal will be sent to the grab widget if there is one.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::can-activate-accel
signal.description: Determines whether an accelerator that activates the signal identified by @signal_id can currently be activated. This signal is present to allow applications and derived widgets to override the default #GtkWidget handling for determining whether an accelerator can be activated.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: signal_id
parameter.parameter_description: the ID of a signal installed on @widget

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal can be activated.

signal.name: GtkWidget::child-notify
signal.description: The ::child-notify signal is emitted for each <link linkend="child-properties">child property</link> that has changed on an object. The signal's detail holds the property name.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: child_property
parameter.parameter_description: the #GParamSpec of the changed child property

signal.name: GtkWidget::composited-changed
signal.description: The ::composited-changed signal is emitted when the composited status of @widget<!-- -->s screen changes. See gdk_screen_is_composited().

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkWidget::configure-event
signal.description:
The ::configure-event signal will be emitted when the size, position or stacking of the @widget's window has changed.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_STRUCTURE_MASK mask. GDK will enable this mask automatically for all new windows.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::damage-event
signal.description:
Emitted when a redirected window belonging to @widget gets drawn into. The region/area members of the event shows what area of the redirected drawable was drawn into.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::delete-event
signal.description: The ::delete-event signal is emitted if a user requests that a toplevel window is closed. The default handler for this signal destroys the window. Connecting gtk_widget_hide_on_delete() to this signal will cause the window to be hidden instead, so that it can later be shown again without reconstructing it.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: the event which triggered this signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::destroy
signal.description: Signals that all holders of a reference to the widget should release the reference that they hold. May result in finalization of the widget if all references are released.

parameter.name: object
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkWidget::destroy-event
signal.description:
The ::destroy-event signal is emitted when a #GdkWindow is destroyed. You rarely get this signal, because most widgets disconnect themselves from their window before they destroy it, so no widget owns the window at destroy time.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_STRUCTURE_MASK mask. GDK will enable this mask automatically for all new windows.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: the event which triggered this signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::direction-changed
signal.description: The ::direction-changed signal is emitted when the text direction of a widget changes.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkWidget::drag-begin
signal.description:
The ::drag-begin signal is emitted on the drag source when a drag is started. A typical reason to connect to this signal is to set up a custom drag icon with e.g. gtk_drag_source_set_icon_pixbuf().
Note that some widgets set up a drag icon in the default handler of this signal, so you may have to use g_signal_connect_after() to override what the default handler did.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkWidget::drag-data-delete
signal.description: The ::drag-data-delete signal is emitted on the drag source when a drag with the action %GDK_ACTION_MOVE is successfully completed. The signal handler is responsible for deleting the data that has been dropped. What "delete" means depends on the context of the drag operation.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkWidget::drag-data-get
signal.description: The ::drag-data-get signal is emitted on the drag source when the drop site requests the data which is dragged. It is the responsibility of the signal handler to fill @data with the data in the format which is indicated by @info. See gtk_selection_data_set() and gtk_selection_data_set_text().

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkSelectionData to be filled with the dragged data

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: the info that has been registered with the target in the #GtkTargetList

parameter.name: time
parameter.parameter_description: the timestamp at which the data was requested

signal.name: GtkWidget::drag-data-received

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: the info that has been registered with the target in the #GtkTargetList

parameter.name: time
parameter.parameter_description: the timestamp at which the data was received

signal.name: GtkWidget::drag-drop
signal.description: The ::drag-drop signal is emitted on the drop site when the user drops the data onto the widget. The signal handler must determine whether the cursor position is in a drop zone or not. If it is not in a drop zone, it returns %FALSE and no further processing is necessary. Otherwise, the handler returns %TRUE. In this case, the handler must ensure that gtk_drag_finish() is called to let the source know that the drop is done. The call to gtk_drag_finish() can be done either directly or in a #GtkWidget::drag-data-received handler which gets triggered by calling gtk_drag_get_data() to receive the data for one or more of the supported targets.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current cursor position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current cursor position

parameter.name: time
parameter.parameter_description: the timestamp of the motion event

signal.return: whether the cursor position is in a drop zone

signal.name: GtkWidget::drag-end
signal.description: The ::drag-end signal is emitted on the drag source when a drag is finished. A typical reason to connect to this signal is to undo things done in #GtkWidget::drag-begin.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkWidget::drag-failed
signal.description:
The ::drag-failed signal is emitted on the drag source when a drag has failed. The signal handler may hook custom code to handle a failed DND operation based on the type of error, it returns %TRUE is the failure has been already handled (not showing the default "drag operation failed" animation), otherwise it returns %FALSE.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: result
parameter.parameter_description: the result of the drag operation

signal.return: %TRUE if the failed drag operation has been already handled.

signal.name: GtkWidget::drag-leave
signal.description: The ::drag-leave signal is emitted on the drop site when the cursor leaves the widget. A typical reason to connect to this signal is to undo things done in #GtkWidget::drag-motion, e.g. undo highlighting with gtk_drag_unhighlight()

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: time
parameter.parameter_description: the timestamp of the motion event

signal.name: GtkWidget::drag-motion

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current cursor position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current cursor position

parameter.name: time
parameter.parameter_description: the timestamp of the motion event

signal.return: whether the cursor position is in a drop zone

signal.name: GtkWidget::draw
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when a widget is supposed to render itself. The @widget's top left corner must be painted at the origin of the passed in context and be sized to the values returned by gtk_widget_get_allocated_width() and gtk_widget_get_allocated_height().
Signal handlers connected to this signal can modify the cairo context passed as @cr in any way they like and don't need to restore it. The signal emission takes care of calling cairo_save() before and cairo_restore() after invoking the handler.
The signal handler will get a @cr with a clip region already set to the widget's dirty region, i.e. to the area that needs repainting. Complicated widgets that want to avoid redrawing themselves completely can get the full extents of the clip region with gdk_cairo_get_clip_rectangle(), or they can get a finer-grained representation of the dirty region with cairo_copy_clip_rectangle_list().
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: cr
parameter.parameter_description: the cairo context to draw to

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. % %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::enter-notify-event
signal.description:
The ::enter-notify-event will be emitted when the pointer enters the @widget's window.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_ENTER_NOTIFY_MASK mask.
This signal will be sent to the grab widget if there is one.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::event
signal.description: The GTK+ main loop will emit three signals for each GDK event delivered to a widget: one generic ::event signal, another, more specific, signal that matches the type of event delivered (e.g. #GtkWidget::key-press-event) and finally a generic #GtkWidget::event-after signal.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event and to cancel the emission of the second specific ::event signal. %FALSE to propagate the event further and to allow the emission of the second signal. The ::event-after signal is emitted regardless of the return value.

signal.name: GtkWidget::event-after
signal.description: After the emission of the #GtkWidget::event signal and (optionally) the second more specific signal, ::event-after will be emitted regardless of the previous two signals handlers return values.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::focus

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::focus-in-event
signal.description:
The ::focus-in-event signal will be emitted when the keyboard focus enters the @widget's window.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_FOCUS_CHANGE_MASK mask.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::focus-out-event
signal.description:
The ::focus-out-event signal will be emitted when the keyboard focus leaves the @widget's window.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_FOCUS_CHANGE_MASK mask.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::grab-broken-event
signal.description:
Emitted when a pointer or keyboard grab on a window belonging to @widget gets broken.
On X11, this happens when the grab window becomes unviewable (i.e. it or one of its ancestors is unmapped), or if the same application grabs the pointer or keyboard again.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::grab-notify
signal.description:
The ::grab-notify signal is emitted when a widget becomes shadowed by a GTK+ grab (not a pointer or keyboard grab) on another widget, or when it becomes unshadowed due to a grab being removed.
A widget is shadowed by a gtk_grab_add() when the topmost grab widget in the grab stack of its window group is not its ancestor.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: was_grabbed
parameter.parameter_description: %FALSE if the widget becomes shadowed, %TRUE if it becomes unshadowed

signal.name: GtkWidget::hide
signal.description: The ::hide signal is emitted when @widget is hidden, for example with gtk_widget_hide().

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::hierarchy-changed
signal.description: The ::hierarchy-changed signal is emitted when the anchored state of a widget changes. A widget is <firstterm>anchored</firstterm> when its toplevel ancestor is a #GtkWindow. This signal is emitted when a widget changes from un-anchored to anchored or vice-versa.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: previous_toplevel
parameter.parameter_description: the previous toplevel ancestor, or %NULL if the widget was previously unanchored

signal.name: GtkWidget::key-press-event
signal.description:
The ::key-press-event signal is emitted when a key is pressed. The signal emission will reoccur at the key-repeat rate when the key is kept pressed.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_KEY_PRESS_MASK mask.
This signal will be sent to the grab widget if there is one.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::key-release-event
signal.description:
The ::key-release-event signal is emitted when a key is released.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_KEY_RELEASE_MASK mask.
This signal will be sent to the grab widget if there is one.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::keynav-failed
signal.description:
Gets emitted if keyboard navigation fails. See gtk_widget_keynav_failed() for details.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE if stopping keyboard navigation is fine, %FALSE if the emitting widget should try to handle the keyboard navigation attempt in its parent container(s).

signal.name: GtkWidget::leave-notify-event
signal.description:
The ::leave-notify-event will be emitted when the pointer leaves the @widget's window.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_LEAVE_NOTIFY_MASK mask.
This signal will be sent to the grab widget if there is one.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::map
signal.description:
The ::map signal is emitted when @widget is going to be mapped, that is when the widget is visible (which is controlled with gtk_widget_set_visible()) and all its parents up to the toplevel widget are also visible. Once the map has occurred, #GtkWidget::map-event will be emitted.
The ::map signal can be used to determine whether a widget will be drawn, for instance it can resume an animation that was stopped during the emission of #GtkWidget::unmap.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::map-event
signal.description:
The ::map-event signal will be emitted when the @widget's window is mapped. A window is mapped when it becomes visible on the screen.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_STRUCTURE_MASK mask. GDK will enable this mask automatically for all new windows.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::mnemonic-activate

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::motion-notify-event
signal.description:
The ::motion-notify-event signal is emitted when the pointer moves over the widget's #GdkWindow.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_POINTER_MOTION_MASK mask.
This signal will be sent to the grab widget if there is one.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::parent-set
signal.description: The ::parent-set signal is emitted when a new parent has been set on a widget.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: old_parent
parameter.parameter_description: the previous parent, or %NULL if the widget just got its initial parent.

signal.name: GtkWidget::popup-menu
signal.description: This signal gets emitted whenever a widget should pop up a context menu. This usually happens through the standard key binding mechanism; by pressing a certain key while a widget is focused, the user can cause the widget to pop up a menu. For example, the #GtkEntry widget creates a menu with clipboard commands. See <xref linkend="checklist-popup-menu"/> for an example of how to use this signal.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE if a menu was activated

signal.name: GtkWidget::property-notify-event
signal.description:
The ::property-notify-event signal will be emitted when a property on the @widget's window has been changed or deleted.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_PROPERTY_CHANGE_MASK mask.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::proximity-in-event
signal.description:
To receive this signal the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_PROXIMITY_IN_MASK mask.
This signal will be sent to the grab widget if there is one.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::proximity-out-event
signal.description:
To receive this signal the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_PROXIMITY_OUT_MASK mask.
This signal will be sent to the grab widget if there is one.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::query-tooltip
signal.description:
Emitted when #GtkWidget:has-tooltip is %TRUE and the hover timeout has expired with the cursor hovering "above" @widget; or emitted when @widget got focus in keyboard mode.
Using the given coordinates, the signal handler should determine whether a tooltip should be shown for @widget. If this is the case %TRUE should be returned, %FALSE otherwise. Note that if @keyboard_mode is %TRUE, the values of @x and @y are undefined and should not be used.
The signal handler is free to manipulate @tooltip with the therefore destined function calls.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the cursor position where the request has been emitted, relative to @widget's left side

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the cursor position where the request has been emitted, relative to @widget's top

parameter.name: keyboard_mode
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the tooltip was trigged using the keyboard

signal.return: %TRUE if @tooltip should be shown right now, %FALSE otherwise.

signal.name: GtkWidget::realize
signal.description: The ::realize signal is emitted when @widget is associated with a #GdkWindow, which means that gtk_wiget_realize() has been called or the widget has been mapped (that is, it is going to be drawn).

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::screen-changed
signal.description: The ::screen-changed signal gets emitted when the screen of a widget has changed.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: previous_screen
parameter.parameter_description: the previous screen, or %NULL if the widget was not associated with a screen before

signal.name: GtkWidget::scroll-event
signal.description:
The ::scroll-event signal is emitted when a button in the 4 to 7 range is pressed. Wheel mice are usually configured to generate button press events for buttons 4 and 5 when the wheel is turned.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_SCROLL_MASK mask.
This signal will be sent to the grab widget if there is one.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::selection-clear-event
signal.description: The ::selection-clear-event signal will be emitted when the the @widget's window has lost ownership of a selection.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::selection-notify-event

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::selection-request-event
signal.description: The ::selection-request-event signal will be emitted when another client requests ownership of the selection owned by the @widget's window.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::show
signal.description: The ::show signal is emitted when @widget is shown, for example with gtk_widget_show().

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::show-help

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::state-changed
signal.description:
The ::state-changed signal is emitted when the widget state changes. See gtk_widget_get_state().
Deprecated: 3.0. Use #GtkWidget::state-flags-changed instead.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::state-flags-changed
signal.description:
The ::state-flags-changed signal is emitted when the widget state changes, see gtk_widget_get_state_flags().
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::style-set
signal.description:
The ::style-set signal is emitted when a new style has been set on a widget. Note that style-modifying functions like gtk_widget_modify_base() also cause this signal to be emitted.
Note that this signal is emitted for changes to the deprecated #GtkStyle. To track changes to the #GtkStyleContext associated with a widget, use the #GtkWidget::style-updated signal.
Deprecated:3.0: Use the #GtkWidget::style-updated signal

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: previous_style
parameter.parameter_description: the previous style, or %NULL if the widget just got its initial style

signal.name: GtkWidget::style-updated
signal.description:
The ::style-updated signal is emitted when the #GtkStyleContext of a widget is changed. Note that style-modifying functions like gtk_widget_override_color() also cause this signal to be emitted.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkWidget::unmap
signal.description:
The ::unmap signal is emitted when @widget is going to be unmapped, which means that either it or any of its parents up to the toplevel widget have been set as hidden.
As ::unmap indicates that a widget will not be shown any longer, it can be used to, for example, stop an animation on the widget.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::unmap-event
signal.description:
The ::unmap-event signal will be emitted when the @widget's window is unmapped. A window is unmapped when it becomes invisible on the screen.
To receive this signal, the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_STRUCTURE_MASK mask. GDK will enable this mask automatically for all new windows.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::unrealize
signal.description: The ::unrealize signal is emitted when the #GdkWindow associated with @widget is destroyed, which means that gtk_widget_unrealize() has been called or the widget has been unmapped (that is, it is going to be hidden).

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkWidget::visibility-notify-event
signal.description:
The ::visibility-notify-event will be emitted when the @widget's window is obscured or unobscured.
To receive this signal the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_VISIBILITY_NOTIFY_MASK mask.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWidget::window-state-event
signal.description:
The ::window-state-event will be emitted when the state of the toplevel window associated to the @widget changes.
To receive this signal the #GdkWindow associated to the widget needs to enable the #GDK_STRUCTURE_MASK mask. GDK will enable this mask automatically for all new windows.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkWindow::activate-default
signal.description: The ::activate-default signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user activates the default widget of @window.

parameter.name: window
parameter.parameter_description: the window which received the signal

signal.name: GtkWindow::activate-focus
signal.description: The ::activate-focus signal is a <link linkend="keybinding-signals">keybinding signal</link> which gets emitted when the user activates the currently focused widget of @window.

parameter.name: window
parameter.parameter_description: the window which received the signal

signal.name: GtkWindow::keys-changed
signal.description: The ::keys-changed signal gets emitted when the set of accelerators or mnemonics that are associated with @window changes.

parameter.name: window
parameter.parameter_description: the window which received the signal

enum.name: GtkWindowPosition
enum.description: Window placement can be influenced using this enumeration. Note that using #GTK_WIN_POS_CENTER_ALWAYS is almost always a bad idea. It won't necessarily work well with all window managers or on all windowing systems.

parameter.name: GTK_WIN_POS_NONE
parameter.parameter_description: No influence is made on placement.

parameter.name: GTK_WIN_POS_CENTER
parameter.parameter_description: Windows should be placed in the center of the screen.

parameter.name: GTK_WIN_POS_MOUSE
parameter.parameter_description: Windows should be placed at the current mouse position.

parameter.name: GTK_WIN_POS_CENTER_ALWAYS
parameter.parameter_description: Keep window centered as it changes size, etc.

parameter.name: GTK_WIN_POS_CENTER_ON_PARENT
parameter.parameter_description: Center the window on its transient parent (see gtk_window_set_transient_for()).

enum.name: GtkWindowType
enum.description: A #GtkWindow can be one of these types. Most things you'd consider a "window" should have type #GTK_WINDOW_TOPLEVEL; windows with this type are managed by the window manager and have a frame by default (call gtk_window_set_decorated() to toggle the frame). Windows with type #GTK_WINDOW_POPUP are ignored by the window manager; window manager keybindings won't work on them, the window manager won't decorate the window with a frame, many GTK+ features that rely on the window manager will not work (e.g. resize grips and maximization/minimization). #GTK_WINDOW_POPUP is used to implement widgets such as #GtkMenu or tooltips that you normally don't think of as windows per se. Nearly all windows should be #GTK_WINDOW_TOPLEVEL. In particular, do not use #GTK_WINDOW_POPUP just to turn off the window borders; use gtk_window_set_decorated() for that.

parameter.name: GTK_WINDOW_TOPLEVEL
parameter.parameter_description: A regular window, such as a dialog.

parameter.name: GTK_WINDOW_POPUP
parameter.parameter_description: A special window such as a tooltip.

enum.name: GtkWrapMode
enum.description: Describes a type of line wrapping.

parameter.name: GTK_WRAP_NONE
parameter.parameter_description: do not wrap lines; just make the text area wider

parameter.name: GTK_WRAP_CHAR
parameter.parameter_description: wrap text, breaking lines anywhere the cursor can appear (between characters, usually - if you want to be technical, between graphemes, see pango_get_log_attrs())

parameter.name: GTK_WRAP_WORD
parameter.parameter_description: wrap text, breaking lines in between words

parameter.name: GTK_WRAP_WORD_CHAR
parameter.parameter_description: wrap text, breaking lines in between words, or if that is not enough, also between graphemes

function.name: add_file
function.description: Adds the given @file with its associated @info to the @model. If the model is frozen, the file will only show up after it is thawn.

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: the information to associate with the file

function.name: freeze_updates
function.description: Freezes most updates on the model, so that performing multiple operations on the files in the model do not cause any events. Use thaw_updates() to resume proper operations. It is fine to call this function multiple times as long as freeze and thaw calls are balanced.

function.name: gtk_about_dialog_add_credit_section

Returns the copyright string.

function.description:
Returns the string which are displayed in the documenters tab of the secondary credits dialog.

Returns the version string.

Returns the website URL.

Returns whether the license text in @about is automatically wrapped.

Creates a new #GtkAboutDialog.

function.name: gtk_about_dialog_set_artists
function.description:
Sets the strings which are displayed in the artists tab of the secondary credits dialog.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_about_dialog_set_authors
function.description:
Sets the strings which are displayed in the authors tab of the secondary credits dialog.
Since: 2.6

function.description:
Sets the comments string to display in the about dialog. This should be a short string of one or two lines.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_about_dialog_set_copyright
function.description:
Sets the copyright string to display in the about dialog. This should be a short string of one or two lines.
Since: 2.6

Sets the strings which are displayed in the documenters tab of the secondary credits dialog.

function.name: gtk_about_dialog_set_license_type
