function.name: gtk_application_add_accelerator

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the action to activate

parameter.name: parameter
parameter.parameter_description: parameter to pass when activating the action, or %NULL if the action does not accept an activation parameter

function.name: gtk_application_add_window
function.description:
Adds a window to @application.
This call is equivalent to setting the #GtkWindow:application property of @window to @application.
Normally, the connection between the application and the window will remain until the window is destroyed, but you can explicitly remove it with gtk_application_remove_window().
GTK+ will keep the application running as long as it has any windows.
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_application_get_active_window
function.description:
Gets the "active" window for the application.
The active window is the one that was most recently focused (within the application). This window may not have the focus at the moment if another application has it -- this is just the most recently-focused window within this application.
Since: 3.6
function.return: the active window

function.name: gtk_application_get_app_menu
function.description:
Returns the menu model that has been set with gtk_application_set_app_menu().
Since: 3.4
function.return: the application menu of @application

function.name: gtk_application_get_menubar
function.description:
Returns the menu model that has been set with gtk_application_set_menubar().
Since: 3.4
function.return: the menubar for windows of @application

function.name: gtk_application_get_window_by_id
function.description:
Returns the #GtkApplicationWindow with the given ID.
Since: 3.6
function.return: the window with ID @id, or %NULL if there is no window with this ID

function.name: gtk_application_get_windows
function.description:
Gets a list of the #GtkWindows associated with @application.
The list is sorted by most recently focused window, such that the first element is the currently focused window. (Useful for choosing a parent for a transient window.)
The list that is returned should not be modified in any way. It will only remain valid until the next focus change or window creation or deletion.
Since: 3.0
function.return: a #GList of #GtkWindow

function.name: gtk_application_inhibit
function.description:
Inform the session manager that certain types of actions should be inhibited. This is not guaranteed to work on all platforms and for all types of actions.
Applications should invoke this method when they begin an operation that should not be interrupted, such as creating a CD or DVD. The types of actions that may be blocked are specified by the @flags parameter. When the application completes the operation it should call gtk_application_uninhibit() to remove the inhibitor. Note that an application can have multiple inhibitors, and all of the must be individually removed. Inhibitors are also cleared when the application exits.
Applications should not expect that they will always be able to block the action. In most cases, users will be given the option to force the action to take place.
Reasons should be short and to the point.
If @window is given, the session manager may point the user to this window to find out more about why the action is inhibited.
Since: 3.4

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: what types of actions should be inhibited

parameter.name: reason
parameter.parameter_description: a short, human-readable string that explains why these operations are inhibited

function.return: A non-zero cookie that is used to uniquely identify this request. It should be used as an argument to gtk_application_uninhibit() in order to remove the request. If the platform does not support inhibiting or the request failed for some reason, 0 is returned.

function.name: gtk_application_is_inhibited
function.description:
Determines if any of the actions specified in @flags are currently inhibited (possibly by another application).
Since: 3.4

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: what types of actions should be queried

function.return: %TRUE if any of the actions specified in @flags are inhibited

function.name: gtk_application_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkApplication instance.
When using #GtkApplication, it is not necessary to call gtk_init() manually. It is called as soon as the application gets registered as the primary instance.
Concretely, gtk_init() is called in the default handler for the #GApplication::startup signal. Therefore, #GtkApplication subclasses should chain up in their #GApplication:startup handler before using any GTK+ API.
Note that commandline arguments are not passed to gtk_init(). All GTK+ functionality that is available via commandline arguments can also be achieved by setting suitable environment variables such as <envar>G_DEBUG</envar>, so this should not be a big problem. If you absolutely must support GTK+ commandline arguments, you can explicitly call gtk_init() before creating the application instance.
If non-%NULL, the application ID must be valid. See g_application_id_is_valid().
If no application ID is given then some features (most notably application uniqueness) will be disabled. A null application ID is only allowed with GTK+ 3.6 or later.
Since: 3.0
function.return: a new #GtkApplication instance

function.name: gtk_application_remove_accelerator
function.description:
Removes an accelerator that has been previously added with gtk_application_add_accelerator().
Since: 3.4

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the action to activate

parameter.name: parameter
parameter.parameter_description: parameter to pass when activating the action, or %NULL if the action does not accept an activation parameter

function.name: gtk_application_remove_window
function.description:
Remove a window from @application.
If @window belongs to @application then this call is equivalent to setting the #GtkWindow:application property of @window to %NULL.
The application may stop running as a result of a call to this function.
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_application_set_app_menu
function.description:
Sets or unsets the application menu for @application.
This can only be done in the primary instance of the application, after it has been registered. #GApplication:startup is a good place to call this.
The application menu is a single menu containing items that typically impact the application as a whole, rather than acting on a specific window or document. For example, you would expect to see "Preferences" or "Quit" in an application menu, but not "Save" or "Print".
If supported, the application menu will be rendered by the desktop environment.
Use the base #GActionMap interface to add actions, to respond to the user selecting these menu items.
Since: 3.4

function.name: gtk_application_set_menubar
function.description:
Sets or unsets the menubar for windows of @application.
This is a menubar in the traditional sense.
This can only be done in the primary instance of the application, after it has been registered. #GApplication:startup is a good place to call this.
Depending on the desktop environment, this may appear at the top of each window, or at the top of the screen. In some environments, if both the application menu and the menubar are set, the application menu will be presented as if it were the first item of the menubar. Other environments treat the two as completely separate -- for example, the application menu may be rendered by the desktop shell while the menubar (if set) remains in each individual window.
Use the base #GActionMap interface to add actions, to respond to the user selecting these menu items.
Since: 3.4

function.name: gtk_application_uninhibit
function.description:
Removes an inhibitor that has been established with gtk_application_inhibit(). Inhibitors are also cleared when the application exits.
Since: 3.4

parameter.name: cookie
parameter.parameter_description: a cookie that was returned by gtk_application_inhibit()

function.name: gtk_application_window_get_id
function.description:
Returns the unique ID of the window. If the window has not yet been added to a #GtkApplication, returns <literal>0</literal>.
Since: 3.6
function.return: the unique ID for @window, or <literal>0</literal> if the window has not yet been added to a #GtkApplication

function.name: gtk_application_window_get_show_menubar
function.description:
Returns whether the window will display a menubar for the app menu and menubar as needed.
Since: 3.4
function.return: %TRUE if @window will display a menubar when needed

function.name: gtk_application_window_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkApplicationWindow.
Since: 3.4
function.return: a newly created #GtkApplicationWindow

function.name: gtk_application_window_set_show_menubar
function.description:
Sets whether the window will display a menubar for the app menu and menubar as needed.
Since: 3.4

parameter.name: show_menubar
parameter.parameter_description: whether to show a menubar when needed

function.name: gtk_arrow_new
function.description: Creates a new #GtkArrow widget.
function.return: the new #GtkArrow widget.

function.name: gtk_arrow_set
function.description: Sets the direction and style of the #GtkArrow, @arrow.

function.name: gtk_aspect_frame_new
function.description: Create a new #GtkAspectFrame.

parameter.name: xalign
parameter.parameter_description: Horizontal alignment of the child within the allocation of the #GtkAspectFrame. This ranges from 0.0 (left aligned) to 1.0 (right aligned)

parameter.name: yalign
parameter.parameter_description: Vertical alignment of the child within the allocation of the #GtkAspectFrame. This ranges from 0.0 (top aligned) to 1.0 (bottom aligned)

parameter.name: obey_child
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE, @ratio is ignored, and the aspect ratio is taken from the requistion of the child.

function.return: the new #GtkAspectFrame.

function.name: gtk_aspect_frame_set
function.description: Set parameters for an existing #GtkAspectFrame.

parameter.name: xalign
parameter.parameter_description: Horizontal alignment of the child within the allocation of the #GtkAspectFrame. This ranges from 0.0 (left aligned) to 1.0 (right aligned)

parameter.name: yalign
parameter.parameter_description: Vertical alignment of the child within the allocation of the #GtkAspectFrame. This ranges from 0.0 (top aligned) to 1.0 (bottom aligned)

parameter.name: obey_child
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE, @ratio is ignored, and the aspect ratio is taken from the requistion of the child.

function.name: gtk_assistant_add_action_widget
function.description:
Adds a widget to the action area of a #GtkAssistant.
Since: 2.10

function.name: gtk_assistant_append_page
function.description:
Appends a page to the @assistant.
Since: 2.10
function.return: the index (starting at 0) of the inserted page

function.name: gtk_assistant_commit
function.description:
Erases the visited page history so the back button is not shown on the current page, and removes the cancel button from subsequent pages.
Use this when the information provided up to the current page is hereafter deemed permanent and cannot be modified or undone. For example, showing a progress page to track a long-running, unreversible operation after the user has clicked apply on a confirmation page.
Since: 2.22

function.name: gtk_assistant_get_current_page
function.description:
Returns the page number of the current page.
Since: 2.10
function.return: The index (starting from 0) of the current page in the @assistant, or -1 if the @assistant has no pages, or no current page.

function.name: gtk_assistant_get_n_pages
function.description:
Returns the number of pages in the @assistant
Since: 2.10
function.return: the number of pages in the @assistant

function.name: gtk_assistant_get_nth_page
function.description:
Returns the child widget contained in page number @page_num.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: page_num
parameter.parameter_description: the index of a page in the @assistant, or -1 to get the last page

function.return: the child widget, or %NULL if @page_num is out of bounds

function.name: gtk_assistant_get_page_complete
function.description:
Gets whether @page is complete.
Since: 2.10
function.return: %TRUE if @page is complete.

function.name: gtk_assistant_get_page_header_image
function.description:
Gets the header image for @page.
Since: 2.10
Deprecated: 3.2: Since GTK+ 3.2, a header is no longer shown; add your header decoration to the page content instead.
function.return: the header image for @page, or %NULL if there's no header image for the page

function.name: gtk_assistant_get_page_side_image
function.description:
Gets the side image for @page.
Since: 2.10
Deprecated: 3.2: Since GTK+ 3.2, sidebar images are not shown anymore.
function.return: the side image for @page, or %NULL if there's no side image for the page

function.name: gtk_assistant_get_page_title
function.description:
Gets the title for @page.
Since: 2.10
function.return: the title for @page

function.name: gtk_assistant_get_page_type
function.description:
Gets the page type of @page.
Since: 2.10
function.return: the page type of @page

function.name: gtk_assistant_insert_page
function.description:
Inserts a page in the @assistant at a given position.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the index (starting at 0) at which to insert the page, or -1 to append the page to the @assistant

function.return: the index (starting from 0) of the inserted page

function.name: gtk_assistant_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkAssistant.
Since: 2.10
function.return: a newly created #GtkAssistant

function.name: gtk_assistant_next_page
function.description:
Navigate to the next page.
It is a programming error to call this function when there is no next page.
This function is for use when creating pages of the #GTK_ASSISTANT_PAGE_CUSTOM type.
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_assistant_prepend_page
function.description:
Prepends a page to the @assistant.
Since: 2.10
function.return: the index (starting at 0) of the inserted page

function.name: gtk_assistant_previous_page
function.description:
Navigate to the previous visited page.
It is a programming error to call this function when no previous page is available.
This function is for use when creating pages of the #GTK_ASSISTANT_PAGE_CUSTOM type.
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_assistant_remove_action_widget
function.description:
Removes a widget from the action area of a #GtkAssistant.
Since: 2.10

function.name: gtk_assistant_remove_page
function.description:
Removes the @page_num's page from @assistant.
Since: 3.2

parameter.name: page_num
parameter.parameter_description: the index of a page in the @assistant, or -1 to remove the last page

function.name: gtk_assistant_set_current_page
function.description:
Switches the page to @page_num.
Note that this will only be necessary in custom buttons, as the @assistant flow can be set with gtk_assistant_set_forward_page_func().
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: page_num
parameter.parameter_description: index of the page to switch to, starting from 0. If negative, the last page will be used. If greater than the number of pages in the @assistant, nothing will be done.

function.name: gtk_assistant_set_forward_page_func
function.description:
Sets the page forwarding function to be @page_func.
This function will be used to determine what will be the next page when the user presses the forward button. Setting @page_func to %NULL will make the assistant to use the default forward function, which just goes to the next visible page.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: page_func
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkAssistantPageFunc, or %NULL to use the default one

function.name: gtk_assistant_set_page_complete
function.description:
Sets whether @page contents are complete.
This will make @assistant update the buttons state to be able to continue the task.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: complete
parameter.parameter_description: the completeness status of the page

function.name: gtk_assistant_set_page_header_image
function.description:
Sets a header image for @page.
Since: 2.10
Deprecated: 3.2: Since GTK+ 3.2, a header is no longer shown; add your header decoration to the page content instead.

function.name: gtk_assistant_set_page_side_image
function.description:
Sets a side image for @page.
This image used to be displayed in the side area of the assistant when @page is the current page.
Since: 2.10
Deprecated: 3.2: Since GTK+ 3.2, sidebar images are not shown anymore.

function.name: gtk_assistant_set_page_title
function.description:
Sets a title for @page.
The title is displayed in the header area of the assistant when @page is the current page.
Since: 2.10

function.name: gtk_assistant_set_page_type
function.description:
Sets the page type for @page.
The page type determines the page behavior in the @assistant.
Since: 2.10

function.name: gtk_assistant_update_buttons_state
function.description:
Forces @assistant to recompute the buttons state.
GTK+ automatically takes care of this in most situations, e.g. when the user goes to a different page, or when the visibility or completeness of a page changes.
One situation where it can be necessary to call this function is when changing a value on the current page affects the future page flow of the assistant.
Since: 2.10

function.name: gtk_bin_get_child
function.description: Gets the child of the #GtkBin, or %NULL if the bin contains no child widget. The returned widget does not have a reference added, so you do not need to unref it.
function.return: pointer to child of the #GtkBin

function.name: gtk_binding_entry_add_signal
function.description: Override or install a new key binding for @keyval with @modifiers on @binding_set. When the binding is activated, @signal_name will be emitted on the target widget, with @n_args @Varargs used as arguments.

parameter.name: binding_set
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkBindingSet to install an entry for

parameter.name: keyval
parameter.parameter_description: key value of binding to install

parameter.name: modifiers
parameter.parameter_description: key modifier of binding to install

function.name: gtk_binding_entry_add_signal_from_string
function.description:
Parses a signal description from @signal_desc and incorporates it into @binding_set.
Signal descriptions may either bind a key combination to one or more signals: <informalexample><programlisting> bind "key" { "signalname" (param, ...) ... } </programlisting></informalexample>
Or they may also unbind a key combination: <informalexample><programlisting> unbind "key" </programlisting></informalexample>
Key combinations must be in a format that can be parsed by gtk_accelerator_parse().
Since: 3.0
function.return: %G_TOKEN_NONE if the signal was successfully parsed and added, the expected token otherwise

function.name: gtk_binding_entry_add_signall
function.description: Override or install a new key binding for @keyval with @modifiers on @binding_set.

parameter.name: binding_set
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkBindingSet to add a signal to

function.name: gtk_binding_entry_remove
function.description: Remove a binding previously installed via gtk_binding_entry_add_signal() on @binding_set.

parameter.name: binding_set
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkBindingSet to remove an entry of

parameter.name: keyval
parameter.parameter_description: key value of binding to remove

parameter.name: modifiers
parameter.parameter_description: key modifier of binding to remove

function.name: gtk_binding_entry_skip
function.description:
Install a binding on @binding_set which causes key lookups to be aborted, to prevent bindings from lower priority sets to be activated.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: binding_set
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkBindingSet to skip an entry of

parameter.name: keyval
parameter.parameter_description: key value of binding to skip

parameter.name: modifiers
parameter.parameter_description: key modifier of binding to skip

function.name: gtk_binding_set_activate
function.description: Find a key binding matching @keyval and @modifiers within @binding_set and activate the binding on @object.

parameter.name: object
parameter.parameter_description: object to activate when binding found

function.return: %TRUE if a binding was found and activated

function.name: gtk_binding_set_add_path
function.description:
This function was used internally by the GtkRC parsing mechanism to assign match patterns to #GtkBindingSet structures.
In GTK+ 3, these match patterns are unused.
Deprecated: 3.0

parameter.name: binding_set
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkBindingSet to add a path to

parameter.name: path_type
parameter.parameter_description: path type the pattern applies to

function.name: gtk_binding_set_by_class
function.description: This function returns the binding set named after the type name of the passed in class structure. New binding sets are created on demand by this function.
function.return: the binding set corresponding to @object_class

function.name: gtk_binding_set_find
function.description:
Find a binding set by its globally unique name.
The @set_name can either be a name used for gtk_binding_set_new() or the type name of a class used in gtk_binding_set_by_class().
function.return: %NULL or the specified binding set

function.name: gtk_binding_set_new
function.description: GTK+ maintains a global list of binding sets. Each binding set has a unique name which needs to be specified upon creation.

parameter.name: set_name
parameter.parameter_description: unique name of this binding set

function.return: new binding set

function.name: gtk_bindings_activate
function.description: Find a key binding matching @keyval and @modifiers and activate the binding on @object.

parameter.name: object
parameter.parameter_description: object to activate when binding found

function.return: %TRUE if a binding was found and activated

function.name: gtk_bindings_activate_event
function.return: %TRUE if a matching key binding was found

function.name: gtk_border_copy
function.description: Copies a #GtkBorder structure.

function.name: gtk_border_free

function.name: gtk_border_new

Allocates a new #GtkBorder structure and initializes its elements to zero.

function.return: a newly allocated #GtkBorder. Free with gtk_border_free()

function.name: gtk_box_get_baseline_position

Gets the value set by gtk_box_set_baseline_position().

function.name: gtk_box_get_homogeneous
function.description: Returns whether the box is homogeneous (all children are the same size). See gtk_box_set_homogeneous().
function.return: %TRUE if the box is homogeneous.

function.name: gtk_box_get_spacing

function.name: gtk_box_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkBox.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: spacing
parameter.parameter_description: the number of pixels to place by default between children.

function.return: a new #GtkBox.

function.name: gtk_box_pack_end
function.description: Adds @child to @box, packed with reference to the end of @box. The @child is packed after (away from end of) any other child packed with reference to the end of @box.

parameter.name: expand
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the new child is to be given extra space allocated to @box. The extra space will be divided evenly between all children of @box that use this option

parameter.name: fill
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if space given to @child by the @expand option is actually allocated to @child, rather than just padding it. This parameter has no effect if @expand is set to %FALSE. A child is always allocated the full height of a horizontal #GtkBox and the full width of a vertical #GtkBox. This option affects the other dimension

parameter.name: padding
parameter.parameter_description: extra space in pixels to put between this child and its neighbors, over and above the global amount specified by #GtkBox:spacing property. If @child is a widget at one of the reference ends of @box, then @padding pixels are also put between @child and the reference edge of @box

function.name: gtk_box_pack_start
function.description: Adds @child to @box, packed with reference to the start of @box. The @child is packed after any other child packed with reference to the start of @box.

parameter.name: expand
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the new child is to be given extra space allocated to @box. The extra space will be divided evenly between all children that use this option

parameter.name: fill
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if space given to @child by the @expand option is actually allocated to @child, rather than just padding it. This parameter has no effect if @expand is set to %FALSE. A child is always allocated the full height of a horizontal #GtkBox and the full width of a vertical #GtkBox. This option affects the other dimension

parameter.name: padding
parameter.parameter_description: extra space in pixels to put between this child and its neighbors, over and above the global amount specified by #GtkBox:spacing property. If @child is a widget at one of the reference ends of @box, then @padding pixels are also put between @child and the reference edge of @box

function.name: gtk_box_query_child_packing
function.description: Obtains information about how @child is packed into @box.

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkWidget of the child to query

parameter.name: expand
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to return location for #GtkBox:expand child property

parameter.name: fill
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to return location for #GtkBox:fill child property

parameter.name: padding
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to return location for #GtkBox:padding child property

parameter.name: pack_type
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to return location for #GtkBox:pack-type child property

function.name: gtk_box_reorder_child
function.description:
Moves @child to a new @position in the list of @box children. The list is the <structfield>children</structfield> field of #GtkBox-struct, and contains both widgets packed #GTK_PACK_START as well as widgets packed #GTK_PACK_END, in the order that these widgets were added to @box.
A widget's position in the @box children list determines where the widget is packed into @box. A child widget at some position in the list will be packed just after all other widgets of the same packing type that appear earlier in the list.

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the new position for @child in the list of children of @box, starting from 0. If negative, indicates the end of the list

function.name: gtk_box_set_baseline_position
function.description:
Sets the baseline position of a box. This affects only horizontal boxes with at least one baseline aligned child. If there is more vertical space availible than requested, and the baseline is not allocated by the parent then @position is used to allocate the baseline wrt the extra space available.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_box_set_child_packing
function.description: Sets the way @child is packed into @box.

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkWidget of the child to set

parameter.name: expand
parameter.parameter_description: the new value of the #GtkBox:expand child property

parameter.name: fill
parameter.parameter_description: the new value of the #GtkBox:fill child property

parameter.name: padding
parameter.parameter_description: the new value of the #GtkBox:padding child property

parameter.name: pack_type
parameter.parameter_description: the new value of the #GtkBox:pack-type child property

function.name: gtk_box_set_homogeneous
function.description: Sets the #GtkBox:homogeneous property of @box, controlling whether or not all children of @box are given equal space in the box.

parameter.name: homogeneous
parameter.parameter_description: a boolean value, %TRUE to create equal allotments, %FALSE for variable allotments

function.name: gtk_box_set_spacing
function.description: Sets the #GtkBox:spacing property of @box, which is the number of pixels to place between children of @box.

parameter.name: spacing
parameter.parameter_description: the number of pixels to put between children

function.name: gtk_buildable_add_child
function.description:
Adds a child to @buildable. @type is an optional string describing how the child should be added.
Since: 2.12

function.name: gtk_buildable_construct_child
function.description:
Constructs a child of @buildable with the name @name.
#GtkBuilder calls this function if a "constructor" has been specified in the UI definition.
Since: 2.12
function.return: the constructed child

function.name: gtk_buildable_custom_finished
function.description:
This is similar to gtk_buildable_parser_finished() but is called once for each custom tag handled by the @buildable.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: child object or %NULL for non-child tags

function.name: gtk_buildable_custom_tag_end
function.description:
This is called at the end of each custom element handled by the buildable.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: child object or %NULL for non-child tags

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: user data that will be passed in to parser functions

function.name: gtk_buildable_custom_tag_start
function.description:
This is called for each unknown element under <child>.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: builder
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkBuilder used to construct this object

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: child object or %NULL for non-child tags

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: return location for user data that will be passed in to parser functions

function.return: %TRUE if a object has a custom implementation, %FALSE if it doesn't.

function.name: gtk_buildable_get_internal_child
function.description:
Get the internal child called @childname of the @buildable object.
Since: 2.12
function.return: the internal child of the buildable object

function.name: gtk_buildable_get_name
function.description:
Gets the name of the @buildable object.
#GtkBuilder sets the name based on the <link linkend="BUILDER-UI">GtkBuilder UI definition</link> used to construct the @buildable.
Since: 2.12
function.return: the name set with gtk_buildable_set_name()

function.name: gtk_buildable_parser_finished
function.description:
Called when the builder finishes the parsing of a <link linkend="BUILDER-UI">GtkBuilder UI definition</link>. Note that this will be called once for each time gtk_builder_add_from_file() or gtk_builder_add_from_string() is called on a builder.
Since: 2.12

function.name: gtk_buildable_set_buildable_property
function.description:
Sets the property name @name to @value on the @buildable object.
Since: 2.12

function.name: gtk_buildable_set_name
function.description:
Sets the name of the @buildable object.
Since: 2.12

function.name: gtk_builder_add_callback_symbol
function.description:
Adds the @callback_symbol to the scope of @builder under the given @callback_name.
Using this function overrides the behavior of gtk_builder_connect_signals() for any callback symbols that are added. Using this method allows for better encapsulation as it does not require that callback symbols be declared in the global namespace.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: callback_name
parameter.parameter_description: The name of the callback, as expected in the XML

function.name: gtk_builder_add_callback_symbols
function.description:
A convenience function to add many callbacks instead of calling gtk_builder_add_callback_symbol() for each symbol.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: first_callback_name
parameter.parameter_description: The name of the callback, as expected in the XML

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: A list of callback name and callback symbol pairs terminated with %NULL

function.name: gtk_builder_add_from_file
function.description:
Parses a file containing a <link linkend="BUILDER-UI">GtkBuilder UI definition</link> and merges it with the current contents of @builder.
Most users will probably want to use gtk_builder_new_from_file().
Upon errors 0 will be returned and @error will be assigned a #GError from the #GTK_BUILDER_ERROR, #G_MARKUP_ERROR or #G_FILE_ERROR domain.
It's not really reasonable to attempt to handle failures of this call. You should not use this function with untrusted files (ie: files that are not part of your application). Broken #GtkBuilder files can easily crash your program, and it's possible that memory was leaked leading up to the reported failure. The only reasonable thing to do when an error is detected is to call g_error().
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the file to parse

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an error, or %NULL

function.return: A positive value on success, 0 if an error occurred

function.name: gtk_builder_add_from_resource
function.description:
Parses a resource file containing a <link linkend="BUILDER-UI">GtkBuilder UI definition</link> and merges it with the current contents of @builder.
Most users will probably want to use gtk_builder_new_from_resource().
Upon errors 0 will be returned and @error will be assigned a #GError from the #GTK_BUILDER_ERROR, #G_MARKUP_ERROR or #G_RESOURCE_ERROR domain.
It's not really reasonable to attempt to handle failures of this call. The only reasonable thing to do when an error is detected is to call g_error().
Since: 3.4

parameter.name: resource_path
parameter.parameter_description: the path of the resource file to parse

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an error, or %NULL

function.return: A positive value on success, 0 if an error occurred

function.name: gtk_builder_add_from_string
function.description:
Parses a string containing a <link linkend="BUILDER-UI">GtkBuilder UI definition</link> and merges it with the current contents of @builder.
Most users will probably want to use gtk_builder_new_from_string().
Upon errors 0 will be returned and @error will be assigned a #GError from the #GTK_BUILDER_ERROR or #G_MARKUP_ERROR domain.
It's not really reasonable to attempt to handle failures of this call. The only reasonable thing to do when an error is detected is to call g_error().
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @buffer (may be -1 if @buffer is nul-terminated)

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an error, or %NULL

function.return: A positive value on success, 0 if an error occurred

function.name: gtk_builder_add_objects_from_file
function.description:
Parses a file containing a <link linkend="BUILDER-UI">GtkBuilder UI definition</link> building only the requested objects and merges them with the current contents of @builder.
Upon errors 0 will be returned and @error will be assigned a #GError from the #GTK_BUILDER_ERROR, #G_MARKUP_ERROR or #G_FILE_ERROR domain.
<note><para> If you are adding an object that depends on an object that is not its child (for instance a #GtkTreeView that depends on its #GtkTreeModel), you have to explicitely list all of them in @object_ids. </para></note>
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the file to parse

parameter.name: object_ids
parameter.parameter_description: nul-terminated array of objects to build

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an error, or %NULL

function.return: A positive value on success, 0 if an error occurred

function.name: gtk_builder_add_objects_from_resource
function.description:
Parses a resource file containing a <link linkend="BUILDER-UI">GtkBuilder UI definition</link> building only the requested objects and merges them with the current contents of @builder.
Upon errors 0 will be returned and @error will be assigned a #GError from the #GTK_BUILDER_ERROR, #G_MARKUP_ERROR or #G_RESOURCE_ERROR domain.
<note><para> If you are adding an object that depends on an object that is not its child (for instance a #GtkTreeView that depends on its #GtkTreeModel), you have to explicitely list all of them in @object_ids. </para></note>
Since: 3.4

parameter.name: resource_path
parameter.parameter_description: the path of the resource file to parse

parameter.name: object_ids
parameter.parameter_description: nul-terminated array of objects to build

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an error, or %NULL

function.return: A positive value on success, 0 if an error occurred

function.name: gtk_builder_add_objects_from_string
function.description:
Parses a string containing a <link linkend="BUILDER-UI">GtkBuilder UI definition</link> building only the requested objects and merges them with the current contents of @builder.
Upon errors 0 will be returned and @error will be assigned a #GError from the #GTK_BUILDER_ERROR or #G_MARKUP_ERROR domain.
<note><para> If you are adding an object that depends on an object that is not its child (for instance a #GtkTreeView that depends on its #GtkTreeModel), you have to explicitely list all of them in @object_ids. </para></note>
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @buffer (may be -1 if @buffer is nul-terminated)

parameter.name: object_ids
parameter.parameter_description: nul-terminated array of objects to build

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an error, or %NULL

function.return: A positive value on success, 0 if an error occurred

function.name: gtk_builder_connect_signals
function.description:
This method is a simpler variation of gtk_builder_connect_signals_full(). It uses symbols explicitly added to @builder with prior calls to gtk_builder_add_callback_symbol(). In the case that symbols are not explicitly added; it uses #GModule's introspective features (by opening the module %NULL) to look at the application's symbol table. From here it tries to match the signal handler names given in the interface description with symbols in the application and connects the signals. Note that this function can only be called once, subsequent calls will do nothing.
Note that unless gtk_builder_add_callback_symbol() is called for all signal callbacks which are referenced by the loaded XML, this function will require that #GModule be supported on the platform.
If you rely on #GModule support to lookup callbacks in the symbol table, the following details should be noted:
When compiling applications for Windows, you must declare signal callbacks with #G_MODULE_EXPORT, or they will not be put in the symbol table. On Linux and Unices, this is not necessary; applications should instead be compiled with the -Wl,--export-dynamic CFLAGS, and linked against gmodule-export-2.0.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a structure sent in as user data to all signals

function.name: gtk_builder_connect_signals_full
function.description:
This function can be thought of the interpreted language binding version of gtk_builder_connect_signals(), except that it does not require GModule to function correctly.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function used to connect the signals

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: arbitrary data that will be passed to the connection function

function.name: gtk_builder_expose_object
function.description:
Add @object to the @builder object pool so it can be referenced just like any other object built by builder.
Since: 3.8

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the object exposed to the builder

function.name: gtk_builder_get_object
function.description:
Gets the object named @name. Note that this function does not increment the reference count of the returned object.
Since: 2.12
function.return: the object named @name or %NULL if it could not be found in the object tree.

function.name: gtk_builder_get_objects
function.description:
Gets all objects that have been constructed by @builder. Note that this function does not increment the reference counts of the returned objects.
Since: 2.12
function.return: a newly-allocated #GSList containing all the objects constructed by the #GtkBuilder instance. It should be freed by g_slist_free()

function.name: gtk_builder_get_translation_domain
function.description:
Gets the translation domain of @builder.
Since: 2.12
function.return: the translation domain. This string is owned by the builder object and must not be modified or freed.

function.name: gtk_builder_get_type_from_name
function.description:
Looks up a type by name, using the virtual function that #GtkBuilder has for that purpose. This is mainly used when implementing the #GtkBuildable interface on a type.
Since: 2.12
function.return: the #GType found for @type_name or #G_TYPE_INVALID if no type was found

function.name: gtk_builder_lookup_callback_symbol
function.description:
Fetches a symbol previously added to @builder with gtk_builder_add_callback_symbols()
This function is intended for possible use in language bindings or for any case that one might be cusomizing signal connections using gtk_builder_connect_signals_full()
Since: 3.10
function.return: The callback symbol in @builder for @callback_name, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_builder_new
function.description:
Creates a new empty builder object.
This function is only useful if you intend to make multiple calls to gtk_builder_add_from_file(), gtk_builder_add_from_resource() or gtk_builder_add_from_string() in order to merge multiple UI descriptions into a single builder.
Most users will probably want to use gtk_builder_new_from_file(), gtk_builder_new_from_resource() or gtk_builder_new_from_string().
Since: 2.12
function.return: a new (empty) #GtkBuilder object

function.name: gtk_builder_new_from_file
function.description:
Builds the <link linkend="BUILDER-UI">GtkBuilder UI definition</link> in the file @filename.
If there is an error opening the file or parsing the description then the program will be aborted. You should only ever attempt to parse user interface descriptions that are shipped as part of your program.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: filename of user interface description file

function.return: a #Gtkbuilder containing the described interface

function.name: gtk_builder_new_from_resource
function.description:
Builds the <link linkend="BUILDER-UI">GtkBuilder UI definition</link> at @resource_path.
If there is an error locating the resurce or parsing the description then the program will be aborted.
Since: 3.10
function.return: a #Gtkbuilder containing the described interface

function.name: gtk_builder_new_from_string
function.description:
Builds the user interface described by @string (in the <link linkend="BUILDER-UI">GtkBuilder UI definition</link> format).
If @string is %NULL-terminated then @length should be -1. If @length is not -1 then it is the length of @string.
If there is an error parsing @string then the program will be aborted. You should not attempt to parse user interface description from untrusted sources.
Since: 3.10
function.return: a #Gtkbuilder containing the interface described by @string

function.name: gtk_builder_set_translation_domain
function.description:
Sets the translation domain of @builder. See #GtkBuilder:translation-domain.
Since: 2.12

function.name: gtk_builder_value_from_string
function.description:
This function demarshals a value from a string. This function calls g_value_init() on the @value argument, so it need not be initialised beforehand.
This function can handle char, uchar, boolean, int, uint, long, ulong, enum, flags, float, double, string, #GdkColor, #GdkRGBA and #GtkAdjustment type values. Support for #GtkWidget type values is still to come.
Upon errors %FALSE will be returned and @error will be assigned a #GError from the #GTK_BUILDER_ERROR domain.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string representation of the value

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: the #GValue to store the result in

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an error, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE on success

function.name: gtk_builder_value_from_string_type
function.description:
Like gtk_builder_value_from_string(), this function demarshals a value from a string, but takes a #GType instead of #GParamSpec. This function calls g_value_init() on the @value argument, so it need not be initialised beforehand.
Upon errors %FALSE will be returned and @error will be assigned a #GError from the #GTK_BUILDER_ERROR domain.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string representation of the value

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: the #GValue to store the result in

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an error, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE on success

function.name: gtk_button_box_get_child_non_homogeneous
function.description:
Returns whether the child is exempted from homogenous sizing.
Since: 3.2
function.return: %TRUE if the child is not subject to homogenous sizing

function.name: gtk_button_box_get_child_secondary
function.description:
Returns whether @child should appear in a secondary group of children.
Since: 2.4
function.return: whether @child should appear in a secondary group of children.

function.name: gtk_button_box_get_layout
function.description: Retrieves the method being used to arrange the buttons in a button box.
function.return: the method used to lay out buttons in @widget.

function.name: gtk_button_box_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkButtonBox.
Since: 3.0
function.return: a new #GtkButtonBox.

function.name: gtk_button_box_set_child_non_homogeneous
function.description:
Sets whether the child is exempted from homogeous sizing.
Since: 3.2

function.name: gtk_button_box_set_child_secondary
function.description:
Sets whether @child should appear in a secondary group of children. A typical use of a secondary child is the help button in a dialog.
This group appears after the other children if the style is %GTK_BUTTONBOX_START, %GTK_BUTTONBOX_SPREAD or %GTK_BUTTONBOX_EDGE, and before the other children if the style is %GTK_BUTTONBOX_END. For horizontal button boxes, the definition of before/after depends on direction of the widget (see gtk_widget_set_direction()). If the style is %GTK_BUTTONBOX_START or %GTK_BUTTONBOX_END, then the secondary children are aligned at the other end of the button box from the main children. For the other styles, they appear immediately next to the main children.

parameter.name: is_secondary
parameter.parameter_description: if %TRUE, the @child appears in a secondary group of the button box.

function.name: gtk_button_box_set_layout
function.description: Changes the way buttons are arranged in their container.

function.name: gtk_button_clicked
function.description: Emits a #GtkButton::clicked signal to the given #GtkButton.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: The #GtkButton you want to send the signal to.

function.name: gtk_button_enter
function.description:
Emits a #GtkButton::enter signal to the given #GtkButton.
Deprecated: 2.20: Use the #GtkWidget::enter-notify-event signal.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: The #GtkButton you want to send the signal to.

function.name: gtk_button_get_alignment
function.description:
Gets the alignment of the child in the button.
Since: 2.4

function.name: gtk_button_get_always_show_image
function.description:
Returns whether the button will always show the image in addition to the label, if available.
Since: 3.6
function.return: %TRUE if the button will always show the image

function.name: gtk_button_get_event_window
function.description:
Returns the button's event window if it is realized, %NULL otherwise. This function should be rarely needed.
Since: 2.22
function.return: @button's event window.

function.name: gtk_button_get_focus_on_click
function.description:
Returns whether the button grabs focus when it is clicked with the mouse. See gtk_button_set_focus_on_click().
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if the button grabs focus when it is clicked with the mouse.

function.name: gtk_button_get_image
function.description:
Gets the widget that is currenty set as the image of @button. This may have been explicitly set by gtk_button_set_image() or constructed by gtk_button_new_from_stock().
Since: 2.6
function.return: a #GtkWidget or %NULL in case there is no image

function.name: gtk_button_get_image_position
function.description:
Gets the position of the image relative to the text inside the button.
Since: 2.10
function.return: the position

function.name: gtk_button_get_label
function.description: Fetches the text from the label of the button, as set by gtk_button_set_label(). If the label text has not been set the return value will be %NULL. This will be the case if you create an empty button with gtk_button_new() to use as a container.
function.return: The text of the label widget. This string is owned by the widget and must not be modified or freed.

function.name: gtk_button_get_relief
function.description: Returns the current relief style of the given #GtkButton.
function.return: The current #GtkReliefStyle

function.name: gtk_button_get_use_stock
function.description:
Returns whether the button label is a stock item.
Deprecated: 3.10
function.return: %TRUE if the button label is used to select a stock item instead of being used directly as the label text.

function.name: gtk_button_get_use_underline
function.description: Returns whether an embedded underline in the button label indicates a mnemonic. See gtk_button_set_use_underline ().
function.return: %TRUE if an embedded underline in the button label indicates the mnemonic accelerator keys.

function.name: gtk_button_leave
function.description:
Emits a #GtkButton::leave signal to the given #GtkButton.
Deprecated: 2.20: Use the #GtkWidget::leave-notify-event signal.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: The #GtkButton you want to send the signal to.

function.name: gtk_button_new
function.description: Creates a new #GtkButton widget. To add a child widget to the button, use gtk_container_add().
function.return: The newly created #GtkButton widget.

function.name: gtk_button_new_from_icon_name
function.description:
Creates a new button containing an icon from the current icon theme.
If the icon name isn't known, a "broken image" icon will be displayed instead. If the current icon theme is changed, the icon will be updated appropriately.
This function is a convenience wrapper around gtk_button_new() and gtk_button_set_image().
Since: 3.10
function.return: a new #GtkButton displaying the themed icon

function.name: gtk_button_new_from_stock
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkButton containing the image and text from a stock item. Some stock ids have preprocessor macros like #GTK_STOCK_OK and #GTK_STOCK_APPLY.
If @stock_id is unknown, then it will be treated as a mnemonic label (as for gtk_button_new_with_mnemonic()).
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_button_new_with_label() instead.

parameter.name: stock_id
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the stock item

function.return: a new #GtkButton

function.name: gtk_button_new_with_label
function.description: Creates a #GtkButton widget with a #GtkLabel child containing the given text.

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: The text you want the #GtkLabel to hold.

function.return: The newly created #GtkButton widget.

function.name: gtk_button_new_with_mnemonic
function.description: Creates a new #GtkButton containing a label. If characters in @label are preceded by an underscore, they are underlined. If you need a literal underscore character in a label, use '__' (two underscores). The first underlined character represents a keyboard accelerator called a mnemonic. Pressing Alt and that key activates the button.

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: The text of the button, with an underscore in front of the mnemonic character

function.return: a new #GtkButton

function.name: gtk_button_pressed
function.description:
Emits a #GtkButton::pressed signal to the given #GtkButton.
Deprecated: 2.20: Use the #GtkWidget::button-press-event signal.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: The #GtkButton you want to send the signal to.

function.name: gtk_button_released
function.description:
Emits a #GtkButton::released signal to the given #GtkButton.
Deprecated: 2.20: Use the #GtkWidget::button-release-event signal.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: The #GtkButton you want to send the signal to.

function.name: gtk_button_set_alignment
function.description:
Sets the alignment of the child. This property has no effect unless the child is a #GtkMisc or a #GtkAlignment.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: xalign
parameter.parameter_description: the horizontal position of the child, 0.0 is left aligned, 1.0 is right aligned

parameter.name: yalign
parameter.parameter_description: the vertical position of the child, 0.0 is top aligned, 1.0 is bottom aligned

function.name: gtk_button_set_always_show_image
function.description:
If %TRUE, the button will always show the image in addition to the label, if available.
Use this property if the button would be useless or hard to use without the image.
Since: 3.6

parameter.name: always_show
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the menuitem should always show the image

function.name: gtk_button_set_focus_on_click
function.description:
Sets whether the button will grab focus when it is clicked with the mouse. Making mouse clicks not grab focus is useful in places like toolbars where you don't want the keyboard focus removed from the main area of the application.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: focus_on_click
parameter.parameter_description: whether the button grabs focus when clicked with the mouse

function.name: gtk_button_set_image
function.description:
Set the image of @button to the given widget. The image will be displayed if the label text is %NULL or if #GtkButton:always-show-image is %TRUE. You don't have to call gtk_widget_show() on @image yourself.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: image
parameter.parameter_description: a widget to set as the image for the button

function.name: gtk_button_set_image_position
function.description:
Sets the position of the image relative to the text inside the button.
Since: 2.10

function.name: gtk_button_set_label
function.description:
Sets the text of the label of the button to @str. This text is also used to select the stock item if gtk_button_set_use_stock() is used.
This will also clear any previously set labels.

function.name: gtk_button_set_relief
function.description:
Sets the relief style of the edges of the given #GtkButton widget. Three styles exist, GTK_RELIEF_NORMAL, GTK_RELIEF_HALF, GTK_RELIEF_NONE. The default style is, as one can guess, GTK_RELIEF_NORMAL.
<!-- FIXME: put pictures of each style -->

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: The #GtkButton you want to set relief styles of.

function.name: gtk_button_set_use_stock
function.description:
If %TRUE, the label set on the button is used as a stock id to select the stock item for the button.
Deprecated: 3.10

parameter.name: use_stock
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the button should use a stock item

function.name: gtk_button_set_use_underline
function.description: If true, an underline in the text of the button label indicates the next character should be used for the mnemonic accelerator key.

parameter.name: use_underline
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if underlines in the text indicate mnemonics

function.name: gtk_cairo_should_draw_window
function.description:
This function is supposed to be called in #GtkWidget::draw implementations for widgets that support multiple windows. @cr must be untransformed from invoking of the draw function. This function will return %TRUE if the contents of the given @window are supposed to be drawn and %FALSE otherwise. Note that when the drawing was not initiated by the windowing system this function will return %TRUE for all windows, so you need to draw the bottommost window first. Also, do not use "else if" statements to check which window should be drawn.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: window
parameter.parameter_description: the window to check. @window may not be an input-only window.

function.return: %TRUE if @window should be drawn

function.name: gtk_cairo_transform_to_window
function.description:
Transforms the given cairo context @cr that from @widget-relative coordinates to @window-relative coordinates. If the @widget's window is not an ancestor of @window, no modification will be applied.
This is the inverse to the transformation GTK applies when preparing an expose event to be emitted with the #GtkWidget::draw signal. It is intended to help porting multiwindow widgets from GTK+ 2 to the rendering architecture of GTK+ 3.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the widget the context is currently centered for

parameter.name: window
parameter.parameter_description: the window to transform the context to

function.name: gtk_calendar_clear_marks
function.description: Remove all visual markers.

function.name: gtk_calendar_get_date
function.description: Obtains the selected date from a #GtkCalendar.

parameter.name: year
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the year as a decimal number (e.g. 2011), or %NULL

parameter.name: month
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the month number (between 0 and 11), or %NULL

parameter.name: day
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the day number (between 1 and 31), or %NULL

function.name: gtk_calendar_get_day_is_marked
function.description:
Returns if the @day of the @calendar is already marked.
Since: 3.0
function.return: whether the day is marked.

function.name: gtk_calendar_get_detail_height_rows
function.description:
Queries the height of detail cells, in rows. See #GtkCalendar:detail-width-chars.
Since: 2.14
function.return: The height of detail cells, in rows.

function.name: gtk_calendar_get_detail_width_chars
function.description:
Queries the width of detail cells, in characters. See #GtkCalendar:detail-width-chars.
Since: 2.14
function.return: The width of detail cells, in characters.

function.name: gtk_calendar_get_display_options
function.description:
Returns the current display options of @calendar.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the display options.

function.name: gtk_calendar_mark_day
function.description: Places a visual marker on a particular day.

parameter.name: day
parameter.parameter_description: the day number to mark between 1 and 31.

function.name: gtk_calendar_new
function.description: Creates a new calendar, with the current date being selected.
function.return: a newly #GtkCalendar widget

function.name: gtk_calendar_select_day
function.description: Selects a day from the current month.

parameter.name: day
parameter.parameter_description: the day number between 1 and 31, or 0 to unselect the currently selected day.

function.name: gtk_calendar_select_month
function.description: Shifts the calendar to a different month.

parameter.name: year
parameter.parameter_description: the year the month is in.

function.name: gtk_calendar_set_detail_func
function.description:
Installs a function which provides Pango markup with detail information for each day. Examples for such details are holidays or appointments. That information is shown below each day when #GtkCalendar:show-details is set. A tooltip containing with full detail information is provided, if the entire text should not fit into the details area, or if #GtkCalendar:show-details is not set.
The size of the details area can be restricted by setting the #GtkCalendar:detail-width-chars and #GtkCalendar:detail-height-rows properties.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: a function providing details for each day.

function.name: gtk_calendar_set_detail_height_rows
function.description:
Updates the height of detail cells. See #GtkCalendar:detail-height-rows.
Since: 2.14

function.name: gtk_calendar_set_detail_width_chars
function.description:
Updates the width of detail cells. See #GtkCalendar:detail-width-chars.
Since: 2.14

function.name: gtk_calendar_set_display_options
function.description:
Sets display options (whether to display the heading and the month headings).
Since: 2.4

function.name: gtk_calendar_unmark_day
function.description: Removes the visual marker from a particular day.

parameter.name: day
parameter.parameter_description: the day number to unmark between 1 and 31.

function.name: gtk_cell_area_activate
function.description:
Activates @area, usually by activating the currently focused cell, however some subclasses which embed widgets in the area can also activate a widget if it currently has the focus.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkCellAreaContext in context with the current row data

parameter.name: cell_area
parameter.parameter_description: the size and location of @area relative to @widget's allocation

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkCellRendererState flags for @area for this row of data.

parameter.name: edit_only
parameter.parameter_description: if %TRUE then only cell renderers that are %GTK_CELL_RENDERER_MODE_EDITABLE will be activated.

function.return: Whether @area was successfully activated.

function.name: gtk_cell_area_activate_cell
function.description:
This is used by #GtkCellArea subclasses when handling events to activate cells, the base #GtkCellArea class activates cells for keyboard events for free in its own GtkCellArea->activate() implementation.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkEvent for which cell activation should occur

parameter.name: cell_area
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkRectangle in @widget relative coordinates of @renderer for the current row.

function.return: whether cell activation was successful

function.name: gtk_cell_area_add
function.description:
Adds @renderer to @area with the default child cell properties.
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_cell_area_add_focus_sibling
function.description:
Adds @sibling to @renderer's focusable area, focus will be drawn around @renderer and all of its siblings if @renderer can focus for a given row.
Events handled by focus siblings can also activate the given focusable @renderer.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: sibling
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkCellRenderer to add to @renderer's focus area

function.name: gtk_cell_area_add_with_properties
function.description:
Adds @renderer to @area, setting cell properties at the same time. See gtk_cell_area_add() and gtk_cell_area_cell_set() for more details.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: first_prop_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the first cell property to set

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: a %NULL-terminated list of property names and values, starting with @first_prop_name

function.name: gtk_cell_area_apply_attributes

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeIter in @tree_model to apply values for

parameter.name: is_expanded
parameter.parameter_description: whether @iter is expanded in the view and children are visible

function.name: gtk_cell_area_attribute_connect
function.description:
Connects an @attribute to apply values from @column for the #GtkTreeModel in use.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: renderer
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkCellRenderer to connect an attribute for

parameter.name: column
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeModel column to fetch attribute values from

function.name: gtk_cell_area_attribute_disconnect
function.description:
Disconnects @attribute for the @renderer in @area so that attribute will no longer be updated with values from the model.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: renderer
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkCellRenderer to disconnect an attribute for

function.name: gtk_cell_area_box_get_spacing
function.description:
Gets the spacing added between cell renderers.
Since: 3.0
function.return: the space added between cell renderers in @box.

function.name: gtk_cell_area_box_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkCellAreaBox.
Since: 3.0
function.return: a newly created #GtkCellAreaBox

function.name: gtk_cell_area_box_pack_end
function.description:
Adds @renderer to @box, packed with reference to the end of @box.
The @renderer is packed after (away from end of) any other #GtkCellRenderer packed with reference to the end of @box.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: expand
parameter.parameter_description: whether @renderer should receive extra space when the area receives more than its natural size

parameter.name: align
parameter.parameter_description: whether @renderer should be aligned in adjacent rows

parameter.name: fixed
parameter.parameter_description: whether @renderer should have the same size in all rows

function.name: gtk_cell_area_box_pack_start
function.description:
Adds @renderer to @box, packed with reference to the start of @box.
The @renderer is packed after any other #GtkCellRenderer packed with reference to the start of @box.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: expand
parameter.parameter_description: whether @renderer should receive extra space when the area receives more than its natural size

parameter.name: align
parameter.parameter_description: whether @renderer should be aligned in adjacent rows

parameter.name: fixed
parameter.parameter_description: whether @renderer should have the same size in all rows

function.name: gtk_cell_area_box_set_spacing
function.description:
Sets the spacing to add between cell renderers in @box.
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_cell_area_cell_get
function.description:
Gets the values of one or more cell properties for @renderer in @area.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: first_prop_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the first cell property to get

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the first cell property, followed optionally by more name/return location pairs, followed by %NULL

function.name: gtk_cell_area_cell_get_property
function.description:
Gets the value of a cell property for @renderer in @area.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the property to get

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: a location to return the value

function.name: gtk_cell_area_cell_get_valist
function.description:
Gets the values of one or more cell properties for @renderer in @area.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the first property to get

parameter.name: var_args
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the first property, followed optionally by more name/return location pairs, followed by %NULL

function.name: gtk_cell_area_cell_set
function.description:
Sets one or more cell properties for @cell in @area.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: renderer
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkCellRenderer which is a cell inside @area

parameter.name: first_prop_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the first cell property to set

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: a %NULL-terminated list of property names and values, starting with @first_prop_name

function.name: gtk_cell_area_cell_set_property
function.description:
Sets a cell property for @renderer in @area.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the cell property to set

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: the value to set the cell property to

function.name: gtk_cell_area_cell_set_valist
function.description:
Sets one or more cell properties for @renderer in @area.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the first cell property to set

parameter.name: var_args
parameter.parameter_description: a %NULL-terminated list of property names and values, starting with @first_prop_name

function.name: gtk_cell_area_class_find_cell_property
function.description:
Finds a cell property of a cell area class by name.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the child property to find

function.return: the #GParamSpec of the child property or %NULL if @aclass has no child property with that name.

function.name: gtk_cell_area_class_install_cell_property
function.description:
Installs a cell property on a cell area class.
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_cell_area_class_list_cell_properties
function.description:
Returns all cell properties of a cell area class.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: n_properties
parameter.parameter_description: location to return the number of cell properties found

function.return: a newly allocated %NULL-terminated array of #GParamSpec*. The array must be freed with g_free().

function.name: gtk_cell_area_context_allocate
function.description:
Allocates a width and/or a height for all rows which are to be rendered with @context.
Usually allocation is performed only horizontally or sometimes vertically since a group of rows are usually rendered side by side vertically or horizontally and share either the same width or the same height. Sometimes they are allocated in both horizontal and vertical orientations producing a homogeneous effect of the rows. This is generally the case for #GtkTreeView when #GtkTreeView:fixed-height-mode is enabled.
Since 3.0

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the allocated width for all #GtkTreeModel rows rendered with @context, or -1.

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the allocated height for all #GtkTreeModel rows rendered with @context, or -1.

function.name: gtk_cell_area_context_get_allocation
function.description:
Fetches the current allocation size for @context.
If the context was not allocated in width or height, or if the context was recently reset with gtk_cell_area_context_reset(), the returned value will be -1.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the allocated width, or %NULL

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the allocated height, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_cell_area_context_get_area
function.description:
Fetches the #GtkCellArea this @context was created by.
This is generally unneeded by layouting widgets; however, it is important for the context implementation itself to fetch information about the area it is being used for.
For instance at #GtkCellAreaContextClass.allocate() time it's important to know details about any cell spacing that the #GtkCellArea is configured with in order to compute a proper allocation.
Since: 3.0
function.return: the #GtkCellArea this context was created by.

function.name: gtk_cell_area_context_get_preferred_height
function.description:
Gets the accumulative preferred height for all rows which have been requested with this context.
After gtk_cell_area_context_reset() is called and/or before ever requesting the size of a #GtkCellArea, the returned values are 0.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: minimum_height
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the minimum height, or %NULL

parameter.name: natural_height
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the natural height, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_cell_area_context_get_preferred_height_for_width
function.description:
Gets the accumulative preferred height for @width for all rows which have been requested for the same said @width with this context.
After gtk_cell_area_context_reset() is called and/or before ever requesting the size of a #GtkCellArea, the returned values are -1.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: minimum_height
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the minimum height, or %NULL

parameter.name: natural_height
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the natural height, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_cell_area_context_get_preferred_width
function.description:
Gets the accumulative preferred width for all rows which have been requested with this context.
After gtk_cell_area_context_reset() is called and/or before ever requesting the size of a #GtkCellArea, the returned values are 0.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: minimum_width
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the minimum width, or %NULL

parameter.name: natural_width
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the natural width, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_cell_area_context_get_preferred_width_for_height
function.description:
Gets the accumulative preferred width for @height for all rows which have been requested for the same said @height with this context.
After gtk_cell_area_context_reset() is called and/or before ever requesting the size of a #GtkCellArea, the returned values are -1.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: minimum_width
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the minimum width, or %NULL

parameter.name: natural_width
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the natural width, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_cell_area_context_push_preferred_height
function.description:
Causes the minimum and/or natural height to grow if the new proposed sizes exceed the current minimum and natural height.
This is used by #GtkCellAreaContext implementations during the request process over a series of #GtkTreeModel rows to progressively push the requested height over a series of gtk_cell_area_get_preferred_height() requests.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: minimum_height
parameter.parameter_description: the proposed new minimum height for @context

parameter.name: natural_height
parameter.parameter_description: the proposed new natural height for @context

function.name: gtk_cell_area_context_push_preferred_width
function.description:
Causes the minimum and/or natural width to grow if the new proposed sizes exceed the current minimum and natural width.
This is used by #GtkCellAreaContext implementations during the request process over a series of #GtkTreeModel rows to progressively push the requested width over a series of gtk_cell_area_get_preferred_width() requests.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: minimum_width
parameter.parameter_description: the proposed new minimum width for @context

parameter.name: natural_width
parameter.parameter_description: the proposed new natural width for @context

function.name: gtk_cell_area_context_reset
function.description:
Resets any previously cached request and allocation data.
When underlying #GtkTreeModel data changes its important to reset the context if the content size is allowed to shrink. If the content size is only allowed to grow (this is usually an option for views rendering large data stores as a measure of optimization), then only the row that changed or was inserted needs to be (re)requested with gtk_cell_area_get_preferred_width().
When the new overall size of the context requires that the allocated size changes (or whenever this allocation changes at all), the variable row sizes need to be re-requested for every row.
For instance, if the rows are displayed all with the same width from top to bottom then a change in the allocated width necessitates a recalculation of all the displayed row heights using gtk_cell_area_get_preferred_height_for_width().
Since 3.0

function.name: gtk_cell_area_copy_context
function.description:
This is sometimes needed for cases where rows need to share alignments in one orientation but may be separately grouped in the opposing orientation.
For instance, #GtkIconView creates all icons (rows) to have the same width and the cells theirin to have the same horizontal alignments. However each row of icons may have a separate collective height. #GtkIconView uses this to request the heights of each row based on a context which was already used to request all the row widths that are to be displayed.
Since: 3.0
function.return: a newly created #GtkCellAreaContext copy of @context.

function.name: gtk_cell_area_create_context
function.description:
Creates a #GtkCellAreaContext to be used with @area for all purposes. #GtkCellAreaContext stores geometry information for rows for which it was operated on, it is important to use the same context for the same row of data at all times (i.e. one should render and handle events with the same #GtkCellAreaContext which was used to request the size of those rows of data).
Since: 3.0
function.return: a newly created #GtkCellAreaContext which can be used with @area.

function.name: gtk_cell_area_event
function.description:
Delegates event handling to a #GtkCellArea.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkCellAreaContext for this row of data.

function.return: %TRUE if the event was handled by @area.

function.name: gtk_cell_area_focus
function.description:
This should be called by the @area's owning layout widget when focus is to be passed to @area, or moved within @area for a given @direction and row data.
Implementing #GtkCellArea classes should implement this method to receive and navigate focus in its own way particular to how it lays out cells.
Since: 3.0
function.return: %TRUE if focus remains inside @area as a result of this call.

function.name: gtk_cell_area_foreach
function.description:
Calls @callback for every #GtkCellRenderer in @area.
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_cell_area_foreach_alloc
function.description:
Calls @callback for every #GtkCellRenderer in @area with the allocated rectangle inside @cell_area.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkCellAreaContext for this row of data.

parameter.name: cell_area
parameter.parameter_description: the @widget relative coordinates and size for @area

parameter.name: background_area
parameter.parameter_description: the @widget relative coordinates of the background area

function.name: gtk_cell_area_get_cell_allocation
function.description:
Derives the allocation of @renderer inside @area if @area were to be renderered in @cell_area.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkCellAreaContext used to hold sizes for @area.

parameter.name: renderer
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkCellRenderer to get the allocation for

parameter.name: cell_area
parameter.parameter_description: the whole allocated area for @area in @widget for this row

parameter.name: allocation
parameter.parameter_description: where to store the allocation for @renderer

function.name: gtk_cell_area_get_cell_at_position
function.description:
Gets the #GtkCellRenderer at @x and @y coordinates inside @area and optionally returns the full cell allocation for it inside @cell_area.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkCellAreaContext used to hold sizes for @area.

parameter.name: cell_area
parameter.parameter_description: the whole allocated area for @area in @widget for this row

parameter.name: alloc_area
parameter.parameter_description: where to store the inner allocated area of the returned cell renderer, or %NULL.
