Sets the wrap width of @combo_box to be @width. The wrap width is basically the preferred number of columns when you want the popup to be layed out in a table.
Since: 2.4

function.name: gtk_combo_box_text_append
function.description:
Appends @text to the list of strings stored in @combo_box. If @id is non-%NULL then it is used as the ID of the row.
This is the same as calling gtk_combo_box_text_insert() with a position of -1.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: a string ID for this value, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_combo_box_text_append_text
function.description:
Appends @text to the list of strings stored in @combo_box.
This is the same as calling gtk_combo_box_text_insert_text() with a position of -1.
Since: 2.24

function.name: gtk_combo_box_text_get_active_text
function.description:
Returns the currently active string in @combo_box, or %NULL if none is selected. If @combo_box contains an entry, this function will return its contents (which will not necessarily be an item from the list).
Since: 2.24
function.return: a newly allocated string containing the currently active text. Must be freed with g_free().

function.name: gtk_combo_box_text_insert
function.description:
Inserts @text at @position in the list of strings stored in @combo_box. If @id is non-%NULL then it is used as the ID of the row. See #GtkComboBox:id-column.
If @position is negative then @text is appended.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: a string ID for this value, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_combo_box_text_insert_text
function.description:
Inserts @text at @position in the list of strings stored in @combo_box.
If @position is negative then @text is appended.
This is the same as calling gtk_combo_box_text_insert() with a %NULL ID string.
Since: 2.24

function.name: gtk_combo_box_text_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkComboBoxText, which is a #GtkComboBox just displaying strings.
Since: 2.24
function.return: A new #GtkComboBoxText

function.name: gtk_combo_box_text_new_with_entry
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkComboBoxText, which is a #GtkComboBox just displaying strings. The combo box created by this function has an entry.
Since: 2.24
function.return: a new #GtkComboBoxText

function.name: gtk_combo_box_text_prepend
function.description:
Prepends @text to the list of strings stored in @combo_box. If @id is non-%NULL then it is used as the ID of the row.
This is the same as calling gtk_combo_box_text_insert() with a position of 0.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: a string ID for this value, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_combo_box_text_prepend_text
function.description:
Prepends @text to the list of strings stored in @combo_box.
This is the same as calling gtk_combo_box_text_insert_text() with a position of 0.
Since: 2.24

function.name: gtk_combo_box_text_remove
function.description:
Removes the string at @position from @combo_box.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: Index of the item to remove

function.name: gtk_combo_box_text_remove_all
function.description:
Removes all the text entries from the combo box.
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_container_add
function.description: Adds @widget to @container. Typically used for simple containers such as #GtkWindow, #GtkFrame, or #GtkButton; for more complicated layout containers such as #GtkBox or #GtkGrid, this function will pick default packing parameters that may not be correct. So consider functions such as gtk_box_pack_start() and gtk_grid_attach() as an alternative to gtk_container_add() in those cases. A widget may be added to only one container at a time; you can't place the same widget inside two different containers.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: a widget to be placed inside @container

function.name: gtk_container_add_with_properties
function.description: Adds @widget to @container, setting child properties at the same time. See gtk_container_add() and gtk_container_child_set() for more details.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: a widget to be placed inside @container

parameter.name: first_prop_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the first child property to set

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: a %NULL-terminated list of property names and values, starting with @first_prop_name

function.name: gtk_container_child_get
function.description: Gets the values of one or more child properties for @child and @container.

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: a widget which is a child of @container

parameter.name: first_prop_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the first property to get

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the first property, followed optionally by more name/return location pairs, followed by %NULL

function.name: gtk_container_child_get_property
function.description: Gets the value of a child property for @child and @container.

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: a widget which is a child of @container

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the property to get

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: a location to return the value

function.name: gtk_container_child_get_valist
function.description: Gets the values of one or more child properties for @child and @container.

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: a widget which is a child of @container

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the first property to get

parameter.name: var_args
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the first property, followed optionally by more name/return location pairs, followed by %NULL

function.name: gtk_container_child_notify
function.description:
Emits a #GtkWidget::child-notify signal for the <link linkend="child-properties">child property</link> @child_property on widget.
This is an analogue of g_object_notify() for child properties.
Also see gtk_widget_child_notify().
Since: 3.2

parameter.name: child_property
parameter.parameter_description: the name of a child property installed on the class of @container

function.name: gtk_container_child_set
function.description: Sets one or more child properties for @child and @container.

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: a widget which is a child of @container

parameter.name: first_prop_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the first property to set

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: a %NULL-terminated list of property names and values, starting with @first_prop_name

function.name: gtk_container_child_set_property
function.description: Sets a child property for @child and @container.

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: a widget which is a child of @container

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the property to set

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: the value to set the property to

function.name: gtk_container_child_set_valist
function.description: Sets one or more child properties for @child and @container.

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: a widget which is a child of @container

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the first property to set

parameter.name: var_args
parameter.parameter_description: a %NULL-terminated list of property names and values, starting with @first_prop_name

function.name: gtk_container_child_type
function.description:
Returns the type of the children supported by the container.
Note that this may return %G_TYPE_NONE to indicate that no more children can be added, e.g. for a #GtkPaned which already has two children.
function.return: a #GType.

function.name: gtk_container_class_find_child_property
function.description: Finds a child property of a container class by name.

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the child property to find

function.return: the #GParamSpec of the child property or %NULL if @class has no child property with that name.

function.name: gtk_container_class_handle_border_width
function.description:
Modifies a subclass of #GtkContainerClass to automatically add and remove the border-width setting on GtkContainer. This allows the subclass to ignore the border width in its size request and allocate methods. The intent is for a subclass to invoke this in its class_init function.
gtk_container_class_handle_border_width() is necessary because it would break API too badly to make this behavior the default. So subclasses must "opt in" to the parent class handling border_width for them.

parameter.name: klass
parameter.parameter_description: the class struct of a #GtkContainer subclass

function.name: gtk_container_class_install_child_property
function.description: Installs a child property on a container class.

function.name: gtk_container_class_list_child_properties
function.description: Returns all child properties of a container class.

parameter.name: n_properties
parameter.parameter_description: location to return the number of child properties found

function.return: a newly allocated %NULL-terminated array of #GParamSpec*. The array must be freed with g_free().

function.name: gtk_container_focus_sort
function.description: Sorts @children in the correct order for focusing with direction type @direction.

parameter.name: children
parameter.parameter_description: a list of descendents of @container (they don't have to be direct children)

parameter.name: old_focus
parameter.parameter_description: widget to use for the starting position, or %NULL to determine this automatically. (Note, this argument isn't used for GTK_DIR_TAB_*, which is the only @direction we use currently, so perhaps this argument should be removed)

function.return: a copy of @children, sorted in correct focusing order, with children that aren't suitable for focusing in this direction removed.

function.name: gtk_container_forall
function.description:
Invokes @callback on each child of @container, including children that are considered "internal" (implementation details of the container). "Internal" children generally weren't added by the user of the container, but were added by the container implementation itself. Most applications should use gtk_container_foreach(), rather than gtk_container_forall().
Virtual: forall

function.name: gtk_container_foreach
function.description: Invokes @callback on each non-internal child of @container. See gtk_container_forall() for details on what constitutes an "internal" child. Most applications should use gtk_container_foreach(), rather than gtk_container_forall().

function.name: gtk_container_get_border_width
function.description: Retrieves the border width of the container. See gtk_container_set_border_width().
function.return: the current border width

function.name: gtk_container_get_children
function.description: Returns the container's non-internal children. See gtk_container_forall() for details on what constitutes an "internal" child.
function.return: a newly-allocated list of the container's non-internal children.

function.name: gtk_container_get_focus_chain
function.description: Retrieves the focus chain of the container, if one has been set explicitly. If no focus chain has been explicitly set, GTK+ computes the focus chain based on the positions of the children. In that case, GTK+ stores %NULL in @focusable_widgets and returns %FALSE.

parameter.name: focusable_widgets
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the focus chain of the container, or %NULL. You should free this list using g_list_free() when you are done with it, however no additional reference count is added to the individual widgets in the focus chain.

function.return: %TRUE if the focus chain of the container has been set explicitly.

function.name: gtk_container_get_focus_child
function.description:
Returns the current focus child widget inside @container. This is not the currently focused widget. That can be obtained by calling gtk_window_get_focus().
Since: 2.14
function.return: The child widget which will receive the focus inside @container when the @conatiner is focussed, or %NULL if none is set.

function.name: gtk_container_get_focus_hadjustment
function.description: Retrieves the horizontal focus adjustment for the container. See gtk_container_set_focus_hadjustment ().
function.return: the horizontal focus adjustment, or %NULL if none has been set.

function.name: gtk_container_get_focus_vadjustment
function.description: Retrieves the vertical focus adjustment for the container. See gtk_container_set_focus_vadjustment().
function.return: the vertical focus adjustment, or %NULL if none has been set.

function.name: gtk_container_get_path_for_child
function.description: Returns a newly created widget path representing all the widget hierarchy from the toplevel down to and including @child.
function.return: A newly created #GtkWidgetPath

function.name: gtk_container_get_resize_mode
function.description: Returns the resize mode for the container. See gtk_container_set_resize_mode ().
function.return: the current resize mode

function.name: gtk_container_propagate_draw
function.description:
When a container receives a call to the draw function, it must send synthetic #GtkWidget::draw calls to all children that don't have their own #GdkWindows. This function provides a convenient way of doing this. A container, when it receives a call to its #GtkWidget::draw function, calls gtk_container_propagate_draw() once for each child, passing in the @cr the container received.
gtk_container_propagate_draw() takes care of translating the origin of @cr, and deciding whether the draw needs to be sent to the child. It is a convenient and optimized way of getting the same effect as calling gtk_widget_draw() on the child directly.
In most cases, a container can simply either inherit the #GtkWidget::draw implementation from #GtkContainer, or do some drawing and then chain to the ::draw implementation from #GtkContainer.

parameter.name: cr
parameter.parameter_description: Cairo context as passed to the container. If you want to use @cr in container's draw function, consider using cairo_save() and cairo_restore() before calling this function.

function.name: gtk_container_remove
function.description: Removes @widget from @container. @widget must be inside @container. Note that @container will own a reference to @widget, and that this may be the last reference held; so removing a widget from its container can destroy that widget. If you want to use @widget again, you need to add a reference to it while it's not inside a container, using g_object_ref(). If you don't want to use @widget again it's usually more efficient to simply destroy it directly using gtk_widget_destroy() since this will remove it from the container and help break any circular reference count cycles.

function.name: gtk_container_resize_children
function.description: Deprecated: 3.10

function.name: gtk_container_set_border_width
function.description:
Sets the border width of the container.
The border width of a container is the amount of space to leave around the outside of the container. The only exception to this is #GtkWindow; because toplevel windows can't leave space outside, they leave the space inside. The border is added on all sides of the container. To add space to only one side, one approach is to create a #GtkAlignment widget, call gtk_widget_set_size_request() to give it a size, and place it on the side of the container as a spacer.

parameter.name: border_width
parameter.parameter_description: amount of blank space to leave <emphasis>outside</emphasis> the container. Valid values are in the range 0-65535 pixels.

function.name: gtk_container_set_focus_chain
function.description:
Sets a focus chain, overriding the one computed automatically by GTK+.
In principle each widget in the chain should be a descendant of the container, but this is not enforced by this method, since it's allowed to set the focus chain before you pack the widgets, or have a widget in the chain that isn't always packed. The necessary checks are done when the focus chain is actually traversed.

function.name: gtk_container_set_focus_child
function.description:
Sets, or unsets if @child is %NULL, the focused child of @container.
This function emits the GtkContainer::set_focus_child signal of @container. Implementations of #GtkContainer can override the default behaviour by overriding the class closure of this signal.
This is function is mostly meant to be used by widgets. Applications can use gtk_widget_grab_focus() to manualy set the focus to a specific widget.

function.name: gtk_container_set_focus_hadjustment
function.description:
Hooks up an adjustment to focus handling in a container, so when a child of the container is focused, the adjustment is scrolled to show that widget. This function sets the horizontal alignment. See gtk_scrolled_window_get_hadjustment() for a typical way of obtaining the adjustment and gtk_container_set_focus_vadjustment() for setting the vertical adjustment.
The adjustments have to be in pixel units and in the same coordinate system as the allocation for immediate children of the container.

parameter.name: adjustment
parameter.parameter_description: an adjustment which should be adjusted when the focus is moved among the descendents of @container

function.name: gtk_container_set_focus_vadjustment
function.description:
Hooks up an adjustment to focus handling in a container, so when a child of the container is focused, the adjustment is scrolled to show that widget. This function sets the vertical alignment. See gtk_scrolled_window_get_vadjustment() for a typical way of obtaining the adjustment and gtk_container_set_focus_hadjustment() for setting the horizontal adjustment.
The adjustments have to be in pixel units and in the same coordinate system as the allocation for immediate children of the container.

parameter.name: adjustment
parameter.parameter_description: an adjustment which should be adjusted when the focus is moved among the descendents of @container

function.name: gtk_container_set_reallocate_redraws
function.description:
Sets the @reallocate_redraws flag of the container to the given value.
Containers requesting reallocation redraws get automatically redrawn if any of their children changed allocation.

parameter.name: needs_redraws
parameter.parameter_description: the new value for the container's @reallocate_redraws flag

function.name: gtk_container_set_resize_mode
function.description:
Sets the resize mode for the container.
The resize mode of a container determines whether a resize request will be passed to the container's parent, queued for later execution or executed immediately.

function.name: gtk_container_unset_focus_chain
function.description: Removes a focus chain explicitly set with gtk_container_set_focus_chain().

function.name: gtk_css_provider_get_default
function.description: Returns the provider containing the style settings used as a fallback for all widgets.
function.return: The provider used for fallback styling. This memory is owned by GTK+, and you must not free it.

function.name: gtk_css_provider_get_named
function.description: Loads a theme from the usual theme paths

parameter.name: variant
parameter.parameter_description: variant to load, for example, "dark", or %NULL for the default

function.return: a #GtkCssProvider with the theme loaded. This memory is owned by GTK+, and you must not free it.

function.name: gtk_css_provider_load_from_data
function.description: Loads @data into @css_provider, making it clear any previously loaded information.

parameter.name: length

function.return: %TRUE. The return value is deprecated and %FALSE will only be returned for backwards compatibility reasons if an @error is not %NULL and a loading error occured. To track errors while loading CSS, connect to the GtkCssProvider::parsing-error signal.

function.name: gtk_css_provider_load_from_file
function.description: Loads the data contained in @file into @css_provider, making it clear any previously loaded information.

parameter.name: file
parameter.parameter_description: #GFile pointing to a file to load

function.return: %TRUE. The return value is deprecated and %FALSE will only be returned for backwards compatibility reasons if an @error is not %NULL and a loading error occured. To track errors while loading CSS, connect to the GtkCssProvider::parsing-error signal.

function.name: gtk_css_provider_load_from_path
function.description: Loads the data contained in @path into @css_provider, making it clear any previously loaded information.

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: the path of a filename to load, in the GLib filename encoding

function.return: %TRUE. The return value is deprecated and %FALSE will only be returned for backwards compatibility reasons if an @error is not %NULL and a loading error occured. To track errors while loading CSS, connect to the GtkCssProvider::parsing-error signal.

function.name: gtk_css_provider_new
function.description: Returns a newly created #GtkCssProvider.
function.return: A new #GtkCssProvider

function.name: gtk_css_provider_to_string
function.description:
Convertes the @provider into a string representation in CSS format.
Using gtk_css_provider_load_from_data() with the return value from this function on a new provider created with gtk_css_provider_new() will basicallu create a duplicate of this @provider.
Since: 3.2

parameter.name: provider
parameter.parameter_description: the provider to write to a string

function.return: a new string representing the @provider.

function.name: gtk_css_section_get_end_line
function.description:
Returns the line in the CSS document where this section end. The line number is 0-indexed, so the first line of the document will return 0. This value may change in future invocations of this function if @section is not yet parsed completely. This will for example happen in the GtkCssProvider::parsing-error signal. The end position and line may be identical to the start position and line for sections which failed to parse anything successfully.
Since: 3.2
function.return: the line number

function.name: gtk_css_section_get_end_position
function.description:
Returns the offset in bytes from the start of the current line returned via gtk_css_section_get_end_line(). This value may change in future invocations of this function if @section is not yet parsed completely. This will for example happen in the GtkCssProvider::parsing-error signal. The end position and line may be identical to the start position and line for sections which failed to parse anything successfully.
Since: 3.2
function.return: the offset in bytes from the start of the line.

function.name: gtk_css_section_get_file
function.description:
Gets the file that @section was parsed from. If no such file exists, for example because the CSS was loaded via @gtk_css_provider_load_from_data(), then %NULL is returned.
Since: 3.2
function.return: the #GFile that @section was parsed from or %NULL if @section was parsed from other data

function.name: gtk_css_section_get_parent
function.description:
Gets the parent section for the given @section. The parent section is the section that contains this @section. A special case are sections of type #GTK_CSS_SECTION_DOCUMENT. Their parent will either be %NULL if they are the original CSS document that was loaded by gtk_css_provider_load_from_file() or a section of type #GTK_CSS_SECTION_IMPORT if it was loaded with an import rule from a different file.
Since: 3.2
function.return: the parent section or %NULL if none

function.name: gtk_css_section_get_section_type
function.description:
Gets the type of information that @section describes.
Since: 3.2
function.return: the type of @section

function.name: gtk_css_section_get_start_line
function.description:
Returns the line in the CSS document where this section starts. The line number is 0-indexed, so the first line of the document will return 0.
Since: 3.2
function.return: the line number

function.name: gtk_css_section_get_start_position
function.description:
Returns the offset in bytes from the start of the current line returned via gtk_css_section_get_start_line().
Since: 3.2
function.return: the offset in bytes from the start of the line.

function.name: gtk_css_section_ref
function.description:
Increments the reference count on @section.
Since: 3.2
function.return: @section itself.

function.name: gtk_css_section_unref
function.description:
Decrements the reference count on @section, freeing the structure if the reference count reaches 0.
Since: 3.2

function.name: gtk_custom_paper_unix_dialog_new
function.description:
Creates a new custom paper dialog.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: title
parameter.parameter_description: the title of the dialog, or %NULL

parameter.name: parent
parameter.parameter_description: transient parent of the dialog, or %NULL

function.return: the new #GtkCustomPaperUnixDialog

function.name: gtk_device_grab_add
function.description:
Adds a GTK+ grab on @device, so all the events on @device and its associated pointer or keyboard (if any) are delivered to @widget. If the @block_others parameter is %TRUE, any other devices will be unable to interact with @widget during the grab.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: block_others
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to prevent other devices to interact with @widget.

function.name: gtk_device_grab_remove
function.description:
Removes a device grab from the given widget.
You have to pair calls to gtk_device_grab_add() and gtk_device_grab_remove().
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_dialog_add_action_widget
function.description: Adds an activatable widget to the action area of a #GtkDialog, connecting a signal handler that will emit the #GtkDialog::response signal on the dialog when the widget is activated. The widget is appended to the end of the dialog's action area. If you want to add a non-activatable widget, simply pack it into the @action_area field of the #GtkDialog struct.

function.name: gtk_dialog_add_button
function.description: Adds a button with the given text and sets things up so that clicking the button will emit the #GtkDialog::response signal with the given @response_id. The button is appended to the end of the dialog's action area. The button widget is returned, but usually you don't need it.
function.return: the #GtkButton widget that was added

function.name: gtk_dialog_add_buttons
function.description: Adds more buttons, same as calling gtk_dialog_add_button() repeatedly. The variable argument list should be %NULL-terminated as with gtk_dialog_new_with_buttons(). Each button must have both text and response ID.

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: response ID for first button, then more text-response_id pairs

function.name: gtk_dialog_get_action_area
function.description:
Returns the action area of @dialog.
Since: 2.14
function.return: the action area.

function.name: gtk_dialog_get_content_area
function.description:
Returns the content area of @dialog.
Since: 2.14
function.return: the content area #GtkBox.

function.name: gtk_dialog_get_response_for_widget
function.description:
Gets the response id of a widget in the action area of a dialog.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: a widget in the action area of @dialog

function.return: the response id of @widget, or %GTK_RESPONSE_NONE if @widget doesn't have a response id set.

function.name: gtk_dialog_get_widget_for_response
function.description:
Gets the widget button that uses the given response ID in the action area of a dialog.
Since: 2.20

parameter.name: response_id
parameter.parameter_description: the response ID used by the @dialog widget

function.return: the @widget button that uses the given @response_id, or %NULL.

function.name: gtk_dialog_new
function.description:
Creates a new dialog box.
Widgets should not be packed into this #GtkWindow directly, but into the @vbox and @action_area, as described above.
function.return: the new dialog as a #GtkWidget

function.name: gtk_dialog_new_with_buttons
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkDialog with title @title (or %NULL for the default title; see gtk_window_set_title()) and transient parent @parent (or %NULL for none; see gtk_window_set_transient_for()). The @flags argument can be used to make the dialog modal (#GTK_DIALOG_MODAL) and/or to have it destroyed along with its transient parent (#GTK_DIALOG_DESTROY_WITH_PARENT). After @flags, button text/response ID pairs should be listed, with a %NULL pointer ending the list. Button text can be arbitrary text. A response ID can be any positive number, or one of the values in the #GtkResponseType enumeration. If the user clicks one of these dialog buttons, #GtkDialog will emit the #GtkDialog::response signal with the corresponding response ID. If a #GtkDialog receives the #GtkWidget::delete-event signal, it will emit ::response with a response ID of #GTK_RESPONSE_DELETE_EVENT. However, destroying a dialog does not emit the ::response signal; so be careful relying on ::response when using the #GTK_DIALOG_DESTROY_WITH_PARENT flag. Buttons are from left to right, so the first button in the list will be the leftmost button in the dialog.
Here's a simple example: |[ GtkWidget *dialog = gtk_dialog_new_with_buttons ("My dialog", main_app_window, GTK_DIALOG_MODAL | GTK_DIALOG_DESTROY_WITH_PARENT, _("_OK"), GTK_RESPONSE_ACCEPT, _("_Cancel"), GTK_RESPONSE_REJECT, NULL); ]|

parameter.name: parent
parameter.parameter_description: Transient parent of the dialog, or %NULL

parameter.name: first_button_text
parameter.parameter_description: text to go in first button, or %NULL

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: response ID for first button, then additional buttons, ending with %NULL

function.return: a new #GtkDialog

function.name: gtk_dialog_response
function.description: Emits the #GtkDialog::response signal with the given response ID. Used to indicate that the user has responded to the dialog in some way; typically either you or gtk_dialog_run() will be monitoring the ::response signal and take appropriate action.

function.name: gtk_dialog_run
function.description:
Blocks in a recursive main loop until the @dialog either emits the #GtkDialog::response signal, or is destroyed. If the dialog is destroyed during the call to gtk_dialog_run(), gtk_dialog_run() returns #GTK_RESPONSE_NONE. Otherwise, it returns the response ID from the ::response signal emission.
Before entering the recursive main loop, gtk_dialog_run() calls gtk_widget_show() on the dialog for you. Note that you still need to show any children of the dialog yourself.
During gtk_dialog_run(), the default behavior of #GtkWidget::delete-event is disabled; if the dialog receives ::delete_event, it will not be destroyed as windows usually are, and gtk_dialog_run() will return #GTK_RESPONSE_DELETE_EVENT. Also, during gtk_dialog_run() the dialog will be modal. You can force gtk_dialog_run() to return at any time by calling gtk_dialog_response() to emit the ::response signal. Destroying the dialog during gtk_dialog_run() is a very bad idea, because your post-run code won't know whether the dialog was destroyed or not.
After gtk_dialog_run() returns, you are responsible for hiding or destroying the dialog if you wish to do so.
Typical usage of this function might be: |[ gint result = gtk_dialog_run (GTK_DIALOG (dialog)); switch (result) { case GTK_RESPONSE_ACCEPT: do_application_specific_something (); break; default: do_nothing_since_dialog_was_cancelled (); break; } gtk_widget_destroy (dialog); ]|
Note that even though the recursive main loop gives the effect of a modal dialog (it prevents the user from interacting with other windows in the same window group while the dialog is run), callbacks such as timeouts, IO channel watches, DND drops, etc, <emphasis>will</emphasis> be triggered during a gtk_dialog_run() call.
function.return: response ID

function.name: gtk_dialog_set_alternative_button_order

parameter.name: first_response_id
parameter.parameter_description: a response id used by one @dialog's buttons

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: a list of more response ids of @dialog's buttons, terminated by -1

function.name: gtk_dialog_set_alternative_button_order_from_array
function.description:
Sets an alternative button order. If the #GtkSettings:gtk-alternative-button-order setting is set to %TRUE, the dialog buttons are reordered according to the order of the response ids in @new_order.
See gtk_dialog_set_alternative_button_order() for more information.
This function is for use by language bindings.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: n_params
parameter.parameter_description: the number of response ids in @new_order

parameter.name: new_order
parameter.parameter_description: an array of response ids of @dialog's buttons

function.name: gtk_dialog_set_default_response
function.description: Sets the last widget in the dialog's action area with the given @response_id as the default widget for the dialog. Pressing "Enter" normally activates the default widget.

function.name: gtk_dialog_set_response_sensitive
function.description: Calls <literal>gtk_widget_set_sensitive (widget, @setting)</literal> for each widget in the dialog's action area with the given @response_id. A convenient way to sensitize/desensitize dialog buttons.

function.name: gtk_disable_setlocale
function.description:
Prevents gtk_init(), gtk_init_check(), gtk_init_with_args() and gtk_parse_args() from automatically calling <literal>setlocale (LC_ALL, "")</literal>. You would want to use this function if you wanted to set the locale for your program to something other than the user's locale, or if you wanted to set different values for different locale categories.
Most programs should not need to call this function.

function.name: gtk_distribute_natural_allocation
function.description:
Distributes @extra_space to child @sizes by bringing smaller children up to natural size first.
The remaining space will be added to the @minimum_size member of the GtkRequestedSize struct. If all sizes reach their natural size then the remaining space is returned.

parameter.name: extra_space
parameter.parameter_description: Extra space to redistribute among children after subtracting minimum sizes and any child padding from the overall allocation

parameter.name: n_requested_sizes
parameter.parameter_description: Number of requests to fit into the allocation

parameter.name: sizes
parameter.parameter_description: An array of structs with a client pointer and a minimum/natural size in the orientation of the allocation.

function.return: The remainder of @extra_space after redistributing space to @sizes.

function.name: gtk_drag_begin
function.description:
This is equivalent to gtk_drag_begin_with_coordinates(), passing -1, -1 as coordinates.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_drag_begin_with_coordinates() instead.

parameter.name: targets
parameter.parameter_description: The targets (data formats) in which the source can provide the data.

parameter.name: actions
parameter.parameter_description: A bitmask of the allowed drag actions for this drag.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: The button the user clicked to start the drag.

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: The event that triggered the start of the drag.

function.return: the context for this drag.

function.name: gtk_drag_begin_with_coordinates
function.description:
Initiates a drag on the source side. The function only needs to be used when the application is starting drags itself, and is not needed when gtk_drag_source_set() is used.
The @event is used to retrieve the timestamp that will be used internally to grab the pointer. If @event is %NULL, then %GDK_CURRENT_TIME will be used. However, you should try to pass a real event in all cases, since that can be used to get information about the drag.
Generally there are three cases when you want to start a drag by hand by calling this function:
1. During a #GtkWidget::button-press-event handler, if you want to start a drag immediately when the user presses the mouse button. Pass the @event that you have in your #GtkWidget::button-press-event handler.
2. During a #GtkWidget::motion-notify-event handler, if you want to start a drag when the mouse moves past a certain threshold distance after a button-press. Pass the @event that you have in your #GtkWidget::motion-notify-event handler.
3. During a timeout handler, if you want to start a drag after the mouse button is held down for some time. Try to save the last event that you got from the mouse, using gdk_event_copy(), and pass it to this function (remember to free the event with gdk_event_free() when you are done). If you can really not pass a real event, pass #NULL instead.

parameter.name: targets
parameter.parameter_description: The targets (data formats) in which the source can provide the data.

parameter.name: actions
parameter.parameter_description: A bitmask of the allowed drag actions for this drag.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: The button the user clicked to start the drag.

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: The event that triggered the start of the drag.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: The initial x coordinate to start dragging from, in the coordinate space of @widget. If -1 is passed, the coordinates are retrieved from @event or the current pointer position.

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: The initial y coordinate to start dragging from, in the coordinate space of @widget. If -1 is passed, the coordinates are retrieved from @event or the current pointer position.

function.return: the context for this drag.

function.name: gtk_drag_check_threshold
function.description: Checks to see if a mouse drag starting at (@start_x, @start_y) and ending at (@current_x, @current_y) has passed the GTK+ drag threshold, and thus should trigger the beginning of a drag-and-drop operation.

parameter.name: start_x
parameter.parameter_description: X coordinate of start of drag

parameter.name: start_y
parameter.parameter_description: Y coordinate of start of drag

function.return: %TRUE if the drag threshold has been passed.

function.name: gtk_drag_dest_add_image_targets
function.description:
Add the image targets supported by #GtkSelection to the target list of the drag destination. The targets are added with @info = 0. If you need another value, use gtk_target_list_add_image_targets() and gtk_drag_dest_set_target_list().
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_drag_dest_add_text_targets
function.description:
Add the text targets supported by #GtkSelection to the target list of the drag destination. The targets are added with @info = 0. If you need another value, use gtk_target_list_add_text_targets() and gtk_drag_dest_set_target_list().
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_drag_dest_add_uri_targets
function.description:
Add the URI targets supported by #GtkSelection to the target list of the drag destination. The targets are added with @info = 0. If you need another value, use gtk_target_list_add_uri_targets() and gtk_drag_dest_set_target_list().
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_drag_dest_find_target
function.description: Looks for a match between the supported targets of @context and the @dest_target_list, returning the first matching target, otherwise returning %GDK_NONE. @dest_target_list should usually be the return value from gtk_drag_dest_get_target_list(), but some widgets may have different valid targets for different parts of the widget; in that case, they will have to implement a drag_motion handler that passes the correct target list to this function.

parameter.name: target_list
parameter.parameter_description: list of droppable targets, or %NULL to use gtk_drag_dest_get_target_list (@widget).

function.return: first target that the source offers and the dest can accept, or %GDK_NONE

function.name: gtk_drag_dest_get_target_list
function.description: Returns the list of targets this widget can accept from drag-and-drop.
function.return: the #GtkTargetList, or %NULL if none

function.name: gtk_drag_dest_get_track_motion
function.description:
Returns whether the widget has been configured to always emit #GtkWidget::drag-motion signals.
Since: 2.10
function.return: %TRUE if the widget always emits #GtkWidget::drag-motion events

function.name: gtk_drag_dest_set
function.description:
Sets a widget as a potential drop destination, and adds default behaviors.
The default behaviors listed in @flags have an effect similar to installing default handlers for the widget's drag-and-drop signals (#GtkWidget::drag-motion, #GtkWidget::drag-drop, ...). They all exist for convenience. When passing #GTK_DEST_DEFAULT_ALL for instance it is sufficient to connect to the widget's #GtkWidget::drag-data-received signal to get primitive, but consistent drag-and-drop support.
Things become more complicated when you try to preview the dragged data, as described in the documentation for #GtkWidget::drag-motion. The default behaviors described by @flags make some assumptions, that can conflict with your own signal handlers. For instance #GTK_DEST_DEFAULT_DROP causes invokations of gdk_drag_status() in the context of #GtkWidget::drag-motion, and invokations of gtk_drag_finish() in #GtkWidget::drag-data-received. Especially the later is dramatic, when your own #GtkWidget::drag-motion handler calls gtk_drag_get_data() to inspect the dragged data.
There's no way to set a default action here, you can use the #GtkWidget::drag-motion callback for that. Here's an example which selects the action to use depending on whether the control key is pressed or not: |[ static void drag_motion (GtkWidget *widget, GdkDragContext *context, gint x, gint y, guint time) { GdkModifierType mask;
gdk_window_get_pointer (gtk_widget_get_window (widget), NULL, NULL, &mask); if (mask & GDK_CONTROL_MASK) gdk_drag_status (context, GDK_ACTION_COPY, time); else gdk_drag_status (context, GDK_ACTION_MOVE, time); } ]|

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: which types of default drag behavior to use

parameter.name: targets
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to an array of #GtkTargetEntry<!-- -->s indicating the drop types that this @widget will accept, or %NULL. Later you can access the list with gtk_drag_dest_get_target_list() and gtk_drag_dest_find_target().

parameter.name: actions
parameter.parameter_description: a bitmask of possible actions for a drop onto this @widget.

function.name: gtk_drag_dest_set_proxy
function.description: Sets this widget as a proxy for drops to another window.

parameter.name: proxy_window
parameter.parameter_description: the window to which to forward drag events

parameter.name: protocol
parameter.parameter_description: the drag protocol which the @proxy_window accepts (You can use gdk_drag_get_protocol() to determine this)

parameter.name: use_coordinates
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE, send the same coordinates to the destination, because it is an embedded subwindow.

function.name: gtk_drag_dest_set_target_list
function.description: Sets the target types that this widget can accept from drag-and-drop. The widget must first be made into a drag destination with gtk_drag_dest_set().

parameter.name: target_list
parameter.parameter_description: list of droppable targets, or %NULL for none

function.name: gtk_drag_dest_set_track_motion
function.description:
Tells the widget to emit #GtkWidget::drag-motion and #GtkWidget::drag-leave events regardless of the targets and the %GTK_DEST_DEFAULT_MOTION flag.
This may be used when a widget wants to do generic actions regardless of the targets that the source offers.
Since: 2.10

function.name: gtk_drag_dest_unset
function.description: Clears information about a drop destination set with gtk_drag_dest_set(). The widget will no longer receive notification of drags.

function.name: gtk_drag_finish
function.description: Informs the drag source that the drop is finished, and that the data of the drag will no longer be required.

parameter.name: success
parameter.parameter_description: a flag indicating whether the drop was successful

parameter.name: del
parameter.parameter_description: a flag indicating whether the source should delete the original data. (This should be %TRUE for a move)

function.name: gtk_drag_get_data
function.description: Gets the data associated with a drag. When the data is received or the retrieval fails, GTK+ will emit a #GtkWidget::drag-data-received signal. Failure of the retrieval is indicated by the length field of the @selection_data signal parameter being negative. However, when gtk_drag_get_data() is called implicitely because the %GTK_DEST_DEFAULT_DROP was set, then the widget will not receive notification of failed drops.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the widget that will receive the #GtkWidget::drag-data-received signal.

parameter.name: target
parameter.parameter_description: the target (form of the data) to retrieve.

parameter.name: time_
parameter.parameter_description: a timestamp for retrieving the data. This will generally be the time received in a #GtkWidget::drag-motion" or #GtkWidget::drag-drop" signal.

function.name: gtk_drag_get_source_widget
function.description: Determines the source widget for a drag.
function.return: if the drag is occurring within a single application, a pointer to the source widget. Otherwise, %NULL.

function.name: gtk_drag_highlight
function.description: Draws a highlight around a widget. This will attach handlers to #GtkWidget::draw, so the highlight will continue to be displayed until gtk_drag_unhighlight() is called.

function.name: gtk_drag_set_icon_default
function.description: Sets the icon for a particular drag to the default icon.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the context for a drag. (This must be called with a context for the source side of a drag)

function.name: gtk_drag_set_icon_gicon
function.description:
Sets the icon for a given drag from the given @icon. See the documentation for gtk_drag_set_icon_name() for more details about using icons in drag and drop.
Since: 3.2

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the context for a drag. (This must be called with a context for the source side of a drag)

parameter.name: hot_x
parameter.parameter_description: the X offset of the hotspot within the icon

parameter.name: hot_y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y offset of the hotspot within the icon

function.name: gtk_drag_set_icon_name
function.description:
Sets the icon for a given drag from a named themed icon. See the docs for #GtkIconTheme for more details. Note that the size of the icon depends on the icon theme (the icon is loaded at the symbolic size #GTK_ICON_SIZE_DND), thus @hot_x and @hot_y have to be used with care.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the context for a drag. (This must be called with a context for the source side of a drag)

parameter.name: hot_x
parameter.parameter_description: the X offset of the hotspot within the icon

parameter.name: hot_y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y offset of the hotspot within the icon

function.name: gtk_drag_set_icon_pixbuf
function.description: Sets @pixbuf as the icon for a given drag.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the context for a drag. (This must be called with a context for the source side of a drag)

parameter.name: pixbuf
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkPixbuf to use as the drag icon.

parameter.name: hot_x
parameter.parameter_description: the X offset within @widget of the hotspot.

parameter.name: hot_y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y offset within @widget of the hotspot.

function.name: gtk_drag_set_icon_stock
function.description:
Sets the icon for a given drag from a stock ID.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_drag_set_icon_name() instead.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the context for a drag. (This must be called with a context for the source side of a drag)

parameter.name: stock_id
parameter.parameter_description: the ID of the stock icon to use for the drag.

parameter.name: hot_x
parameter.parameter_description: the X offset within the icon of the hotspot.

parameter.name: hot_y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y offset within the icon of the hotspot.

function.name: gtk_drag_set_icon_surface
function.description:
Sets @surface as the icon for a given drag. GTK+ retains references for the arguments, and will release them when they are no longer needed.
To position the surface relative to the mouse, use cairo_surface_set_device_offset() on @surface. The mouse cursor will be positioned at the (0,0) coordinate of the surface.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the context for a drag. (This must be called with a context for the source side of a drag)

parameter.name: surface
parameter.parameter_description: the surface to use as icon

function.name: gtk_drag_set_icon_widget
function.description: Changes the icon for a widget to a given widget. GTK+ will not destroy the icon, so if you don't want it to persist, you should connect to the "drag-end" signal and destroy it yourself.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the context for a drag. (This must be called with a context for the source side of a drag)

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: a toplevel window to use as an icon.

parameter.name: hot_x
parameter.parameter_description: the X offset within @widget of the hotspot.

parameter.name: hot_y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y offset within @widget of the hotspot.

function.name: gtk_drag_source_add_image_targets
function.description:
Add the writable image targets supported by #GtkSelection to the target list of the drag source. The targets are added with @info = 0. If you need another value, use gtk_target_list_add_image_targets() and gtk_drag_source_set_target_list().
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkWidget that's is a drag source

function.name: gtk_drag_source_add_text_targets
function.description:
Add the text targets supported by #GtkSelection to the target list of the drag source. The targets are added with @info = 0. If you need another value, use gtk_target_list_add_text_targets() and gtk_drag_source_set_target_list().
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkWidget that's is a drag source

function.name: gtk_drag_source_add_uri_targets
function.description:
Add the URI targets supported by #GtkSelection to the target list of the drag source. The targets are added with @info = 0. If you need another value, use gtk_target_list_add_uri_targets() and gtk_drag_source_set_target_list().
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkWidget that's is a drag source

function.name: gtk_drag_source_get_target_list
function.description:
Gets the list of targets this widget can provide for drag-and-drop.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the #GtkTargetList, or %NULL if none

function.name: gtk_drag_source_set
function.description: Sets up a widget so that GTK+ will start a drag operation when the user clicks and drags on the widget. The widget must have a window.

parameter.name: start_button_mask
parameter.parameter_description: the bitmask of buttons that can start the drag

parameter.name: targets
parameter.parameter_description: the table of targets that the drag will support, may be %NULL

parameter.name: actions
parameter.parameter_description: the bitmask of possible actions for a drag from this widget

function.name: gtk_drag_source_set_icon_gicon
function.description:
Sets the icon that will be used for drags from a particular source to @icon. See the docs for #GtkIconTheme for more details.
Since: 3.2

function.name: gtk_drag_source_set_icon_name
function.description:
Sets the icon that will be used for drags from a particular source to a themed icon. See the docs for #GtkIconTheme for more details.
Since: 2.8

function.name: gtk_drag_source_set_icon_pixbuf
function.description: Sets the icon that will be used for drags from a particular widget from a #GdkPixbuf. GTK+ retains a reference for @pixbuf and will release it when it is no longer needed.

function.name: gtk_drag_source_set_icon_stock
function.description:
Sets the icon that will be used for drags from a particular source to a stock icon.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_drag_source_set_icon_name() instead.

parameter.name: stock_id
parameter.parameter_description: the ID of the stock icon to use

function.name: gtk_drag_source_set_target_list
function.description:
Changes the target types that this widget offers for drag-and-drop. The widget must first be made into a drag source with gtk_drag_source_set().
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: target_list
parameter.parameter_description: list of draggable targets, or %NULL for none

function.name: gtk_drag_source_unset
function.description: Undoes the effects of gtk_drag_source_set().

function.name: gtk_drag_unhighlight
function.description: Removes a highlight set by gtk_drag_highlight() from a widget.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: a widget to remove the highlight from.

function.name: gtk_drag_update
function.description: Updates the status of the drag; called when the cursor moves or the modifier changes

function.name: gtk_draw_insertion_cursor
function.description:
Draws a text caret on @cr at @location. This is not a style function but merely a convenience function for drawing the standard cursor shape.
Since: 3.0 Deprecated: 3.4: Use gtk_render_insertion_cursor() instead.

parameter.name: location
parameter.parameter_description: location where to draw the cursor (@location->width is ignored)

parameter.name: is_primary
parameter.parameter_description: if the cursor should be the primary cursor color.

parameter.name: direction
parameter.parameter_description: whether the cursor is left-to-right or right-to-left. Should never be #GTK_TEXT_DIR_NONE

parameter.name: draw_arrow
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to draw a directional arrow on the cursor. Should be %FALSE unless the cursor is split.

function.name: gtk_drawing_area_new
function.description: Creates a new drawing area.
function.return: a new #GtkDrawingArea

function.name: gtk_editable_copy_clipboard
function.description: Copies the contents of the currently selected content in the editable and puts it on the clipboard.

function.name: gtk_editable_cut_clipboard
function.description: Removes the contents of the currently selected content in the editable and puts it on the clipboard.

function.name: gtk_editable_delete_selection
function.description: Deletes the currently selected text of the editable. This call doesn't do anything if there is no selected text.

function.name: gtk_editable_delete_text
function.description:
Deletes a sequence of characters. The characters that are deleted are those characters at positions from @start_pos up to, but not including @end_pos. If @end_pos is negative, then the characters deleted are those from @start_pos to the end of the text.
Note that the positions are specified in characters, not bytes.
Virtual: do_delete_text

function.name: gtk_editable_get_chars
function.description:
Retrieves a sequence of characters. The characters that are retrieved are those characters at positions from @start_pos up to, but not including @end_pos. If @end_pos is negative, then the characters retrieved are those characters from @start_pos to the end of the text.
Note that positions are specified in characters, not bytes.
function.return: a pointer to the contents of the widget as a string. This string is allocated by the #GtkEditable implementation and should be freed by the caller.

function.name: gtk_editable_get_editable
function.description: Retrieves whether @editable is editable. See gtk_editable_set_editable().
function.return: %TRUE if @editable is editable.

function.name: gtk_editable_get_position
function.description:
Retrieves the current position of the cursor relative to the start of the content of the editable.
Note that this position is in characters, not in bytes.
function.return: the cursor position

function.name: gtk_editable_get_selection_bounds
function.description:
Retrieves the selection bound of the editable. start_pos will be filled with the start of the selection and @end_pos with end. If no text was selected both will be identical and %FALSE will be returned.
Note that positions are specified in characters, not bytes.

parameter.name: start_pos
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the starting position, or %NULL

parameter.name: end_pos
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the end position, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if an area is selected, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_editable_insert_text
function.description:
Inserts @new_text_length bytes of @new_text into the contents of the widget, at position @position.
Note that the position is in characters, not in bytes. The function updates @position to point after the newly inserted text.
Virtual: do_insert_text

parameter.name: new_text_length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of the text in bytes, or -1

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: location of the position text will be inserted at

function.name: gtk_editable_paste_clipboard
function.description: Pastes the content of the clipboard to the current position of the cursor in the editable.

function.name: gtk_editable_select_region
function.description:
Selects a region of text. The characters that are selected are those characters at positions from @start_pos up to, but not including @end_pos. If @end_pos is negative, then the characters selected are those characters from @start_pos to the end of the text.
Note that positions are specified in characters, not bytes.
Virtual: set_selection_bounds

function.name: gtk_editable_set_editable
function.description: Determines if the user can edit the text in the editable widget or not.

parameter.name: is_editable
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the user is allowed to edit the text in the widget

function.name: gtk_editable_set_position
function.description:
Sets the cursor position in the editable to the given value.
The cursor is displayed before the character with the given (base 0) index in the contents of the editable. The value must be less than or equal to the number of characters in the editable. A value of -1 indicates that the position should be set after the last character of the editable. Note that @position is in characters, not in bytes.

function.name: gtk_entry_buffer_delete_text
function.description:
Deletes a sequence of characters from the buffer. @n_chars characters are deleted starting at @position. If @n_chars is negative, then all characters until the end of the text are deleted.
If @position or @n_chars are out of bounds, then they are coerced to sane values.
Note that the positions are specified in characters, not bytes.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: position at which to delete text

function.return: The number of characters deleted.

function.name: gtk_entry_buffer_emit_deleted_text
function.description:
Used when subclassing #GtkEntryBuffer
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: position at which text was deleted

function.name: gtk_entry_buffer_emit_inserted_text
function.description:
Used when subclassing #GtkEntryBuffer
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: position at which text was inserted

function.name: gtk_entry_buffer_get_bytes
function.description:
Retrieves the length in bytes of the buffer. See gtk_entry_buffer_get_length().
Since: 2.18
function.return: The byte length of the buffer.

function.name: gtk_entry_buffer_get_length
function.description:
Retrieves the length in characters of the buffer.
Since: 2.18
function.return: The number of characters in the buffer.

function.name: gtk_entry_buffer_get_max_length
function.return: the maximum allowed number of characters in #GtkEntryBuffer, or 0 if there is no maximum.

function.name: gtk_entry_buffer_get_text
function.description:
Retrieves the contents of the buffer.
The memory pointer returned by this call will not change unless this object emits a signal, or is finalized.
Since: 2.18
function.return: a pointer to the contents of the widget as a string. This string points to internally allocated storage in the buffer and must not be freed, modified or stored.

function.name: gtk_entry_buffer_insert_text
function.description:
Inserts @n_chars characters of @chars into the contents of the buffer, at position @position.
If @n_chars is negative, then characters from chars will be inserted until a null-terminator is found. If @position or @n_chars are out of bounds, or the maximum buffer text length is exceeded, then they are coerced to sane values.
Note that the position and length are in characters, not in bytes.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position at which to insert text.

parameter.name: chars
parameter.parameter_description: the text to insert into the buffer.

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: the length of the text in characters, or -1

function.return: The number of characters actually inserted.

function.name: gtk_entry_buffer_new
function.description:
Create a new GtkEntryBuffer object.
Optionally, specify initial text to set in the buffer.
Since: 2.18
function.return: A new GtkEntryBuffer object.

function.name: gtk_entry_buffer_set_max_length
function.description:
Sets the maximum allowed length of the contents of the buffer. If the current contents are longer than the given length, then they will be truncated to fit.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: max_length
parameter.parameter_description: the maximum length of the entry buffer, or 0 for no maximum. (other than the maximum length of entries.) The value passed in will be clamped to the range 0-65536.

function.name: gtk_entry_buffer_set_text
function.description:
Sets the text in the buffer.
This is roughly equivalent to calling gtk_entry_buffer_delete_text() and gtk_entry_buffer_insert_text().
Note that @n_chars is in characters, not in bytes.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: the number of characters in @text, or -1

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_complete
function.description:
Requests a completion operation, or in other words a refiltering of the current list with completions, using the current key. The completion list view will be updated accordingly.
Since: 2.4

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_compute_prefix
function.description:
Computes the common prefix that is shared by all rows in @completion that start with @key. If no row matches @key, %NULL will be returned. Note that a text column must have been set for this function to work, see gtk_entry_completion_set_text_column() for details.
Since: 3.4
function.return: The common prefix all rows starting with @key or %NULL if no row matches @key.

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_delete_action
function.description:
Deletes the action at @index_ from @completion's action list.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the item to delete

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_get_completion_prefix
function.description:
Get the original text entered by the user that triggered the completion or %NULL if there's no completion ongoing.
Since: 2.12
function.return: the prefix for the current completion

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_get_entry
function.description:
Gets the entry @completion has been attached to.
Since: 2.4
function.return: The entry @completion has been attached to

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_get_inline_completion
function.description:
Returns whether the common prefix of the possible completions should be automatically inserted in the entry.
Since: 2.6
function.return: %TRUE if inline completion is turned on

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_get_inline_selection
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if inline-selection mode is turned on.
Since: 2.12
function.return: %TRUE if inline-selection mode is on

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_get_minimum_key_length
function.description:
Returns the minimum key length as set for @completion.
Since: 2.4
function.return: The currently used minimum key length

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_get_model
function.description:
Returns the model the #GtkEntryCompletion is using as data source. Returns %NULL if the model is unset.
Since: 2.4
function.return: A #GtkTreeModel, or %NULL if none is currently being used

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_get_popup_completion
function.description:
Returns whether the completions should be presented in a popup window.
Since: 2.6
function.return: %TRUE if popup completion is turned on

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_get_popup_set_width
function.description:
Returns whether the completion popup window will be resized to the width of the entry.
Since: 2.8
function.return: %TRUE if the popup window will be resized to the width of the entry

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_get_popup_single_match
function.description:
Returns whether the completion popup window will appear even if there is only a single match.
Since: 2.8
function.return: %TRUE if the popup window will appear regardless of the number of matches

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_get_text_column
function.description:
Returns the column in the model of @completion to get strings from.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the column containing the strings

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_insert_action_markup
function.description:
Inserts an action in @completion's action item list at position @index_ with markup @markup.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the item to insert

parameter.name: markup
parameter.parameter_description: markup of the item to insert

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_insert_action_text
function.description:
Inserts an action in @completion's action item list at position @index_ with text @text. If you want the action item to have markup, use gtk_entry_completion_insert_action_markup().
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the item to insert

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: text of the item to insert

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_insert_prefix
function.description:
Requests a prefix insertion.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkEntryCompletion object.
Since: 2.4
function.return: A newly created #GtkEntryCompletion object

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_new_with_area
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkEntryCompletion object using the specified @area to layout cells in the underlying #GtkTreeViewColumn for the drop-down menu.
Since: 3.0
function.return: A newly created #GtkEntryCompletion object

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_set_inline_completion
function.description:
Sets whether the common prefix of the possible completions should be automatically inserted in the entry.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_set_inline_selection
function.description:
Sets whether it is possible to cycle through the possible completions inside the entry.
Since: 2.12

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_set_match_func
function.description:
Sets the match function for @completion to be @func. The match function is used to determine if a row should or should not be in the completion list.
Since: 2.4

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_set_minimum_key_length
function.description:
Requires the length of the search key for @completion to be at least @length. This is useful for long lists, where completing using a small key takes a lot of time and will come up with meaningless results anyway (ie, a too large dataset).
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the minimum length of the key in order to start completing

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_set_model
function.description:
Sets the model for a #GtkEntryCompletion. If @completion already has a model set, it will remove it before setting the new model. If model is %NULL, then it will unset the model.
Since: 2.4

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_set_popup_completion
function.description:
Sets whether the completions should be presented in a popup window.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_set_popup_set_width
function.description:
Sets whether the completion popup window will be resized to be the same width as the entry.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: popup_set_width
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to make the width of the popup the same as the entry

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_set_popup_single_match
function.description:
Sets whether the completion popup window will appear even if there is only a single match. You may want to set this to %FALSE if you are using <link linkend="GtkEntryCompletion--inline-completion">inline completion</link>.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: popup_single_match
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the popup should appear even for a single match

function.name: gtk_entry_completion_set_text_column
function.description:
Convenience function for setting up the most used case of this code: a completion list with just strings. This function will set up @completion to have a list displaying all (and just) strings in the completion list, and to get those strings from @column in the model of @completion.
This functions creates and adds a #GtkCellRendererText for the selected column. If you need to set the text column, but don't want the cell renderer, use g_object_set() to set the #GtkEntryCompletion:text-column property directly.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: column
parameter.parameter_description: the column in the model of @completion to get strings from

function.name: gtk_entry_get_activates_default
function.description: Retrieves the value set by gtk_entry_set_activates_default().
function.return: %TRUE if the entry will activate the default widget

function.name: gtk_entry_get_alignment
function.description:
Gets the value set by gtk_entry_set_alignment().
Since: 2.4
function.return: the alignment

function.name: gtk_entry_get_attributes
function.description:
Gets the attribute list that was set on the entry using gtk_entry_set_attributes(), if any.
Since: 3.6
function.return: the attribute list, or %NULL if none was set.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_buffer
function.description:
Get the #GtkEntryBuffer object which holds the text for this widget.
Since: 2.18
function.return: A #GtkEntryBuffer object.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_completion
function.description:
Returns the auxiliary completion object currently in use by @entry.
Since: 2.4
function.return: The auxiliary completion object currently in use by @entry.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_current_icon_drag_source
function.description:
Returns the index of the icon which is the source of the current DND operation, or -1.
This function is meant to be used in a #GtkWidget::drag-data-get callback.
Since: 2.16
function.return: index of the icon which is the source of the current DND operation, or -1.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_cursor_hadjustment
function.description:
Retrieves the horizontal cursor adjustment for the entry. See gtk_entry_set_cursor_hadjustment().
Since: 2.12
function.return: the horizontal cursor adjustment, or %NULL if none has been set.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_has_frame
function.description: Gets the value set by gtk_entry_set_has_frame().
function.return: whether the entry has a beveled frame

function.name: gtk_entry_get_icon_activatable
function.description:
Returns whether the icon is activatable.
Since: 2.16
function.return: %TRUE if the icon is activatable.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_icon_area
function.description:
Gets the area where entry's icon at @icon_pos is drawn. This function is useful when drawing something to the entry in a draw callback.
If the entry is not realized or has no icon at the given position, @icon_area is filled with zeros.
See also gtk_entry_get_text_area()
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: icon_area
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the icon's area

function.name: gtk_entry_get_icon_at_pos
function.description:
Finds the icon at the given position and return its index. The position's coordinates are relative to the @entry's top left corner. If @x, @y doesn't lie inside an icon, -1 is returned. This function is intended for use in a #GtkWidget::query-tooltip signal handler.
Since: 2.16

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the position to find

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the position to find

function.return: the index of the icon at the given position, or -1

function.name: gtk_entry_get_icon_gicon
function.description:
Retrieves the #GIcon used for the icon, or %NULL if there is no icon or if the icon was set by some other method (e.g., by stock, pixbuf, or icon name).
Since: 2.16
function.return: A #GIcon, or %NULL if no icon is set or if the icon is not a #GIcon

function.name: gtk_entry_get_icon_name
function.description:
Retrieves the icon name used for the icon, or %NULL if there is no icon or if the icon was set by some other method (e.g., by pixbuf, stock or gicon).
Since: 2.16
function.return: An icon name, or %NULL if no icon is set or if the icon wasn't set from an icon name

function.name: gtk_entry_get_icon_pixbuf
function.description:
Retrieves the image used for the icon.
Unlike the other methods of setting and getting icon data, this method will work regardless of whether the icon was set using a #GdkPixbuf, a #GIcon, a stock item, or an icon name.
Since: 2.16
function.return: A #GdkPixbuf, or %NULL if no icon is set for this position.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_icon_sensitive
function.description:
Returns whether the icon appears sensitive or insensitive.
Since: 2.16
function.return: %TRUE if the icon is sensitive.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_icon_stock
function.description:
Retrieves the stock id used for the icon, or %NULL if there is no icon or if the icon was set by some other method (e.g., by pixbuf, icon name or gicon).
Since: 2.16
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_entry_get_icon_name() instead.
function.return: A stock id, or %NULL if no icon is set or if the icon wasn't set from a stock id

function.name: gtk_entry_get_icon_storage_type
function.description:
Gets the type of representation being used by the icon to store image data. If the icon has no image data, the return value will be %GTK_IMAGE_EMPTY.
Since: 2.16
function.return: image representation being used

function.name: gtk_entry_get_icon_tooltip_markup
function.description:
Gets the contents of the tooltip on the icon at the specified position in @entry.
Since: 2.16
function.return: the tooltip text, or %NULL. Free the returned string with g_free() when done.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_icon_tooltip_text
function.description:
Gets the contents of the tooltip on the icon at the specified position in @entry.
Since: 2.16
function.return: the tooltip text, or %NULL. Free the returned string with g_free() when done.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_inner_border
function.description:
This function returns the entry's #GtkEntry:inner-border property. See gtk_entry_set_inner_border() for more information.
Since: 2.10
Deprecated: 3.4: Use the standard border and padding CSS properties (through objects like #GtkStyleContext and #GtkCssProvider); the value returned by this function is ignored by #GtkEntry.
function.return: the entry's #GtkBorder, or %NULL if none was set.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_input_hints
function.description:
Gets the value of the #GtkEntry:input-hints property.
Since: 3.6

function.name: gtk_entry_get_input_purpose
function.description:
Gets the value of the #GtkEntry:input-purpose property.
Since: 3.6

function.name: gtk_entry_get_invisible_char
function.description: Retrieves the character displayed in place of the real characters for entries with visibility set to false. See gtk_entry_set_invisible_char().
function.return: the current invisible char, or 0, if the entry does not show invisible text at all.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_layout
function.description:
Gets the #PangoLayout used to display the entry. The layout is useful to e.g. convert text positions to pixel positions, in combination with gtk_entry_get_layout_offsets(). The returned layout is owned by the entry and must not be modified or freed by the caller.
Keep in mind that the layout text may contain a preedit string, so gtk_entry_layout_index_to_text_index() and gtk_entry_text_index_to_layout_index() are needed to convert byte indices in the layout to byte indices in the entry contents.
function.return: the #PangoLayout for this entry

function.name: gtk_entry_get_layout_offsets
function.description:
Obtains the position of the #PangoLayout used to render text in the entry, in widget coordinates. Useful if you want to line up the text in an entry with some other text, e.g. when using the entry to implement editable cells in a sheet widget.
Also useful to convert mouse events into coordinates inside the #PangoLayout, e.g. to take some action if some part of the entry text is clicked.
Note that as the user scrolls around in the entry the offsets will change; you'll need to connect to the "notify::scroll-offset" signal to track this. Remember when using the #PangoLayout functions you need to convert to and from pixels using PANGO_PIXELS() or #PANGO_SCALE.
Keep in mind that the layout text may contain a preedit string, so gtk_entry_layout_index_to_text_index() and gtk_entry_text_index_to_layout_index() are needed to convert byte indices in the layout to byte indices in the entry contents.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: location to store X offset of layout, or %NULL

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: location to store Y offset of layout, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_entry_get_max_length
function.return: the maximum allowed number of characters in #GtkEntry, or 0 if there is no maximum.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_overwrite_mode
function.description:
Gets the value set by gtk_entry_set_overwrite_mode().
Since: 2.14
function.return: whether the text is overwritten when typing.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_placeholder_text
function.description:
Retrieves the text that will be displayed when @entry is empty and unfocused
Since: 3.2
function.return: a pointer to the placeholder text as a string. This string points to internally allocated storage in the widget and must not be freed, modified or stored.

function.name: gtk_entry_get_progress_fraction
function.description:
Returns the current fraction of the task that's been completed. See gtk_entry_set_progress_fraction().
Since: 2.16
function.return: a fraction from 0.0 to 1.0

function.name: gtk_entry_get_progress_pulse_step
function.description:
Retrieves the pulse step set with gtk_entry_set_progress_pulse_step().
Since: 2.16
function.return: a fraction from 0.0 to 1.0

function.name: gtk_entry_get_tabs
function.description:
