function.name: gtk_handle_box_get_handle_position
function.description:
Gets the handle position of the handle box. See gtk_handle_box_set_handle_position().
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkHandleBox has been deprecated.
function.return: the current handle position.

function.name: gtk_handle_box_get_shadow_type
function.description:
Gets the type of shadow drawn around the handle box. See gtk_handle_box_set_shadow_type().
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkHandleBox has been deprecated.
function.return: the type of shadow currently drawn around the handle box.

function.name: gtk_handle_box_get_snap_edge
function.description:
Gets the edge used for determining reattachment of the handle box. See gtk_handle_box_set_snap_edge().
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkHandleBox has been deprecated.
function.return: the edge used for determining reattachment, or (GtkPositionType)-1 if this is determined (as per default) from the handle position.

function.name: gtk_handle_box_new
function.description:
Create a new handle box.
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkHandleBox has been deprecated.
function.return: a new #GtkHandleBox.

function.name: gtk_handle_box_set_handle_position
function.description:
Sets the side of the handlebox where the handle is drawn.
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkHandleBox has been deprecated.

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the side of the handlebox where the handle should be drawn.

function.name: gtk_handle_box_set_shadow_type
function.description:
Sets the type of shadow to be drawn around the border of the handle box.
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkHandleBox has been deprecated.

function.name: gtk_handle_box_set_snap_edge
function.description:
Sets the snap edge of a handlebox. The snap edge is the edge of the detached child that must be aligned with the corresponding edge of the "ghost" left behind when the child was detached to reattach the torn-off window. Usually, the snap edge should be chosen so that it stays in the same place on the screen when the handlebox is torn off.
If the snap edge is not set, then an appropriate value will be guessed from the handle position. If the handle position is %GTK_POS_RIGHT or %GTK_POS_LEFT, then the snap edge will be %GTK_POS_TOP, otherwise it will be %GTK_POS_LEFT.
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkHandleBox has been deprecated.

parameter.name: edge
parameter.parameter_description: the snap edge, or -1 to unset the value; in which case GTK+ will try to guess an appropriate value in the future.

function.name: gtk_hbox_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkHBox.
Deprecated: 3.2: You can use gtk_box_new() with %GTK_ORIENTATION_HORIZONTAL instead, which is a quick and easy change. But the recommendation is to switch to #GtkGrid, since #GtkBox is going to go away eventually. See <xref linkend="gtk-migrating-GtkGrid"/>.

parameter.name: homogeneous
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if all children are to be given equal space allotments.

parameter.name: spacing
parameter.parameter_description: the number of pixels to place by default between children.

function.return: a new #GtkHBox.

function.name: gtk_hbutton_box_new
function.description:
Creates a new horizontal button box.
Deprecated: 3.2: Use gtk_button_box_new() with %GTK_ORIENTATION_HORIZONTAL instead
function.return: a new button box #GtkWidget.

function.name: gtk_header_bar_get_custom_title
function.description:
Retrieves the custom title widget of the header. See gtk_header_bar_set_custom_title().
Since: 3.10
function.return: the custom title widget of the header, or %NULL if none has been set explicitely.

function.name: gtk_header_bar_get_show_close_button
function.description:
Returns whether this header bar shows a window close button.
Since: 3.10
function.return: %TRUE if a window close button is shown

function.name: gtk_header_bar_get_subtitle
function.description:
Retrieves the subtitle of the header. See gtk_header_bar_set_subtitle().
Since: 3.10
function.return: the subtitle of the header, or %NULL if none has been set explicitely. The returned string is owned by the widget and must not be modified or freed.

function.name: gtk_header_bar_get_title
function.description:
Retrieves the title of the header. See gtk_header_bar_set_title().
Since: 3.10
function.return: the title of the header, or %NULL if none has been set explicitely. The returned string is owned by the widget and must not be modified or freed.

function.name: gtk_header_bar_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkHeaderBar widget.
Since: 3.10
function.return: a new #GtkHeaderBar

function.name: gtk_header_bar_pack_end
function.description:
Adds @child to @box, packed with reference to the end of the @box.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_header_bar_pack_start
function.description:
Adds @child to @box, packed with reference to the start of the @box.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_header_bar_set_custom_title
function.description:
Sets a custom title for the #GtkHeaderBar. The title should help a user identify the current view. This supercedes any title set by gtk_header_bar_set_title() or gtk_header_bar_set_subtitle(). You should set the custom title to %NULL, for the header title label to be visible again.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: title_widget
parameter.parameter_description: a custom widget to use for a title

function.name: gtk_header_bar_set_show_close_button
function.description:
Sets whether this header bar shows a window close button.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: setting
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to show a window close button

function.name: gtk_header_bar_set_subtitle
function.description:
Sets the subtitle of the #GtkHeaderBar. The title should give a user an additional detail to help him identify the current view.
Note that GtkHeaderBar always reserves room for the subtitle, even if none is currently set. If this is not desired, use gtk_header_bar_set_custom_title().
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_header_bar_set_title
function.description:
Sets the title of the #GtkHeaderBar. The title should help a user identify the current view. A good title should not include the application name.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_hpaned_new
function.description:
Create a new #GtkHPaned
Deprecated: 3.2: Use gtk_paned_new() with %GTK_ORIENTATION_HORIZONTAL instead
function.return: the new #GtkHPaned

function.name: gtk_hscale_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkHScale.
Deprecated: 3.2: Use gtk_scale_new() with %GTK_ORIENTATION_HORIZONTAL instead

parameter.name: adjustment
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkAdjustment which sets the range of the scale.

function.return: a new #GtkHScale.

function.name: gtk_hscale_new_with_range
function.description:
Creates a new horizontal scale widget that lets the user input a number between @min and @max (including @min and @max) with the increment @step. @step must be nonzero; it's the distance the slider moves when using the arrow keys to adjust the scale value.
Note that the way in which the precision is derived works best if @step is a power of ten. If the resulting precision is not suitable for your needs, use gtk_scale_set_digits() to correct it.
Deprecated: 3.2: Use gtk_scale_new_with_range() with %GTK_ORIENTATION_HORIZONTAL instead

parameter.name: step
parameter.parameter_description: step increment (tick size) used with keyboard shortcuts

function.return: a new #GtkHScale

function.name: gtk_hscrollbar_new
function.description:
Creates a new horizontal scrollbar.
Deprecated: 3.2: Use gtk_scrollbar_new() with %GTK_ORIENTATION_HORIZONTAL instead

parameter.name: adjustment
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkAdjustment to use, or %NULL to create a new adjustment

function.return: the new #GtkHScrollbar

function.name: gtk_hseparator_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkHSeparator.
Deprecated: 3.2: Use gtk_separator_new() with %GTK_ORIENTATION_HORIZONTAL instead
function.return: a new #GtkHSeparator.

function.name: gtk_hsv_get_color
function.description:
Queries the current color in an HSV color selector. Returned values will be in the [0.0, 1.0] range.
Since: 2.14

function.name: gtk_hsv_get_metrics
function.description:
Queries the size and ring width of an HSV color selector.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: Return value for the diameter of the hue ring

parameter.name: ring_width
parameter.parameter_description: Return value for the width of the hue ring

function.name: gtk_hsv_is_adjusting
function.description:
An HSV color selector can be said to be adjusting if multiple rapid changes are being made to its value, for example, when the user is adjusting the value with the mouse. This function queries whether the HSV color selector is being adjusted or not.
Since: 2.14
function.return: %TRUE if clients can ignore changes to the color value, since they may be transitory, or %FALSE if they should consider the color value status to be final.

function.name: gtk_hsv_new
function.description:
Creates a new HSV color selector.
Since: 2.14
function.return: A newly-created HSV color selector.

function.name: gtk_hsv_set_color
function.description:
Sets the current color in an HSV color selector. Color component values must be in the [0.0, 1.0] range.
Since: 2.14

function.name: gtk_hsv_set_metrics
function.description:
Sets the size and ring width of an HSV color selector.
Since: 2.14

function.name: gtk_hsv_to_rgb
function.description:
Converts a color from HSV space to RGB.
Input values must be in the [0.0, 1.0] range; output values will be in the same range.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: r
parameter.parameter_description: Return value for the red component

parameter.name: g
parameter.parameter_description: Return value for the green component

parameter.name: b
parameter.parameter_description: Return value for the blue component

function.name: gtk_icon_factory_add
function.description:
Adds the given @icon_set to the icon factory, under the name @stock_id. @stock_id should be namespaced for your application, e.g. "myapp-whatever-icon". Normally applications create a #GtkIconFactory, then add it to the list of default factories with gtk_icon_factory_add_default(). Then they pass the @stock_id to widgets such as #GtkImage to display the icon. Themes can provide an icon with the same name (such as "myapp-whatever-icon") to override your application's default icons. If an icon already existed in @factory for @stock_id, it is unreferenced and replaced with the new @icon_set.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

function.name: gtk_icon_factory_add_default
function.description:
Adds an icon factory to the list of icon factories searched by gtk_style_lookup_icon_set(). This means that, for example, gtk_image_new_from_stock() will be able to find icons in @factory. There will normally be an icon factory added for each library or application that comes with icons. The default icon factories can be overridden by themes.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

function.name: gtk_icon_factory_lookup
function.description:
Looks up @stock_id in the icon factory, returning an icon set if found, otherwise %NULL. For display to the user, you should use gtk_style_lookup_icon_set() on the #GtkStyle for the widget that will display the icon, instead of using this function directly, so that themes are taken into account.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: icon set of @stock_id.

function.name: gtk_icon_factory_lookup_default
function.description:
Looks for an icon in the list of default icon factories. For display to the user, you should use gtk_style_lookup_icon_set() on the #GtkStyle for the widget that will display the icon, instead of using this function directly, so that themes are taken into account.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: a #GtkIconSet, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_icon_factory_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkIconFactory. An icon factory manages a collection of #GtkIconSet<!-- -->s; a #GtkIconSet manages a set of variants of a particular icon (i.e. a #GtkIconSet contains variants for different sizes and widget states). Icons in an icon factory are named by a stock ID, which is a simple string identifying the icon. Each #GtkStyle has a list of #GtkIconFactory<!-- -->s derived from the current theme; those icon factories are consulted first when searching for an icon. If the theme doesn't set a particular icon, GTK+ looks for the icon in a list of default icon factories, maintained by gtk_icon_factory_add_default() and gtk_icon_factory_remove_default(). Applications with icons should add a default icon factory with their icons, which will allow themes to override the icons for the application.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: a new #GtkIconFactory

function.name: gtk_icon_factory_remove_default
function.description:
Removes an icon factory from the list of default icon factories. Not normally used; you might use it for a library that can be unloaded or shut down.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

function.name: gtk_icon_info_copy
function.description:
Make a copy of a #GtkIconInfo.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.8: Use g_object_ref()
function.return: the new GtkIconInfo

function.name: gtk_icon_info_free
function.description:
Free a #GtkIconInfo and associated information
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.8: Use g_object_unref()

function.name: gtk_icon_info_get_attach_points
function.description:
Fetches the set of attach points for an icon. An attach point is a location in the icon that can be used as anchor points for attaching emblems or overlays to the icon.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: points
parameter.parameter_description: location to store pointer to an array of points, or %NULL free the array of points with g_free().

parameter.name: n_points
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the number of points in @points, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if there are any attach points for the icon.

function.name: gtk_icon_info_get_base_scale
function.description:
Gets the base scale for the icon. The base scale is a scale for the icon that was specified by the icon theme creator. For instance an icon drawn for a high-dpi screen with window-scale 2 for a base size of 32 will be 64 pixels tall and have a base_scale of 2.
Since: 3.10
function.return: the base scale.

function.name: gtk_icon_info_get_base_size
function.description:
Gets the base size for the icon. The base size is a size for the icon that was specified by the icon theme creator. This may be different than the actual size of image; an example of this is small emblem icons that can be attached to a larger icon. These icons will be given the same base size as the larger icons to which they are attached.
Note that for scaled icons the base size does not include the base scale.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the base size, or 0, if no base size is known for the icon.

function.name: gtk_icon_info_get_builtin_pixbuf
function.description:
Gets the built-in image for this icon, if any. To allow GTK+ to use built in icon images, you must pass the %GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_USE_BUILTIN to gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon().
Since: 2.4
function.return: the built-in image pixbuf, or %NULL. No extra reference is added to the returned pixbuf, so if you want to keep it around, you must use g_object_ref(). The returned image must not be modified.

function.name: gtk_icon_info_get_display_name
function.description:
Gets the display name for an icon. A display name is a string to be used in place of the icon name in a user visible context like a list of icons.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the display name for the icon or %NULL, if the icon doesn't have a specified display name. This value is owned @icon_info and must not be modified or free.

function.name: gtk_icon_info_get_embedded_rect
function.description:
Gets the coordinates of a rectangle within the icon that can be used for display of information such as a preview of the contents of a text file. See gtk_icon_info_set_raw_coordinates() for further information about the coordinate system.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: rectangle
parameter.parameter_description: #GdkRectangle in which to store embedded rectangle coordinates; coordinates are only stored when this function returns %TRUE.

function.return: %TRUE if the icon has an embedded rectangle

function.name: gtk_icon_info_get_filename
function.description:
Gets the filename for the icon. If the %GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_USE_BUILTIN flag was passed to gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon(), there may be no filename if a builtin icon is returned; in this case, you should use gtk_icon_info_get_builtin_pixbuf().
Since: 2.4
function.return: the filename for the icon, or %NULL if gtk_icon_info_get_builtin_pixbuf() should be used instead. The return value is owned by GTK+ and should not be modified or freed.

function.name: gtk_icon_info_load_icon
function.description:
Renders an icon previously looked up in an icon theme using gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon(); the size will be based on the size passed to gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon(). Note that the resulting pixbuf may not be exactly this size; an icon theme may have icons that differ slightly from their nominal sizes, and in addition GTK+ will avoid scaling icons that it considers sufficiently close to the requested size or for which the source image would have to be scaled up too far. (This maintains sharpness.). This behaviour can be changed by passing the %GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_FORCE_SIZE flag when obtaining the #GtkIconInfo. If this flag has been specified, the pixbuf returned by this function will be scaled to the exact size.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store error information on failure, or %NULL.

function.return: the rendered icon; this may be a newly created icon or a new reference to an internal icon, so you must not modify the icon. Use g_object_unref() to release your reference to the icon.

function.name: gtk_icon_info_load_icon_async
function.description:
Asynchronously load, render and scale an icon previously looked up from the icon theme using gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon().
For more details, see gtk_icon_info_load_icon() which is the synchronous version of this call.
Since: 3.8

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: gtk_icon_info_load_icon_finish
function.description:
Finishes an async icon load, see gtk_icon_info_load_icon_async().
Since: 3.8

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store error information on failure, or %NULL.

function.return: the rendered icon; this may be a newly created icon or a new reference to an internal icon, so you must not modify the icon. Use g_object_unref() to release your reference to the icon.

function.name: gtk_icon_info_load_surface
function.description:
Renders an icon previously looked up in an icon theme using gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon(); the size will be based on the size passed to gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon(). Note that the resulting surface may not be exactly this size; an icon theme may have icons that differ slightly from their nominal sizes, and in addition GTK+ will avoid scaling icons that it considers sufficiently close to the requested size or for which the source image would have to be scaled up too far. (This maintains sharpness.). This behaviour can be changed by passing the %GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_FORCE_SIZE flag when obtaining the #GtkIconInfo. If this flag has been specified, the pixbuf returned by this function will be scaled to the exact size.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store error information on failure, or %NULL.

function.return: the rendered icon; this may be a newly created icon or a new reference to an internal icon, so you must not modify the icon. Use cairo_surface_destroy() to release your reference to the icon.

function.name: gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic
function.description:
Loads an icon, modifying it to match the system colours for the foreground, success, warning and error colors provided. If the icon is not a symbolic one, the function will return the result from gtk_icon_info_load_icon().
This allows loading symbolic icons that will match the system theme.
Unless you are implementing a widget, you will want to use g_themed_icon_new_with_default_fallbacks() to load the icon.
As implementation details, the icon loaded needs to be of SVG type, contain the "symbolic" term as the last component of the icon name, and use the 'fg', 'success', 'warning' and 'error' CSS styles in the SVG file itself.
See the <ulink url="http://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/SymbolicIcons">Symbolic Icons spec</ulink> for more information about symbolic icons.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: fg
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkRGBA representing the foreground color of the icon

parameter.name: success_color
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkRGBA representing the warning color of the icon or %NULL to use the default color

parameter.name: warning_color
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkRGBA representing the warning color of the icon or %NULL to use the default color

parameter.name: error_color
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkRGBA representing the error color of the icon or %NULL to use the default color (allow-none)

parameter.name: was_symbolic
parameter.parameter_description: a #gboolean, returns whether the loaded icon was a symbolic one and whether the @fg color was applied to it.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store error information on failure, or %NULL.

function.return: a #GdkPixbuf representing the loaded icon

function.name: gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic_async
function.description:
Asynchronously load, render and scale a symbolic icon previously looked up from the icon theme using gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon().
For more details, see gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic() which is the synchronous version of this call.
Since: 3.8

parameter.name: fg
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkRGBA representing the foreground color of the icon

parameter.name: success_color
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkRGBA representing the warning color of the icon or %NULL to use the default color

parameter.name: warning_color
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkRGBA representing the warning color of the icon or %NULL to use the default color

parameter.name: error_color
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkRGBA representing the error color of the icon or %NULL to use the default color (allow-none)

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic_finish
function.description:
Finishes an async icon load, see gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic_async().
Since: 3.8

parameter.name: was_symbolic
parameter.parameter_description: a #gboolean, returns whether the loaded icon was a symbolic one and whether the @fg color was applied to it.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store error information on failure, or %NULL.

function.return: the rendered icon; this may be a newly created icon or a new reference to an internal icon, so you must not modify the icon. Use g_object_unref() to release your reference to the icon.

function.name: gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic_for_context
function.description:
Loads an icon, modifying it to match the system colors for the foreground, success, warning and error colors provided. If the icon is not a symbolic one, the function will return the result from gtk_icon_info_load_icon(). This function uses the regular foreground color and the symbolic colors with the names "success_color", "warning_color" and "error_color" from the context.
This allows loading symbolic icons that will match the system theme.
See gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic() for more details.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: was_symbolic
parameter.parameter_description: a #gboolean, returns whether the loaded icon was a symbolic one and whether the @fg color was applied to it.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store error information on failure, or %NULL.

function.return: a #GdkPixbuf representing the loaded icon

function.name: gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic_for_context_async
function.description:
Asynchronously load, render and scale a symbolic icon previously looked up from the icon theme using gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon().
For more details, see gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic_for_context() which is the synchronous version of this call.
Since: 3.8

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic_for_context_finish
function.description:
Finishes an async icon load, see gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic_for_context_async().
Since: 3.8

parameter.name: was_symbolic
parameter.parameter_description: a #gboolean, returns whether the loaded icon was a symbolic one and whether the @fg color was applied to it.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store error information on failure, or %NULL.

function.return: the rendered icon; this may be a newly created icon or a new reference to an internal icon, so you must not modify the icon. Use g_object_unref() to release your reference to the icon.

function.name: gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic_for_style
function.description:
Loads an icon, modifying it to match the system colours for the foreground, success, warning and error colors provided. If the icon is not a symbolic one, the function will return the result from gtk_icon_info_load_icon().
This allows loading symbolic icons that will match the system theme.
See gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic() for more details.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.0: Use gtk_icon_info_load_symbolic_for_context() instead

parameter.name: style
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkStyle to take the colors from

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: the widget state to use for colors

parameter.name: was_symbolic
parameter.parameter_description: a #gboolean, returns whether the loaded icon was a symbolic one and whether the @fg color was applied to it.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store error information on failure, or %NULL.

function.return: a #GdkPixbuf representing the loaded icon

function.name: gtk_icon_info_new_for_pixbuf
function.description:
Creates a #GtkIconInfo for a #GdkPixbuf.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: pixbuf
parameter.parameter_description: the pixbuf to wrap in a #GtkIconInfo

function.return: a #GtkIconInfo

function.name: gtk_icon_info_set_raw_coordinates
function.description:
Sets whether the coordinates returned by gtk_icon_info_get_embedded_rect() and gtk_icon_info_get_attach_points() should be returned in their original form as specified in the icon theme, instead of scaled appropriately for the pixbuf returned by gtk_icon_info_load_icon().
Raw coordinates are somewhat strange; they are specified to be with respect to the unscaled pixmap for PNG and XPM icons, but for SVG icons, they are in a 1000x1000 coordinate space that is scaled to the final size of the icon. You can determine if the icon is an SVG icon by using gtk_icon_info_get_filename(), and seeing if it is non-%NULL and ends in '.svg'.
This function is provided primarily to allow compatibility wrappers for older API's, and is not expected to be useful for applications.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: raw_coordinates
parameter.parameter_description: whether the coordinates of embedded rectangles and attached points should be returned in their original (unscaled) form.

function.name: gtk_icon_set_add_source
function.description:
Icon sets have a list of #GtkIconSource, which they use as base icons for rendering icons in different states and sizes. Icons are scaled, made to look insensitive, etc. in gtk_icon_set_render_icon(), but #GtkIconSet needs base images to work with. The base images and when to use them are described by a #GtkIconSource.
This function copies @source, so you can reuse the same source immediately without affecting the icon set.
An example of when you'd use this function: a web browser's "Back to Previous Page" icon might point in a different direction in Hebrew and in English; it might look different when insensitive; and it might change size depending on toolbar mode (small/large icons). So a single icon set would contain all those variants of the icon, and you might add a separate source for each one.
You should nearly always add a "default" icon source with all fields wildcarded, which will be used as a fallback if no more specific source matches. #GtkIconSet always prefers more specific icon sources to more generic icon sources. The order in which you add the sources to the icon set does not matter.
gtk_icon_set_new_from_pixbuf() creates a new icon set with a default icon source based on the given pixbuf.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

function.name: gtk_icon_set_copy
function.description:
Copies @icon_set by value.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: a new #GtkIconSet identical to the first.

function.name: gtk_icon_set_get_sizes
function.description:
Obtains a list of icon sizes this icon set can render. The returned array must be freed with g_free().
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

parameter.name: sizes
parameter.parameter_description: return location for array of sizes

parameter.name: n_sizes
parameter.parameter_description: location to store number of elements in returned array

function.name: gtk_icon_set_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkIconSet. A #GtkIconSet represents a single icon in various sizes and widget states. It can provide a #GdkPixbuf for a given size and state on request, and automatically caches some of the rendered #GdkPixbuf objects.
Normally you would use gtk_widget_render_icon_pixbuf() instead of using #GtkIconSet directly. The one case where you'd use #GtkIconSet is to create application-specific icon sets to place in a #GtkIconFactory.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: a new #GtkIconSet

function.name: gtk_icon_set_new_from_pixbuf
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkIconSet with @pixbuf as the default/fallback source image. If you don't add any additional #GtkIconSource to the icon set, all variants of the icon will be created from @pixbuf, using scaling, pixelation, etc. as required to adjust the icon size or make the icon look insensitive/prelighted.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: a new #GtkIconSet

function.name: gtk_icon_set_ref
function.description:
Increments the reference count on @icon_set.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: @icon_set.

function.name: gtk_icon_set_render_icon
function.description:
Renders an icon using gtk_style_render_icon(). In most cases, gtk_widget_render_icon() is better, since it automatically provides most of the arguments from the current widget settings. This function never returns %NULL; if the icon can't be rendered (perhaps because an image file fails to load), a default "missing image" icon will be returned instead.
Deprecated: 3.0: Use gtk_icon_set_render_icon_pixbuf() instead

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: icon size. A size of (GtkIconSize)-1 means render at the size of the source and don't scale.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: widget that will display the icon, or %NULL. The only use that is typically made of this is to determine the appropriate #GdkScreen.

parameter.name: detail
parameter.parameter_description: detail to pass to the theme engine, or %NULL. Note that passing a detail of anything but %NULL will disable caching.

function.return: a #GdkPixbuf to be displayed

function.name: gtk_icon_set_render_icon_pixbuf
function.description:
Renders an icon using gtk_render_icon_pixbuf(). In most cases, gtk_widget_render_icon_pixbuf() is better, since it automatically provides most of the arguments from the current widget settings. This function never returns %NULL; if the icon can't be rendered (perhaps because an image file fails to load), a default "missing image" icon will be returned instead.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: icon size. A size of (GtkIconSize)-1 means render at the size of the source and don't scale.

function.return: a #GdkPixbuf to be displayed

function.name: gtk_icon_set_render_icon_surface
function.description:
Renders an icon using gtk_render_icon_pixbuf() and converts it to a cairo surface.
This function never returns %NULL; if the icon can't be rendered (perhaps because an image file fails to load), a default "missing image" icon will be returned instead.
Since: 3.10
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: icon size. A size of (GtkIconSize)-1 means render at the size of the source and don't scale.

parameter.name: scale
parameter.parameter_description: the window scale to render for

function.return: a #cairo_surface_t to be displayed

function.name: gtk_icon_set_unref
function.description:
Decrements the reference count on @icon_set, and frees memory if the reference count reaches 0.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

function.name: gtk_icon_size_from_name
function.description:
Looks up the icon size associated with @name.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: the icon size

function.name: gtk_icon_size_get_name
function.description:
Gets the canonical name of the given icon size. The returned string is statically allocated and should not be freed.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: the name of the given icon size.

function.name: gtk_icon_size_lookup
function.description: Obtains the pixel size of a semantic icon size @size: #GTK_ICON_SIZE_MENU, #GTK_ICON_SIZE_BUTTON, etc. This function isn't normally needed, gtk_icon_theme_load_icon() is the usual way to get an icon for rendering, then just look at the size of the rendered pixbuf. The rendered pixbuf may not even correspond to the width/height returned by gtk_icon_size_lookup(), because themes are free to render the pixbuf however they like, including changing the usual size.
function.return: %TRUE if @size was a valid size

function.name: gtk_icon_size_lookup_for_settings
function.description:
Obtains the pixel size of a semantic icon size, possibly modified by user preferences for a particular #GtkSettings. Normally @size would be #GTK_ICON_SIZE_MENU, #GTK_ICON_SIZE_BUTTON, etc. This function isn't normally needed, gtk_widget_render_icon_pixbuf() is the usual way to get an icon for rendering, then just look at the size of the rendered pixbuf. The rendered pixbuf may not even correspond to the width/height returned by gtk_icon_size_lookup(), because themes are free to render the pixbuf however they like, including changing the usual size.
Since: 2.2
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_icon_size_lookup() instead.

parameter.name: settings
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkSettings object, used to determine which set of user preferences to used.

function.return: %TRUE if @size was a valid size

function.name: gtk_icon_size_register
function.description:
Registers a new icon size, along the same lines as #GTK_ICON_SIZE_MENU, etc. Returns the integer value for the size.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: integer value representing the size

function.name: gtk_icon_size_register_alias
function.description:
Registers @alias as another name for @target. So calling gtk_icon_size_from_name() with @alias as argument will return @target.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

function.name: gtk_icon_source_copy
function.description:
Creates a copy of @source; mostly useful for language bindings.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: a new #GtkIconSource

function.name: gtk_icon_source_free
function.description:
Frees a dynamically-allocated icon source, along with its filename, size, and pixbuf fields if those are not %NULL.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

function.name: gtk_icon_source_get_direction
function.description:
Obtains the text direction this icon source applies to. The return value is only useful/meaningful if the text direction is <emphasis>not</emphasis> wildcarded.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: text direction this source matches

function.name: gtk_icon_source_get_direction_wildcarded
function.description:
Gets the value set by gtk_icon_source_set_direction_wildcarded().
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: %TRUE if this icon source is a base for any text direction variant

function.name: gtk_icon_source_get_filename
function.description:
Retrieves the source filename, or %NULL if none is set. The filename is not a copy, and should not be modified or expected to persist beyond the lifetime of the icon source.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: image filename. This string must not be modified or freed.

function.name: gtk_icon_source_get_icon_name
function.description:
Retrieves the source icon name, or %NULL if none is set. The icon_name is not a copy, and should not be modified or expected to persist beyond the lifetime of the icon source.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: icon name. This string must not be modified or freed.

function.name: gtk_icon_source_get_pixbuf
function.description:
Retrieves the source pixbuf, or %NULL if none is set. In addition, if a filename source is in use, this function in some cases will return the pixbuf from loaded from the filename. This is, for example, true for the GtkIconSource passed to the GtkStyle::render_icon() virtual function. The reference count on the pixbuf is not incremented.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: source pixbuf

function.name: gtk_icon_source_get_size
function.description:
Obtains the icon size this source applies to. The return value is only useful/meaningful if the icon size is <emphasis>not</emphasis> wildcarded.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: icon size this source matches.

function.name: gtk_icon_source_get_size_wildcarded
function.description:
Gets the value set by gtk_icon_source_set_size_wildcarded().
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: %TRUE if this icon source is a base for any icon size variant

function.name: gtk_icon_source_get_state
function.description:
Obtains the widget state this icon source applies to. The return value is only useful/meaningful if the widget state is <emphasis>not</emphasis> wildcarded.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: widget state this source matches

function.name: gtk_icon_source_get_state_wildcarded
function.description:
Gets the value set by gtk_icon_source_set_state_wildcarded().
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: %TRUE if this icon source is a base for any widget state variant

function.name: gtk_icon_source_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkIconSource. A #GtkIconSource contains a #GdkPixbuf (or image filename) that serves as the base image for one or more of the icons in a #GtkIconSet, along with a specification for which icons in the icon set will be based on that pixbuf or image file. An icon set contains a set of icons that represent "the same" logical concept in different states, different global text directions, and different sizes.
So for example a web browser's "Back to Previous Page" icon might point in a different direction in Hebrew and in English; it might look different when insensitive; and it might change size depending on toolbar mode (small/large icons). So a single icon set would contain all those variants of the icon. #GtkIconSet contains a list of #GtkIconSource from which it can derive specific icon variants in the set.
In the simplest case, #GtkIconSet contains one source pixbuf from which it derives all variants. The convenience function gtk_icon_set_new_from_pixbuf() handles this case; if you only have one source pixbuf, just use that function.
If you want to use a different base pixbuf for different icon variants, you create multiple icon sources, mark which variants they'll be used to create, and add them to the icon set with gtk_icon_set_add_source().
By default, the icon source has all parameters wildcarded. That is, the icon source will be used as the base icon for any desired text direction, widget state, or icon size.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.
function.return: a new #GtkIconSource

function.name: gtk_icon_source_set_direction
function.description:
Sets the text direction this icon source is intended to be used with.
Setting the text direction on an icon source makes no difference if the text direction is wildcarded. Therefore, you should usually call gtk_icon_source_set_direction_wildcarded() to un-wildcard it in addition to calling this function.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

parameter.name: direction
parameter.parameter_description: text direction this source applies to

function.name: gtk_icon_source_set_direction_wildcarded
function.description:
If the text direction is wildcarded, this source can be used as the base image for an icon in any #GtkTextDirection. If the text direction is not wildcarded, then the text direction the icon source applies to should be set with gtk_icon_source_set_direction(), and the icon source will only be used with that text direction.
#GtkIconSet prefers non-wildcarded sources (exact matches) over wildcarded sources, and will use an exact match when possible.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

function.name: gtk_icon_source_set_filename
function.description:
Sets the name of an image file to use as a base image when creating icon variants for #GtkIconSet. The filename must be absolute.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

function.name: gtk_icon_source_set_icon_name
function.description:
Sets the name of an icon to look up in the current icon theme to use as a base image when creating icon variants for #GtkIconSet.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

function.name: gtk_icon_source_set_pixbuf
function.description:
Sets a pixbuf to use as a base image when creating icon variants for #GtkIconSet.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

parameter.name: pixbuf
parameter.parameter_description: pixbuf to use as a source

function.name: gtk_icon_source_set_size
function.description:
Sets the icon size this icon source is intended to be used with.
Setting the icon size on an icon source makes no difference if the size is wildcarded. Therefore, you should usually call gtk_icon_source_set_size_wildcarded() to un-wildcard it in addition to calling this function.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: icon size this source applies to

function.name: gtk_icon_source_set_size_wildcarded
function.description:
If the icon size is wildcarded, this source can be used as the base image for an icon of any size. If the size is not wildcarded, then the size the source applies to should be set with gtk_icon_source_set_size() and the icon source will only be used with that specific size.
#GtkIconSet prefers non-wildcarded sources (exact matches) over wildcarded sources, and will use an exact match when possible.
#GtkIconSet will normally scale wildcarded source images to produce an appropriate icon at a given size, but will not change the size of source images that match exactly.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

function.name: gtk_icon_source_set_state
function.description:
Sets the widget state this icon source is intended to be used with.
Setting the widget state on an icon source makes no difference if the state is wildcarded. Therefore, you should usually call gtk_icon_source_set_state_wildcarded() to un-wildcard it in addition to calling this function.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: widget state this source applies to

function.name: gtk_icon_source_set_state_wildcarded
function.description:
If the widget state is wildcarded, this source can be used as the base image for an icon in any #GtkStateType. If the widget state is not wildcarded, then the state the source applies to should be set with gtk_icon_source_set_state() and the icon source will only be used with that specific state.
#GtkIconSet prefers non-wildcarded sources (exact matches) over wildcarded sources, and will use an exact match when possible.
#GtkIconSet will normally transform wildcarded source images to produce an appropriate icon for a given state, for example lightening an image on prelight, but will not modify source images that match exactly.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use #GtkIconTheme instead.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_add_builtin_icon
function.description:
Registers a built-in icon for icon theme lookups. The idea of built-in icons is to allow an application or library that uses themed icons to function requiring files to be present in the file system. For instance, the default images for all of GTK+'s stock icons are registered as built-icons.
In general, if you use gtk_icon_theme_add_builtin_icon() you should also install the icon in the icon theme, so that the icon is generally available.
This function will generally be used with pixbufs loaded via gdk_pixbuf_new_from_inline().
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: icon_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the icon to register

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the size at which to register the icon (different images can be registered for the same icon name at different sizes.)

parameter.name: pixbuf
parameter.parameter_description: #GdkPixbuf that contains the image to use for @icon_name.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_append_search_path
function.description:
Appends a directory to the search path. See gtk_icon_theme_set_search_path().
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: directory name to append to the icon path

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_choose_icon
function.description:
Looks up a named icon and returns a structure containing information such as the filename of the icon. The icon can then be rendered into a pixbuf using gtk_icon_info_load_icon(). (gtk_icon_theme_load_icon() combines these two steps if all you need is the pixbuf.)
If @icon_names contains more than one name, this function tries them all in the given order before falling back to inherited icon themes.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: icon_names
parameter.parameter_description: %NULL-terminated array of icon names to lookup

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags modifying the behavior of the icon lookup

function.return: a #GtkIconInfo object containing information about the icon, or %NULL if the icon wasn't found.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_choose_icon_for_scale
function.description:
Looks up a named icon for a particular window scale and returns a structure containing information such as the filename of the icon. The icon can then be rendered into a pixbuf using gtk_icon_info_load_icon(). (gtk_icon_theme_load_icon() combines these two steps if all you need is the pixbuf.)
If @icon_names contains more than one name, this function tries them all in the given order before falling back to inherited icon themes.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: icon_names
parameter.parameter_description: %NULL-terminated array of icon names to lookup

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags modifying the behavior of the icon lookup

function.return: a #GtkIconInfo object containing information about the icon, or %NULL if the icon wasn't found.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_get_default
function.description:
Gets the icon theme for the default screen. See gtk_icon_theme_get_for_screen().
Since: 2.4
function.return: A unique #GtkIconTheme associated with the default screen. This icon theme is associated with the screen and can be used as long as the screen is open. Do not ref or unref it.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_get_example_icon_name
function.description:
Gets the name of an icon that is representative of the current theme (for instance, to use when presenting a list of themes to the user.)
Since: 2.4
function.return: the name of an example icon or %NULL. Free with g_free().

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_get_for_screen
function.description:
Gets the icon theme object associated with @screen; if this function has not previously been called for the given screen, a new icon theme object will be created and associated with the screen. Icon theme objects are fairly expensive to create, so using this function is usually a better choice than calling than gtk_icon_theme_new() and setting the screen yourself; by using this function a single icon theme object will be shared between users.
Since: 2.4
function.return: A unique #GtkIconTheme associated with the given screen. This icon theme is associated with the screen and can be used as long as the screen is open. Do not ref or unref it.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_get_icon_sizes
function.description:
Returns an array of integers describing the sizes at which the icon is available without scaling. A size of -1 means that the icon is available in a scalable format. The array is zero-terminated.
Since: 2.6
function.return: An newly allocated array describing the sizes at which the icon is available. The array should be freed with g_free() when it is no longer needed.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_get_search_path
function.description:
Gets the current search path. See gtk_icon_theme_set_search_path().
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: location to store a list of icon theme path directories or %NULL. The stored value should be freed with g_strfreev().

parameter.name: n_elements
parameter.parameter_description: location to store number of elements in @path, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_has_icon
function.description:
Checks whether an icon theme includes an icon for a particular name.
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if @icon_theme includes an icon for @icon_name.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_list_contexts
function.description:
Gets the list of contexts available within the current hierarchy of icon themes
Since: 2.12
function.return: a #GList list holding the names of all the contexts in the theme. You must first free each element in the list with g_free(), then free the list itself with g_list_free().

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_list_icons
function.description:
Lists the icons in the current icon theme. Only a subset of the icons can be listed by providing a context string. The set of values for the context string is system dependent, but will typically include such values as "Applications" and "MimeTypes".
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: a string identifying a particular type of icon, or %NULL to list all icons.

function.return: a #GList list holding the names of all the icons in the theme. You must first free each element in the list with g_free(), then free the list itself with g_list_free().

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_load_icon
function.description:
Looks up an icon in an icon theme, scales it to the given size and renders it into a pixbuf. This is a convenience function; if more details about the icon are needed, use gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon() followed by gtk_icon_info_load_icon().
Note that you probably want to listen for icon theme changes and update the icon. This is usually done by connecting to the GtkWidget::style-set signal. If for some reason you do not want to update the icon when the icon theme changes, you should consider using gdk_pixbuf_copy() to make a private copy of the pixbuf returned by this function. Otherwise GTK+ may need to keep the old icon theme loaded, which would be a waste of memory.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: icon_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the icon to lookup

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the desired icon size. The resulting icon may not be exactly this size; see gtk_icon_info_load_icon().

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags modifying the behavior of the icon lookup

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: Location to store error information on failure, or %NULL.

function.return: the rendered icon; this may be a newly created icon or a new reference to an internal icon, so you must not modify the icon. Use g_object_unref() to release your reference to the icon. %NULL if the icon isn't found.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_load_icon_for_scale
function.description:
Looks up an icon in an icon theme for a particular window scale, scales it to the given size and renders it into a pixbuf. This is a convenience function; if more details about the icon are needed, use gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon() followed by gtk_icon_info_load_icon().
Note that you probably want to listen for icon theme changes and update the icon. This is usually done by connecting to the GtkWidget::style-set signal. If for some reason you do not want to update the icon when the icon theme changes, you should consider using gdk_pixbuf_copy() to make a private copy of the pixbuf returned by this function. Otherwise GTK+ may need to keep the old icon theme loaded, which would be a waste of memory.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: icon_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the icon to lookup

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the desired icon size. The resulting icon may not be exactly this size; see gtk_icon_info_load_icon().

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags modifying the behavior of the icon lookup

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: Location to store error information on failure, or %NULL.

function.return: the rendered icon; this may be a newly created icon or a new reference to an internal icon, so you must not modify the icon. Use g_object_unref() to release your reference to the icon. %NULL if the icon isn't found.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_load_surface
function.description:
Looks up an icon in an icon theme for a particular window scale, scales it to the given size and renders it into a cairo surface. This is a convenience function; if more details about the icon are needed, use gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon() followed by gtk_icon_info_load_surface().
Note that you probably want to listen for icon theme changes and update the icon. This is usually done by connecting to the GtkWidget::style-set signal.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: icon_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the icon to lookup

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the desired icon size. The resulting icon may not be exactly this size; see gtk_icon_info_load_icon().

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags modifying the behavior of the icon lookup

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: Location to store error information on failure, or %NULL.

function.return: the rendered icon; this may be a newly created icon or a new reference to an internal icon, so you must not modify the icon. Use cairo_surface_destroy() to release your reference to the icon. %NULL if the icon isn't found.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_lookup_by_gicon
function.description:
Looks up an icon and returns a structure containing information such as the filename of the icon. The icon can then be rendered into a pixbuf using gtk_icon_info_load_icon().
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags modifying the behavior of the icon lookup

function.return: a #GtkIconInfo structure containing information about the icon, or %NULL if the icon wasn't found. Unref with g_object_unref()

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_lookup_by_gicon_for_scale
function.description:
Looks up an icon and returns a structure containing information such as the filename of the icon. The icon can then be rendered into a pixbuf using gtk_icon_info_load_icon_for_scale ().
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags modifying the behavior of the icon lookup

function.return: a #GtkIconInfo structure containing information about the icon, or %NULL if the icon wasn't found. Unref with g_object_unref()

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon
function.description:
Looks up a named icon and returns a structure containing information such as the filename of the icon. The icon can then be rendered into a pixbuf using gtk_icon_info_load_icon(). (gtk_icon_theme_load_icon() combines these two steps if all you need is the pixbuf.)
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: icon_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the icon to lookup

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags modifying the behavior of the icon lookup

function.return: a #GtkIconInfo object containing information about the icon, or %NULL if the icon wasn't found.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon_for_scale
function.description:
Looks up a named icon for a particular window scale and returns a structure containing information such as the filename of the icon. The icon can then be rendered into a pixbuf using gtk_icon_info_load_icon(). (gtk_icon_theme_load_icon() combines these two steps if all you need is the pixbuf.)
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: icon_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the icon to lookup

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags modifying the behavior of the icon lookup

function.return: a #GtkIconInfo object containing information about the icon, or %NULL if the icon wasn't found.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_new
function.description:
Creates a new icon theme object. Icon theme objects are used to lookup up an icon by name in a particular icon theme. Usually, you'll want to use gtk_icon_theme_get_default() or gtk_icon_theme_get_for_screen() rather than creating a new icon theme object for scratch.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the newly created #GtkIconTheme object.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_prepend_search_path
function.description:
Prepends a directory to the search path. See gtk_icon_theme_set_search_path().
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: directory name to prepend to the icon path

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_rescan_if_needed
function.description:
Checks to see if the icon theme has changed; if it has, any currently cached information is discarded and will be reloaded next time @icon_theme is accessed.
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if the icon theme has changed and needed to be reloaded.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_set_custom_theme
function.description:
Sets the name of the icon theme that the #GtkIconTheme object uses overriding system configuration. This function cannot be called on the icon theme objects returned from gtk_icon_theme_get_default() and gtk_icon_theme_get_for_screen().
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: theme_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of icon theme to use instead of configured theme, or %NULL to unset a previously set custom theme

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_set_screen
function.description:
Sets the screen for an icon theme; the screen is used to track the user's currently configured icon theme, which might be different for different screens.
Since: 2.4

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_set_search_path
function.description:
Sets the search path for the icon theme object. When looking for an icon theme, GTK+ will search for a subdirectory of one or more of the directories in @path with the same name as the icon theme. (Themes from multiple of the path elements are combined to allow themes to be extended by adding icons in the user's home directory.)
In addition if an icon found isn't found either in the current icon theme or the default icon theme, and an image file with the right name is found directly in one of the elements of @path, then that image will be used for the icon name. (This is legacy feature, and new icons should be put into the default icon theme, which is called DEFAULT_THEME_NAME, rather than directly on the icon path.)
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: array of directories that are searched for icon themes

function.name: gtk_icon_view_convert_widget_to_bin_window_coords
function.description:
Converts widget coordinates to coordinates for the bin_window, as expected by e.g. gtk_icon_view_get_path_at_pos().
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: wx
parameter.parameter_description: X coordinate relative to the widget

parameter.name: wy
parameter.parameter_description: Y coordinate relative to the widget

parameter.name: bx
parameter.parameter_description: return location for bin_window X coordinate

parameter.name: by
parameter.parameter_description: return location for bin_window Y coordinate

function.name: gtk_icon_view_create_drag_icon
function.description:
Creates a #cairo_surface_t representation of the item at @path. This image is used for a drag icon.
Since: 2.8
function.return: a newly-allocated surface of the drag icon.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_enable_model_drag_dest
function.description:
Turns @icon_view into a drop destination for automatic DND. Calling this method sets #GtkIconView:reorderable to %FALSE.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: targets
parameter.parameter_description: the table of targets that the drag will support

parameter.name: actions
parameter.parameter_description: the bitmask of possible actions for a drag to this widget

function.name: gtk_icon_view_enable_model_drag_source
function.description:
Turns @icon_view into a drag source for automatic DND. Calling this method sets #GtkIconView:reorderable to %FALSE.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: start_button_mask
parameter.parameter_description: Mask of allowed buttons to start drag

parameter.name: targets
parameter.parameter_description: the table of targets that the drag will support

parameter.name: actions
parameter.parameter_description: the bitmask of possible actions for a drag from this widget

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_activate_on_single_click
function.description:
Gets the setting set by gtk_icon_view_set_activate_on_single_click().
Since: 3.8
function.return: %TRUE if item-activated will be emitted on a single click

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_cell_rect
function.description:
Fills the bounding rectangle in widget coordinates for the cell specified by @path and @cell. If @cell is %NULL the main cell area is used.
This function is only valid if @icon_view is realized.
Since: 3.6

parameter.name: rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle to fill with cell rect

function.return: %FALSE if there is no such item, %TRUE otherwise

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_column_spacing
function.description:
Returns the value of the ::column-spacing property.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the space between columns

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_columns
function.description:
Returns the value of the ::columns property.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the number of columns, or -1

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_cursor
function.description:
Fills in @path and @cell with the current cursor path and cell. If the cursor isn't currently set, then *@path will be %NULL. If no cell currently has focus, then *@cell will be %NULL.
The returned #GtkTreePath must be freed with gtk_tree_path_free().
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the current cursor path, or %NULL

parameter.name: cell
parameter.parameter_description: Return location the current focus cell, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if the cursor is set.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_dest_item_at_pos
function.description:
Determines the destination item for a given position.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: drag_x
parameter.parameter_description: the position to determine the destination item for

parameter.name: drag_y
parameter.parameter_description: the position to determine the destination item for

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the path of the item, or %NULL.

parameter.name: pos
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the drop position, or %NULL

function.return: whether there is an item at the given position.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_drag_dest_item
function.description:
Gets information about the item that is highlighted for feedback.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the path of the highlighted item, or %NULL.

parameter.name: pos
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the drop position, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_item_at_pos
function.description:
Finds the path at the point (@x, @y), relative to bin_window coordinates. In contrast to gtk_icon_view_get_path_at_pos(), this function also obtains the cell at the specified position. The returned path should be freed with gtk_tree_path_free(). See gtk_icon_view_convert_widget_to_bin_window_coords() for converting widget coordinates to bin_window coordinates.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: The x position to be identified

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: The y position to be identified

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the path, or %NULL

parameter.name: cell
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the renderer responsible for the cell at (@x, @y), or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if an item exists at the specified position

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_item_column
function.description:
Gets the column in which the item @path is currently displayed. Column numbers start at 0.
Since: 2.22
function.return: The column in which the item is displayed

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_item_orientation
function.description:
Returns the value of the ::item-orientation property which determines whether the labels are drawn beside the icons instead of below.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the relative position of texts and icons

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_item_padding
function.description:
Returns the value of the ::item-padding property.
Since: 2.18
function.return: the padding around items

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_item_row
function.description:
Gets the row in which the item @path is currently displayed. Row numbers start at 0.
Since: 2.22
function.return: The row in which the item is displayed

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_item_width
function.description:
Returns the value of the ::item-width property.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the width of a single item, or -1

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_margin
function.description:
Returns the value of the ::margin property.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the space at the borders

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_markup_column
function.description:
Returns the column with markup text for @icon_view.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the markup column, or -1 if it's unset.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_model
function.description:
Returns the model the #GtkIconView is based on. Returns %NULL if the model is unset.
Since: 2.6
function.return: A #GtkTreeModel, or %NULL if none is currently being used.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_path_at_pos
function.description:
Finds the path at the point (@x, @y), relative to bin_window coordinates. See gtk_icon_view_get_item_at_pos(), if you are also interested in the cell at the specified position. See gtk_icon_view_convert_widget_to_bin_window_coords() for converting widget coordinates to bin_window coordinates.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: The x position to be identified

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: The y position to be identified

function.return: The #GtkTreePath corresponding to the icon or %NULL if no icon exists at that position.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_pixbuf_column
function.description:
Returns the column with pixbufs for @icon_view.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the pixbuf column, or -1 if it's unset.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_reorderable
function.description:
Retrieves whether the user can reorder the list via drag-and-drop. See gtk_icon_view_set_reorderable().
Since: 2.8
function.return: %TRUE if the list can be reordered.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_row_spacing
function.description:
Returns the value of the ::row-spacing property.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the space between rows

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_selected_items
function.description:
Creates a list of paths of all selected items. Additionally, if you are planning on modifying the model after calling this function, you may want to convert the returned list into a list of #GtkTreeRowReference<!-- -->s. To do this, you can use gtk_tree_row_reference_new().
To free the return value, use: |[ g_list_free_full (list, (GDestroyNotify) gtk_tree_path_free); ]|
Since: 2.6
function.return: A #GList containing a #GtkTreePath for each selected row.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_selection_mode
function.description:
Gets the selection mode of the @icon_view.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the current selection mode

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_spacing
function.description:
Returns the value of the ::spacing property.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the space between cells

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_text_column
function.description:
Returns the column with text for @icon_view.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the text column, or -1 if it's unset.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_tooltip_column
function.description:
Returns the column of @icon_view's model which is being used for displaying tooltips on @icon_view's rows.
Since: 2.12
function.return: the index of the tooltip column that is currently being used, or -1 if this is disabled.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_tooltip_context
function.description:
This function is supposed to be used in a #GtkWidget::query-tooltip signal handler for #GtkIconView. The @x, @y and @keyboard_tip values which are received in the signal handler, should be passed to this function without modification.
The return value indicates whether there is an icon view item at the given coordinates (%TRUE) or not (%FALSE) for mouse tooltips. For keyboard tooltips the item returned will be the cursor item. When %TRUE, then any of @model, @path and @iter which have been provided will be set to point to that row and the corresponding model. @x and @y will always be converted to be relative to @icon_view's bin_window if @keyboard_tooltip is %FALSE.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate (relative to widget coordinates)

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate (relative to widget coordinates)

parameter.name: keyboard_tip
parameter.parameter_description: whether this is a keyboard tooltip or not

parameter.name: model
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to receive a #GtkTreeModel or %NULL

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to receive a #GtkTreePath or %NULL

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to receive a #GtkTreeIter or %NULL

function.return: whether or not the given tooltip context points to a item

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_visible_range
function.description:
Sets @start_path and @end_path to be the first and last visible path. Note that there may be invisible paths in between.
Both paths should be freed with gtk_tree_path_free() after use.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: start_path
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for start of region, or %NULL

parameter.name: end_path
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for end of region, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE, if valid paths were placed in @start_path and @end_path

function.name: gtk_icon_view_item_activated
function.description:
Activates the item determined by @path.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_icon_view_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkIconView widget
Since: 2.6
function.return: A newly created #GtkIconView widget

function.name: gtk_icon_view_new_with_area
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkIconView widget using the specified @area to layout cells inside the icons.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: area
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkCellArea to use to layout cells

function.return: A newly created #GtkIconView widget

function.name: gtk_icon_view_new_with_model
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkIconView widget with the model @model.
Since: 2.6
function.return: A newly created #GtkIconView widget.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_path_is_selected
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if the icon pointed to by @path is currently selected. If @path does not point to a valid location, %FALSE is returned.
Since: 2.6
function.return: %TRUE if @path is selected.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_scroll_to_path
function.description:
Moves the alignments of @icon_view to the position specified by @path. @row_align determines where the row is placed, and @col_align determines where @column is placed. Both are expected to be between 0.0 and 1.0. 0.0 means left/top alignment, 1.0 means right/bottom alignment, 0.5 means center.
If @use_align is %FALSE, then the alignment arguments are ignored, and the tree does the minimum amount of work to scroll the item onto the screen. This means that the item will be scrolled to the edge closest to its current position. If the item is currently visible on the screen, nothing is done.
This function only works if the model is set, and @path is a valid row on the model. If the model changes before the @icon_view is realized, the centered path will be modified to reflect this change.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: The path of the item to move to.

parameter.name: use_align
parameter.parameter_description: whether to use alignment arguments, or %FALSE.

parameter.name: row_align
parameter.parameter_description: The vertical alignment of the item specified by @path.

parameter.name: col_align
parameter.parameter_description: The horizontal alignment of the item specified by @path.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_select_all
function.description:
Selects all the icons. @icon_view must has its selection mode set to #GTK_SELECTION_MULTIPLE.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_icon_view_select_path
function.description:
Selects the row at @path.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_icon_view_selected_foreach
function.description:
Calls a function for each selected icon. Note that the model or selection cannot be modified from within this function.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: The function to call for each selected icon.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: User data to pass to the function.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_activate_on_single_click
function.description:
Causes the #GtkIconView::item-activated signal to be emitted on a single click instead of a double click.
Since: 3.8

parameter.name: single
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to emit item-activated on a single click

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_column_spacing
function.description:
Sets the ::column-spacing property which specifies the space which is inserted between the columns of the icon view.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_columns
function.description:
Sets the ::columns property which determines in how many columns the icons are arranged. If @columns is -1, the number of columns will be chosen automatically to fill the available area.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_cursor
function.description:
Sets the current keyboard focus to be at @path, and selects it. This is useful when you want to focus the user's attention on a particular item. If @cell is not %NULL, then focus is given to the cell specified by it. Additionally, if @start_editing is %TRUE, then editing should be started in the specified cell.
This function is often followed by <literal>gtk_widget_grab_focus (icon_view)</literal> in order to give keyboard focus to the widget. Please note that editing can only happen when the widget is realized.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: cell
parameter.parameter_description: One of the cell renderers of @icon_view, or %NULL

parameter.name: start_editing
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the specified cell should start being edited.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_drag_dest_item
function.description:
Sets the item that is highlighted for feedback.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: The path of the item to highlight, or %NULL.

parameter.name: pos
parameter.parameter_description: Specifies where to drop, relative to the item

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_item_orientation
function.description:
Sets the ::item-orientation property which determines whether the labels are drawn beside the icons instead of below.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: orientation
parameter.parameter_description: the relative position of texts and icons

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_item_padding
function.description:
Sets the #GtkIconView:item-padding property which specifies the padding around each of the icon view's items.
Since: 2.18

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_item_width
function.description:
Sets the ::item-width property which specifies the width to use for each item. If it is set to -1, the icon view will automatically determine a suitable item size.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_margin
function.description:
Sets the ::margin property which specifies the space which is inserted at the top, bottom, left and right of the icon view.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_markup_column
function.description:
Sets the column with markup information for @icon_view to be @column. The markup column must be of type #G_TYPE_STRING. If the markup column is set to something, it overrides the text column set by gtk_icon_view_set_text_column().
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: column
parameter.parameter_description: A column in the currently used model, or -1 to display no text

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_model
function.description:
Sets the model for a #GtkIconView. If the @icon_view already has a model set, it will remove it before setting the new model. If @model is %NULL, then it will unset the old model.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_pixbuf_column
function.description:
Sets the column with pixbufs for @icon_view to be @column. The pixbuf column must be of type #GDK_TYPE_PIXBUF
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: column
parameter.parameter_description: A column in the currently used model, or -1 to disable

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_reorderable
function.description:
This function is a convenience function to allow you to reorder models that support the #GtkTreeDragSourceIface and the #GtkTreeDragDestIface. Both #GtkTreeStore and #GtkListStore support these. If @reorderable is %TRUE, then the user can reorder the model by dragging and dropping rows. The developer can listen to these changes by connecting to the model's row_inserted and row_deleted signals. The reordering is implemented by setting up the icon view as a drag source and destination. Therefore, drag and drop can not be used in a reorderable view for any other purpose.
