This function does not give you any degree of control over the order -- any reordering is allowed. If more control is needed, you should probably handle drag and drop manually.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: reorderable
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE, if the list of items can be reordered.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_row_spacing
function.description:
Sets the ::row-spacing property which specifies the space which is inserted between the rows of the icon view.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_selection_mode
function.description:
Sets the selection mode of the @icon_view.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_spacing
function.description:
Sets the ::spacing property which specifies the space which is inserted between the cells (i.e. the icon and the text) of an item.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_text_column
function.description:
Sets the column with text for @icon_view to be @column. The text column must be of type #G_TYPE_STRING.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: column
parameter.parameter_description: A column in the currently used model, or -1 to display no text

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_tooltip_cell
function.description:
Sets the tip area of @tooltip to the area which @cell occupies in the item pointed to by @path. See also gtk_tooltip_set_tip_area().
See also gtk_icon_view_set_tooltip_column() for a simpler alternative.
Since: 2.12

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_tooltip_column
function.description:
If you only plan to have simple (text-only) tooltips on full items, you can use this function to have #GtkIconView handle these automatically for you. @column should be set to the column in @icon_view's model containing the tooltip texts, or -1 to disable this feature.
When enabled, #GtkWidget:has-tooltip will be set to %TRUE and @icon_view will connect a #GtkWidget::query-tooltip signal handler.
Note that the signal handler sets the text with gtk_tooltip_set_markup(), so &, <, etc have to be escaped in the text.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: column
parameter.parameter_description: an integer, which is a valid column number for @icon_view's model

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_tooltip_item
function.description:
Sets the tip area of @tooltip to be the area covered by the item at @path. See also gtk_icon_view_set_tooltip_column() for a simpler alternative. See also gtk_tooltip_set_tip_area().
Since: 2.12

function.name: gtk_icon_view_unselect_all
function.description:
Unselects all the icons.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_icon_view_unselect_path
function.description:
Unselects the row at @path.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_icon_view_unset_model_drag_dest
function.description:
Undoes the effect of gtk_icon_view_enable_model_drag_dest(). Calling this method sets #GtkIconView:reorderable to %FALSE.
Since: 2.8

function.name: gtk_icon_view_unset_model_drag_source
function.description:
Undoes the effect of gtk_icon_view_enable_model_drag_source(). Calling this method sets #GtkIconView:reorderable to %FALSE.
Since: 2.8

function.name: gtk_im_context_delete_surrounding
function.description:
Asks the widget that the input context is attached to to delete characters around the cursor position by emitting the GtkIMContext::delete_surrounding signal. Note that @offset and @n_chars are in characters not in bytes which differs from the usage other places in #GtkIMContext.
In order to use this function, you should first call gtk_im_context_get_surrounding() to get the current context, and call this function immediately afterwards to make sure that you know what you are deleting. You should also account for the fact that even if the signal was handled, the input context might not have deleted all the characters that were requested to be deleted.
This function is used by an input method that wants to make subsitutions in the existing text in response to new input. It is not useful for applications.

parameter.name: offset
parameter.parameter_description: offset from cursor position in chars; a negative value means start before the cursor.

function.return: %TRUE if the signal was handled.

function.name: gtk_im_context_filter_keypress
function.description: Allow an input method to internally handle key press and release events. If this function returns %TRUE, then no further processing should be done for this key event.
function.return: %TRUE if the input method handled the key event.

function.name: gtk_im_context_focus_in
function.description: Notify the input method that the widget to which this input context corresponds has gained focus. The input method may, for example, change the displayed feedback to reflect this change.

function.name: gtk_im_context_focus_out
function.description: Notify the input method that the widget to which this input context corresponds has lost focus. The input method may, for example, change the displayed feedback or reset the contexts state to reflect this change.

function.name: gtk_im_context_get_preedit_string
function.description: Retrieve the current preedit string for the input context, and a list of attributes to apply to the string. This string should be displayed inserted at the insertion point.

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the retrieved string. The string retrieved must be freed with g_free().

parameter.name: attrs
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the retrieved attribute list. When you are done with this list, you must unreference it with pango_attr_list_unref().

parameter.name: cursor_pos
parameter.parameter_description: location to store position of cursor (in characters) within the preedit string.

function.name: gtk_im_context_get_surrounding
function.description:
Retrieves context around the insertion point. Input methods typically want context in order to constrain input text based on existing text; this is important for languages such as Thai where only some sequences of characters are allowed.
This function is implemented by emitting the GtkIMContext::retrieve_surrounding signal on the input method; in response to this signal, a widget should provide as much context as is available, up to an entire paragraph, by calling gtk_im_context_set_surrounding(). Note that there is no obligation for a widget to respond to the ::retrieve_surrounding signal, so input methods must be prepared to function without context.

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: location to store a UTF-8 encoded string of text holding context around the insertion point. If the function returns %TRUE, then you must free the result stored in this location with g_free().

parameter.name: cursor_index
parameter.parameter_description: location to store byte index of the insertion cursor within @text.

function.return: %TRUE if surrounding text was provided; in this case you must free the result stored in *text.

function.name: gtk_im_context_reset
function.description: Notify the input method that a change such as a change in cursor position has been made. This will typically cause the input method to clear the preedit state.

function.name: gtk_im_context_set_client_window
function.description: Set the client window for the input context; this is the #GdkWindow in which the input appears. This window is used in order to correctly position status windows, and may also be used for purposes internal to the input method.

parameter.name: window
parameter.parameter_description: the client window. This may be %NULL to indicate that the previous client window no longer exists.

function.name: gtk_im_context_set_cursor_location
function.description: Notify the input method that a change in cursor position has been made. The location is relative to the client window.

function.name: gtk_im_context_set_surrounding
function.description: Sets surrounding context around the insertion point and preedit string. This function is expected to be called in response to the GtkIMContext::retrieve_surrounding signal, and will likely have no effect if called at other times.

parameter.name: text
len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @text, or -1 if @text is nul-terminated

parameter.name: cursor_index
parameter.parameter_description: the byte index of the insertion cursor within @text.

function.name: gtk_im_context_set_use_preedit
function.description: Sets whether the IM context should use the preedit string to display feedback. If @use_preedit is FALSE (default is TRUE), then the IM context may use some other method to display feedback, such as displaying it in a child of the root window.

parameter.name: use_preedit
parameter.parameter_description: whether the IM context should use the preedit string.

function.name: gtk_im_context_simple_add_table
function.description:
Adds an additional table to search to the input context. Each row of the table consists of @max_seq_len key symbols followed by two #guint16 interpreted as the high and low words of a #gunicode value. Tables are searched starting from the last added.
The table must be sorted in dictionary order on the numeric value of the key symbol fields. (Values beyond the length of the sequence should be zero.)

parameter.name: max_seq_len
parameter.parameter_description: Maximum length of a sequence in the table (cannot be greater than #GTK_MAX_COMPOSE_LEN)

parameter.name: n_seqs
parameter.parameter_description: number of sequences in the table

function.name: gtk_im_context_simple_new
function.description: Creates a new #GtkIMContextSimple.
function.return: a new #GtkIMContextSimple.

function.name: gtk_im_multicontext_append_menuitems
function.description:
Add menuitems for various available input methods to a menu; the menuitems, when selected, will switch the input method for the context and the global default input method.
Deprecated: 3.10: It is better to use the system-wide input method framework for changing input methods. Modern desktop shells offer on-screen displays for this that can triggered with a keyboard shortcut, e.g. Super-Space.

function.name: gtk_im_multicontext_get_context_id
function.description:
Gets the id of the currently active slave of the @context.
Since: 2.16
function.return: the id of the currently active slave

function.name: gtk_im_multicontext_new
function.description: Creates a new #GtkIMMulticontext.
function.return: a new #GtkIMMulticontext.

function.name: gtk_im_multicontext_set_context_id
function.description:
Sets the context id for @context.
This causes the currently active slave of @context to be replaced by the slave corresponding to the new context id.
Since: 2.16

function.name: gtk_image_clear
function.description:
Resets the image to be empty.
Since: 2.8

function.name: gtk_image_get_animation
function.description: Gets the #GdkPixbufAnimation being displayed by the #GtkImage. The storage type of the image must be %GTK_IMAGE_EMPTY or %GTK_IMAGE_ANIMATION (see gtk_image_get_storage_type()). The caller of this function does not own a reference to the returned animation.
function.return: the displayed animation, or %NULL if the image is empty

function.name: gtk_image_get_gicon
function.description:
Gets the #GIcon and size being displayed by the #GtkImage. The storage type of the image must be %GTK_IMAGE_EMPTY or %GTK_IMAGE_GICON (see gtk_image_get_storage_type()). The caller of this function does not own a reference to the returned #GIcon.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: place to store an icon size, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_image_get_icon_name
function.description:
Gets the icon name and size being displayed by the #GtkImage. The storage type of the image must be %GTK_IMAGE_EMPTY or %GTK_IMAGE_ICON_NAME (see gtk_image_get_storage_type()). The returned string is owned by the #GtkImage and should not be freed.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: icon_name
parameter.parameter_description: place to store an icon name, or %NULL

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: place to store an icon size, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_image_get_icon_set
function.description:
Gets the icon set and size being displayed by the #GtkImage. The storage type of the image must be %GTK_IMAGE_EMPTY or %GTK_IMAGE_ICON_SET (see gtk_image_get_storage_type()).
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_image_get_icon_name() instead.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: location to store a stock icon size, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_image_get_pixbuf
function.description: Gets the #GdkPixbuf being displayed by the #GtkImage. The storage type of the image must be %GTK_IMAGE_EMPTY or %GTK_IMAGE_PIXBUF (see gtk_image_get_storage_type()). The caller of this function does not own a reference to the returned pixbuf.
function.return: the displayed pixbuf, or %NULL if the image is empty

function.name: gtk_image_get_pixel_size
function.description:
Gets the pixel size used for named icons.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the pixel size used for named icons.

function.name: gtk_image_get_stock
function.description:
Gets the stock icon name and size being displayed by the #GtkImage. The storage type of the image must be %GTK_IMAGE_EMPTY or %GTK_IMAGE_STOCK (see gtk_image_get_storage_type()). The returned string is owned by the #GtkImage and should not be freed.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_image_get_icon_name() instead.

parameter.name: stock_id
parameter.parameter_description: place to store a stock icon name, or %NULL

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: place to store a stock icon size, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_image_get_storage_type
function.description: Gets the type of representation being used by the #GtkImage to store image data. If the #GtkImage has no image data, the return value will be %GTK_IMAGE_EMPTY.
function.return: image representation being used

function.name: gtk_image_menu_item_get_always_show_image
function.description:
Returns whether the menu item will always show the image, if available.
Since: 2.16
Deprecated: 3.10
function.return: %TRUE if the menu item will always show the image

function.name: gtk_image_menu_item_get_image
function.description:
Gets the widget that is currently set as the image of @image_menu_item. See gtk_image_menu_item_set_image().
Deprecated: 3.10
function.return: the widget set as image of @image_menu_item

function.name: gtk_image_menu_item_get_use_stock
function.description:
Checks whether the label set in the menuitem is used as a stock id to select the stock item for the item.
Since: 2.16
Deprecated: 3.10
function.return: %TRUE if the label set in the menuitem is used as a stock id to select the stock item for the item

function.name: gtk_image_menu_item_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkImageMenuItem with an empty label.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_menu_item_new() instead.
function.return: a new #GtkImageMenuItem

function.name: gtk_image_menu_item_new_from_stock
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkImageMenuItem containing the image and text from a stock item. Some stock ids have preprocessor macros like #GTK_STOCK_OK and #GTK_STOCK_APPLY.
If you want this menu item to have changeable accelerators, then pass in %NULL for accel_group. Next call gtk_menu_item_set_accel_path() with an appropriate path for the menu item, use gtk_stock_lookup() to look up the standard accelerator for the stock item, and if one is found, call gtk_accel_map_add_entry() to register it.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_menu_item_new() instead.

parameter.name: stock_id
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the stock item.

parameter.name: accel_group
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkAccelGroup to add the menu items accelerator to, or %NULL.

function.return: a new #GtkImageMenuItem.

function.name: gtk_image_menu_item_new_with_label
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkImageMenuItem containing a label.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_menu_item_new_with_label() instead.

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: the text of the menu item.

function.return: a new #GtkImageMenuItem.

function.name: gtk_image_menu_item_new_with_mnemonic
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkImageMenuItem containing a label. The label will be created using gtk_label_new_with_mnemonic(), so underscores in @label indicate the mnemonic for the menu item.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_menu_item_new_with_mnemonic() instead.

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: the text of the menu item, with an underscore in front of the mnemonic character

function.return: a new #GtkImageMenuItem

function.name: gtk_image_menu_item_set_accel_group
function.description:
Specifies an @accel_group to add the menu items accelerator to (this only applies to stock items so a stock item must already be set, make sure to call gtk_image_menu_item_set_use_stock() and gtk_menu_item_set_label() with a valid stock item first).
If you want this menu item to have changeable accelerators then you shouldnt need this (see gtk_image_menu_item_new_from_stock()).
Since: 2.16
Deprecated: 3.10

function.name: gtk_image_menu_item_set_always_show_image
function.description:
If %TRUE, the menu item will always show the image, if available.
Use this property if the menuitem would be useless or hard to use without the image.
Since: 2.16
Deprecated: 3.10

parameter.name: always_show
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the menuitem should always show the image

function.name: gtk_image_menu_item_set_image
function.description:
Sets the image of @image_menu_item to the given widget. Note that it depends on the show-menu-images setting whether the image will be displayed or not.
Deprecated: 3.10

parameter.name: image
parameter.parameter_description: a widget to set as the image for the menu item.

function.name: gtk_image_menu_item_set_use_stock
function.description:
If %TRUE, the label set in the menuitem is used as a stock id to select the stock item for the item.
Since: 2.16
Deprecated: 3.10

parameter.name: use_stock
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the menuitem should use a stock item

function.name: gtk_image_new
function.description: Creates a new empty #GtkImage widget.
function.return: a newly created #GtkImage widget.

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_animation
function.description:
Creates a #GtkImage displaying the given animation. The #GtkImage does not assume a reference to the animation; you still need to unref it if you own references. #GtkImage will add its own reference rather than adopting yours.
Note that the animation frames are shown using a timeout with #G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT. When using animations to indicate busyness, keep in mind that the animation will only be shown if the main loop is not busy with something that has a higher priority.
function.return: a new #GtkImage widget

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_file
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkImage displaying the file @filename. If the file isn't found or can't be loaded, the resulting #GtkImage will display a "broken image" icon. This function never returns %NULL, it always returns a valid #GtkImage widget.
If the file contains an animation, the image will contain an animation.
If you need to detect failures to load the file, use gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file() to load the file yourself, then create the #GtkImage from the pixbuf. (Or for animations, use gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_file()).
The storage type (gtk_image_get_storage_type()) of the returned image is not defined, it will be whatever is appropriate for displaying the file.
function.return: a new #GtkImage

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_gicon
function.description:
Creates a #GtkImage displaying an icon from the current icon theme. If the icon name isn't known, a "broken image" icon will be displayed instead. If the current icon theme is changed, the icon will be updated appropriately.
Since: 2.14
function.return: a new #GtkImage displaying the themed icon

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_icon_name
function.description:
Creates a #GtkImage displaying an icon from the current icon theme. If the icon name isn't known, a "broken image" icon will be displayed instead. If the current icon theme is changed, the icon will be updated appropriately.
Since: 2.6
function.return: a new #GtkImage displaying the themed icon

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_icon_set
function.description:
Creates a #GtkImage displaying an icon set. Sample stock sizes are #GTK_ICON_SIZE_MENU, #GTK_ICON_SIZE_SMALL_TOOLBAR. Instead of using this function, usually it's better to create a #GtkIconFactory, put your icon sets in the icon factory, add the icon factory to the list of default factories with gtk_icon_factory_add_default(), and then use gtk_image_new_from_stock(). This will allow themes to override the icon you ship with your application.
The #GtkImage does not assume a reference to the icon set; you still need to unref it if you own references. #GtkImage will add its own reference rather than adopting yours.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_image_new_from_icon_name() instead.
function.return: a new #GtkImage

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_pixbuf
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkImage displaying @pixbuf. The #GtkImage does not assume a reference to the pixbuf; you still need to unref it if you own references. #GtkImage will add its own reference rather than adopting yours.
Note that this function just creates an #GtkImage from the pixbuf. The #GtkImage created will not react to state changes. Should you want that, you should use gtk_image_new_from_icon_name().
function.return: a new #GtkImage

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_resource
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkImage displaying the resource file @resource_path. If the file isn't found or can't be loaded, the resulting #GtkImage will display a "broken image" icon. This function never returns %NULL, it always returns a valid #GtkImage widget.
If the file contains an animation, the image will contain an animation.
If you need to detect failures to load the file, use gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file() to load the file yourself, then create the #GtkImage from the pixbuf. (Or for animations, use gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_file()).
The storage type (gtk_image_get_storage_type()) of the returned image is not defined, it will be whatever is appropriate for displaying the file.
Since: 3.4
function.return: a new #GtkImage

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_stock
function.description:
Creates a #GtkImage displaying a stock icon. Sample stock icon names are #GTK_STOCK_OPEN, #GTK_STOCK_QUIT. Sample stock sizes are #GTK_ICON_SIZE_MENU, #GTK_ICON_SIZE_SMALL_TOOLBAR. If the stock icon name isn't known, the image will be empty. You can register your own stock icon names, see gtk_icon_factory_add_default() and gtk_icon_factory_add().
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_image_new_from_icon_name() instead.
function.return: a new #GtkImage displaying the stock icon

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_surface
function.description: Creates a new #GtkImage displaying @surface. The #GtkImage does not assume a reference to the surface; you still need to unref it if you own references. #GtkImage will add its own reference rather than adopting yours.
function.return: a new #GtkImage

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_animation
function.description: Causes the #GtkImage to display the given animation (or display nothing, if you set the animation to %NULL).

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_file
function.description: See gtk_image_new_from_file() for details.

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_gicon
function.description:
See gtk_image_new_from_gicon() for details.
Since: 2.14

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_icon_name
function.description:
See gtk_image_new_from_icon_name() for details.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_icon_set
function.description:
See gtk_image_new_from_icon_set() for details.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_image_set_from_icon_name() instead.

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_pixbuf
function.description: See gtk_image_new_from_pixbuf() for details.

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_resource
function.description: See gtk_image_new_from_resource() for details.

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_stock
function.description:
See gtk_image_new_from_stock() for details.
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_image_set_from_icon_name() instead.

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_surface
function.description:
See gtk_image_new_from_surface() for details.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_image_set_pixel_size
function.description:
Sets the pixel size to use for named icons. If the pixel size is set to a value != -1, it is used instead of the icon size set by gtk_image_set_from_icon_name().
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_info_bar_add_action_widget
function.description:
Add an activatable widget to the action area of a #GtkInfoBar, connecting a signal handler that will emit the #GtkInfoBar::response signal on the message area when the widget is activated. The widget is appended to the end of the message areas action area.
Since: 2.18

function.name: gtk_info_bar_add_button
function.description:
Adds a button with the given text and sets things up so that clicking the button will emit the "response" signal with the given response_id. The button is appended to the end of the info bars's action area. The button widget is returned, but usually you don't need it.
Since: 2.18
function.return: the #GtkButton widget that was added

function.name: gtk_info_bar_add_buttons
function.description:
Adds more buttons, same as calling gtk_info_bar_add_button() repeatedly. The variable argument list should be %NULL-terminated as with gtk_info_bar_new_with_buttons(). Each button must have both text and response ID.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: response ID for first button, then more text-response_id pairs, ending with %NULL

function.name: gtk_info_bar_get_action_area
function.description:
Returns the action area of @info_bar.
Since: 2.18
function.return: the action area

function.name: gtk_info_bar_get_content_area
function.description:
Returns the content area of @info_bar.
Since: 2.18
function.return: the content area

function.name: gtk_info_bar_get_message_type
function.description:
Returns the message type of the message area.
Since: 2.18
function.return: the message type of the message area.

function.name: gtk_info_bar_get_show_close_button
function.description:
Returns whether the widget will display a standard close button.
Since: 3.10
function.return: %TRUE if the widget displays standard close button

function.name: gtk_info_bar_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkInfoBar object.
Since: 2.18
function.return: a new #GtkInfoBar object

function.name: gtk_info_bar_new_with_buttons
function.description: Creates a new #GtkInfoBar with buttons. Button text/response ID pairs should be listed, with a %NULL pointer ending the list. Button text can be either a stock ID such as %GTK_STOCK_OK, or some arbitrary text. A response ID can be any positive number, or one of the values in the #GtkResponseType enumeration. If the user clicks one of these dialog buttons, GtkInfoBar will emit the "response" signal with the corresponding response ID.

parameter.name: first_button_text
parameter.parameter_description: stock ID or text to go in first button, or %NULL

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: response ID for first button, then additional buttons, ending with %NULL

function.return: a new #GtkInfoBar

function.name: gtk_info_bar_response
function.description:
Emits the 'response' signal with the given @response_id.
Since: 2.18

function.name: gtk_info_bar_set_default_response
function.description:
Sets the last widget in the info bar's action area with the given response_id as the default widget for the dialog. Pressing "Enter" normally activates the default widget.
Note that this function currently requires @info_bar to be added to a widget hierarchy.
Since: 2.18

function.name: gtk_info_bar_set_message_type
function.description:
Sets the message type of the message area. GTK+ uses this type to determine what color to use when drawing the message area.
Since: 2.18

function.name: gtk_info_bar_set_response_sensitive
function.description:
Calls gtk_widget_set_sensitive (widget, setting) for each widget in the info bars's action area with the given response_id. A convenient way to sensitize/desensitize dialog buttons.
Since: 2.18

function.name: gtk_info_bar_set_show_close_button
function.description:
If true, a standard close button is shown. When clicked it emits the response %GTK_RESPONSE_CLOSE.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_init
function.description:
Call this function before using any other GTK+ functions in your GUI applications. It will initialize everything needed to operate the toolkit and parses some standard command line options.
Although you are expected to pass the @argc, @argv parameters from main() to this function, it is possible to pass %NULL if @argv is not available or commandline handling is not required.
@argc and @argv are adjusted accordingly so your own code will never see those standard arguments.
Note that there are some alternative ways to initialize GTK+: if you are calling gtk_parse_args(), gtk_init_check(), gtk_init_with_args() or g_option_context_parse() with the option group returned by gtk_get_option_group(), you <emphasis>don't</emphasis> have to call gtk_init().
<note><para> This function will terminate your program if it was unable to initialize the windowing system for some reason. If you want your program to fall back to a textual interface you want to call gtk_init_check() instead. </para></note>
<note><para> Since 2.18, GTK+ calls <literal>signal (SIGPIPE, SIG_IGN)</literal> during initialization, to ignore SIGPIPE signals, since these are almost never wanted in graphical applications. If you do need to handle SIGPIPE for some reason, reset the handler after gtk_init(), but notice that other libraries (e.g. libdbus or gvfs) might do similar things. </para></note>

parameter.name: argc
parameter.parameter_description: Address of the <parameter>argc</parameter> parameter of your main() function (or 0 if @argv is %NULL). This will be changed if any arguments were handled.

parameter.name: argv
parameter.parameter_description: Address of the <parameter>argv</parameter> parameter of main(), or %NULL. Any options understood by GTK+ are stripped before return.

function.name: gtk_init_check
function.description:
This function does the same work as gtk_init() with only a single change: It does not terminate the program if the windowing system can't be initialized. Instead it returns %FALSE on failure.
This way the application can fall back to some other means of communication with the user - for example a curses or command line interface.

parameter.name: argc
parameter.parameter_description: Address of the <parameter>argc</parameter> parameter of your main() function (or 0 if @argv is %NULL). This will be changed if any arguments were handled.

parameter.name: argv
parameter.parameter_description: Address of the <parameter>argv</parameter> parameter of main(), or %NULL. Any options understood by GTK+ are stripped before return.

function.return: %TRUE if the windowing system has been successfully initialized, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_init_with_args
function.description:
This function does the same work as gtk_init_check(). Additionally, it allows you to add your own commandline options, and it automatically generates nicely formatted <option>--help</option> output. Note that your program will be terminated after writing out the help output.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: argc
parameter.parameter_description: Address of the <parameter>argc</parameter> parameter of your main() function (or 0 if @argv is %NULL). This will be changed if any arguments were handled.

parameter.name: argv
parameter.parameter_description: Address of the <parameter>argv</parameter> parameter of main(), or %NULL. Any options understood by GTK+ are stripped before return.

parameter.name: parameter_string
parameter.parameter_description: a string which is displayed in the first line of <option>--help</option> output, after <literal><replaceable>programname</replaceable> [OPTION...]</literal>

parameter.name: entries
parameter.parameter_description: a %NULL-terminated array of #GOptionEntrys describing the options of your program

parameter.name: translation_domain
parameter.parameter_description: a translation domain to use for translating the <option>--help</option> output for the options in @entries and the @parameter_string with gettext(), or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if the windowing system has been successfully initialized, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_invisible_get_screen
function.description:
Returns the #GdkScreen object associated with @invisible
Since: 2.2
function.return: the associated #GdkScreen.

function.name: gtk_invisible_new
function.description: Creates a new #GtkInvisible.
function.return: a new #GtkInvisible.

function.name: gtk_invisible_new_for_screen
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkInvisible object for a specified screen
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: screen
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkScreen which identifies on which the new #GtkInvisible will be created.

function.return: a newly created #GtkInvisible object

function.name: gtk_invisible_set_screen
function.description:
Sets the #GdkScreen where the #GtkInvisible object will be displayed.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gtk_key_hash_free
function.description: Destroys a key hash created with gtk_key_hash_new()

function.name: gtk_key_snooper_install
function.description:
Installs a key snooper function, which will get called on all key events before delivering them normally.
Deprecated: 3.4: Key snooping should not be done. Events should be handled by widgets.
function.return: a unique id for this key snooper for use with gtk_key_snooper_remove().

function.name: gtk_key_snooper_remove
function.description:
Removes the key snooper function with the given id.
Deprecated: 3.4: Key snooping should not be done. Events should be handled by widgets.

parameter.name: snooper_handler_id
parameter.parameter_description: Identifies the key snooper to remove

function.name: gtk_label_get_angle
function.description:
Gets the angle of rotation for the label. See gtk_label_set_angle().
Since: 2.6
function.return: the angle of rotation for the label

function.name: gtk_label_get_attributes
function.description: Gets the attribute list that was set on the label using gtk_label_set_attributes(), if any. This function does not reflect attributes that come from the labels markup (see gtk_label_set_markup()). If you want to get the effective attributes for the label, use pango_layout_get_attribute (gtk_label_get_layout (label)).
function.return: the attribute list, or %NULL if none was set.

function.name: gtk_label_get_current_uri
function.description:
Returns the URI for the currently active link in the label. The active link is the one under the mouse pointer or, in a selectable label, the link in which the text cursor is currently positioned.
This function is intended for use in a #GtkLabel::activate-link handler or for use in a #GtkWidget::query-tooltip handler.
Since: 2.18
function.return: the currently active URI. The string is owned by GTK+ and must not be freed or modified.

function.name: gtk_label_get_ellipsize
function.description:
Returns the ellipsizing position of the label. See gtk_label_set_ellipsize().
Since: 2.6
function.return: #PangoEllipsizeMode

function.name: gtk_label_get_justify
function.description: Returns the justification of the label. See gtk_label_set_justify().
function.return: #GtkJustification

function.name: gtk_label_get_label
function.description: Fetches the text from a label widget including any embedded underlines indicating mnemonics and Pango markup. (See gtk_label_get_text()).
function.return: the text of the label widget. This string is owned by the widget and must not be modified or freed.

function.name: gtk_label_get_layout
function.description: Gets the #PangoLayout used to display the label. The layout is useful to e.g. convert text positions to pixel positions, in combination with gtk_label_get_layout_offsets(). The returned layout is owned by the @label so need not be freed by the caller. The @label is free to recreate its layout at any time, so it should be considered read-only.
function.return: the #PangoLayout for this label

function.name: gtk_label_get_layout_offsets
function.description: Obtains the coordinates where the label will draw the #PangoLayout representing the text in the label; useful to convert mouse events into coordinates inside the #PangoLayout, e.g. to take some action if some part of the label is clicked. Of course you will need to create a #GtkEventBox to receive the events, and pack the label inside it, since labels are a #GTK_NO_WINDOW widget. Remember when using the #PangoLayout functions you need to convert to and from pixels using PANGO_PIXELS() or #PANGO_SCALE.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: location to store X offset of layout, or %NULL

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: location to store Y offset of layout, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_label_get_line_wrap
function.description: Returns whether lines in the label are automatically wrapped. See gtk_label_set_line_wrap().
function.return: %TRUE if the lines of the label are automatically wrapped.

function.name: gtk_label_get_line_wrap_mode
function.description:
Returns line wrap mode used by the label. See gtk_label_set_line_wrap_mode().
Since: 2.10
function.return: %TRUE if the lines of the label are automatically wrapped.

function.name: gtk_label_get_lines
function.description:
Gets the number of lines to which an ellipsized, wrapping label should be limited. See gtk_label_set_lines().
Since: 3.10
function.return: The number of lines

function.name: gtk_label_get_max_width_chars
function.description:
Retrieves the desired maximum width of @label, in characters. See gtk_label_set_width_chars().
Since: 2.6
function.return: the maximum width of the label in characters.

function.name: gtk_label_get_measuring_layout
function.description: Gets a layout that can be used for measuring sizes. The returned layout will be identical to the label's layout except for the layout's width, which will be set to @width. Do not modify the returned layout.

parameter.name: existing_layout
parameter.parameter_description: %NULL or an existing layout already in use.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the width to measure with in pango units, or -1 for infinite

function.return: a new reference to a pango layout

function.name: gtk_label_get_mnemonic_keyval
function.description: If the label has been set so that it has an mnemonic key this function returns the keyval used for the mnemonic accelerator. If there is no mnemonic set up it returns #GDK_KEY_VoidSymbol.
function.return: GDK keyval usable for accelerators, or #GDK_KEY_VoidSymbol

function.name: gtk_label_get_mnemonic_widget
function.description: Retrieves the target of the mnemonic (keyboard shortcut) of this label. See gtk_label_set_mnemonic_widget().
function.return: the target of the label's mnemonic, or %NULL if none has been set and the default algorithm will be used.

function.name: gtk_label_get_selectable
function.description: Gets the value set by gtk_label_set_selectable().
function.return: %TRUE if the user can copy text from the label

function.name: gtk_label_get_selection_bounds
function.description: Gets the selected range of characters in the label, returning %TRUE if there's a selection.

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: return location for start of selection, as a character offset

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: return location for end of selection, as a character offset

function.return: %TRUE if selection is non-empty

function.name: gtk_label_get_single_line_mode
function.description:
Returns whether the label is in single line mode.
Since: 2.6
function.return: %TRUE when the label is in single line mode.

function.name: gtk_label_get_text
function.description: Fetches the text from a label widget, as displayed on the screen. This does not include any embedded underlines indicating mnemonics or Pango markup. (See gtk_label_get_label())
function.return: the text in the label widget. This is the internal string used by the label, and must not be modified.

function.name: gtk_label_get_track_visited_links
function.description:
Returns whether the label is currently keeping track of clicked links.
Since: 2.18
function.return: %TRUE if clicked links are remembered

function.name: gtk_label_get_use_markup
function.description: Returns whether the label's text is interpreted as marked up with the <link linkend="PangoMarkupFormat">Pango text markup language</link>. See gtk_label_set_use_markup ().
function.return: %TRUE if the label's text will be parsed for markup.

function.name: gtk_label_get_use_underline
function.description: Returns whether an embedded underline in the label indicates a mnemonic. See gtk_label_set_use_underline().
function.return: %TRUE whether an embedded underline in the label indicates the mnemonic accelerator keys.

function.name: gtk_label_get_width_chars
function.description:
Retrieves the desired width of @label, in characters. See gtk_label_set_width_chars().
Since: 2.6
function.return: the width of the label in characters.

function.name: gtk_label_new
function.description: Creates a new label with the given text inside it. You can pass %NULL to get an empty label widget.
function.return: the new #GtkLabel

function.name: gtk_label_new_with_mnemonic
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkLabel, containing the text in @str.
If characters in @str are preceded by an underscore, they are underlined. If you need a literal underscore character in a label, use '__' (two underscores). The first underlined character represents a keyboard accelerator called a mnemonic. The mnemonic key can be used to activate another widget, chosen automatically, or explicitly using gtk_label_set_mnemonic_widget().
If gtk_label_set_mnemonic_widget() is not called, then the first activatable ancestor of the #GtkLabel will be chosen as the mnemonic widget. For instance, if the label is inside a button or menu item, the button or menu item will automatically become the mnemonic widget and be activated by the mnemonic.

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: The text of the label, with an underscore in front of the mnemonic character

function.return: the new #GtkLabel

function.name: gtk_label_select_region
function.description: Selects a range of characters in the label, if the label is selectable. See gtk_label_set_selectable(). If the label is not selectable, this function has no effect. If @start_offset or @end_offset are -1, then the end of the label will be substituted.

function.name: gtk_label_set_angle
function.description:
Sets the angle of rotation for the label. An angle of 90 reads from from bottom to top, an angle of 270, from top to bottom. The angle setting for the label is ignored if the label is selectable, wrapped, or ellipsized.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: angle
parameter.parameter_description: the angle that the baseline of the label makes with the horizontal, in degrees, measured counterclockwise

function.name: gtk_label_set_attributes
function.description:
Sets a #PangoAttrList; the attributes in the list are applied to the label text.
<note><para>The attributes set with this function will be applied and merged with any other attributes previously effected by way of the #GtkLabel:use-underline or #GtkLabel:use-markup properties. While it is not recommended to mix markup strings with manually set attributes, if you must; know that the attributes will be applied to the label after the markup string is parsed.</para></note>

function.name: gtk_label_set_ellipsize
function.description:
Sets the mode used to ellipsize (add an ellipsis: "...") to the text if there is not enough space to render the entire string.
Since: 2.6

function.name: gtk_label_set_justify
function.description: Sets the alignment of the lines in the text of the label relative to each other. %GTK_JUSTIFY_LEFT is the default value when the widget is first created with gtk_label_new(). If you instead want to set the alignment of the label as a whole, use gtk_misc_set_alignment() instead. gtk_label_set_justify() has no effect on labels containing only a single line.

function.name: gtk_label_set_label
function.description: Sets the text of the label. The label is interpreted as including embedded underlines and/or Pango markup depending on the values of the #GtkLabel:use-underline" and #GtkLabel:use-markup properties.

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: the new text to set for the label

function.name: gtk_label_set_line_wrap
function.description:
Toggles line wrapping within the #GtkLabel widget. %TRUE makes it break lines if text exceeds the widget's size. %FALSE lets the text get cut off by the edge of the widget if it exceeds the widget size.
Note that setting line wrapping to %TRUE does not make the label wrap at its parent container's width, because GTK+ widgets conceptually can't make their requisition depend on the parent container's size. For a label that wraps at a specific position, set the label's width using gtk_widget_set_size_request().

function.name: gtk_label_set_line_wrap_mode
function.description:
If line wrapping is on (see gtk_label_set_line_wrap()) this controls how the line wrapping is done. The default is %PANGO_WRAP_WORD which means wrap on word boundaries.
Since: 2.10

function.name: gtk_label_set_lines
function.description:
Sets the number of lines to which an ellipsized, wrapping label should be limited. This has no effect if the label is not wrapping or ellipsized. Set this to -1 if you don't want to limit the number of lines.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: lines
parameter.parameter_description: the desired number of lines, or -1

function.name: gtk_label_set_markup

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: a markup string (see <link linkend="PangoMarkupFormat">Pango markup format</link>)

function.name: gtk_label_set_markup_with_mnemonic
function.description:
Parses @str which is marked up with the <link linkend="PangoMarkupFormat">Pango text markup language</link>, setting the label's text and attribute list based on the parse results. If characters in @str are preceded by an underscore, they are underlined indicating that they represent a keyboard accelerator called a mnemonic.
The mnemonic key can be used to activate another widget, chosen automatically, or explicitly using gtk_label_set_mnemonic_widget().

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: a markup string (see <link linkend="PangoMarkupFormat">Pango markup format</link>)

function.name: gtk_label_set_max_width_chars
function.description:
Sets the desired maximum width in characters of @label to @n_chars.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: the new desired maximum width, in characters.

function.name: gtk_label_set_mnemonic_widget
function.description:
If the label has been set so that it has an mnemonic key (using i.e. gtk_label_set_markup_with_mnemonic(), gtk_label_set_text_with_mnemonic(), gtk_label_new_with_mnemonic() or the "use_underline" property) the label can be associated with a widget that is the target of the mnemonic. When the label is inside a widget (like a #GtkButton or a #GtkNotebook tab) it is automatically associated with the correct widget, but sometimes (i.e. when the target is a #GtkEntry next to the label) you need to set it explicitly using this function.
The target widget will be accelerated by emitting the GtkWidget::mnemonic-activate signal on it. The default handler for this signal will activate the widget if there are no mnemonic collisions and toggle focus between the colliding widgets otherwise.

function.name: gtk_label_set_pattern
function.description: The pattern of underlines you want under the existing text within the #GtkLabel widget. For example if the current text of the label says "FooBarBaz" passing a pattern of "___ ___" will underline "Foo" and "Baz" but not "Bar".

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: The #GtkLabel you want to set the pattern to.

function.name: gtk_label_set_selectable
function.description: Selectable labels allow the user to select text from the label, for copy-and-paste.

parameter.name: setting
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to allow selecting text in the label

function.name: gtk_label_set_single_line_mode
function.description:
Sets whether the label is in single line mode.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: single_line_mode
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the label should be in single line mode

function.name: gtk_label_set_text
function.description:
Sets the text within the #GtkLabel widget. It overwrites any text that was there before.
This will also clear any previously set mnemonic accelerators.

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: The text you want to set

function.name: gtk_label_set_text_with_mnemonic
function.description: Sets the label's text from the string @str. If characters in @str are preceded by an underscore, they are underlined indicating that they represent a keyboard accelerator called a mnemonic. The mnemonic key can be used to activate another widget, chosen automatically, or explicitly using gtk_label_set_mnemonic_widget().

function.name: gtk_label_set_track_visited_links
function.description:
Sets whether the label should keep track of clicked links (and use a different color for them).
Since: 2.18

function.name: gtk_label_set_use_markup
function.description: Sets whether the text of the label contains markup in <link linkend="PangoMarkupFormat">Pango's text markup language</link>. See gtk_label_set_markup().

parameter.name: setting
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the label's text should be parsed for markup.

function.name: gtk_label_set_use_underline
function.description: If true, an underline in the text indicates the next character should be used for the mnemonic accelerator key.

parameter.name: setting
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if underlines in the text indicate mnemonics

function.name: gtk_label_set_width_chars
function.description:
Sets the desired width in characters of @label to @n_chars.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: the new desired width, in characters.

function.name: gtk_layout_get_bin_window
function.description:
Retrieve the bin window of the layout used for drawing operations.
Since: 2.14
function.return: a #GdkWindow

function.name: gtk_layout_get_hadjustment
function.description:
This function should only be called after the layout has been placed in a #GtkScrolledWindow or otherwise configured for scrolling. It returns the #GtkAdjustment used for communication between the horizontal scrollbar and @layout.
See #GtkScrolledWindow, #GtkScrollbar, #GtkAdjustment for details.
Deprecated: 3.0: Use gtk_scrollable_get_hadjustment()
function.return: horizontal scroll adjustment

function.name: gtk_layout_get_size
function.description: Gets the size that has been set on the layout, and that determines the total extents of the layout's scrollbar area. See gtk_layout_set_size ().

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the width set on @layout, or %NULL

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the height set on @layout, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_layout_get_vadjustment
function.description:
This function should only be called after the layout has been placed in a #GtkScrolledWindow or otherwise configured for scrolling. It returns the #GtkAdjustment used for communication between the vertical scrollbar and @layout.
See #GtkScrolledWindow, #GtkScrollbar, #GtkAdjustment for details.
Deprecated: 3.0: Use gtk_scrollable_get_vadjustment()
function.return: vertical scroll adjustment

function.name: gtk_layout_move
function.description: Moves a current child of @layout to a new position.

function.name: gtk_layout_new
function.return: a new #GtkLayout

function.name: gtk_layout_put
function.description: Adds @child_widget to @layout, at position (@x,@y). @layout becomes the new parent container of @child_widget.

function.name: gtk_layout_set_hadjustment
function.description:
Sets the horizontal scroll adjustment for the layout.
See #GtkScrolledWindow, #GtkScrollbar, #GtkAdjustment for details.
Deprecated: 3.0: Use gtk_scrollable_set_hadjustment()

function.name: gtk_layout_set_size
function.description: Sets the size of the scrollable area of the layout.

function.name: gtk_layout_set_vadjustment
function.description:
Sets the vertical scroll adjustment for the layout.
See #GtkScrolledWindow, #GtkScrollbar, #GtkAdjustment for details.
Deprecated: 3.0: Use gtk_scrollable_set_vadjustment()

function.name: gtk_level_bar_add_offset_value
function.description:
Adds a new offset marker on @self at the position specified by @value. When the bar value is in the interval topped by @value (or between @value and #GtkLevelBar:max-value in case the offset is the last one on the bar) a style class named <literal>level-</literal>@name will be applied when rendering the level bar fill. If another offset marker named @name exists, its value will be replaced by @value.
Since: 3.6

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the new offset

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: the value for the new offset

function.name: gtk_level_bar_get_inverted
function.description:
Return the value of the #GtkLevelBar:inverted property.
Since: 3.8
function.return: %TRUE if the level bar is inverted

function.name: gtk_level_bar_get_max_value
function.description:
Returns the value of the #GtkLevelBar:max-value property.
Since: 3.6
function.return: a positive value

function.name: gtk_level_bar_get_min_value
function.description:
Returns the value of the #GtkLevelBar:min-value property.
Since: 3.6
function.return: a positive value

function.name: gtk_level_bar_get_mode
function.description:
Returns the value of the #GtkLevelBar:mode property.
Since: 3.6
function.return: a #GtkLevelBarMode

function.name: gtk_level_bar_get_offset_value
function.description:
Fetches the value specified for the offset marker @name in @self, returning %TRUE in case an offset named @name was found.
Since: 3.6

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of an offset in the bar

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: location where to store the value

function.return: %TRUE if the specified offset is found

function.name: gtk_level_bar_get_value
function.description:
Returns the value of the #GtkLevelBar:value property.
Since: 3.6
function.return: a value in the interval between #GtkLevelBar:min-value and #GtkLevelBar:max-value

function.name: gtk_level_bar_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkLevelBar.
Since: 3.6
function.return: a #GtkLevelBar.

function.name: gtk_level_bar_new_for_interval
function.description:
Utility constructor that creates a new #GtkLevelBar for the specified interval.
Since: 3.6
function.return: a #GtkLevelBar

function.name: gtk_level_bar_remove_offset_value
function.description:
Removes an offset marker previously added with gtk_level_bar_add_offset_value().
Since: 3.6

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of an offset in the bar

function.name: gtk_level_bar_set_inverted
function.description:
Sets the value of the #GtkLevelBar:inverted property.
Since: 3.8

function.name: gtk_level_bar_set_max_value
function.description:
Sets the value of the #GtkLevelBar:max-value property.
Since: 3.6

function.name: gtk_level_bar_set_min_value
function.description:
Sets the value of the #GtkLevelBar:min-value property.
Since: 3.6

function.name: gtk_level_bar_set_mode
function.description:
Sets the value of the #GtkLevelBar:mode property.
Since: 3.6

function.name: gtk_level_bar_set_value
function.description:
Sets the value of the #GtkLevelBar:value property.
Since: 3.6

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: a value in the interval between #GtkLevelBar:min-value and #GtkLevelBar:max-value

function.name: gtk_link_button_get_uri
function.description:
Retrieves the URI set using gtk_link_button_set_uri().
Since: 2.10
function.return: a valid URI. The returned string is owned by the link button and should not be modified or freed.

function.name: gtk_link_button_get_visited
function.description:
Retrieves the 'visited' state of the URI where the #GtkLinkButton points. The button becomes visited when it is clicked. If the URI is changed on the button, the 'visited' state is unset again.
The state may also be changed using gtk_link_button_set_visited().
Since: 2.14
function.return: %TRUE if the link has been visited, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_link_button_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkLinkButton with the URI as its text.
Since: 2.10
function.return: a new link button widget.

function.name: gtk_link_button_new_with_label
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkLinkButton containing a label.
Since: 2.10
function.return: a new link button widget.

function.name: gtk_link_button_set_uri
function.description:
Sets @uri as the URI where the #GtkLinkButton points. As a side-effect this unsets the 'visited' state of the button.
Since: 2.10

function.name: gtk_link_button_set_visited
function.description:
Sets the 'visited' state of the URI where the #GtkLinkButton points. See gtk_link_button_get_visited() for more details.
Since: 2.14

function.name: gtk_list_box_drag_highlight_row
function.description:
This is a helper function for implementing DnD onto a #GtkListBox. The passed in @row will be highlighted via gtk_drag_highlight(), and any previously highlighted row will be unhighlighted.
The row will also be unhighlighted when the widget gets a drag leave event.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_drag_unhighlight_row
function.description:
If a row has previously been highlighted via gtk_list_box_drag_highlight_row() it will have the highlight removed.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_activate_on_single_click
function.description:
Returns whether rows activate on single clicks.
Since: 3.10
function.return: %TRUE if rows are activated on single click, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_adjustment
function.description:
Gets the adjustment (if any) that the widget uses to for vertical scrolling.
Since: 3.10
function.return: the adjustment

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_row_at_index
function.description:
Gets the n:th child in the list (not counting headers).
Since: 3.10
function.return: the child #GtkWidget

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_row_at_y
function.description:
Gets the row at the @y position.
Since: 3.10
function.return: the row

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_selected_row
function.description:
Gets the selected row.
Since: 3.10
function.return: the selected #GtkWidget

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_selection_mode
function.description:
Gets the selection mode of the listbox.
Since: 3.10
function.return: a #GtkSelectionMode

function.name: gtk_list_box_insert
function.description:
Insert the @child into the @list_box at @position. If a sort function is set, the widget will actually be inserted at the calculated position and this function has the same effect of gtk_container_add().
If @position is -1, or larger than the total number of items in the @list_box, then the @child will be appended to the end.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_invalidate_filter
function.description:
Update the filtering for all rows. Call this when result of the filter function on the @list_box is changed due to an external factor. For instance, this would be used if the filter function just looked for a specific search string and the entry with the search string has changed.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_invalidate_headers
function.description:
Update the separators for all rows. Call this when result of the header function on the @list_box is changed due to an external factor.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_invalidate_sort
function.description:
Update the sorting for all rows. Call this when result of the sort function on the @list_box is changed due to an external factor.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkListBox container.
Since: 3.10
function.return: a new #GtkListBox

function.name: gtk_list_box_prepend
function.description:
Prepend a widget to the list. If a sort function is set, the widget will actually be inserted at the calculated position and this function has the same effect of gtk_container_add().
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_changed
function.description:
Marks @row as changed, causing any state that depends on this to be updated. This affects sorting, filtering and headers.
Note that calls to this method must be in sync with the data used for the row functions. For instance, if the list is mirroring some external data set, and *two* rows changed in the external data set then when you call gtk_list_box_row_changed() on the first row the sort function must only read the new data for the first of the two changed rows, otherwise the resorting of the rows will be wrong.
This generally means that if you don't fully control the data model you have to duplicate the data that affects the listbox row functions into the row widgets themselves. Another alternative is to call gtk_list_box_invalidate_sort() on any model change, but that is more expensive.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_get_header
function.description:
Returns the current header of the @row. This can be used in a #GtkListBoxUpdateHeaderFunc to see if there is a header set already, and if so to update the state of it.
Since: 3.10
function.return: the current header, or %NULL if none

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_get_index
function.description:
Gets the current index of the @row in its #GtkListBox container.
Since: 3.10
function.return: the index of the @row, or -1 if the @row is not in a listbox

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkListBoxRow, to be used as a child of a #GtkListBox.
Since: 3.10
function.return: a new #GtkListBoxRow

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_set_header
function.description:
Sets the current header of the @row. This is only allowed to be called from a #GtkListBoxUpdateHeaderFunc. It will replace any existing header in the row, and be shown in front of the row in the listbox.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_select_row
function.description:
Make @row the currently selected row.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_set_activate_on_single_click
function.description:
If @single is %TRUE, rows will be activated when you click on them, otherwise you need to double-click.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_set_adjustment
function.description:
Sets the adjustment (if any) that the widget uses to for vertical scrolling. For instance, this is used to get the page size for PageUp/Down key handling.
In the normal case when the @list_box is packed inside a #GtkScrolledWindow the adjustment from that will be picked up automatically, so there is no need to manually do that.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_set_filter_func
function.description:
By setting a filter function on the @list_box one can decide dynamically which of the rows to show. For instance, to implement a search function on a list that filters the original list to only show the matching rows.
The @filter_func will be called for each row after the call, and it will continue to be called each time a row changes (via gtk_list_box_row_changed()) or when gtk_list_box_invalidate_filter() is called.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: filter_func
parameter.parameter_description: callback that lets you filter which rows to show

function.name: gtk_list_box_set_header_func
function.description:
By setting a header function on the @list_box one can dynamically add headers in front of rows, depending on the contents of the row and its position in the list. For instance, one could use it to add headers in front of the first item of a new kind, in a list sorted by the kind.
The @update_header can look at the current header widget using gtk_list_box_row_get_header() and either update the state of the widget as needed, or set a new one using gtk_list_box_row_set_header(). If no header is needed, set the header to %NULL.
Note that you may get many calls @update_header to this for a particular row when e.g. changing things that don't affect the header. In this case it is important for performance to not blindly replace an exisiting header widh an identical one.
The @update_header function will be called for each row after the call, and it will continue to be called each time a row changes (via gtk_list_box_row_changed()) and when the row before changes (either by gtk_list_box_row_changed() on the previous row, or when the previous row becomes a different row). It is also called for all rows when gtk_list_box_invalidate_headers() is called.
Since: 3.10

parameter.name: update_header
parameter.parameter_description: callback that lets you add row headers

function.name: gtk_list_box_set_placeholder
function.description:
Sets the placeholder widget that is shown in the list when it doesn't display any visible children.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_set_selection_mode
function.description:
Sets how selection works in the listbox. See #GtkSelectionMode for details.
Note: #GtkListBox does not support @GTK_SELECTION_MULTIPLE.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_box_set_sort_func
function.description:
By setting a sort function on the @list_box one can dynamically reorder the rows of the list, based on the contents of the rows.
The @sort_func will be called for each row after the call, and will continue to be called each time a row changes (via gtk_list_box_row_changed()) and when gtk_list_box_invalidate_sort() is called.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_list_store_append
function.description: Appends a new row to @list_store. @iter will be changed to point to this new row. The row will be empty after this function is called. To fill in values, you need to call gtk_list_store_set() or gtk_list_store_set_value().

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: An unset #GtkTreeIter to set to the appended row

function.name: gtk_list_store_clear
function.description: Removes all rows from the list store.

function.name: gtk_list_store_insert
function.description: Creates a new row at @position. @iter will be changed to point to this new row. If @position is -1 or is larger than the number of rows on the list, then the new row will be appended to the list. The row will be empty after this function is called. To fill in values, you need to call gtk_list_store_set() or gtk_list_store_set_value().

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: An unset #GtkTreeIter to set to the new row

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: position to insert the new row, or -1 for last

function.name: gtk_list_store_insert_after
function.description: Inserts a new row after @sibling. If @sibling is %NULL, then the row will be prepended to the beginning of the list. @iter will be changed to point to this new row. The row will be empty after this function is called. To fill in values, you need to call gtk_list_store_set() or gtk_list_store_set_value().

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: An unset #GtkTreeIter to set to the new row

function.name: gtk_list_store_insert_before
function.description: Inserts a new row before @sibling. If @sibling is %NULL, then the row will be appended to the end of the list. @iter will be changed to point to this new row. The row will be empty after this function is called. To fill in values, you need to call gtk_list_store_set() or gtk_list_store_set_value().

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: An unset #GtkTreeIter to set to the new row

function.name: gtk_list_store_insert_with_values
function.description:
Creates a new row at @position. @iter will be changed to point to this new row. If @position is -1, or larger than the number of rows in the list, then the new row will be appended to the list. The row will be filled with the values given to this function.
Calling <literal>gtk_list_store_insert_with_values (list_store, iter, position...)</literal> has the same effect as calling |[ gtk_list_store_insert (list_store, iter, position); gtk_list_store_set (list_store, iter, ...); ]| with the difference that the former will only emit a row_inserted signal, while the latter will emit row_inserted, row_changed and, if the list store is sorted, rows_reordered. Since emitting the rows_reordered signal repeatedly can affect the performance of the program, gtk_list_store_insert_with_values() should generally be preferred when inserting rows in a sorted list store.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: An unset #GtkTreeIter to set to the new row, or %NULL

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: position to insert the new row, or -1 to append after existing rows

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: pairs of column number and value, terminated with -1

function.name: gtk_list_store_insert_with_valuesv
function.description:
A variant of gtk_list_store_insert_with_values() which takes the columns and values as two arrays, instead of varargs. This function is mainly intended for language-bindings.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: An unset #GtkTreeIter to set to the new row, or %NULL.

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: position to insert the new row, or -1 for last

parameter.name: n_values
parameter.parameter_description: the length of the @columns and @values arrays

function.name: gtk_list_store_iter_is_valid
function.description:
<warning>This function is slow. Only use it for debugging and/or testing purposes.</warning>
Checks if the given iter is a valid iter for this #GtkListStore.
Since: 2.2
function.return: %TRUE if the iter is valid, %FALSE if the iter is invalid.

function.name: gtk_list_store_move_after
function.description:
Moves @iter in @store to the position after @position. Note that this function only works with unsorted stores. If @position is %NULL, @iter will be moved to the start of the list.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gtk_list_store_move_before
function.description:
Moves @iter in @store to the position before @position. Note that this function only works with unsorted stores. If @position is %NULL, @iter will be moved to the end of the list.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gtk_list_store_new
function.description:
Creates a new list store as with @n_columns columns each of the types passed in. Note that only types derived from standard GObject fundamental types are supported.
As an example, <literal>gtk_list_store_new (3, G_TYPE_INT, G_TYPE_STRING, GDK_TYPE_PIXBUF);</literal> will create a new #GtkListStore with three columns, of type int, string and #GdkPixbuf respectively.

parameter.name: n_columns
parameter.parameter_description: number of columns in the list store

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: all #GType types for the columns, from first to last

function.return: a new #GtkListStore

function.name: gtk_list_store_newv
function.description: Non-vararg creation function. Used primarily by language bindings.

parameter.name: n_columns
parameter.parameter_description: number of columns in the list store

parameter.name: types
parameter.parameter_description: an array of #GType types for the columns, from first to last

function.return: a new #GtkListStore

function.name: gtk_list_store_prepend
function.description: Prepends a new row to @list_store. @iter will be changed to point to this new row. The row will be empty after this function is called. To fill in values, you need to call gtk_list_store_set() or gtk_list_store_set_value().

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: An unset #GtkTreeIter to set to the prepend row

function.name: gtk_list_store_remove
function.return: %TRUE if @iter is valid, %FALSE if not.

function.name: gtk_list_store_reorder
function.description:
Reorders @store to follow the order indicated by @new_order. Note that this function only works with unsorted stores.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: new_order
parameter.parameter_description: an array of integers mapping the new position of each child to its old position before the re-ordering, i.e. @new_order<literal>[newpos] = oldpos</literal>. It must have exactly as many items as the list store's length.

function.name: gtk_list_store_set
function.description:
Sets the value of one or more cells in the row referenced by @iter. The variable argument list should contain integer column numbers, each column number followed by the value to be set. The list is terminated by a -1. For example, to set column 0 with type %G_TYPE_STRING to "Foo", you would write <literal>gtk_list_store_set (store, iter, 0, "Foo", -1)</literal>.
The value will be referenced by the store if it is a %G_TYPE_OBJECT, and it will be copied if it is a %G_TYPE_STRING or %G_TYPE_BOXED.

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: pairs of column number and value, terminated with -1

function.name: gtk_list_store_set_column_types
function.description: This function is meant primarily for #GObjects that inherit from #GtkListStore, and should only be used when constructing a new #GtkListStore. It will not function after a row has been added, or a method on the #GtkTreeModel interface is called.

parameter.name: n_columns
parameter.parameter_description: Number of columns for the list store

function.name: gtk_list_store_set_valist
function.description: See gtk_list_store_set(); this version takes a va_list for use by language bindings.

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: A valid #GtkTreeIter for the row being modified

function.name: gtk_list_store_set_value
function.description: Sets the data in the cell specified by @iter and @column. The type of @value must be convertible to the type of the column.

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: A valid #GtkTreeIter for the row being modified

function.name: gtk_list_store_set_valuesv
function.description:
A variant of gtk_list_store_set_valist() which takes the columns and values as two arrays, instead of varargs. This function is mainly intended for language-bindings and in case the number of columns to change is not known until run-time.
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: A valid #GtkTreeIter for the row being modified

parameter.name: n_values
parameter.parameter_description: the length of the @columns and @values arrays

function.name: gtk_list_store_swap
function.description:
Swaps @a and @b in @store. Note that this function only works with unsorted stores.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gtk_lock_button_get_permission
function.description:
Obtains the #GPermission object that controls @button.
Since: 3.2
function.return: the #GPermission of @button

function.name: gtk_lock_button_new
function.description:
Creates a new lock button which reflects the @permission.
Since: 3.2
function.return: a new #GtkLockButton

function.name: gtk_lock_button_set_permission
function.description:
Sets the #GPermission object that controls @button.
Since: 3.2

function.name: gtk_main
function.description:
Runs the main loop until gtk_main_quit() is called.
You can nest calls to gtk_main(). In that case gtk_main_quit() will make the innermost invocation of the main loop return.

function.name: gtk_main_do_event
function.description:
Processes a single GDK event.
This is public only to allow filtering of events between GDK and GTK+. You will not usually need to call this function directly.
While you should not call this function directly, you might want to know how exactly events are handled. So here is what this function does with the event:
<orderedlist> <listitem><para> Compress enter/leave notify events. If the event passed build an enter/leave pair together with the next event (peeked from GDK), both events are thrown away. This is to avoid a backlog of (de-)highlighting widgets crossed by the pointer. </para></listitem> <listitem><para> Find the widget which got the event. If the widget can't be determined the event is thrown away unless it belongs to a INCR transaction. </para></listitem> <listitem><para> Then the event is pushed onto a stack so you can query the currently handled event with gtk_get_current_event(). </para></listitem> <listitem><para> The event is sent to a widget. If a grab is active all events for widgets that are not in the contained in the grab widget are sent to the latter with a few exceptions: <itemizedlist> <listitem><para> Deletion and destruction events are still sent to the event widget for obvious reasons. </para></listitem> <listitem><para> Events which directly relate to the visual representation of the event widget. </para></listitem> <listitem><para> Leave events are delivered to the event widget if there was an enter event delivered to it before without the paired leave event. </para></listitem> <listitem><para> Drag events are not redirected because it is unclear what the semantics of that would be. </para></listitem> </itemizedlist> Another point of interest might be that all key events are first passed through the key snooper functions if there are any. Read the description of gtk_key_snooper_install() if you need this feature. </para></listitem> <listitem><para> After finishing the delivery the event is popped from the event stack. </para></listitem> </orderedlist>

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: An event to process (normally passed by GDK)

function.name: gtk_main_iteration
function.description:
Runs a single iteration of the mainloop.
If no events are waiting to be processed GTK+ will block until the next event is noticed. If you don't want to block look at gtk_main_iteration_do() or check if any events are pending with gtk_events_pending() first.
function.return: %TRUE if gtk_main_quit() has been called for the innermost mainloop

function.name: gtk_main_iteration_do
function.description: Runs a single iteration of the mainloop. If no events are available either return or block depending on the value of @blocking.

parameter.name: blocking
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if you want GTK+ to block if no events are pending

function.return: %TRUE if gtk_main_quit() has been called for the innermost mainloop

function.name: gtk_main_level
function.description: Asks for the current nesting level of the main loop.
function.return: the nesting level of the current invocation of the main loop

function.name: gtk_main_quit
function.description: Makes the innermost invocation of the main loop return when it regains control.

function.name: gtk_menu_attach
function.description:
Adds a new #GtkMenuItem to a (table) menu. The number of 'cells' that an item will occupy is specified by @left_attach, @right_attach, @top_attach and @bottom_attach. These each represent the leftmost, rightmost, uppermost and lower column and row numbers of the table. (Columns and rows are indexed from zero).
Note that this function is not related to gtk_menu_detach().
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: left_attach
parameter.parameter_description: The column number to attach the left side of the item to

parameter.name: right_attach
parameter.parameter_description: The column number to attach the right side of the item to
