Sets the parent style context for @context. The parent style context is used to implement <ulink url="http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-cascade/#inheritance">inheritance</ulink> of properties.
If you are using a #GtkStyleContext returned from gtk_widget_get_style_context(), the parent will be set for you.
Since: 3.4

function.name: gtk_style_context_set_path
function.description:
Sets the #GtkWidgetPath used for style matching. As a consequence, the style will be regenerated to match the new given path.
If you are using a #GtkStyleContext returned from gtk_widget_get_style_context(), you do not need to call this yourself.
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_style_context_set_scale
function.description:
Sets the scale to use when getting image assets for the style .
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_style_context_set_screen
function.description:
Attaches @context to the given screen.
The screen is used to add style information from 'global' style providers, such as the screens #GtkSettings instance.
If you are using a #GtkStyleContext returned from gtk_widget_get_style_context(), you do not need to call this yourself.
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_style_context_set_state
function.description:
Sets the state to be used when rendering with any of the gtk_render_*() functions.
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_style_context_state_is_running
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if there is a transition animation running for the current region (see gtk_style_context_push_animatable_region()).
If @progress is not %NULL, the animation progress will be returned there, 0.0 means the state is closest to being unset, while 1.0 means it's closest to being set. This means transition animation will run from 0 to 1 when @state is being set and from 1 to 0 when it's being unset.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.6: This function always returns %FALSE

parameter.name: progress
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the transition progress

function.return: %TRUE if there is a running transition animation for @state.

function.name: gtk_style_copy
function.description:
Creates a copy of the passed in #GtkStyle object.
Deprecated:3.0: Use #GtkStyleContext instead
function.return: a copy of @style

function.name: gtk_style_detach
function.description:
Detaches a style from a window. If the style is not attached to any windows anymore, it is unrealized. See gtk_style_attach().
Deprecated:3.0: Use #GtkStyleContext instead

function.name: gtk_style_get
function.description:
Gets the values of a multiple style properties for @widget_type from @style.
Since: 2.16

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the first style property to get

parameter.name: Varargs

function.name: gtk_style_get_style_property

Queries the value of a style property corresponding to a widget class is in the given style.

Non-vararg variant of gtk_style_get(). Used primarily by language bindings.

Returns whether @style has an associated #GtkStyleContext.
Since: 3.0
function.return: %TRUE if @style has a #GtkStyleContext

Looks up @color_name in the style's logical color mappings, filling in @color and returning %TRUE if found, otherwise returning %FALSE. Do not cache the found mapping, because it depends on the #GtkStyle and might change when a theme switch occurs.
Since: 2.10
Deprecated:3.0: Use gtk_style_context_lookup_color() instead

function.name: gtk_style_lookup_icon_set
function.description:
Looks up @stock_id in the icon factories associated with @style and the default icon factory, returning an icon set if found, otherwise %NULL.
Deprecated:3.0: Use gtk_style_context_lookup_icon_set() instead
function.return: icon set of @stock_id

function.name: gtk_style_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkStyle.
Deprecated: 3.0: Use #GtkStyleContext
function.return: a new #GtkStyle.

function.name: gtk_style_properties_clear
function.description: Clears all style information from @props.

Retrieves several style property values from @props for a given state.

Gets a style property from @props for the given state. When done with @value, g_value_unset() needs to be called to free any allocated memory.

Retrieves several style property values from @props for a given state.

Returns the symbolic color that is mapped to @name.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: #GtkSymbolicColor is deprecated.

function.name: gtk_style_properties_lookup_property
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if a property has been registered, if @pspec or @parse_func are not %NULL, the #GParamSpec and parsing function will be respectively returned.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: This code could only look up custom properties and those are deprecated.

parameter.name: parse_func
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the parse function

function.name: gtk_style_properties_map_color
function.description:
Maps @color so it can be referenced by @name. See gtk_style_properties_lookup_color()
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: #GtkSymbolicColor is deprecated.

function.name: gtk_style_properties_merge
function.description:
Merges into @props all the style information contained in @props_to_merge. If @replace is %TRUE, the values will be overwritten, if it is %FALSE, the older values will prevail.
Since: 3.0

function.description: Returns a newly created #GtkStyleProperties

Registers a property so it can be used in the CSS file format. This function is the low-level equivalent of gtk_theming_engine_register_property(), if you are implementing a theming engine, you want to use that function instead.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: Code should use the default properties provided by CSS.

function.name: gtk_style_properties_set
function.description:
Sets several style properties on @props.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: state to set the values for

function.name: gtk_style_properties_set_property
function.description:
Sets a styling property in @props.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: state to set the value for

function.name: gtk_style_properties_set_valist
function.description:
Sets several style properties on @props.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: state to set the values for

parameter.name: args
parameter.parameter_description: va_list of property name/value pairs, followed by %NULL

function.name: gtk_style_properties_unset_property
function.description:
Unsets a style property in @props.
Since: 3.0

function.name: gtk_style_provider_get_icon_factory
function.description:
Returns the #GtkIconFactory defined to be in use for @path, or %NULL if none is defined.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: Will always return %NULL for all GTK-provided style providers.
function.return: The icon factory to use for @path, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_style_provider_get_style
function.description:
Returns the style settings affecting a widget defined by @path, or %NULL if @provider doesn't contemplate styling @path.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: Will always return %NULL for all GTK-provided style providers as the interface cannot correctly work the way CSS is specified.
function.return: a #GtkStyleProperties containing the style settings affecting @path

function.name: gtk_style_provider_get_style_property
function.description:
Looks up a widget style property as defined by @provider for the widget represented by @path.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: state

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the property value

function.return: %TRUE if the property was found and has a value, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_style_render_icon
function.description:
Renders the icon specified by @source at the given @size according to the given parameters and returns the result in a pixbuf.
Deprecated:3.0: Use gtk_render_icon_pixbuf() instead

parameter.name: source
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkIconSource specifying the icon to render

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the size to render the icon at. A size of (GtkIconSize)-1 means render at the size of the source and don't scale.

function.return: a newly-created #GdkPixbuf containing the rendered icon

function.name: gtk_style_set_background
function.description:
Sets the background of @window to the background color or pixmap specified by @style for the given state.
Deprecated:3.0: Use gtk_style_context_set_background() instead

function.name: gtk_switch_get_active
function.description:
Gets whether the #GtkSwitch is in its "on" or "off" state.
Since: 3.0
function.return: %TRUE if the #GtkSwitch is active, and %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_switch_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkSwitch widget.
Since: 3.0
function.return: the newly created #GtkSwitch instance

function.name: gtk_switch_set_active
function.description:
Changes the state of @sw to the desired one.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: is_active
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if @sw should be active, and %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_symbolic_color_new_alpha
function.description:
Creates a symbolic color by modifying the relative alpha value of @color. A factor < 1.0 would resolve to a more transparent color, while > 1.0 would resolve to a more opaque color.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: #GtkSymbolicColor is deprecated.
function.return: A newly created #GtkSymbolicColor

function.name: gtk_symbolic_color_new_literal
function.description:
Creates a symbolic color pointing to a literal color.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: #GtkSymbolicColor is deprecated.
function.return: a newly created #GtkSymbolicColor

function.name: gtk_symbolic_color_new_mix
function.description:
Creates a symbolic color defined as a mix of another two colors. a mix factor of 0 would resolve to @color1, while a factor of 1 would resolve to @color2.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: #GtkSymbolicColor is deprecated.
function.return: A newly created #GtkSymbolicColor

function.name: gtk_symbolic_color_new_name
function.description:
Creates a symbolic color pointing to an unresolved named color. See gtk_style_context_lookup_color() and gtk_style_properties_lookup_color().
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: #GtkSymbolicColor is deprecated.
function.return: a newly created #GtkSymbolicColor

function.name: gtk_symbolic_color_new_shade
function.description:
Creates a symbolic color defined as a shade of another color. A factor > 1.0 would resolve to a brighter color, while < 1.0 would resolve to a darker color.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: #GtkSymbolicColor is deprecated.
function.return: A newly created #GtkSymbolicColor

function.name: gtk_symbolic_color_new_win32
function.description:
Creates a symbolic color based on the current win32 theme.
Note that while this call is available on all platforms the actual value returned is not reliable on non-win32 platforms.
Since: 3.4
Deprecated: 3.8: #GtkSymbolicColor is deprecated.

parameter.name: theme_class
parameter.parameter_description: The theme class to pull color from

function.return: A newly created #GtkSymbolicColor

function.name: gtk_symbolic_color_ref
function.description:
Increases the reference count of @color
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: #GtkSymbolicColor is deprecated.
function.return: the same @color

function.name: gtk_symbolic_color_resolve
function.description:
If @color is resolvable, @resolved_color will be filled in with the resolved color, and %TRUE will be returned. Generally, if @color can't be resolved, it is due to it being defined on top of a named color that doesn't exist in @props.
When @props is %NULL, resolving of named colors will fail, so if your @color is or references such a color, this function will return %FALSE.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: #GtkSymbolicColor is deprecated.

parameter.name: props
parameter.parameter_description: #GtkStyleProperties to use when resolving named colors, or %NULL

parameter.name: resolved_color
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the resolved color

function.return: %TRUE if the color has been resolved

function.name: gtk_symbolic_color_to_string
function.description:
Converts the given @color to a string representation. This is useful both for debugging and for serialization of strings. The format of the string may change between different versions of GTK, but it is guaranteed that the GTK css parser is able to read the string and create the same symbolic color from it.
Deprecated: 3.8: #GtkSymbolicColor is deprecated.

parameter.name: color
parameter.parameter_description: color to convert to a string

function.return: a new string representing @color

function.name: gtk_symbolic_color_unref
function.description:
Decreases the reference count of @color, freeing its memory if the reference count reaches 0.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: #GtkSymbolicColor is deprecated.

function.name: gtk_table_attach
function.description:
Adds a widget to a table. The number of 'cells' that a widget will occupy is specified by @left_attach, @right_attach, @top_attach and @bottom_attach. These each represent the leftmost, rightmost, uppermost and lowest column and row numbers of the table. (Columns and rows are indexed from zero).
To make a button occupy the lower right cell of a 2x2 table, use <informalexample><programlisting> gtk_table_attach (table, button, 1, 2, // left, right attach 1, 2, // top, bottom attach xoptions, yoptions, xpadding, ypadding); </programlisting></informalexample> If you want to make the button span the entire bottom row, use @left_attach == 0 and @right_attach = 2 instead.
Deprecated: 3.4: Use gtk_grid_attach() with #GtkGrid. Note that the attach arguments differ between those two functions.

parameter.name: table
parameter.parameter_description: The #GtkTable to add a new widget to.

parameter.name: left_attach
parameter.parameter_description: the column number to attach the left side of a child widget to.

parameter.name: right_attach
parameter.parameter_description: the column number to attach the right side of a child widget to.

parameter.name: top_attach
parameter.parameter_description: the row number to attach the top of a child widget to.

parameter.name: bottom_attach
parameter.parameter_description: the row number to attach the bottom of a child widget to.

parameter.name: xoptions
parameter.parameter_description: Used to specify the properties of the child widget when the table is resized.

parameter.name: yoptions
parameter.parameter_description: The same as xoptions, except this field determines behaviour of vertical resizing.

parameter.name: xpadding
parameter.parameter_description: An integer value specifying the padding on the left and right of the widget being added to the table.

parameter.name: ypadding
parameter.parameter_description: The amount of padding above and below the child widget.

function.name: gtk_table_attach_defaults
function.description:
As there are many options associated with gtk_table_attach(), this convenience function provides the programmer with a means to add children to a table with identical padding and expansion options. The values used for the #GtkAttachOptions are <literal>GTK_EXPAND | GTK_FILL</literal>, and the padding is set to 0.
Deprecated: 3.4: Use gtk_grid_attach() with #GtkGrid. Note that the attach arguments differ between those two functions.

parameter.name: table
parameter.parameter_description: The table to add a new child widget to.

parameter.name: left_attach
parameter.parameter_description: The column number to attach the left side of the child widget to.

parameter.name: right_attach
parameter.parameter_description: The column number to attach the right side of the child widget to.

parameter.name: top_attach
parameter.parameter_description: The row number to attach the top of the child widget to.

parameter.name: bottom_attach
parameter.parameter_description: The row number to attach the bottom of the child widget to.

function.name: gtk_table_get_col_spacing
function.description:
Gets the amount of space between column @col, and column @col + 1. See gtk_table_set_col_spacing().
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkGrid does not offer a replacement for this functionality.

parameter.name: column
parameter.parameter_description: a column in the table, 0 indicates the first column

function.return: the column spacing

function.name: gtk_table_get_default_col_spacing
function.description:
Gets the default column spacing for the table. This is the spacing that will be used for newly added columns. (See gtk_table_set_col_spacings())
Deprecated: 3.4: Use gtk_grid_get_column_spacing() with #GtkGrid.
function.return: the default column spacing

function.name: gtk_table_get_default_row_spacing
function.description:
Gets the default row spacing for the table. This is the spacing that will be used for newly added rows. (See gtk_table_set_row_spacings())
Deprecated: 3.4: Use gtk_grid_get_row_spacing() with #GtkGrid.
function.return: the default row spacing

function.name: gtk_table_get_homogeneous
function.description:
Returns whether the table cells are all constrained to the same width and height. (See gtk_table_set_homogenous ())
Deprecated: 3.4: Use gtk_grid_get_row_homogeneous() and gtk_grid_get_column_homogeneous() with #GtkGrid.
function.return: %TRUE if the cells are all constrained to the same size

function.name: gtk_table_get_row_spacing
function.description:
Gets the amount of space between row @row, and row @row + 1. See gtk_table_set_row_spacing().
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkGrid does not offer a replacement for this functionality.

parameter.name: row
parameter.parameter_description: a row in the table, 0 indicates the first row

function.return: the row spacing

function.name: gtk_table_get_size
function.description:
Gets the number of rows and columns in the table.
Since: 2.22
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkGrid does not expose the number of columns and rows.

parameter.name: rows
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of rows, or %NULL

parameter.name: columns
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of columns, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_table_new
function.description:
Used to create a new table widget. An initial size must be given by specifying how many rows and columns the table should have, although this can be changed later with gtk_table_resize(). @rows and @columns must both be in the range 1 .. 65535. For historical reasons, 0 is accepted as well and is silently interpreted as 1.
Deprecated: 3.4: Use gtk_grid_new().

parameter.name: rows
parameter.parameter_description: The number of rows the new table should have.

parameter.name: columns
parameter.parameter_description: The number of columns the new table should have.

parameter.name: homogeneous
parameter.parameter_description: If set to %TRUE, all table cells are resized to the size of the cell containing the largest widget.

function.return: A pointer to the newly created table widget.

function.name: gtk_table_resize
function.description:
If you need to change a table's size <emphasis>after</emphasis> it has been created, this function allows you to do so.
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkGrid resizes automatically.

parameter.name: table
parameter.parameter_description: The #GtkTable you wish to change the size of.

function.name: gtk_table_set_col_spacing
function.description:
Alters the amount of space between a given table column and the following column.
Deprecated: 3.4: Use gtk_widget_set_margin_left() and gtk_widget_set_margin_right() on the widgets contained in the row if you need this functionality. #GtkGrid does not support per-row spacing.

parameter.name: column
parameter.parameter_description: the column whose spacing should be changed.

parameter.name: spacing
parameter.parameter_description: number of pixels that the spacing should take up.

function.name: gtk_table_set_col_spacings
function.description:
Sets the space between every column in @table equal to @spacing.
Deprecated: 3.4: Use gtk_grid_set_column_spacing() with #GtkGrid.

parameter.name: spacing
parameter.parameter_description: the number of pixels of space to place between every column in the table.

function.name: gtk_table_set_homogeneous
function.description:
Changes the homogenous property of table cells, ie. whether all cells are an equal size or not.
Deprecated: 3.4: Use gtk_grid_set_row_homogeneous() and gtk_grid_set_column_homogeneous() with #GtkGrid.

parameter.name: table
parameter.parameter_description: The #GtkTable you wish to set the homogeneous properties of.

parameter.name: homogeneous
parameter.parameter_description: Set to %TRUE to ensure all table cells are the same size. Set to %FALSE if this is not your desired behaviour.

function.name: gtk_table_set_row_spacing
function.description:
Changes the space between a given table row and the subsequent row.
Deprecated: 3.4: Use gtk_widget_set_margin_top() and gtk_widget_set_margin_bottom() on the widgets contained in the row if you need this functionality. #GtkGrid does not support per-row spacing.

parameter.name: table
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkTable containing the row whose properties you wish to change.

parameter.name: row
parameter.parameter_description: row number whose spacing will be changed.

parameter.name: spacing
parameter.parameter_description: number of pixels that the spacing should take up.

function.name: gtk_table_set_row_spacings
function.description:
Sets the space between every row in @table equal to @spacing.
Deprecated: 3.4: Use gtk_grid_set_row_spacing() with #GtkGrid.

parameter.name: spacing
parameter.parameter_description: the number of pixels of space to place between every row in the table.

function.name: gtk_target_entry_copy
function.description: Makes a copy of a #GtkTargetEntry structure and its data.
function.return: a pointer to a copy of @data. Free with gtk_target_entry_free()

function.name: gtk_target_entry_free
function.description: Frees a #GtkTargetEntry structure returned from gtk_target_entry_new() or gtk_target_entry_copy().

function.name: gtk_target_entry_new
function.description: Makes a new #GtkTargetEntry structure.

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: an ID that will be passed back to the application

function.return: a pointer to a new GtkTargetEntry structure. Free with gtk_target_entry_free()

function.name: gtk_target_list_add
function.description: Appends another target to a #GtkTargetList.

parameter.name: target
parameter.parameter_description: the interned atom representing the target

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: an ID that will be passed back to the application

function.name: gtk_target_list_add_image_targets
function.description:
Appends the image targets supported by #GtkSelection to the target list. All targets are added with the same @info.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: an ID that will be passed back to the application

parameter.name: writable
parameter.parameter_description: whether to add only targets for which GTK+ knows how to convert a pixbuf into the format

function.name: gtk_target_list_add_rich_text_targets
function.description:
Appends the rich text targets registered with gtk_text_buffer_register_serialize_format() or gtk_text_buffer_register_deserialize_format() to the target list. All targets are added with the same @info.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: an ID that will be passed back to the application

parameter.name: deserializable
parameter.parameter_description: if %TRUE, then deserializable rich text formats will be added, serializable formats otherwise.

function.name: gtk_target_list_add_table
function.description: Prepends a table of #GtkTargetEntry to a target list.

parameter.name: ntargets
parameter.parameter_description: number of targets in the table

function.name: gtk_target_list_add_text_targets
function.description:
Appends the text targets supported by #GtkSelection to the target list. All targets are added with the same @info.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: an ID that will be passed back to the application

function.name: gtk_target_list_add_uri_targets
function.description:
Appends the URI targets supported by #GtkSelection to the target list. All targets are added with the same @info.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: an ID that will be passed back to the application

function.name: gtk_target_list_find
function.description: Looks up a given target in a #GtkTargetList.

parameter.name: target
parameter.parameter_description: an interned atom representing the target to search for

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the location to store application info for target, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if the target was found, otherwise %FALSE

function.name: gtk_target_list_new
function.description: Creates a new #GtkTargetList from an array of #GtkTargetEntry.
function.return: the new #GtkTargetList.

function.name: gtk_target_list_ref
function.description: Increases the reference count of a #GtkTargetList by one.
function.return: the passed in #GtkTargetList.

function.name: gtk_target_list_remove
function.description: Removes a target from a target list.

parameter.name: target
parameter.parameter_description: the interned atom representing the target

function.name: gtk_target_list_unref
function.description: Decreases the reference count of a #GtkTargetList by one. If the resulting reference count is zero, frees the list.

function.name: gtk_target_table_free
function.description:
This function frees a target table as returned by gtk_target_table_new_from_list()
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: n_targets
parameter.parameter_description: the number of entries in the array

function.name: gtk_target_table_new_from_list
function.description:
This function creates an #GtkTargetEntry array that contains the same targets as the passed %list. The returned table is newly allocated and should be freed using gtk_target_table_free() when no longer needed.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: n_targets
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number ot targets in the table

function.return: the new table.

function.name: gtk_targets_include_image
function.description:
Determines if any of the targets in @targets can be used to provide a #GdkPixbuf.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: writable
parameter.parameter_description: whether to accept only targets for which GTK+ knows how to convert a pixbuf into the format

function.return: %TRUE if @targets include a suitable target for images, otherwise %FALSE.

function.name: gtk_targets_include_rich_text
function.description:
Determines if any of the targets in @targets can be used to provide rich text.
Since: 2.10
function.return: %TRUE if @targets include a suitable target for rich text, otherwise %FALSE.

function.name: gtk_targets_include_text
function.description:
Determines if any of the targets in @targets can be used to provide text.
Since: 2.10
function.return: %TRUE if @targets include a suitable target for text, otherwise %FALSE.

function.name: gtk_targets_include_uri
function.description:
Determines if any of the targets in @targets can be used to provide an uri list.
Since: 2.10
function.return: %TRUE if @targets include a suitable target for uri lists, otherwise %FALSE.

function.name: gtk_tearoff_menu_item_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkTearoffMenuItem.
Deprecated: 3.4: #GtkTearoffMenuItem is deprecated and should not be used in newly written code.
function.return: a new #GtkTearoffMenuItem.

function.name: gtk_test_create_simple_window
function.description:
Create a simple window with window title @window_title and text contents @dialog_text. The window will quit any running gtk_main()-loop when destroyed, and it will automatically be destroyed upon test function teardown.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: window_title
parameter.parameter_description: Title of the window to be displayed.

parameter.name: dialog_text
parameter.parameter_description: Text inside the window to be displayed.

function.return: a widget pointer to the newly created GtkWindow.

function.name: gtk_test_create_widget
function.description:
This function wraps g_object_new() for widget types. It'll automatically show all created non window widgets, also g_object_ref_sink() them (to keep them alive across a running test) and set them up for destruction during the next test teardown phase.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: Name of first property to set or %NULL

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: value to set the first property to, followed by more name-value pairs, terminated by %NULL

function.return: a newly created widget.

function.name: gtk_test_display_button_window
function.description:
Create a window with window title @window_title, text contents @dialog_text, and a number of buttons, according to the paired argument list given as @... parameters. Each button is created with a @label and a ::clicked signal handler that incremrents the integer stored in @nump. The window will be automatically shown with gtk_widget_show_now() after creation, so when this function returns it has already been mapped, resized and positioned on screen. The window will quit any running gtk_main()-loop when destroyed, and it will automatically be destroyed upon test function teardown.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: window_title
parameter.parameter_description: Title of the window to be displayed.

parameter.name: dialog_text
parameter.parameter_description: Text inside the window to be displayed.

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: %NULL terminated list of (const char *label, int *nump) pairs.

function.return: a widget pointer to the newly created GtkWindow.

function.name: gtk_test_find_label
function.description:
This function will search @widget and all its descendants for a GtkLabel widget with a text string matching @label_pattern. The @label_pattern may contain asterisks '*' and question marks '?' as placeholders, g_pattern_match() is used for the matching. Note that locales other than "C" tend to alter (translate" label strings, so this function is genrally only useful in test programs with predetermined locales, see gtk_test_init() for more details.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: label_pattern
parameter.parameter_description: Shell-glob pattern to match a label string.

function.return: a GtkLabel widget if any is found.

function.name: gtk_test_find_sibling
function.description:
This function will search siblings of @base_widget and siblings of its ancestors for all widgets matching @widget_type. Of the matching widgets, the one that is geometrically closest to @base_widget will be returned. The general purpose of this function is to find the most likely "action" widget, relative to another labeling widget. Such as finding a button or text entry widget, given its corresponding label widget.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: base_widget
parameter.parameter_description: Valid widget, part of a widget hierarchy

parameter.name: widget_type
parameter.parameter_description: Type of a aearched for sibling widget

function.return: a widget of type @widget_type if any is found.

function.name: gtk_test_find_widget
function.description:
This function will search the descendants of @widget for a widget of type @widget_type that has a label matching @label_pattern next to it. This is most useful for automated GUI testing, e.g. to find the "OK" button in a dialog and synthesize clicks on it. However see gtk_test_find_label(), gtk_test_find_sibling() and gtk_test_widget_click() for possible caveats involving the search of such widgets and synthesizing widget events.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: label_pattern
parameter.parameter_description: Shell-glob pattern to match a label string.

parameter.name: widget_type
parameter.parameter_description: Type of a aearched for label sibling widget.

function.return: a valid widget if any is found or %NULL.

function.name: gtk_test_init
function.description:
This function is used to initialize a GTK+ test program.
It will in turn call g_test_init() and gtk_init() to properly initialize the testing framework and graphical toolkit. It'll also set the program's locale to "C" and prevent loading of rc files and Gtk+ modules. This is done to make tets program environments as deterministic as possible.
Like gtk_init() and g_test_init(), any known arguments will be processed and stripped from @argc and @argv.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: argcp
parameter.parameter_description: Address of the <parameter>argc</parameter> parameter of the main() function. Changed if any arguments were handled.

parameter.name: argvp
parameter.parameter_description: Address of the <parameter>argv</parameter> parameter of main(). Any parameters understood by g_test_init() or gtk_init() are stripped before return.

function.name: gtk_test_list_all_types
function.description:
Return the type ids that have been registered after calling gtk_test_register_all_types().
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: n_types
parameter.parameter_description: location to store number of types

function.return: 0-terminated array of type ids

function.name: gtk_test_register_all_types
function.description:
Force registration of all core Gtk+ and Gdk object types. This allowes to refer to any of those object types via g_type_from_name() after calling this function.
Since: 2.14

function.name: gtk_test_slider_get_value
function.description:
Retrive the literal adjustment value for GtkRange based widgets and spin buttons. Note that the value returned by this function is anything between the lower and upper bounds of the adjustment belonging to @widget, and is not a percentage as passed in to gtk_test_slider_set_perc().
Since: 2.14
function.return: gtk_adjustment_get_value (adjustment) for an adjustment belonging to @widget.

function.name: gtk_test_slider_set_perc
function.description:
This function will adjust the slider position of all GtkRange based widgets, such as scrollbars or scales, it'll also adjust spin buttons. The adjustment value of these widgets is set to a value between the lower and upper limits, according to the @percentage argument.
Since: 2.14

function.name: gtk_test_spin_button_click
function.description:
This function will generate a @button click in the upwards or downwards spin button arrow areas, usually leading to an increase or decrease of spin button's value.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: Number of the pointer button for the event, usually 1, 2 or 3.

parameter.name: upwards
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE for upwards arrow click, %FALSE for downwards arrow click.

function.return: whether all actions neccessary for the button click simulation were carried out successfully.

function.name: gtk_test_text_get
function.description:
Retrive the text string of @widget if it is a GtkLabel, GtkEditable (entry and text widgets) or GtkTextView.
Since: 2.14
function.return: new 0-terminated C string, needs to be released with g_free().

function.name: gtk_test_text_set
function.description:
Set the text string of @widget to @string if it is a GtkLabel, GtkEditable (entry and text widgets) or GtkTextView.
Since: 2.14

function.name: gtk_test_widget_click
function.description:
This function will generate a @button click (button press and button release event) in the middle of the first GdkWindow found that belongs to @widget. For %GTK_NO_WINDOW widgets like GtkButton, this will often be an input-only event window. For other widgets, this is usually widget->window. Certain caveats should be considered when using this function, in particular because the mouse pointer is warped to the button click location, see gdk_test_simulate_button() for details.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: Widget to generate a button click on.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: Number of the pointer button for the event, usually 1, 2 or 3.

parameter.name: modifiers
parameter.parameter_description: Keyboard modifiers the event is setup with.

function.return: whether all actions neccessary for the button click simulation were carried out successfully.

function.name: gtk_test_widget_send_key
function.description:
This function will generate keyboard press and release events in the middle of the first GdkWindow found that belongs to @widget. For %GTK_NO_WINDOW widgets like GtkButton, this will often be an input-only event window. For other widgets, this is usually widget->window. Certain caveats should be considered when using this function, in particular because the mouse pointer is warped to the key press location, see gdk_test_simulate_key() for details.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: Widget to generate a key press and release on.

parameter.name: modifiers
parameter.parameter_description: Keyboard modifiers the event is setup with.

function.return: whether all actions neccessary for the key event simulation were carried out successfully.

function.name: gtk_test_widget_wait_for_draw
function.description:
Enters the main loop and waits for @widget to be "drawn". In this context that means it waits for the frame clock of @widget to have run a full styling, layout and drawing cycle.
This function is intended to be used for syncing with actions that depend on @widget relayouting or on interaction with the display server.
Since: 3.10

function.name: gtk_text_attributes_copy
function.description: Copies @src and returns a new #GtkTextAttributes.
function.return: a copy of @src, free with gtk_text_attributes_unref()

function.name: gtk_text_attributes_copy_values
function.description: Copies the values from @src to @dest so that @dest has the same values as @src. Frees existing values in @dest.

function.name: gtk_text_attributes_new
function.description: Creates a #GtkTextAttributes, which describes a set of properties on some text.
function.return: a new #GtkTextAttributes, free with gtk_text_attributes_unref().

function.name: gtk_text_attributes_ref
function.description: Increments the reference count on @values.
function.return: the #GtkTextAttributes that were passed in

function.name: gtk_text_attributes_unref
function.description: Decrements the reference count on @values, freeing the structure if the reference count reaches 0.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_add_mark
function.description:
Adds the mark at position @where. The mark must not be added to another buffer, and if its name is not %NULL then there must not be another mark in the buffer with the same name.
Emits the "mark-set" signal as notification of the mark's initial placement.
Since: 2.12

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_add_selection_clipboard
function.description: Adds @clipboard to the list of clipboards in which the selection contents of @buffer are available. In most cases, @clipboard will be the #GtkClipboard of type %GDK_SELECTION_PRIMARY for a view of @buffer.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_apply_tag

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: one bound of range to be tagged

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: other bound of range to be tagged

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_apply_tag_by_name
function.description: Calls gtk_text_tag_table_lookup() on the buffer's tag table to get a #GtkTextTag, then calls gtk_text_buffer_apply_tag().

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: one bound of range to be tagged

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: other bound of range to be tagged

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_backspace
function.description:
Performs the appropriate action as if the user hit the delete key with the cursor at the position specified by @iter. In the normal case a single character will be deleted, but when combining accents are involved, more than one character can be deleted, and when precomposed character and accent combinations are involved, less than one character will be deleted.
Because the buffer is modified, all outstanding iterators become invalid after calling this function; however, the @iter will be re-initialized to point to the location where text was deleted.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: interactive
parameter.parameter_description: whether the deletion is caused by user interaction

parameter.name: default_editable
parameter.parameter_description: whether the buffer is editable by default

function.return: %TRUE if the buffer was modified

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_begin_user_action
function.description:
Called to indicate that the buffer operations between here and a call to gtk_text_buffer_end_user_action() are part of a single user-visible operation. The operations between gtk_text_buffer_begin_user_action() and gtk_text_buffer_end_user_action() can then be grouped when creating an undo stack. #GtkTextBuffer maintains a count of calls to gtk_text_buffer_begin_user_action() that have not been closed with a call to gtk_text_buffer_end_user_action(), and emits the "begin-user-action" and "end-user-action" signals only for the outermost pair of calls. This allows you to build user actions from other user actions.
The "interactive" buffer mutation functions, such as gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive(), automatically call begin/end user action around the buffer operations they perform, so there's no need to add extra calls if you user action consists solely of a single call to one of those functions.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_copy_clipboard
function.description: Copies the currently-selected text to a clipboard.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_create_child_anchor
function.description: This is a convenience function which simply creates a child anchor with gtk_text_child_anchor_new() and inserts it into the buffer with gtk_text_buffer_insert_child_anchor(). The new anchor is owned by the buffer; no reference count is returned to the caller of gtk_text_buffer_create_child_anchor().
function.return: the created child anchor

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_create_mark
function.description:
Creates a mark at position @where. If @mark_name is %NULL, the mark is anonymous; otherwise, the mark can be retrieved by name using gtk_text_buffer_get_mark(). If a mark has left gravity, and text is inserted at the mark's current location, the mark will be moved to the left of the newly-inserted text. If the mark has right gravity (@left_gravity = %FALSE), the mark will end up on the right of newly-inserted text. The standard left-to-right cursor is a mark with right gravity (when you type, the cursor stays on the right side of the text you're typing).
The caller of this function does <emphasis>not</emphasis> own a reference to the returned #GtkTextMark, so you can ignore the return value if you like. Marks are owned by the buffer and go away when the buffer does.
Emits the "mark-set" signal as notification of the mark's initial placement.

parameter.name: left_gravity
parameter.parameter_description: whether the mark has left gravity

function.return: the new #GtkTextMark object

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_create_tag
function.description:
Creates a tag and adds it to the tag table for @buffer. Equivalent to calling gtk_text_tag_new() and then adding the tag to the buffer's tag table. The returned tag is owned by the buffer's tag table, so the ref count will be equal to one.
If @tag_name is %NULL, the tag is anonymous.
If @tag_name is non-%NULL, a tag called @tag_name must not already exist in the tag table for this buffer.
The @first_property_name argument and subsequent arguments are a list of properties to set on the tag, as with g_object_set().

parameter.name: tag_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the new tag, or %NULL

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of first property to set, or %NULL

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: %NULL-terminated list of property names and values

function.return: a new tag

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_cut_clipboard
function.description: Copies the currently-selected text to a clipboard, then deletes said text if it's editable.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_delete
function.description: Deletes text between @start and @end. The order of @start and @end is not actually relevant; gtk_text_buffer_delete() will reorder them. This function actually emits the "delete-range" signal, and the default handler of that signal deletes the text. Because the buffer is modified, all outstanding iterators become invalid after calling this function; however, the @start and @end will be re-initialized to point to the location where text was deleted.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_delete_interactive
function.description: Deletes all <emphasis>editable</emphasis> text in the given range. Calls gtk_text_buffer_delete() for each editable sub-range of [@start,@end). @start and @end are revalidated to point to the location of the last deleted range, or left untouched if no text was deleted.

parameter.name: default_editable
parameter.parameter_description: whether the buffer is editable by default

function.return: whether some text was actually deleted

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_delete_mark
function.description: Deletes @mark, so that it's no longer located anywhere in the buffer. Removes the reference the buffer holds to the mark, so if you haven't called g_object_ref() on the mark, it will be freed. Even if the mark isn't freed, most operations on @mark become invalid, until it gets added to a buffer again with gtk_text_buffer_add_mark(). Use gtk_text_mark_get_deleted() to find out if a mark has been removed from its buffer. The "mark-deleted" signal will be emitted as notification after the mark is deleted.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_delete_mark_by_name
function.description: Deletes the mark named @name; the mark must exist. See gtk_text_buffer_delete_mark() for details.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_delete_selection
function.description: Deletes the range between the "insert" and "selection_bound" marks, that is, the currently-selected text. If @interactive is %TRUE, the editability of the selection will be considered (users can't delete uneditable text).

parameter.name: interactive
parameter.parameter_description: whether the deletion is caused by user interaction

parameter.name: default_editable
parameter.parameter_description: whether the buffer is editable by default

function.return: whether there was a non-empty selection to delete

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_deserialize

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: the rich text format to use for deserializing

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: insertion point for the deserialized text

function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_deserialize_get_can_create_tags
function.description:
This functions returns the value set with gtk_text_buffer_deserialize_set_can_create_tags()
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkAtom representing a registered rich text format

function.return: whether deserializing this format may create tags

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_deserialize_set_can_create_tags
function.description:
Use this function to allow a rich text deserialization function to create new tags in the receiving buffer. Note that using this function is almost always a bad idea, because the rich text functions you register should know how to map the rich text format they handler to your text buffers set of tags.
The ability of creating new (arbitrary!) tags in the receiving buffer is meant for special rich text formats like the internal one that is registered using gtk_text_buffer_register_deserialize_tagset(), because that format is essentially a dump of the internal structure of the source buffer, including its tag names.
You should allow creation of tags only if you know what you are doing, e.g. if you defined a tagset name for your application suite's text buffers and you know that it's fine to receive new tags from these buffers, because you know that your application can handle the newly created tags.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkAtom representing a registered rich text format

parameter.name: can_create_tags
parameter.parameter_description: whether deserializing this format may create tags

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_end_user_action
function.description: Should be paired with a call to gtk_text_buffer_begin_user_action(). See that function for a full explanation.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_bounds
function.description: Retrieves the first and last iterators in the buffer, i.e. the entire buffer lies within the range [@start,@end).

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: iterator to initialize with first position in the buffer

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: iterator to initialize with the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_char_count
function.description: Gets the number of characters in the buffer; note that characters and bytes are not the same, you can't e.g. expect the contents of the buffer in string form to be this many bytes long. The character count is cached, so this function is very fast.
function.return: number of characters in the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_copy_target_list
function.description:
This function returns the list of targets this text buffer can provide for copying and as DND source. The targets in the list are added with @info values from the #GtkTextBufferTargetInfo enum, using gtk_target_list_add_rich_text_targets() and gtk_target_list_add_text_targets().
Since: 2.10
function.return: the #GtkTargetList

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_deserialize_formats
function.description:
This function returns the rich text deserialize formats registered with @buffer using gtk_text_buffer_register_deserialize_format() or gtk_text_buffer_register_deserialize_tagset()
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: n_formats
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of formats

function.return: an array of #GdkAtom<!-- -->s representing the registered formats.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_end_iter
function.description: Initializes @iter with the "end iterator," one past the last valid character in the text buffer. If dereferenced with gtk_text_iter_get_char(), the end iterator has a character value of 0. The entire buffer lies in the range from the first position in the buffer (call gtk_text_buffer_get_start_iter() to get character position 0) to the end iterator.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_has_selection
function.description:
Indicates whether the buffer has some text currently selected.
Since: 2.10
function.return: %TRUE if the there is text selected

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_insert
function.description: Returns the mark that represents the cursor (insertion point). Equivalent to calling gtk_text_buffer_get_mark() to get the mark named "insert", but very slightly more efficient, and involves less typing.
function.return: insertion point mark

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_child_anchor
function.description: Obtains the location of @anchor within @buffer.

parameter.name: anchor
parameter.parameter_description: a child anchor that appears in @buffer

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_line
function.description: Initializes @iter to the start of the given line.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_line_index
function.description: Obtains an iterator pointing to @byte_index within the given line. @byte_index must be the start of a UTF-8 character, and must not be beyond the end of the line. Note <emphasis>bytes</emphasis>, not characters; UTF-8 may encode one character as multiple bytes.

parameter.name: byte_index
parameter.parameter_description: byte index from start of line

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_line_offset
function.description: Obtains an iterator pointing to @char_offset within the given line. The @char_offset must exist, offsets off the end of the line are not allowed. Note <emphasis>characters</emphasis>, not bytes; UTF-8 may encode one character as multiple bytes.

parameter.name: char_offset
parameter.parameter_description: char offset from start of line

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_mark
function.description: Initializes @iter with the current position of @mark.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_offset
function.description: Initializes @iter to a position @char_offset chars from the start of the entire buffer. If @char_offset is -1 or greater than the number of characters in the buffer, @iter is initialized to the end iterator, the iterator one past the last valid character in the buffer.

parameter.name: char_offset
parameter.parameter_description: char offset from start of buffer, counting from 0, or -1

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_line_count
function.description: Obtains the number of lines in the buffer. This value is cached, so the function is very fast.
function.return: number of lines in the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_mark
function.description: Returns the mark named @name in buffer @buffer, or %NULL if no such mark exists in the buffer.
function.return: a #GtkTextMark, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_modified
function.description: Indicates whether the buffer has been modified since the last call to gtk_text_buffer_set_modified() set the modification flag to %FALSE. Used for example to enable a "save" function in a text editor.
function.return: %TRUE if the buffer has been modified

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_paste_target_list
function.description:
This function returns the list of targets this text buffer supports for pasting and as DND destination. The targets in the list are added with @info values from the #GtkTextBufferTargetInfo enum, using gtk_target_list_add_rich_text_targets() and gtk_target_list_add_text_targets().
Since: 2.10
function.return: the #GtkTargetList

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_selection_bound
function.description:
Returns the mark that represents the selection bound. Equivalent to calling gtk_text_buffer_get_mark() to get the mark named "selection_bound", but very slightly more efficient, and involves less typing.
The currently-selected text in @buffer is the region between the "selection_bound" and "insert" marks. If "selection_bound" and "insert" are in the same place, then there is no current selection. gtk_text_buffer_get_selection_bounds() is another convenient function for handling the selection, if you just want to know whether there's a selection and what its bounds are.
function.return: selection bound mark

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_selection_bounds
function.description: Returns %TRUE if some text is selected; places the bounds of the selection in @start and @end (if the selection has length 0, then @start and @end are filled in with the same value). @start and @end will be in ascending order. If @start and @end are NULL, then they are not filled in, but the return value still indicates whether text is selected.

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: iterator to initialize with selection start

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: iterator to initialize with selection end

function.return: whether the selection has nonzero length

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_serialize_formats
function.description:
This function returns the rich text serialize formats registered with @buffer using gtk_text_buffer_register_serialize_format() or gtk_text_buffer_register_serialize_tagset()
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: n_formats
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of formats

function.return: an array of #GdkAtom<!-- -->s representing the registered formats.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_slice
function.description: Returns the text in the range [@start,@end). Excludes undisplayed text (text marked with tags that set the invisibility attribute) if @include_hidden_chars is %FALSE. The returned string includes a 0xFFFC character whenever the buffer contains embedded images, so byte and character indexes into the returned string <emphasis>do</emphasis> correspond to byte and character indexes into the buffer. Contrast with gtk_text_buffer_get_text(). Note that 0xFFFC can occur in normal text as well, so it is not a reliable indicator that a pixbuf or widget is in the buffer.
function.return: an allocated UTF-8 string

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_start_iter
function.description: Initialized @iter with the first position in the text buffer. This is the same as using gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_offset() to get the iter at character offset 0.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_tag_table
function.description: Get the #GtkTextTagTable associated with this buffer.
function.return: the buffer's tag table

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_text
function.description: Returns the text in the range [@start,@end). Excludes undisplayed text (text marked with tags that set the invisibility attribute) if @include_hidden_chars is %FALSE. Does not include characters representing embedded images, so byte and character indexes into the returned string do <emphasis>not</emphasis> correspond to byte and character indexes into the buffer. Contrast with gtk_text_buffer_get_slice().
function.return: an allocated UTF-8 string

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert
function.description: Inserts @len bytes of @text at position @iter. If @len is -1, @text must be nul-terminated and will be inserted in its entirety. Emits the "insert-text" signal; insertion actually occurs in the default handler for the signal. @iter is invalidated when insertion occurs (because the buffer contents change), but the default signal handler revalidates it to point to the end of the inserted text.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: length of text in bytes, or -1

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_at_cursor
function.description: Simply calls gtk_text_buffer_insert(), using the current cursor position as the insertion point.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_child_anchor
function.description: Inserts a child widget anchor into the text buffer at @iter. The anchor will be counted as one character in character counts, and when obtaining the buffer contents as a string, will be represented by the Unicode "object replacement character" 0xFFFC. Note that the "slice" variants for obtaining portions of the buffer as a string include this character for child anchors, but the "text" variants do not. E.g. see gtk_text_buffer_get_slice() and gtk_text_buffer_get_text(). Consider gtk_text_buffer_create_child_anchor() as a more convenient alternative to this function. The buffer will add a reference to the anchor, so you can unref it after insertion.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive
function.description:
Like gtk_text_buffer_insert(), but the insertion will not occur if @iter is at a non-editable location in the buffer. Usually you want to prevent insertions at ineditable locations if the insertion results from a user action (is interactive).
@default_editable indicates the editability of text that doesn't have a tag affecting editability applied to it. Typically the result of gtk_text_view_get_editable() is appropriate here.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: length of text in bytes, or -1

function.return: whether text was actually inserted

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive_at_cursor
function.description:
Calls gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive() at the cursor position.
@default_editable indicates the editability of text that doesn't have a tag affecting editability applied to it. Typically the result of gtk_text_view_get_editable() is appropriate here.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: length of text in bytes, or -1

function.return: whether text was actually inserted

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_pixbuf
function.description: Inserts an image into the text buffer at @iter. The image will be counted as one character in character counts, and when obtaining the buffer contents as a string, will be represented by the Unicode "object replacement character" 0xFFFC. Note that the "slice" variants for obtaining portions of the buffer as a string include this character for pixbufs, but the "text" variants do not. e.g. see gtk_text_buffer_get_slice() and gtk_text_buffer_get_text().

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_range
function.description:
Copies text, tags, and pixbufs between @start and @end (the order of @start and @end doesn't matter) and inserts the copy at @iter. Used instead of simply getting/inserting text because it preserves images and tags. If @start and @end are in a different buffer from @buffer, the two buffers must share the same tag table.
Implemented via emissions of the insert_text and apply_tag signals, so expect those.

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: another position in the same buffer as @start

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_range_interactive
function.description: Same as gtk_text_buffer_insert_range(), but does nothing if the insertion point isn't editable. The @default_editable parameter indicates whether the text is editable at @iter if no tags enclosing @iter affect editability. Typically the result of gtk_text_view_get_editable() is appropriate here.

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: another position in the same buffer as @start

function.return: whether an insertion was possible at @iter

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_with_tags
function.description: Inserts @text into @buffer at @iter, applying the list of tags to the newly-inserted text. The last tag specified must be %NULL to terminate the list. Equivalent to calling gtk_text_buffer_insert(), then gtk_text_buffer_apply_tag() on the inserted text; gtk_text_buffer_insert_with_tags() is just a convenience function.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_with_tags_by_name
function.description: Same as gtk_text_buffer_insert_with_tags(), but allows you to pass in tag names instead of tag objects.

parameter.name: first_tag_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of a tag to apply to @text

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_move_mark
function.description: Moves @mark to the new location @where. Emits the "mark-set" signal as notification of the move.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_move_mark_by_name
function.description: Moves the mark named @name (which must exist) to location @where. See gtk_text_buffer_move_mark() for details.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_new
function.description: Creates a new text buffer.

parameter.name: table
parameter.parameter_description: a tag table, or %NULL to create a new one

function.return: a new text buffer

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_paste_clipboard
function.description: Pastes the contents of a clipboard at the insertion point, or at @override_location. (Note: pasting is asynchronous, that is, we'll ask for the paste data and return, and at some point later after the main loop runs, the paste data will be inserted.)

parameter.name: override_location
parameter.parameter_description: location to insert pasted text, or %NULL for at the cursor

parameter.name: default_editable
parameter.parameter_description: whether the buffer is editable by default

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_place_cursor
function.description: This function moves the "insert" and "selection_bound" marks simultaneously. If you move them to the same place in two steps with gtk_text_buffer_move_mark(), you will temporarily select a region in between their old and new locations, which can be pretty inefficient since the temporarily-selected region will force stuff to be recalculated. This function moves them as a unit, which can be optimized.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_register_deserialize_format
function.description:
This function registers a rich text deserialization @function along with its @mime_type with the passed @buffer.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: user_data_destroy
parameter.parameter_description: a function to call when @user_data is no longer needed

function.return: the #GdkAtom that corresponds to the newly registered format's mime-type.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_register_deserialize_tagset
function.description:
This function registers GTK+'s internal rich text serialization format with the passed @buffer. See gtk_text_buffer_register_serialize_tagset() for details.
Since: 2.10
function.return: the #GdkAtom that corresponds to the newly registered format's mime-type.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_register_serialize_format
function.description:
This function registers a rich text serialization @function along with its @mime_type with the passed @buffer.
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: user_data_destroy
parameter.parameter_description: a function to call when @user_data is no longer needed

function.return: the #GdkAtom that corresponds to the newly registered format's mime-type.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_register_serialize_tagset
function.description:
This function registers GTK+'s internal rich text serialization format with the passed @buffer. The internal format does not comply to any standard rich text format and only works between #GtkTextBuffer instances. It is capable of serializing all of a text buffer's tags and embedded pixbufs.
This function is just a wrapper around gtk_text_buffer_register_serialize_format(). The mime type used for registering is "application/x-gtk-text-buffer-rich-text", or "application/x-gtk-text-buffer-rich-text;format=@tagset_name" if a @tagset_name was passed.
The @tagset_name can be used to restrict the transfer of rich text to buffers with compatible sets of tags, in order to avoid unknown tags from being pasted. It is probably the common case to pass an identifier != %NULL here, since the %NULL tagset requires the receiving buffer to deal with with pasting of arbitrary tags.
Since: 2.10
function.return: the #GdkAtom that corresponds to the newly registered format's mime-type.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_remove_all_tags
function.description: Removes all tags in the range between @start and @end. Be careful with this function; it could remove tags added in code unrelated to the code you're currently writing. That is, using this function is probably a bad idea if you have two or more unrelated code sections that add tags.

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: one bound of range to be untagged

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: other bound of range to be untagged

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_remove_selection_clipboard
function.description: Removes a #GtkClipboard added with gtk_text_buffer_add_selection_clipboard().

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_remove_tag

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: one bound of range to be untagged

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: other bound of range to be untagged

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_remove_tag_by_name
function.description: Calls gtk_text_tag_table_lookup() on the buffer's tag table to get a #GtkTextTag, then calls gtk_text_buffer_remove_tag().

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: one bound of range to be untagged

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: other bound of range to be untagged

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_select_range
function.description:
This function moves the "insert" and "selection_bound" marks simultaneously. If you move them in two steps with gtk_text_buffer_move_mark(), you will temporarily select a region in between their old and new locations, which can be pretty inefficient since the temporarily-selected region will force stuff to be recalculated. This function moves them as a unit, which can be optimized.
Since: 2.4

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_serialize

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: the rich text format to use for serializing

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: start of block of text to serialize

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: end of block of test to serialize

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the length of the serialized data

function.return: the serialized data, encoded as @format

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_set_mark
function.description: Move the mark to the given position, if not @should_exist, create the mark.

parameter.name: left_gravity
parameter.parameter_description: if the mark is created by this function, gravity for the new mark

parameter.name: should_exist
parameter.parameter_description: if %TRUE, warn if the mark does not exist, and return immediately

function.return: mark

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_set_modified
function.description: Used to keep track of whether the buffer has been modified since the last time it was saved. Whenever the buffer is saved to disk, call gtk_text_buffer_set_modified (@buffer, FALSE). When the buffer is modified, it will automatically toggled on the modified bit again. When the modified bit flips, the buffer emits the #GtkTextBuffer::modified-changed signal.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_set_text
function.description: Deletes current contents of @buffer, and inserts @text instead. If @len is -1, @text must be nul-terminated. @text must be valid UTF-8.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_unregister_deserialize_format
function.description:
This function unregisters a rich text format that was previously registered using gtk_text_buffer_register_deserialize_format() or gtk_text_buffer_register_deserialize_tagset().
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkAtom representing a registered rich text format.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_unregister_serialize_format
function.description:
This function unregisters a rich text format that was previously registered using gtk_text_buffer_register_serialize_format() or gtk_text_buffer_register_serialize_tagset()
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkAtom representing a registered rich text format.

function.name: gtk_text_child_anchor_get_deleted
function.description: Determines whether a child anchor has been deleted from the buffer. Keep in mind that the child anchor will be unreferenced when removed from the buffer, so you need to hold your own reference (with g_object_ref()) if you plan to use this function — otherwise all deleted child anchors will also be finalized.
function.return: %TRUE if the child anchor has been deleted from its buffer

function.name: gtk_text_child_anchor_get_widgets
function.description: Gets a list of all widgets anchored at this child anchor. The returned list should be freed with g_list_free().
function.return: list of widgets anchored at @anchor

function.name: gtk_text_child_anchor_new
function.description: Creates a new #GtkTextChildAnchor. Usually you would then insert it into a #GtkTextBuffer with gtk_text_buffer_insert_child_anchor(). To perform the creation and insertion in one step, use the convenience function gtk_text_buffer_create_child_anchor().
function.return: a new #GtkTextChildAnchor

function.name: gtk_text_iter_assign
function.description:
Assigns the value of @other to @iter. This function is not useful in applications, because iterators can be assigned with <literal>GtkTextIter i = j;</literal>. The function is used by language bindings.
Since: 3.2

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_char
function.description: Moves backward by one character offset. Returns %TRUE if movement was possible; if @iter was the first in the buffer (character offset 0), gtk_text_iter_backward_char () returns %FALSE for convenience when writing loops.
function.return: whether movement was possible

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_chars
function.description: Moves @count characters backward, if possible (if @count would move past the start or end of the buffer, moves to the start or end of the buffer). The return value indicates whether the iterator moved onto a dereferenceable position; if the iterator didn't move, or moved onto the end iterator, then %FALSE is returned. If @count is 0, the function does nothing and returns %FALSE.
function.return: whether @iter moved and is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_cursor_position
function.description: Like gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position(), but moves backward.
function.return: %TRUE if we moved

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_cursor_positions
function.description: Moves up to @count cursor positions. See gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position() for details.
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_find_char
function.description: Same as gtk_text_iter_forward_find_char(), but goes backward from @iter.

parameter.name: pred
parameter.parameter_description: function to be called on each character

function.return: whether a match was found

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_line
function.description: Moves @iter to the start of the previous line. Returns %TRUE if @iter could be moved; i.e. if @iter was at character offset 0, this function returns %FALSE. Therefore if @iter was already on line 0, but not at the start of the line, @iter is snapped to the start of the line and the function returns %TRUE. (Note that this implies that in a loop calling this function, the line number may not change on every iteration, if your first iteration is on line 0.)
function.return: whether @iter moved

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_lines
function.description: Moves @count lines backward, if possible (if @count would move past the start or end of the buffer, moves to the start or end of the buffer). The return value indicates whether the iterator moved onto a dereferenceable position; if the iterator didn't move, or moved onto the end iterator, then %FALSE is returned. If @count is 0, the function does nothing and returns %FALSE. If @count is negative, moves forward by 0 - @count lines.

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: number of lines to move backward

function.return: whether @iter moved and is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_search

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: bitmask of flags affecting the search

parameter.name: match_start
parameter.parameter_description: return location for start of match, or %NULL

parameter.name: match_end
parameter.parameter_description: return location for end of match, or %NULL

parameter.name: limit
parameter.parameter_description: location of last possible @match_start, or %NULL for start of buffer

function.return: whether a match was found

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_sentence_start
function.description: Moves backward to the previous sentence start; if @iter is already at the start of a sentence, moves backward to the next one. Sentence boundaries are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango text boundary algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_sentence_starts
function.description: Calls gtk_text_iter_backward_sentence_start() up to @count times, or until it returns %FALSE. If @count is negative, moves forward instead of backward.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_text_chars
function.description: Moves backward by @count text characters (pixbufs, widgets, etc. do not count as characters for this). Equivalent to moving through the results of gtk_text_iter_get_text (), rather than gtk_text_iter_get_slice ().
function.return: whether @iter moved and is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_to_tag_toggle
function.description: Moves backward to the next toggle (on or off) of the #GtkTextTag @tag, or to the next toggle of any tag if @tag is %NULL. If no matching tag toggles are found, returns %FALSE, otherwise %TRUE. Does not return toggles located at @iter, only toggles before @iter. Sets @iter to the location of the toggle, or the start of the buffer if no toggle is found.
function.return: whether we found a tag toggle before @iter

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_cursor_position
function.description:
Moves @iter forward to the previous visible cursor position. See gtk_text_iter_backward_cursor_position() for details.
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_cursor_positions
function.description:
Moves up to @count visible cursor positions. See gtk_text_iter_backward_cursor_position() for details.
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_line
function.description:
Moves @iter to the start of the previous visible line. Returns %TRUE if @iter could be moved; i.e. if @iter was at character offset 0, this function returns %FALSE. Therefore if @iter was already on line 0, but not at the start of the line, @iter is snapped to the start of the line and the function returns %TRUE. (Note that this implies that in a loop calling this function, the line number may not change on every iteration, if your first iteration is on line 0.)
Since: 2.8
function.return: whether @iter moved

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_lines
function.description:
Moves @count visible lines backward, if possible (if @count would move past the start or end of the buffer, moves to the start or end of the buffer). The return value indicates whether the iterator moved onto a dereferenceable position; if the iterator didn't move, or moved onto the end iterator, then %FALSE is returned. If @count is 0, the function does nothing and returns %FALSE. If @count is negative, moves forward by 0 - @count lines.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: number of lines to move backward

function.return: whether @iter moved and is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_word_start
function.description:
Moves backward to the previous visible word start. (If @iter is currently on a word start, moves backward to the next one after that.) Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_word_starts
function.description:
Calls gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_word_start() up to @count times.
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_word_start
function.description: Moves backward to the previous word start. (If @iter is currently on a word start, moves backward to the next one after that.) Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_word_starts
function.description: Calls gtk_text_iter_backward_word_start() up to @count times.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_begins_tag
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if @tag is toggled on at exactly this point. If @tag is %NULL, returns %TRUE if any tag is toggled on at this point.
Note that if gtk_text_iter_begins_tag() returns %TRUE, it means that @iter is at the beginning of the tagged range, and that the <emphasis>character</emphasis> at @iter is inside the tagged range.
