In other words, unlike gtk_text_iter_ends_tag(), if gtk_text_iter_begins_tag() returns %TRUE, gtk_text_iter_has_tag() will also return %TRUE for the same parameters.
function.return: whether @iter is the start of a range tagged with @tag

function.name: gtk_text_iter_can_insert
function.description: Considering the default editability of the buffer, and tags that affect editability, determines whether text inserted at @iter would be editable. If text inserted at @iter would be editable then the user should be allowed to insert text at @iter. gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive() uses this function to decide whether insertions are allowed at a given position.

parameter.name: default_editability
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if text is editable by default

function.return: whether text inserted at @iter would be editable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_compare
function.description: A qsort()-style function that returns negative if @lhs is less than @rhs, positive if @lhs is greater than @rhs, and 0 if they're equal. Ordering is in character offset order, i.e. the first character in the buffer is less than the second character in the buffer.
function.return: -1 if @lhs is less than @rhs, 1 if @lhs is greater, 0 if they are equal

function.name: gtk_text_iter_copy
function.description: Creates a dynamically-allocated copy of an iterator. This function is not useful in applications, because iterators can be copied with a simple assignment (<literal>GtkTextIter i = j;</literal>). The function is used by language bindings.
function.return: a copy of the @iter, free with gtk_text_iter_free ()

function.name: gtk_text_iter_editable
function.description:
Returns whether the character at @iter is within an editable region of text. Non-editable text is "locked" and can't be changed by the user via #GtkTextView. This function is simply a convenience wrapper around gtk_text_iter_get_attributes (). If no tags applied to this text affect editability, @default_setting will be returned.
You don't want to use this function to decide whether text can be inserted at @iter, because for insertion you don't want to know whether the char at @iter is inside an editable range, you want to know whether a new character inserted at @iter would be inside an editable range. Use gtk_text_iter_can_insert() to handle this case.

parameter.name: default_setting
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if text is editable by default

function.return: whether @iter is inside an editable range

function.name: gtk_text_iter_ends_line
function.description: Returns %TRUE if @iter points to the start of the paragraph delimiter characters for a line (delimiters will be either a newline, a carriage return, a carriage return followed by a newline, or a Unicode paragraph separator character). Note that an iterator pointing to the \n of a \r\n pair will not be counted as the end of a line, the line ends before the \r. The end iterator is considered to be at the end of a line, even though there are no paragraph delimiter chars there.
function.return: whether @iter is at the end of a line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_ends_sentence
function.description: Determines whether @iter ends a sentence. Sentence boundaries are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango text boundary algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter is at the end of a sentence.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_ends_tag
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if @tag is toggled off at exactly this point. If @tag is %NULL, returns %TRUE if any tag is toggled off at this point.
Note that if gtk_text_iter_ends_tag() returns %TRUE, it means that @iter is at the end of the tagged range, but that the <emphasis>character</emphasis> at @iter is <emphasis>outside</emphasis> the tagged range. In other words, unlike gtk_text_iter_begins_tag(), if gtk_text_iter_ends_tag() returns %TRUE, gtk_text_iter_has_tag() will return %FALSE for the same parameters.
function.return: whether @iter is the end of a range tagged with @tag

function.name: gtk_text_iter_ends_word
function.description: Determines whether @iter ends a natural-language word. Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter is at the end of a word

function.name: gtk_text_iter_equal
function.description: Tests whether two iterators are equal, using the fastest possible mechanism. This function is very fast; you can expect it to perform better than e.g. getting the character offset for each iterator and comparing the offsets yourself. Also, it's a bit faster than gtk_text_iter_compare().
function.return: %TRUE if the iterators point to the same place in the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_char
function.description: Moves @iter forward by one character offset. Note that images embedded in the buffer occupy 1 character slot, so gtk_text_iter_forward_char () may actually move onto an image instead of a character, if you have images in your buffer. If @iter is the end iterator or one character before it, @iter will now point at the end iterator, and gtk_text_iter_forward_char () returns %FALSE for convenience when writing loops.
function.return: whether @iter moved and is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_chars
function.description: Moves @count characters if possible (if @count would move past the start or end of the buffer, moves to the start or end of the buffer). The return value indicates whether the new position of @iter is different from its original position, and dereferenceable (the last iterator in the buffer is not dereferenceable). If @count is 0, the function does nothing and returns %FALSE.

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: number of characters to move, may be negative

function.return: whether @iter moved and is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position
function.description: Moves @iter forward by a single cursor position. Cursor positions are (unsurprisingly) positions where the cursor can appear. Perhaps surprisingly, there may not be a cursor position between all characters. The most common example for European languages would be a carriage return/newline sequence. For some Unicode characters, the equivalent of say the letter "a" with an accent mark will be represented as two characters, first the letter then a "combining mark" that causes the accent to be rendered; so the cursor can't go between those two characters. See also the #PangoLogAttr structure and pango_break() function.
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_positions
function.description: Moves up to @count cursor positions. See gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position() for details.
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_find_char

parameter.name: pred
parameter.parameter_description: a function to be called on each character

function.return: whether a match was found

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_line
function.description: Moves @iter to the start of the next line. If the iter is already on the last line of the buffer, moves the iter to the end of the current line. If after the operation, the iter is at the end of the buffer and not dereferencable, returns %FALSE. Otherwise, returns %TRUE.
function.return: whether @iter can be dereferenced

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_lines
function.description: Moves @count lines forward, if possible (if @count would move past the start or end of the buffer, moves to the start or end of the buffer). The return value indicates whether the iterator moved onto a dereferenceable position; if the iterator didn't move, or moved onto the end iterator, then %FALSE is returned. If @count is 0, the function does nothing and returns %FALSE. If @count is negative, moves backward by 0 - @count lines.

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: number of lines to move forward

function.return: whether @iter moved and is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_search

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags affecting how the search is done

parameter.name: match_start
parameter.parameter_description: return location for start of match, or %NULL

parameter.name: match_end
parameter.parameter_description: return location for end of match, or %NULL

parameter.name: limit
parameter.parameter_description: location of last possible @match_end, or %NULL for the end of the buffer

function.return: whether a match was found

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_sentence_end
function.description: Moves forward to the next sentence end. (If @iter is at the end of a sentence, moves to the next end of sentence.) Sentence boundaries are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango text boundary algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_sentence_ends
function.description: Calls gtk_text_iter_forward_sentence_end() @count times (or until gtk_text_iter_forward_sentence_end() returns %FALSE). If @count is negative, moves backward instead of forward.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_text_chars
function.description: Moves forward by @count text characters (pixbufs, widgets, etc. do not count as characters for this). Equivalent to moving through the results of gtk_text_iter_get_text (), rather than gtk_text_iter_get_slice ().
function.return: whether @iter moved and is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_to_end
function.description: Moves @iter forward to the "end iterator," which points one past the last valid character in the buffer. gtk_text_iter_get_char() called on the end iterator returns 0, which is convenient for writing loops.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_to_line_end
function.description: Moves the iterator to point to the paragraph delimiter characters, which will be either a newline, a carriage return, a carriage return/newline in sequence, or the Unicode paragraph separator character. If the iterator is already at the paragraph delimiter characters, moves to the paragraph delimiter characters for the next line. If @iter is on the last line in the buffer, which does not end in paragraph delimiters, moves to the end iterator (end of the last line), and returns %FALSE.
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new location is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_to_tag_toggle
function.description: Moves forward to the next toggle (on or off) of the #GtkTextTag @tag, or to the next toggle of any tag if @tag is %NULL. If no matching tag toggles are found, returns %FALSE, otherwise %TRUE. Does not return toggles located at @iter, only toggles after @iter. Sets @iter to the location of the toggle, or to the end of the buffer if no toggle is found.
function.return: whether we found a tag toggle after @iter

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_cursor_position
function.description:
Moves @iter forward to the next visible cursor position. See gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position() for details.
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_cursor_positions
function.description:
Moves up to @count visible cursor positions. See gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position() for details.
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_line
function.description:
Moves @iter to the start of the next visible line. Returns %TRUE if there was a next line to move to, and %FALSE if @iter was simply moved to the end of the buffer and is now not dereferenceable, or if @iter was already at the end of the buffer.
Since: 2.8
function.return: whether @iter can be dereferenced

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_lines
function.description:
Moves @count visible lines forward, if possible (if @count would move past the start or end of the buffer, moves to the start or end of the buffer). The return value indicates whether the iterator moved onto a dereferenceable position; if the iterator didn't move, or moved onto the end iterator, then %FALSE is returned. If @count is 0, the function does nothing and returns %FALSE. If @count is negative, moves backward by 0 - @count lines.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: number of lines to move forward

function.return: whether @iter moved and is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_word_end
function.description:
Moves forward to the next visible word end. (If @iter is currently on a word end, moves forward to the next one after that.) Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_word_ends
function.description:
Calls gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_word_end() up to @count times.
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_word_end
function.description: Moves forward to the next word end. (If @iter is currently on a word end, moves forward to the next one after that.) Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_word_ends
function.description: Calls gtk_text_iter_forward_word_end() up to @count times.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_free
function.description: Free an iterator allocated on the heap. This function is intended for use in language bindings, and is not especially useful for applications, because iterators can simply be allocated on the stack.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_attributes
function.description:
Computes the effect of any tags applied to this spot in the text. The @values parameter should be initialized to the default settings you wish to use if no tags are in effect. You'd typically obtain the defaults from gtk_text_view_get_default_attributes().
gtk_text_iter_get_attributes () will modify @values, applying the effects of any tags present at @iter. If any tags affected @values, the function returns %TRUE.
function.return: %TRUE if @values was modified

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_buffer
function.description: Returns the #GtkTextBuffer this iterator is associated with.
function.return: the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_bytes_in_line
function.description: Returns the number of bytes in the line containing @iter, including the paragraph delimiters.
function.return: number of bytes in the line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_char
function.description: The Unicode character at this iterator is returned. (Equivalent to operator* on a C++ iterator.) If the element at this iterator is a non-character element, such as an image embedded in the buffer, the Unicode "unknown" character 0xFFFC is returned. If invoked on the end iterator, zero is returned; zero is not a valid Unicode character. So you can write a loop which ends when gtk_text_iter_get_char() returns 0.
function.return: a Unicode character, or 0 if @iter is not dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_chars_in_line
function.description: Returns the number of characters in the line containing @iter, including the paragraph delimiters.
function.return: number of characters in the line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_child_anchor
function.description: If the location at @iter contains a child anchor, the anchor is returned (with no new reference count added). Otherwise, %NULL is returned.
function.return: the anchor at @iter

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_language
function.description: A convenience wrapper around gtk_text_iter_get_attributes (), which returns the language in effect at @iter. If no tags affecting language apply to @iter, the return value is identical to that of gtk_get_default_language ().
function.return: language in effect at @iter

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_line
function.description: Returns the line number containing the iterator. Lines in a #GtkTextBuffer are numbered beginning with 0 for the first line in the buffer.
function.return: a line number

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_line_index
function.description: Returns the byte index of the iterator, counting from the start of a newline-terminated line. Remember that #GtkTextBuffer encodes text in UTF-8, and that characters can require a variable number of bytes to represent.
function.return: distance from start of line, in bytes

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_line_offset
function.description: Returns the character offset of the iterator, counting from the start of a newline-terminated line. The first character on the line has offset 0.
function.return: offset from start of line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_marks
function.description: Returns a list of all #GtkTextMark at this location. Because marks are not iterable (they don't take up any "space" in the buffer, they are just marks in between iterable locations), multiple marks can exist in the same place. The returned list is not in any meaningful order.
function.return: list of #GtkTextMark

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_offset
function.description: Returns the character offset of an iterator. Each character in a #GtkTextBuffer has an offset, starting with 0 for the first character in the buffer. Use gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_offset () to convert an offset back into an iterator.
function.return: a character offset

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_pixbuf
function.description: If the element at @iter is a pixbuf, the pixbuf is returned (with no new reference count added). Otherwise, %NULL is returned.
function.return: the pixbuf at @iter

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_slice
function.description: Returns the text in the given range. A "slice" is an array of characters encoded in UTF-8 format, including the Unicode "unknown" character 0xFFFC for iterable non-character elements in the buffer, such as images. Because images are encoded in the slice, byte and character offsets in the returned array will correspond to byte offsets in the text buffer. Note that 0xFFFC can occur in normal text as well, so it is not a reliable indicator that a pixbuf or widget is in the buffer.

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: iterator at start of a range

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: iterator at end of a range

function.return: slice of text from the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_tags
function.description: Returns a list of tags that apply to @iter, in ascending order of priority (highest-priority tags are last). The #GtkTextTag in the list don't have a reference added, but you have to free the list itself.
function.return: list of #GtkTextTag

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_text
function.description: Returns <emphasis>text</emphasis> in the given range. If the range contains non-text elements such as images, the character and byte offsets in the returned string will not correspond to character and byte offsets in the buffer. If you want offsets to correspond, see gtk_text_iter_get_slice ().

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: iterator at start of a range

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: iterator at end of a range

function.return: array of characters from the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_toggled_tags
function.description: Returns a list of #GtkTextTag that are toggled on or off at this point. (If @toggled_on is %TRUE, the list contains tags that are toggled on.) If a tag is toggled on at @iter, then some non-empty range of characters following @iter has that tag applied to it. If a tag is toggled off, then some non-empty range following @iter does <emphasis>not</emphasis> have the tag applied to it.
function.return: tags toggled at this point

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_visible_line_index
function.description: Returns the number of bytes from the start of the line to the given @iter, not counting bytes that are invisible due to tags with the "invisible" flag toggled on.
function.return: byte index of @iter with respect to the start of the line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_visible_line_offset
function.description: Returns the offset in characters from the start of the line to the given @iter, not counting characters that are invisible due to tags with the "invisible" flag toggled on.
function.return: offset in visible characters from the start of the line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_visible_slice
function.description: Like gtk_text_iter_get_slice (), but invisible text is not included. Invisible text is usually invisible because a #GtkTextTag with the "invisible" attribute turned on has been applied to it.
function.return: slice of text from the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_visible_text
function.description: Like gtk_text_iter_get_text (), but invisible text is not included. Invisible text is usually invisible because a #GtkTextTag with the "invisible" attribute turned on has been applied to it.
function.return: string containing visible text in the range

function.name: gtk_text_iter_has_tag
function.description: Returns %TRUE if @iter points to a character that is part of a range tagged with @tag. See also gtk_text_iter_begins_tag() and gtk_text_iter_ends_tag().
function.return: whether @iter is tagged with @tag

function.name: gtk_text_iter_in_range
function.description: Checks whether @iter falls in the range [@start, @end). @start and @end must be in ascending order.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter is in the range

function.name: gtk_text_iter_inside_sentence
function.description: Determines whether @iter is inside a sentence (as opposed to in between two sentences, e.g. after a period and before the first letter of the next sentence). Sentence boundaries are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango text boundary algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter is inside a sentence.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_inside_word
function.description: Determines whether @iter is inside a natural-language word (as opposed to say inside some whitespace). Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter is inside a word

function.name: gtk_text_iter_is_cursor_position
function.description: See gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position() or #PangoLogAttr or pango_break() for details on what a cursor position is.
function.return: %TRUE if the cursor can be placed at @iter

function.name: gtk_text_iter_is_end
function.description: Returns %TRUE if @iter is the end iterator, i.e. one past the last dereferenceable iterator in the buffer. gtk_text_iter_is_end () is the most efficient way to check whether an iterator is the end iterator.
function.return: whether @iter is the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_is_start
function.description: Returns %TRUE if @iter is the first iterator in the buffer, that is if @iter has a character offset of 0.
function.return: whether @iter is the first in the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_iter_order
function.description: Swaps the value of @first and @second if @second comes before @first in the buffer. That is, ensures that @first and @second are in sequence. Most text buffer functions that take a range call this automatically on your behalf, so there's no real reason to call it yourself in those cases. There are some exceptions, such as gtk_text_iter_in_range(), that expect a pre-sorted range.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_set_line
gtk_text_iter_set_line_index
function.description: Same as gtk_text_iter_set_line_offset(), but works with a <emphasis>byte</emphasis> index. The given byte index must be at the start of a character, it can't be in the middle of a UTF-8 encoded character.

parameter.name: byte_on_line
parameter.parameter_description: a byte index relative to the start of @iter's current line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_set_line_offset
function.description: Moves @iter within a line, to a new <emphasis>character</emphasis> (not byte) offset. The given character offset must be less than or equal to the number of characters in the line; if equal, @iter moves to the start of the next line. See gtk_text_iter_set_line_index() if you have a byte index rather than a character offset.

parameter.name: char_on_line
parameter.parameter_description: a character offset relative to the start of @iter's current line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_set_offset
function.description: Sets @iter to point to @char_offset. @char_offset counts from the start of the entire text buffer, starting with 0.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_set_visible_line_index
function.description: Like gtk_text_iter_set_line_index(), but the index is in visible bytes, i.e. text with a tag making it invisible is not counted in the index.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_set_visible_line_offset
function.description: Like gtk_text_iter_set_line_offset(), but the offset is in visible characters, i.e. text with a tag making it invisible is not counted in the offset.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_starts_line
function.description: Returns %TRUE if @iter begins a paragraph, i.e. if gtk_text_iter_get_line_offset () would return 0. However this function is potentially more efficient than gtk_text_iter_get_line_offset () because it doesn't have to compute the offset, it just has to see whether it's 0.
function.return: whether @iter begins a line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_starts_sentence
function.description: Determines whether @iter begins a sentence. Sentence boundaries are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango text boundary algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter is at the start of a sentence.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_starts_word
function.description: Determines whether @iter begins a natural-language word. Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter is at the start of a word

function.name: gtk_text_iter_toggles_tag
function.return: whether @tag is toggled on or off at @iter

function.name: gtk_text_layout_clamp_iter_to_vrange
function.description: If the iterator is not fully in the range @top <= y < @bottom, then, if possible, move it the minimum distance so that the iterator in this range.
function.return: %TRUE if the iterator was moved, otherwise %FALSE.

function.name: gtk_text_layout_get_buffer
function.description: Gets the text buffer used by the layout. See gtk_text_layout_set_buffer().
function.return: the text buffer used by the layout.

function.name: gtk_text_layout_get_cursor_locations
function.description: Given an iterator within a text layout, determine the positions of the strong and weak cursors if the insertion point is at that iterator. The position of each cursor is stored as a zero-width rectangle. The strong cursor location is the location where characters of the directionality equal to the base direction of the paragraph are inserted. The weak cursor location is the location where characters of the directionality opposite to the base direction of the paragraph are inserted.

parameter.name: strong_pos
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the strong cursor position (may be %NULL)

parameter.name: weak_pos
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the weak cursor position (may be %NULL)

function.name: gtk_text_layout_get_cursor_visible
function.description: Returns whether the insertion cursor will be shown.
function.return: if %FALSE, the insertion cursor will not be shown, even if the text is editable.

function.name: gtk_text_layout_get_line_at_y
function.description: Get the iter at the beginning of the line which is displayed at the given y.

parameter.name: target_iter
parameter.parameter_description: the iterator in which the result is stored

parameter.name: line_top
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the y coordinate of the top of the line. (Can by %NULL)

function.name: gtk_text_layout_get_line_yrange
function.description: Find the range of y coordinates for the paragraph containing the given iter.

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the top of the paragraph in pixels, or %NULL. @height location to store the height of the paragraph in pixels, or %NULL.

function.name: gtk_text_layout_is_valid
function.description: Check if there are any invalid regions in a #GtkTextLayout's buffer
function.return: %TRUE if any invalid regions were found

function.name: gtk_text_layout_iter_starts_line
function.description: Tests whether an iterator is at the start of a display line.

function.name: gtk_text_layout_move_iter_to_line_end
function.description: Move to the beginning or end of a display line.

parameter.name: direction
parameter.parameter_description: if negative, move to beginning of line, otherwise move to end of line.

function.name: gtk_text_layout_move_iter_to_next_line
function.description: Move the iterator to the beginning of the next line. The lines of a wrapped paragraph are treated as distinct for this operation.

function.name: gtk_text_layout_move_iter_to_previous_line
function.description: Move the iterator to the beginning of the previous line. The lines of a wrapped paragraph are treated as distinct for this operation.

function.name: gtk_text_layout_move_iter_to_x
function.description: Keeping the iterator on the same line of the layout, move it to the specified X coordinate. The lines of a wrapped paragraph are treated as distinct for this operation.

function.name: gtk_text_layout_move_iter_visually
function.description:
Move the iterator a given number of characters visually, treating it as the strong cursor position. If @count is positive, then the new strong cursor position will be @count positions to the right of the old cursor position. If @count is negative then the new strong cursor position will be @count positions to the left of the old cursor position.
In the presence of bidirection text, the correspondence between logical and visual order will depend on the direction of the current run, and there may be jumps when the cursor is moved off of the end of a run.

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: number of characters to move (negative moves left, positive moves right)

function.name: gtk_text_layout_set_cursor_direction
function.description: Sets which text directions (left-to-right and/or right-to-left) for which cursors will be drawn for the insertion point. The visual point at which new text is inserted depends on whether the new text is right-to-left or left-to-right, so it may be desired to make the drawn position of the cursor depend on the keyboard state.

parameter.name: direction
parameter.parameter_description: the new direction(s) for which to draw cursors. %GTK_TEXT_DIR_NONE means draw cursors for both left-to-right insertion and right-to-left insertion. (The two cursors will be visually distinguished.)

function.name: gtk_text_layout_set_cursor_visible
function.description: Sets whether the insertion cursor should be shown. Generally, widgets using #GtkTextLayout will hide the cursor when the widget does not have the input focus.

parameter.name: cursor_visible
parameter.parameter_description: If %FALSE, then the insertion cursor will not be shown, even if the text is editable.

function.name: gtk_text_layout_set_keyboard_direction
function.description: Sets the keyboard direction; this is used as for the bidirectional base direction for the line with the cursor if the line contains only neutral characters.

parameter.name: keyboard_dir
parameter.parameter_description: the current direction of the keyboard.

function.name: gtk_text_layout_set_overwrite_mode
function.description: Sets overwrite mode

function.name: gtk_text_layout_set_preedit_string
function.description: Set the preedit string and attributes. The preedit string is a string showing text that is currently being edited and not yet committed into the buffer.

parameter.name: preedit_string
parameter.parameter_description: a string to display at the insertion point

parameter.name: preedit_attrs
parameter.parameter_description: a #PangoAttrList of attributes that apply to @preedit_string

parameter.name: cursor_pos
parameter.parameter_description: position of cursor within preedit string in chars

function.name: gtk_text_layout_validate
function.description: Validate regions of a #GtkTextLayout. The ::changed signal will be emitted for each region validated.

parameter.name: max_pixels
parameter.parameter_description: the maximum number of pixels to validate. (No more than one paragraph beyond this limit will be validated)

function.name: gtk_text_layout_validate_yrange
function.description: Ensure that a region of a #GtkTextLayout is valid. The ::changed signal will be emitted if any lines are validated.

parameter.name: anchor
parameter.parameter_description: iter pointing into a line that will be used as the coordinate origin

parameter.name: y0_
parameter.parameter_description: offset from the top of the line pointed to by @anchor at which to begin validation. (The offset here is in pixels after validation.)

parameter.name: y1_
parameter.parameter_description: offset from the top of the line pointed to by @anchor at which to end validation. (The offset here is in pixels after validation.)

function.name: gtk_text_mark_get_buffer
function.description: Gets the buffer this mark is located inside, or %NULL if the mark is deleted.
function.return: the mark's #GtkTextBuffer

function.name: gtk_text_mark_get_deleted
function.description: Returns %TRUE if the mark has been removed from its buffer with gtk_text_buffer_delete_mark(). See gtk_text_buffer_add_mark() for a way to add it to a buffer again.
function.return: whether the mark is deleted

function.name: gtk_text_mark_get_left_gravity
function.description: Determines whether the mark has left gravity.
function.return: %TRUE if the mark has left gravity, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_text_mark_get_name
function.description: Returns the mark name; returns NULL for anonymous marks.
function.return: mark name

function.name: gtk_text_mark_get_visible
function.description: Returns %TRUE if the mark is visible (i.e. a cursor is displayed for it).
function.return: %TRUE if visible

function.name: gtk_text_mark_new
function.description:
Creates a text mark. Add it to a buffer using gtk_text_buffer_add_mark(). If @name is %NULL, the mark is anonymous; otherwise, the mark can be retrieved by name using gtk_text_buffer_get_mark(). If a mark has left gravity, and text is inserted at the mark's current location, the mark will be moved to the left of the newly-inserted text. If the mark has right gravity (@left_gravity = %FALSE), the mark will end up on the right of newly-inserted text. The standard left-to-right cursor is a mark with right gravity (when you type, the cursor stays on the right side of the text you're typing).
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: left_gravity
parameter.parameter_description: whether the mark should have left gravity

function.return: new #GtkTextMark

function.name: gtk_text_mark_set_visible
function.description: Sets the visibility of @mark; the insertion point is normally visible, i.e. you can see it as a vertical bar. Also, the text widget uses a visible mark to indicate where a drop will occur when dragging-and-dropping text. Most other marks are not visible. Marks are not visible by default.

function.name: gtk_text_tag_event
function.description: Emits the "event" signal on the #GtkTextTag.

parameter.name: event_object
parameter.parameter_description: object that received the event, such as a widget

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: location where the event was received

function.return: result of signal emission (whether the event was handled)

function.name: gtk_text_tag_get_priority
function.description: Get the tag priority.
function.return: The tag's priority.

function.name: gtk_text_tag_new
function.description: Creates a #GtkTextTag. Configure the tag using object arguments, i.e. using g_object_set().
function.return: a new #GtkTextTag

function.name: gtk_text_tag_set_priority
function.description: Sets the priority of a #GtkTextTag. Valid priorities are start at 0 and go to one less than gtk_text_tag_table_get_size(). Each tag in a table has a unique priority; setting the priority of one tag shifts the priorities of all the other tags in the table to maintain a unique priority for each tag. Higher priority tags "win" if two tags both set the same text attribute. When adding a tag to a tag table, it will be assigned the highest priority in the table by default; so normally the precedence of a set of tags is the order in which they were added to the table, or created with gtk_text_buffer_create_tag(), which adds the tag to the buffer's table automatically.

function.name: gtk_text_tag_table_add
function.description:
Add a tag to the table. The tag is assigned the highest priority in the table.
@tag must not be in a tag table already, and may not have the same name as an already-added tag.

function.name: gtk_text_tag_table_foreach
function.description: Calls @func on each tag in @table, with user data @data. Note that the table may not be modified while iterating over it (you can't add/remove tags).

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to call on each tag

function.name: gtk_text_tag_table_get_size
function.description: Returns the size of the table (number of tags)
function.return: number of tags in @table

function.name: gtk_text_tag_table_lookup
function.description: Look up a named tag.
function.return: The tag, or %NULL if none by that name is in the table.

function.name: gtk_text_tag_table_new
function.description: Creates a new #GtkTextTagTable. The table contains no tags by default.
function.return: a new #GtkTextTagTable

function.name: gtk_text_tag_table_remove
function.description: Remove a tag from the table. If a #GtkTextBuffer has @table as its tag table, the tag is removed from the buffer. The table's reference to the tag is removed, so the tag will end up destroyed if you don't have a reference to it.

function.name: gtk_text_view_add_child_at_anchor
function.description: Adds a child widget in the text buffer, at the given @anchor.

function.name: gtk_text_view_add_child_in_window
function.description:
Adds a child at fixed coordinates in one of the text widget's windows.
The window must have nonzero size (see gtk_text_view_set_border_window_size()). Note that the child coordinates are given relative to the #GdkWindow in question, and that these coordinates have no sane relationship to scrolling. When placing a child in #GTK_TEXT_WINDOW_WIDGET, scrolling is irrelevant, the child floats above all scrollable areas. But when placing a child in one of the scrollable windows (border windows or text window), you'll need to compute the child's correct position in buffer coordinates any time scrolling occurs or buffer changes occur, and then call gtk_text_view_move_child() to update the child's position.

parameter.name: which_window
parameter.parameter_description: which window the child should appear in

parameter.name: xpos
parameter.parameter_description: X position of child in window coordinates

parameter.name: ypos
parameter.parameter_description: Y position of child in window coordinates

function.name: gtk_text_view_backward_display_line
function.description: Moves the given @iter backward by one display (wrapped) line. A display line is different from a paragraph. Paragraphs are separated by newlines or other paragraph separator characters. Display lines are created by line-wrapping a paragraph. If wrapping is turned off, display lines and paragraphs will be the same. Display lines are divided differently for each view, since they depend on the view's width; paragraphs are the same in all views, since they depend on the contents of the #GtkTextBuffer.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter was moved and is not on the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_view_backward_display_line_start
function.description: Moves the given @iter backward to the next display line start. A display line is different from a paragraph. Paragraphs are separated by newlines or other paragraph separator characters. Display lines are created by line-wrapping a paragraph. If wrapping is turned off, display lines and paragraphs will be the same. Display lines are divided differently for each view, since they depend on the view's width; paragraphs are the same in all views, since they depend on the contents of the #GtkTextBuffer.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter was moved and is not on the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_view_buffer_to_window_coords
function.description:
Converts coordinate (@buffer_x, @buffer_y) to coordinates for the window @win, and stores the result in (@window_x, @window_y).
Note that you can't convert coordinates for a nonexisting window (see gtk_text_view_set_border_window_size()).

parameter.name: window_x
parameter.parameter_description: window x coordinate return location or %NULL

parameter.name: window_y
parameter.parameter_description: window y coordinate return location or %NULL

function.name: gtk_text_view_forward_display_line
function.description: Moves the given @iter forward by one display (wrapped) line. A display line is different from a paragraph. Paragraphs are separated by newlines or other paragraph separator characters. Display lines are created by line-wrapping a paragraph. If wrapping is turned off, display lines and paragraphs will be the same. Display lines are divided differently for each view, since they depend on the view's width; paragraphs are the same in all views, since they depend on the contents of the #GtkTextBuffer.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter was moved and is not on the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_view_forward_display_line_end
function.description: Moves the given @iter forward to the next display line end. A display line is different from a paragraph. Paragraphs are separated by newlines or other paragraph separator characters. Display lines are created by line-wrapping a paragraph. If wrapping is turned off, display lines and paragraphs will be the same. Display lines are divided differently for each view, since they depend on the view's width; paragraphs are the same in all views, since they depend on the contents of the #GtkTextBuffer.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter was moved and is not on the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_accepts_tab
function.description:
Returns whether pressing the Tab key inserts a tab characters. gtk_text_view_set_accepts_tab().
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if pressing the Tab key inserts a tab character, %FALSE if pressing the Tab key moves the keyboard focus.

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_border_window_size
function.description: Gets the width of the specified border window. See gtk_text_view_set_border_window_size().
function.return: width of window

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_buffer
function.description: Returns the #GtkTextBuffer being displayed by this text view. The reference count on the buffer is not incremented; the caller of this function won't own a new reference.
function.return: a #GtkTextBuffer

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_cursor_locations
function.description:
Given an @iter within a text layout, determine the positions of the strong and weak cursors if the insertion point is at that iterator. The position of each cursor is stored as a zero-width rectangle. The strong cursor location is the location where characters of the directionality equal to the base direction of the paragraph are inserted. The weak cursor location is the location where characters of the directionality opposite to the base direction of the paragraph are inserted.
If @iter is %NULL, the actual cursor position is used.
Note that if @iter happens to be the actual cursor position, and there is currently an IM preedit sequence being entered, the returned locations will be adjusted to account for the preedit cursor's offset within the preedit sequence.
The rectangle position is in buffer coordinates; use gtk_text_view_buffer_to_window_coords() to convert these coordinates to coordinates for one of the windows in the text view.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: strong
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the strong cursor position (may be %NULL)

parameter.name: weak
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the weak cursor position (may be %NULL)

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_cursor_visible
function.description: Find out whether the cursor is being displayed.
function.return: whether the insertion mark is visible

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_default_attributes
function.description:
Obtains a copy of the default text attributes. These are the attributes used for text unless a tag overrides them. You'd typically pass the default attributes in to gtk_text_iter_get_attributes() in order to get the attributes in effect at a given text position.
The return value is a copy owned by the caller of this function, and should be freed.
function.return: a new #GtkTextAttributes

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_editable
function.description: Returns the default editability of the #GtkTextView. Tags in the buffer may override this setting for some ranges of text.
function.return: whether text is editable by default

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_hadjustment
function.description:
Gets the horizontal-scrolling #GtkAdjustment.
Since: 2.22
Deprecated: 3.0: Use gtk_scrollable_get_hadjustment()
function.return: pointer to the horizontal #GtkAdjustment

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_indent
function.description: Gets the default indentation of paragraphs in @text_view. Tags in the view's buffer may override the default. The indentation may be negative.
function.return: number of pixels of indentation

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_input_hints
function.description:
Gets the value of the #GtkTextView:input-hints property.
Since: 3.6

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_input_purpose
function.description:
Gets the value of the #GtkTextView:input-purpose property.
Since: 3.6

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_iter_at_location
function.description: Retrieves the iterator at buffer coordinates @x and @y. Buffer coordinates are coordinates for the entire buffer, not just the currently-displayed portion. If you have coordinates from an event, you have to convert those to buffer coordinates with gtk_text_view_window_to_buffer_coords().

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_iter_at_position
function.description:
Retrieves the iterator pointing to the character at buffer coordinates @x and @y. Buffer coordinates are coordinates for the entire buffer, not just the currently-displayed portion. If you have coordinates from an event, you have to convert those to buffer coordinates with gtk_text_view_window_to_buffer_coords().
Note that this is different from gtk_text_view_get_iter_at_location(), which returns cursor locations, i.e. positions <emphasis>between</emphasis> characters.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: trailing
parameter.parameter_description: if non-%NULL, location to store an integer indicating where in the grapheme the user clicked. It will either be zero, or the number of characters in the grapheme. 0 represents the trailing edge of the grapheme.

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_iter_location
function.description: Gets a rectangle which roughly contains the character at @iter. The rectangle position is in buffer coordinates; use gtk_text_view_buffer_to_window_coords() to convert these coordinates to coordinates for one of the windows in the text view.

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_justification
function.description: Gets the default justification of paragraphs in @text_view. Tags in the buffer may override the default.
function.return: default justification

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_left_margin
function.description: Gets the default left margin size of paragraphs in the @text_view. Tags in the buffer may override the default.
function.return: left margin in pixels

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_line_at_y
function.description: Gets the #GtkTextIter at the start of the line containing the coordinate @y. @y is in buffer coordinates, convert from window coordinates with gtk_text_view_window_to_buffer_coords(). If non-%NULL, @line_top will be filled with the coordinate of the top edge of the line.

parameter.name: line_top
parameter.parameter_description: return location for top coordinate of the line

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_line_yrange

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: return location for a y coordinate

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_overwrite
function.description:
Returns whether the #GtkTextView is in overwrite mode or not.
Since: 2.4
function.return: whether @text_view is in overwrite mode or not.

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_pixels_above_lines
function.description: Gets the default number of pixels to put above paragraphs.
function.return: default number of pixels above paragraphs

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_pixels_below_lines
function.description: Gets the value set by gtk_text_view_set_pixels_below_lines().
function.return: default number of blank pixels below paragraphs

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_pixels_inside_wrap
function.description: Gets the value set by gtk_text_view_set_pixels_inside_wrap().
function.return: default number of pixels of blank space between wrapped lines

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_right_margin
function.description: Gets the default right margin for text in @text_view. Tags in the buffer may override the default.
function.return: right margin in pixels

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_tabs
function.description: Gets the default tabs for @text_view. Tags in the buffer may override the defaults. The returned array will be %NULL if "standard" (8-space) tabs are used. Free the return value with pango_tab_array_free().
function.return: copy of default tab array, or %NULL if "standard" tabs are used; must be freed with pango_tab_array_free().

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_vadjustment
function.description:
Gets the vertical-scrolling #GtkAdjustment.
Since: 2.22
Deprecated: 3.0: Use gtk_scrollable_get_vadjustment()
function.return: pointer to the vertical #GtkAdjustment

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_visible_rect
function.description: Fills @visible_rect with the currently-visible region of the buffer, in buffer coordinates. Convert to window coordinates with gtk_text_view_buffer_to_window_coords().

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_window
function.description: Retrieves the #GdkWindow corresponding to an area of the text view; possible windows include the overall widget window, child windows on the left, right, top, bottom, and the window that displays the text buffer. Windows are %NULL and nonexistent if their width or height is 0, and are nonexistent before the widget has been realized.
function.return: a #GdkWindow, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_window_type
function.description: Usually used to find out which window an event corresponds to. If you connect to an event signal on @text_view, this function should be called on <literal>event->window</literal> to see which window it was.
function.return: the window type.

function.name: gtk_text_view_get_wrap_mode
function.description: Gets the line wrapping for the view.
function.return: the line wrap setting

function.name: gtk_text_view_im_context_filter_keypress
function.return: %TRUE if the input method handled the key event.

function.name: gtk_text_view_move_child
function.description: Updates the position of a child, as for gtk_text_view_add_child_in_window().

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: child widget already added to the text view

parameter.name: xpos
parameter.parameter_description: new X position in window coordinates

parameter.name: ypos
parameter.parameter_description: new Y position in window coordinates

function.name: gtk_text_view_move_mark_onscreen
function.description: Moves a mark within the buffer so that it's located within the currently-visible text area.
function.return: %TRUE if the mark moved (wasn't already onscreen)

function.name: gtk_text_view_move_visually
function.description:
Move the iterator a given number of characters visually, treating it as the strong cursor position. If @count is positive, then the new strong cursor position will be @count positions to the right of the old cursor position. If @count is negative then the new strong cursor position will be @count positions to the left of the old cursor position.
In the presence of bi-directional text, the correspondence between logical and visual order will depend on the direction of the current run, and there may be jumps when the cursor is moved off of the end of a run.

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: number of characters to move (negative moves left, positive moves right)

function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not on the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_view_new
function.description: Creates a new #GtkTextView. If you don't call gtk_text_view_set_buffer() before using the text view, an empty default buffer will be created for you. Get the buffer with gtk_text_view_get_buffer(). If you want to specify your own buffer, consider gtk_text_view_new_with_buffer().
function.return: a new #GtkTextView

function.name: gtk_text_view_new_with_buffer
function.return: a new #GtkTextView.

function.name: gtk_text_view_place_cursor_onscreen
function.description: Moves the cursor to the currently visible region of the buffer, it it isn't there already.
function.return: %TRUE if the cursor had to be moved.

function.name: gtk_text_view_reset_im_context
function.description:
Reset the input method context of the text view if needed.
This can be necessary in the case where modifying the buffer would confuse on-going input method behavior.
Since: 2.22

function.name: gtk_text_view_scroll_mark_onscreen
function.description: Scrolls @text_view the minimum distance such that @mark is contained within the visible area of the widget.

parameter.name: mark
parameter.parameter_description: a mark in the buffer for @text_view

function.name: gtk_text_view_scroll_to_iter
function.description:
Scrolls @text_view so that @iter is on the screen in the position indicated by @xalign and @yalign. An alignment of 0.0 indicates left or top, 1.0 indicates right or bottom, 0.5 means center. If @use_align is %FALSE, the text scrolls the minimal distance to get the mark onscreen, possibly not scrolling at all. The effective screen for purposes of this function is reduced by a margin of size @within_margin.
Note that this function uses the currently-computed height of the lines in the text buffer. Line heights are computed in an idle handler; so this function may not have the desired effect if it's called before the height computations. To avoid oddness, consider using gtk_text_view_scroll_to_mark() which saves a point to be scrolled to after line validation.

parameter.name: within_margin
parameter.parameter_description: margin as a [0.0,0.5) fraction of screen size

parameter.name: use_align
parameter.parameter_description: whether to use alignment arguments (if %FALSE, just get the mark onscreen)

parameter.name: xalign
parameter.parameter_description: horizontal alignment of mark within visible area

parameter.name: yalign
parameter.parameter_description: vertical alignment of mark within visible area

function.return: %TRUE if scrolling occurred

function.name: gtk_text_view_scroll_to_mark
function.description: Scrolls @text_view so that @mark is on the screen in the position indicated by @xalign and @yalign. An alignment of 0.0 indicates left or top, 1.0 indicates right or bottom, 0.5 means center. If @use_align is %FALSE, the text scrolls the minimal distance to get the mark onscreen, possibly not scrolling at all. The effective screen for purposes of this function is reduced by a margin of size @within_margin.

parameter.name: within_margin
parameter.parameter_description: margin as a [0.0,0.5) fraction of screen size

parameter.name: use_align
parameter.parameter_description: whether to use alignment arguments (if %FALSE, just get the mark onscreen)

parameter.name: xalign
parameter.parameter_description: horizontal alignment of mark within visible area

parameter.name: yalign
parameter.parameter_description: vertical alignment of mark within visible area

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_accepts_tab
function.description:
Sets the behavior of the text widget when the Tab key is pressed. If @accepts_tab is %TRUE, a tab character is inserted. If @accepts_tab is %FALSE the keyboard focus is moved to the next widget in the focus chain.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: accepts_tab
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if pressing the Tab key should insert a tab character, %FALSE, if pressing the Tab key should move the keyboard focus.

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_border_window_size
function.description: Sets the width of %GTK_TEXT_WINDOW_LEFT or %GTK_TEXT_WINDOW_RIGHT, or the height of %GTK_TEXT_WINDOW_TOP or %GTK_TEXT_WINDOW_BOTTOM. Automatically destroys the corresponding window if the size is set to 0, and creates the window if the size is set to non-zero. This function can only be used for the "border windows," it doesn't work with #GTK_TEXT_WINDOW_WIDGET, #GTK_TEXT_WINDOW_TEXT, or #GTK_TEXT_WINDOW_PRIVATE.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: width or height of the window

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_buffer
function.description: Sets @buffer as the buffer being displayed by @text_view. The previous buffer displayed by the text view is unreferenced, and a reference is added to @buffer. If you owned a reference to @buffer before passing it to this function, you must remove that reference yourself; #GtkTextView will not "adopt" it.

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_cursor_visible
function.description: Toggles whether the insertion point is displayed. A buffer with no editable text probably shouldn't have a visible cursor, so you may want to turn the cursor off.

parameter.name: setting
parameter.parameter_description: whether to show the insertion cursor

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_editable
function.description: Sets the default editability of the #GtkTextView. You can override this default setting with tags in the buffer, using the "editable" attribute of tags.

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_indent
function.description: Sets the default indentation for paragraphs in @text_view. Tags in the buffer may override the default.

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_input_hints
function.description:
Sets the #GtkTextView:input-hints property, which allows input methods to fine-tune their behaviour.
Since: 3.6

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_input_purpose
function.description:
Sets the #GtkTextView:input-purpose property which can be used by on-screen keyboards and other input methods to adjust their behaviour.
Since: 3.6

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_justification
function.description: Sets the default justification of text in @text_view. Tags in the view's buffer may override the default.

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_left_margin
function.description: Sets the default left margin for text in @text_view. Tags in the buffer may override the default.

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_overwrite
function.description:
Changes the #GtkTextView overwrite mode.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: overwrite
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to turn on overwrite mode, %FALSE to turn it off

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_pixels_above_lines
function.description: Sets the default number of blank pixels above paragraphs in @text_view. Tags in the buffer for @text_view may override the defaults.

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_pixels_below_lines
function.description: Sets the default number of pixels of blank space to put below paragraphs in @text_view. May be overridden by tags applied to @text_view's buffer.

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_pixels_inside_wrap
function.description: Sets the default number of pixels of blank space to leave between display/wrapped lines within a paragraph. May be overridden by tags in @text_view's buffer.

parameter.name: pixels_inside_wrap
parameter.parameter_description: default number of pixels between wrapped lines

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_right_margin
function.description: Sets the default right margin for text in the text view. Tags in the buffer may override the default.

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_tabs
function.description: Sets the default tab stops for paragraphs in @text_view. Tags in the buffer may override the default.

function.name: gtk_text_view_set_wrap_mode
function.description: Sets the line wrapping for the view.

function.name: gtk_text_view_starts_display_line
function.description: Determines whether @iter is at the start of a display line. See gtk_text_view_forward_display_line() for an explanation of display lines vs. paragraphs.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter begins a wrapped line

function.name: gtk_text_view_window_to_buffer_coords
function.description:
Converts coordinates on the window identified by @win to buffer coordinates, storing the result in (@buffer_x,@buffer_y).
Note that you can't convert coordinates for a nonexisting window (see gtk_text_view_set_border_window_size()).

parameter.name: buffer_x
parameter.parameter_description: buffer x coordinate return location or %NULL

parameter.name: buffer_y
parameter.parameter_description: buffer y coordinate return location or %NULL

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get
function.description:
Retrieves several style property values that apply to the currently rendered element.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: property name /return value pairs, followed by %NULL

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_background_color
function.description:
Gets the background color for a given state.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: state to retrieve the color for

parameter.name: color
parameter.parameter_description: return value for the background color

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_border
function.description:
Gets the border for a given state as a #GtkBorder.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: state to retrieve the border for

parameter.name: border
parameter.parameter_description: return value for the border settings

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_border_color
function.description:
Gets the border color for a given state.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: state to retrieve the color for

parameter.name: color
parameter.parameter_description: return value for the border color

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_color
function.description:
Gets the foreground color for a given state.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: state to retrieve the color for

parameter.name: color
parameter.parameter_description: return value for the foreground color

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_direction
function.description:
Returns the widget direction used for rendering.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: Use gtk_theming_engine_get_state() and check for #GTK_STATE_FLAG_DIR_LTR and #GTK_STATE_FLAG_DIR_RTL instead.
function.return: the widget direction

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_font
function.description:
Returns the font description for a given state.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: Use gtk_theming_engine_get()

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: state to retrieve the font for

function.return: the #PangoFontDescription for the given state. This object is owned by GTK+ and should not be freed.

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_junction_sides
function.description:
Returns the widget direction used for rendering.
Since: 3.0
function.return: the widget direction

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_margin
function.description:
Gets the margin for a given state as a #GtkBorder.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: state to retrieve the border for

parameter.name: margin
parameter.parameter_description: return value for the margin settings

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_padding
function.description:
Gets the padding for a given state as a #GtkBorder.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: state to retrieve the padding for

parameter.name: padding
parameter.parameter_description: return value for the padding settings

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_path
function.description:
Returns the widget path used for style matching.
Since: 3.0
function.return: A #GtkWidgetPath

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_property
function.description:
Gets a property value as retrieved from the style settings that apply to the currently rendered element.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: state to retrieve the value for

parameter.name: value

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_screen
function.description: Returns the #GdkScreen to which @engine currently rendering to.
function.return: a #GdkScreen, or %NULL.

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_state
function.description:
returns the state used when rendering.
Since: 3.0
function.return: the state flags

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_style
function.description:
Retrieves several widget style properties from @engine according to the currently rendered content's style.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: property name /return value pairs, followed by %NULL

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_style_property
function.description:
Gets the value for a widget style property.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: property_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the widget style property

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the property value, free with g_value_unset() after use.

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_style_valist
function.description:
Retrieves several widget style properties from @engine according to the currently rendered content's style.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: args
parameter.parameter_description: va_list of property name/return location pairs, followed by %NULL

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_get_valist
function.description:
Retrieves several style property values that apply to the currently rendered element.
Since: 3.0

parameter.name: args
parameter.parameter_description: va_list of property name/return location pairs, followed by %NULL

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_has_class
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if the currently rendered contents have defined the given class name.
Since: 3.0
function.return: %TRUE if @engine has @class_name defined

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_has_region
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if the currently rendered contents have the region defined. If @flags_return is not %NULL, it is set to the flags affecting the region.
Since: 3.0
function.return: %TRUE if region is defined

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_load
function.description: Loads and initializes a theming engine module from the standard directories.
function.return: A theming engine, or %NULL if the engine @name doesn't exist.

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_lookup_color
function.description: Looks up and resolves a color name in the current style's color map.

parameter.name: color
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the looked up color

function.return: %TRUE if @color_name was found and resolved, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_register_property
function.description:
Registers a property so it can be used in the CSS file format, on the CSS file the property will look like "-${@name_space}-${property_name}". being ${property_name} the given to @pspec. @name_space will usually be the theme engine name.
For any type a @parse_func may be provided, being this function used for turning any property value (between ':' and ';') in CSS to the #GValue needed. For basic types there is already builtin parsing support, so %NULL may be provided for these cases.
<note> Engines must ensure property registration happens exactly once, usually GTK+ deals with theming engines as singletons, so this should be guaranteed to happen once, but bear this in mind when creating #GtkThemeEngine<!-- -->s yourself. </note>
<note> In order to make use of the custom registered properties in the CSS file, make sure the engine is loaded first by specifying the engine property, either in a previous rule or within the same one. <programlisting> * { engine: someengine; -SomeEngine-custom-property: 2; } </programlisting> </note>
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.8: Code should use the default properties provided by CSS.

function.name: gtk_theming_engine_state_is_running
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if there is a transition animation running for the current region (see gtk_style_context_push_animatable_region()).
If @progress is not %NULL, the animation progress will be returned there, 0.0 means the state is closest to being %FALSE, while 1.0 means it's closest to being %TRUE. This means transition animations will run from 0 to 1 when @state is being set to %TRUE and from 1 to 0 when it's being set to %FALSE.
Since: 3.0
Deprecated: 3.6: Always returns %FALSE

parameter.name: progress
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the transition progress

function.return: %TRUE if there is a running transition animation for @state.

function.name: gtk_toggle_action_get_active
function.description:
Returns the checked state of the toggle action.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10
function.return: the checked state of the toggle action

function.name: gtk_toggle_action_get_draw_as_radio
function.description:
Returns whether the action should have proxies like a radio action.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10
function.return: whether the action should have proxies like a radio action.

function.name: gtk_toggle_action_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkToggleAction object. To add the action to a #GtkActionGroup and set the accelerator for the action, call gtk_action_group_add_action_with_accel().
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: A unique name for the action

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: The label displayed in menu items and on buttons, or %NULL

parameter.name: tooltip
parameter.parameter_description: A tooltip for the action, or %NULL

parameter.name: stock_id
parameter.parameter_description: The stock icon to display in widgets representing the action, or %NULL

function.return: a new #GtkToggleAction

function.name: gtk_toggle_action_set_active
function.description:
Sets the checked state on the toggle action.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

parameter.name: is_active
parameter.parameter_description: whether the action should be checked or not

function.name: gtk_toggle_action_set_draw_as_radio
function.description:
Sets whether the action should have proxies like a radio action.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

parameter.name: draw_as_radio
parameter.parameter_description: whether the action should have proxies like a radio action

function.name: gtk_toggle_action_toggled
function.description:
Emits the "toggled" signal on the toggle action.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10

function.name: gtk_toggle_button_get_active
function.description: Queries a #GtkToggleButton and returns its current state. Returns %TRUE if the toggle button is pressed in and %FALSE if it is raised.
function.return: a #gboolean value.

function.name: gtk_toggle_button_get_inconsistent
function.description: Gets the value set by gtk_toggle_button_set_inconsistent().
function.return: %TRUE if the button is displayed as inconsistent, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_toggle_button_get_mode
function.description: Retrieves whether the button is displayed as a separate indicator and label. See gtk_toggle_button_set_mode().
function.return: %TRUE if the togglebutton is drawn as a separate indicator and label.

function.name: gtk_toggle_button_new
function.description: Creates a new toggle button. A widget should be packed into the button, as in gtk_button_new().
function.return: a new toggle button.

function.name: gtk_toggle_button_new_with_label
function.description: Creates a new toggle button with a text label.

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: a string containing the message to be placed in the toggle button.

function.return: a new toggle button.

function.name: gtk_toggle_button_new_with_mnemonic
function.description: Creates a new #GtkToggleButton containing a label. The label will be created using gtk_label_new_with_mnemonic(), so underscores in @label indicate the mnemonic for the button.

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: the text of the button, with an underscore in front of the mnemonic character

function.return: a new #GtkToggleButton

function.name: gtk_toggle_button_set_active
function.description: Sets the status of the toggle button. Set to %TRUE if you want the GtkToggleButton to be 'pressed in', and %FALSE to raise it. This action causes the #GtkToggleButton::toggled signal and the #GtkButton::clicked signal to be emitted.

function.name: gtk_toggle_button_set_inconsistent
function.description: If the user has selected a range of elements (such as some text or spreadsheet cells) that are affected by a toggle button, and the current values in that range are inconsistent, you may want to display the toggle in an "in between" state. This function turns on "in between" display. Normally you would turn off the inconsistent state again if the user toggles the toggle button. This has to be done manually, gtk_toggle_button_set_inconsistent() only affects visual appearance, it doesn't affect the semantics of the button.

function.name: gtk_toggle_button_set_mode
function.description:
Sets whether the button is displayed as a separate indicator and label. You can call this function on a checkbutton or a radiobutton with @draw_indicator = %FALSE to make the button look like a normal button
This function only affects instances of classes like #GtkCheckButton and #GtkRadioButton that derive from #GtkToggleButton, not instances of #GtkToggleButton itself.

parameter.name: draw_indicator
parameter.parameter_description: if %TRUE, draw the button as a separate indicator and label; if %FALSE, draw the button like a normal button

function.name: gtk_toggle_button_toggled
function.description: Emits the #GtkToggleButton::toggled signal on the #GtkToggleButton. There is no good reason for an application ever to call this function.

function.name: gtk_toggle_tool_button_get_active
function.description:
Queries a #GtkToggleToolButton and returns its current state. Returns %TRUE if the toggle button is pressed in and %FALSE if it is raised.
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if the toggle tool button is pressed in, %FALSE if not

function.name: gtk_toggle_tool_button_new
function.description:
Returns a new #GtkToggleToolButton
Since: 2.4
function.return: a newly created #GtkToggleToolButton

function.name: gtk_toggle_tool_button_new_from_stock
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkToggleToolButton containing the image and text from a stock item. Some stock ids have preprocessor macros like #GTK_STOCK_OK and #GTK_STOCK_APPLY.
It is an error if @stock_id is not a name of a stock item.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_toggle_tool_button_new() instead.

parameter.name: stock_id
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the stock item

function.return: A new #GtkToggleToolButton

function.name: gtk_toggle_tool_button_set_active
function.description:
Sets the status of the toggle tool button. Set to %TRUE if you want the GtkToggleButton to be 'pressed in', and %FALSE to raise it. This action causes the toggled signal to be emitted.
Since: 2.4

function.name: gtk_tool_button_get_icon_name
function.description:
Returns the name of the themed icon for the tool button, see gtk_tool_button_set_icon_name().
Since: 2.8
function.return: the icon name or %NULL if the tool button has no themed icon

function.name: gtk_tool_button_get_icon_widget
function.description:
Return the widget used as icon widget on @button. See gtk_tool_button_set_icon_widget().
Since: 2.4
function.return: The widget used as icon on @button, or %NULL.

function.name: gtk_tool_button_get_label
function.description:
Returns the label used by the tool button, or %NULL if the tool button doesn't have a label. or uses a the label from a stock item. The returned string is owned by GTK+, and must not be modified or freed.
Since: 2.4
function.return: The label, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_tool_button_get_label_widget
function.description:
Returns the widget used as label on @button. See gtk_tool_button_set_label_widget().
Since: 2.4
function.return: The widget used as label on @button, or %NULL.

function.name: gtk_tool_button_get_stock_id
function.description:
Returns the name of the stock item. See gtk_tool_button_set_stock_id(). The returned string is owned by GTK+ and must not be freed or modifed.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_tool_button_get_icon_name() instead.
function.return: the name of the stock item for @button.

function.name: gtk_tool_button_get_use_underline
function.description:
Returns whether underscores in the label property are used as mnemonics on menu items on the overflow menu. See gtk_tool_button_set_use_underline().
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if underscores in the label property are used as mnemonics on menu items on the overflow menu.

function.name: gtk_tool_button_new
function.description:
Creates a new %GtkToolButton using @icon_widget as contents and @label as label.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: label
parameter.parameter_description: a string that will be used as label, or %NULL

parameter.name: icon_widget
parameter.parameter_description: a widget that will be used as the button contents, or %NULL

function.return: A new #GtkToolButton

function.name: gtk_tool_button_new_from_stock
function.description:
Creates a new #GtkToolButton containing the image and text from a stock item. Some stock ids have preprocessor macros like #GTK_STOCK_OK and #GTK_STOCK_APPLY.
It is an error if @stock_id is not a name of a stock item.
Since: 2.4
Deprecated: 3.10: Use gtk_tool_button_new() instead.

parameter.name: stock_id
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the stock item

function.return: A new #GtkToolButton

function.name: gtk_tool_button_set_icon_name
function.description:
Sets the icon for the tool button from a named themed icon. See the docs for #GtkIconTheme for more details. The "icon_name" property only has an effect if not overridden by non-%NULL "label", "icon_widget" and "stock_id" properties.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: icon_name
